reviewText.content: I don't think I need to say anything. It's Tetris, but a battle royale. It fits so well in the medium that it feels like it was made for it.

reviews.title: One Piece: Pirate Warriors 3: a fun mess

reviewText.content:
PW3 is a game in the Warriors series by Koei Tecmo. If you know how one plays, you know the basics of all of them. But for the uninformed, I'll summarize. Warriors games put you in control of a character in the middle of a battlefield. your goal is to execute tactics in the flashiest way possible, taking on hordes of enemies at once. your KO count can easily reach over 2k. the more KOs you get, the more your special gauge increases. When the gauge is full, you can unleash a devastating special attack, which can easily KO hundreds at a time. Unique to this installment is the Special Kizuna attack. the more damage you deal with a certain character at your side, the higher your Kizuna gauge will go for that character. When full, activating it will put you in a special state where every KO is replaced with a ! KO, which are counted separately from normal KOs. Once active, a clock starts ticking, and before it runs out, pressing A will unleash a devastating Kizuna attack, which can have up to 4 other combatants joining you in an all out assault!

Warriors games are always the ultimate power fantasy and Pirate Warriors 3 is no different. Each of the game's 22 levels span anywhere from 20 minutes to an hour, and usually end with fighting a powerful boss character. The levels stay relatively faithful to the source (we'll get to it,) and with 22, there's quite a lot of playtime packed in. 

Along with the main game, called the Legend Log, and free play mode, called the Free Log, there's also the Dream Log. The Dream Log contains a series of randomly generated challenges scaling in level across around 100 Islands. Each level has random factions, bosses, layout, and goals. As a result, they can all feel same-y and get repetitive fast. Along with these challenges, you can fight Boss enemies on these Islands and unlock them for the Free Log. These two modes exist in tension. It's clear that the developers want you to explore the Dream Log in tandem with the Legend Log, as the early Dream Log islands are so low level, but you level up so fast that it makes the Legend Log a joke. Even on Hard mode for the whole game, I didn't fail a single Legend log level once, and only failed a Dream log encounter once. 


The Graphics are ok, but nothing special. They do the 2D manga characters in 3D style better than most of the JoJo games (but that's a story for another time). The lip sync is awful, and the very obvious use of mocap certainly doesn't do the game any favours. The graphical quality in the levels themselves are really good, nothing special for 2015, but I say It still holds up. The Music is fine, but again nothing special. The graphical and musical quality is the definition of middle of the road. The main theme is memorable, but the other songs only serve to make the game not silent, nothing more. The only reason I critique so hard is because they could have been more. The designs are taken from the anime, and Toei's logo is all over this thing, so why they didn't license the anime's phenomenal OST is beyond me.

The cast of PW3 is....alright. not perfect but alright. Of course all 9 of the straw-hats and Jinbei are playable, but the rest of the choices can be strange. you'd expect Vivi and Belamy to be playable, but neither are. characters with full move sets and models are in the game, but never unlockable (which is a main gripe with most of the warriors games I've played). Don Krieg, Arlong, Bonclay, Mr. 3 and Jesus Burges are never playable. characters like Eustace Kid, Gin, Corazone, and Vander Deken (for better or worse) aren't even mentioned at all. Here lies my biggest gripe with PW3, the way it mangles the story of One Piece and its characters. 

I understand Adaptational changes needed to be made, of course they did, but the way they did it feels lazy and strange. Romance Dawn, an arc that spans only 3 episodes in Included as a full 20 minute level, but Little Garden, which spans 8, is skipped completely. Punk Hazard, which is a full 46 episodes, is condensed into the same 20 minute length as the 8 episode Gaya. The 33 episode Marineford is separated into 2 40 minute levels! The story is mangled from the anime and manga, and this is by far the weakest element of the whole game. The ending of the Dressrosa arc is game original, not reflecting the anime or manga, and it shows. The ending of the story is abysmal, and I'm not just saying that because it's different. 

If you've been paying attention it's probably clear that I know a lot and have a great appreciation for the story of One Piece and how it was crafted, and I've been getting upset whenever they change something to make it worse. Dressrosa ended in 2015, and the game came out that same year. As a result, they didn't know how the arc would end, and the plot suffers greatly because of that. The Tontatta did not yet exist when PW3 was released, so it cover's the plot up to greenbit faithfully, and then falls apart completely. Fujitora becomes another one of Doflamingo's goons, and none of the Donquixote family appear in the game, not even characters like Baby 5 who existed well before. Kuzan arrives and becomes an ally, and Blackbeard & Sakazuki also begin working for Doflamingo, who ends up escaping anyway! If you are paying attention to the plot in game, and care even a little, it will utterly disappoint, and the ending ruins what enjoyment I was getting from it.

I want to talk about this game's biggest flaw, in my opinion. For each level, there are 9 optional objectives you can perform to complete a 9x9 photo called a legend, which are then combined into a bigger 5 x 6 portrait and I will never be completing this portrait. Most of the requirements are fine, things like defeating a boss as a certain character, or achieving a certain number of KOs, but one requirement...is impossible. One of the 8 Dream Log requirements is to achieve an S rank on every single boring tedious repetitive island. to get an S overall, you need to get 3 smaller S ranks. and S in time, KOs and ! KOs. it's those last 2 that pose the biggest problem. to get an S rank in both, you need to constantly be micromanaging your Kizuna gauges, using Specials as soon as they are available, and fail certain objectives on purpose to get enough normal and ! KOs to actually even get close to an S. ON TOP OF THAT, it's not guaranteed that you'll get a map with enough bases and enemies to actually hit above an A. Just like Hyrule and Fire Emblem Warriors (the other two warriors games I've played), This fun and worth-wile experience gets bogged down and ruined by the completion requirements. Although, the Legend is optional, so It's not ruined per say.
animal crossing sure is pretty great huh
It's a nice take on the franchise (better than Amiibo Festival, that's for sure). I just enjoyed the first 2 hours. Nothing stands out from the other entries besides the crafting mechanic.

While I've never been a fan of Animal Crossing, New Horizons has changed that, this game is so soothing and enjoyable to a level I didn't except. I went into this game expecting a overhyped game but I was decently surprised. I do have issues with the way Nintendo handles the multiple accounts thing as well as the online and like a lot of switch games the game feels unresponsive at times. Overall this was a surprise and is weirdly the perfect companion to Doom: Eternal.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Clubhouse Games: 51 Worldwide Classics

reviewText.content: Fantastic collection of games. Clean design, easy to pick up and play. Yacht is the best. However, despite this being advertised as 51 games, a lot of them can be played under specific conditions (single-player only, local multi-player, 2 consoles needed, etc.). And secondly, this is nowhere near worth the price it is selling for.

Fire Emblem Engage is a very well-designed strategy game that is mostly held back by its story. The actual strategy gameplay is basically the best in the series. It's so well designed, fleshed out, and balanced. The emblems add a ton of gameplay options as well. Of course, the issue with Engage is that the story is just bad. There's no sugar coating it, it's poorly written and generic. I wish they had put as much thought into the story here as they did on Three Houses because that's what's really holding this game back. The characters are a mixed bag, some I really like and some (like the story) are generic and boring. I guess it depends on your preferences. There were a few small story moments that I liked, but overall it makes it hard to go back to, even if I really enjoyed playing it.

Overall Score: 7/10

reviews.title: nanabells's review of Fire Emblem Engage

reviewText.content: (Played on casual for 50hrs, 11 Feb-10Mar 23) I've been playing since Awakening, although like the vast majority of players I would say Three Houses is my favorite since I'm into story-driven, character-focused stories. All the reviews said not to expect another FE3H so I tried to temper my expectations, but this was still a disappointment for me.

I believe with the Smash Brothers series you have it's ups and its down, (Smash 4.)  It's been 10 years since I've enjoyed a Smash Brothers game with that being Brawl for the Nintendo Wii. For me a game can easily and quickly rope me in by having a beautiful story, deep meaning, and good gameplay and a lot of games I play most of the time miss the mark. Brawl's Subspace mode was special to me and already played Melee and the 64 version of the game I was blown away- I never played anything like Brawl before. So, not to go into detail about Brawl since this is an Ultimate review I'll make it short.

Brawl opened a door for me in story telling that I never thought I'd actually love. Me being 9 years old when playing the game I wasn't aware that these Nintendo faces had a bigger and badder threat looming over them, this threat is Tabuu. Since then I have always told myself Brawl will always be special to me for making me invested in this world. For Example seeing Ness and Lucas on the same screen interacting with each other was something bonkers for me. Mainly because as a lot of people who's had one conversation with me knows Earthbound is my all time favorite game. So seeing Nintendo acknowledge these legends was something I would've never expected in my wildest dreams. 
Continuing forth with Smash 4 (ahahaha, see?)
I did not like Smash 4. 

Now Ultimate - the game I've waited 10 years for, a game that upon announcement made me do something that hadn't happened since the announcement of God of War (2018.) And that was scream so loud I literally strained my vocal chords and I was unable to speak at a certain volume for a few days. Now honestly I shouldn't have screamed becasue in the back of my mind I thought; it'll probably be just another Smash 4 where a lot of the game isn't my tea and I still won't see Ice Climbers. I was wrong. Watching every Official Nintendo Announcement regarding Ultimate was life changing every time and with the success of the Nintendo Switch it's a game I had high hopes for. 

Let's start off with the game itself, how it feels, how it plays. The game is fast paced, this isn't anything new for the series at all. But when you go from Brawl to Ultimate you feel a bit more grounded feel. Where characters instead of being floaty and light. Almost feel and play like they look. For example, the first thing I did when booting up the game was go to Classic mode and play captain falcon. He is this really thin character with quick movements and fast and fluid punches. 
Before the release of Smash Ultimate I did play Smash 4 to get a feel on what I missed out on and quickly switching from Smash 4 to Smash 5 (6 since Sakruai considers Smash wii u and Smash 3ds to be different games, there's your fun fact of the day) it was not a drastic change and I learned things primarily by testing what worked in Smash 4 and what works in this installment. Which you'd be surprised is a lot. I won't lie I'm not a big vocab user and at the end of the day I am just a guy with a nose. 

Moving forward  on with Adventure mode; spirits. A mode that for me felt like it wasn't as great as Subspace but I do feel tone they were going for. After running about 30+ hours in the Adventure mode I could appreciate the many fights it gives you the fact that a lot of fights are never the same and will either be a finger tearing challenge or a walk in the park.  It is pretty much after the first areas what you see is what you get. There is New Game Plus after you beat the main story, which i haven't started admittedly but the Spirits will keep you invested in the Adventure mode with different approaches to each fight. 

Online mode is Online. Nothing has really changed if one of the players you play even has the thought of going into a 3 bar connection it will tank and you will be mashing hoping it'll let go soon. It's also really bare when it comes to it's features online, there isn't much of a co-op online. like why can't I play Smashdown Online? Why? That'll be amazing literally amazing. Or why can't I run classic online? Atleast with a friend?? Options like these have an easy work around with using things like Parsec (which I'm trying to figure that out still.)  Moving forward Online would be a miss if it wasn't one of the main focuses of the game.

Smash - core modes, everything is the same with the exception of Smashdown and the new and improved Custom Battle mode. I never cared much for other modes but in Ultimate it feels almost as if was tweaked so you can throw yourself in almost in situation and find different solutions in and out of any battle. let's see, there's super sudden death mode which is absolutely insane and every moment of it makes me nervous and my heart pound with anxiety. 

In conclusion Super Smash Brothers Ultimate takes something from each Smash game and builds upon that with love and care. Although I am critical of Smash for the Wii u/3DS I would have to thank it for being the successor and having good mechanics which are made better in this one. Sorry this took so long to make, sickness, personal family things and overall laziness I would recommend this game to newcomers and veterans. -12/22/2018 2 weeks after the game came out.

It's perfect in every way. As a person who has only played Melee, The 3DS version of Smash 4, and now Ultimate, I finally got to experience some characters and stages I missed out on. World of light is an okay mode, if your going to collect spirits. (You do get to play as Master Hand in that mode though, so that's a plus!)
Every fighter is back and many stages have been remastered. Nothing really stands out other than that.

reviews.title: It's Monopoly, but slightly faster and fun.

reviewText.content:
The main gameplay takes most of the hassle out and speeds up the game. There was just enough time to say something or grab a handful of chips between turns. Unlike early reviews, the frame rate is steady and load times fixed.

The game worked great with 5 people on one Switch, everyone using their own JoyCon, JoyCon Grip, Pro and 8bitdo controllers. It automatically pulled player names from user profiles, or lets you use "Player X."

Problems:

▫ Guests cannot set their name, and only the first 6 profiles can be used.
▫ The menus for selling, mortgaging and trading take getting used and slow down the game a bit.
▫ The bus on speed die rules doesn't always let you see where you will land. (I wish we could move the camera with the joystick.)
▫ If you forget how much rent you have to pay, you have to exit out of the menus to sell or trade to see the amount. (Showing rent on the left, unused part of the screen would fix this.)
[Finished at 41hrs on 20 Dec 20, playing 2P.] My first Zelda game after Breath of the Wild failed to capture my interest.

Nos guste o no Street Fighter II es uno de esos juegos que se resisten a morir. Un clásico que llega a Switch con una jugabilidad tradicional y la posibilidad de llevarte el juego a cualquier lugar. Con esto dicho, es un juego que no ofrece nada significativo.

My third Fire Emblem game! It feels more like Persona than Fire Emblem, what with all the new features such as instructing, quests, and fishing, and the ability to roam around such a lively "home base." However, the game seems easier than usual.

I have never played another Fire Emblem game. The only thing I knew of the series were the characters in Smash Bros. However, with this game I decided to give it a try and holy sh*t my mind was blown by how good this game was! 

The story is super intriguing and characters are all (except Ignatz and Cyril) wonderfully written and you become connected with them. I chose Black Eagles as my house for my first run and I couldn't put the game down for the whole weekend, luckily it was summer vacation so I had lots of time to play (which you'll need for this game lol). I honestly can't really explain everything I love about this game from the first time I played but I remember the story was really captivating and engaging. The gameplay is fun and not as boring as I originally thought. At times you'll really struggle on some maps (unless you're a strategy game veteran, I suppose) and I really enjoyed the challenge although I will admit the game was kinda easy at times but for my first time playing a strategy game I got challenged enough. 

When I finished my first run with Black Eagles, I immediately wanted to play the next one. I chose the Blue Lions. I was blown away by how different each house's story is! It's not like you'll choose one house and get the same thing, nono. Each house could seriously be it's own game cause of how differently they play out. I was amazed by this. I knew of Fire Emblem Fates for the 3DS which had a similar thing but they sold that as different games; Birthright and Conquest. Here you get it all in one game. The Blue Lions route focuses a lot more on characters than the overarching narrative and it's so freaking good. It's impossible not to connect with the characters in this game. 

For my third playthrough I chose, of course, Golden Deer. This was the house that I was least interested in but oh my was I wrong to think that. I think this route's story might be my favorite along Black Eagles. It's difficult to chose a favorite to be honest, cause all of them are great. After I finished the third run, I started a fourth. This is because of (small spoiler?) the fact that there is a fourth route. I could not get more blown away by how much effort went into this game and how much you get for your money! I was satisfied after my first run, but after playing all of them I dont think "satisfied" is the right word anymore.

Also, the new things you learn in the different routes will change your perspective on other characters and their motivations when you know more about them. I can't tell you how many secret details lie in this game and it's so fun to connect the dots by yourself (or online as well). 

Before I forget; this soundtrack is amazing! Seriously every song in this game is a banger, I kid you not. 

I was so obsessed with this game for the longest time that I went out of my way to get *every* support conversation between all the characters. To put it simply, I'm 100% it. There is also the season pass that is definitely worth the money. It adds a new story that is of the same quality as the main game, and new characters to use. Along with new amazing music tracks. 

11/10 game, and it shares the spot of my favorite of all time along with Kingdom Hearts 2 Final Mix. Even if you've never played a Fire Emblem game or a strategy game before (like I hadn't) please try this one out. One route takes maybe around 40 hours but by the time I finished my fourth run I was at 200...then I started my 5th run. No, I'm not joking. Although that is on a pause for now.

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Fire Emblem: Three Houses

reviewText.content:
Fire Emblem: Three Houses is perhaps the most solid game in the series. It has everything you could want out of a Fire Emblem game: great characters, a compelling plot, and deep strategy gameplay.

The aspect that makes this game stand out of course, is its characters and storyline. Every character feels complete and complicated. You end up liking all of them, even the ones from rival houses. The house leads, especially, are given strong portrayals and motivations. Its easy to see where each of them are coming from, making it difficult to make the more impactful decisions later in the game.

In terms of the amount of content you will experience for each house, I do think that your experience could vary. I played as the Black Eagles house, which I believe likely has the most amount of content and plot twists to it. I don't know if I would have had the same reaction to one of the big twists in the middle of the game if I had been playing as one of the other houses. That being said, in order to get the full story, you really need to play all four available routes. I definitely feel that there were plot points left unexplored in my playthrough, and reading the wiki afterwards confirmed this. That isn't necessarily a negative, as it gives you a good reason to do another run.

The core gameplay is the complex turn-based strategy. Managing your equipment and units is crucial, and it really makes you think deeply about how to win each battle.

The support system is implemented really well, allowing you to see characters develop over the course of the game. Their relationships with each other will change, you will get more insight into their past and motivations, and you will see them learn and grow.

One character complaint that I do have is Byleth. As the main character, the developers clearly wanted you to insert yourself into Byleth's situation, which is why they are the only character that does not talk during cutscenes. I found this, however, to be incredibly distracting, given that they aren't just a self-insert character. They have their own motivations, opinions, and desires, so it is really weird that the most you get out of them is a line of text at a time. I still found myself liking them as a character, I just wish they were given more voice lines.

Also, the music is great.

Overall Score: 10/10

reviews.title: lovrize's review of Fire Emblem: Three Houses

reviewText.content: Сейчас вот до ключевых моментов в FE Three Houses дошёл (выбор между монастырем и Эди). И о боже как же игра меня обосрала в плане антагонистов. Хотя.. Сама по себе игра представляет собой выбор между Humanism, Justice, Revolution и Seeking truth. И по ходу сюжета дают намеки что придётся выбирать между домами и монастырём, но когда карикатурный злодей за маской (Flame Emperor, Противник дискриминации по происхождению) оказалась Edelgard я выпал в осадок. (Ну зачем рушить монастырь. Ну нахрена). Думаю вот дропнуть ибо монастырь это святое, хотя кажется больше из-за неё и расправой над ней в будущем. Знаю есть другие руты, но я уже успел выгореть. У меня так было с игрой престолов. До сих пор последнюю серию не досмотрел, да и про Джона не понял. К финалу у любого продукта у меня разговор на ты. Не начинаю что либо для себя открывать если финал оказывается слитым. Да и не сказать что драму не люблю. Просто обидно иногда бывает за все те выделенные на что-то часы, дни, недели..
I am so disappointed. It had so much potential, but fell short of a battle royale staring Pac-Man.

reviews.title: jignjorf's review of Princess Peach: Showtime!

reviewText.content:
This is a fun game oozing with charm, but it isn't going to blow your mind. There's a good amount of gameplay variety and all the Peach designs are great, but there's a noticeable lack of any real challenge. That in of itself isn't a bad thing, not every game has to be challenging and the primary audience for this game is younger kids, but difficulty options wouldn't have hurt either. Really the only glaring flaw for me is how this game loves to waste your time if you're going for 100% completion. You'll have to play through each level at least twice to get everything, but there is no way to skip any of the in-level dialogue or cutscenes, which makes every subsequent attempt/playthrough of a level feel way more tedious than it needs to be.

Fun game overall but it's quite short for the asking price of $60, I'd argue $40 is a much more fair price
I really like this game and it's was wonderful, powerful and fun.
This game is the sequel to the Bible and has changed my life forever.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Ring Fit Adventure

reviewText.content: I can't think of a game who would do this better than Ring Fit. If you approach this game as exercise, you will love it. If you approach it as a game where you have to move to control your character, you are looking at it wrong. It is perfect for what it is, and I absolutely recommend it to anyone to try.

reviews.title: gatorbox's review of Ring Fit Adventure

reviewText.content: I've turned up my nose at "fitness games" for about 30 years but I finally buckled and bought Ring Fit Adventure because after reading about it I was willing to give this game the benefit of the doubt. Over 400 in-game hours later I can safely say this game is a real workout! I've played through the game's story on New Game+ and New Game++ and unlocked literally everything. I turned the grind into an exercise session and I used the item unlocks as points to mark my progress. What I like most about this game is it's a workout without feeling like it's really "work". You're moving and active doing things like squats and scissor kicks and jogging in place and all of this is getting your heart rate up but it still feels like you're just playing a game, Ring Fit Adventure is that good. The story is charming and the characters are likable and as the game's tale unfolds you'll want to push yourself through just one more level to find out what happens next. My only real complaint with Ring Fit Adventure is certain exercises have certain attack "types" that are effective against specific enemies. You'll eventually unlock the max level exercises that are effective against everything universally but when you're just starting out you have to do certain motions to attack specific enemies.

reviews.title: fl4shp01nt's review of Super Mario Bros. Wonder

reviewText.content: Super Mario Bros. Wonder is one of the best 2D Mario games ever made, with a lot of content, creativity, and fun to offer. It is a must-play for fans of the series and newcomers alike. And if you love games for their “sit back and enjoy the ride” vibe, then this is the best among the bunch!

reviews.title: danilocrimi's review of Super Mario Bros. Wonder

reviewText.content: Questo gioco è molto diverso dal concetto di 2d usato nei capitoli precedenti di Super Mario, infatti è molto creativo e si vede che Nintendo ha cercato di dare il massimo. Sono molto felice e stupito da questo bellissimo capitolo di Mario

reviews.title: dariovaccaro's review of Super Mario Bros. Wonder

reviewText.content: Mario Wonder is the first 2.5D Mario in more than 10 years and it manages to keep the gameplay formula fresh, while being a stale on the narrative side. I am incredibly tired of defeating Bowser and Boswer Jr, and, even though Nintendo is not famous for its engrossing stories, they could try to be a bit more creative on that end as well. The gameplay is incredibly varied and full of crazy ideas, though they are sometimes a bit random and out of place. I get that it is part of the idea for the Wonder Flowers to create unexpected situations, but it also sometimes feels like they just didn't care to create a coherent whole. The introduction of Badges with unique powers is amazing, providing numerous different ways to approach a level, though I miss the triple jump from previous iterations.

reviews.title: vlndk's review of Super Mario Bros. Wonder

reviewText.content: Super Mario Bros. Wonder is a delightful return to form for the series, bringing back the whimsical joy of 2D Mario with a fresh coat of paint and a whole lot of wonderful surprises. The Wonder Flowers add a level of chaotic fun that kept me grinning from ear to ear, and the vibrant visuals and catchy soundtrack made every level a treat. It might not be the most challenging Mario game, but it's pure fun from start to finish.

Super Mario Bros. Wonder is a fantastic return to the series after the puttering out of the "New" series. It really feels like a fresh start, differentiating itself from the "New" series in art style, level design, and, most importantly, creativity. The new powers are fun to use. The level design is much more varied. The music, sound design, and art style are all top-notch. The new voice of Mario is also doing a great job. The biggest complaint, as with most 2D Mario games, is the boss fights. In particular, the midpoint/checkpoint bosses are incredibly easy to fight, repetitive, and uninteresting. The main boss fights are a bit better, but I would still like to see the series improve on this aspect in future titles.

Overall Score: 9/10

This is a phenomenal title. Nintendo actually lent out the Zelda IP to an indie company. Nobody saw this coming.  The remixes of old and new Zelda music going through places like the Lost Woods felt so amazing.

Un juego grandioso que debe ser compra obligada para todos los usuarios de Switch. Tiene una jugabilidad única y divertida, el Grand Prix tiene una curva de dificultad bastante bien hecha y el online es bastante bueno. El juego parece simple pero es bastante técnico, por lo que si no te interesa dominar al 100% un juego te van a patear el trasero y si tu umbral de frustración es pequeño, aléjate de ARMS, porque no te va a parecer divertido.
good game that lacked the extra content for casuals and im not sure where the competitive scene is

reviews.title: amsandor's review of Big Brain Academy: Brain vs. Brain

reviewText.content: Big Brain Academy: Brain vs. Brain, is a fantastic and simple game that helps build quick thinking skills and hand eye coordination in a number of categories, from memorization, picture recognition, math, analysis and so forth. You can play in various modes - practice, an overall testing mode, and - the most fun, in head to head mode, either as couch multiplayer or online. I have been playing a few rounds of this game almost every day throughout the year, and have had a blast playing. There are a number of customizations for your character, and a monthly ranking system that is rewarding to climb, but the main fun and utility of the game is in increasing your quick thinking and hand eye coordination, both excellent skills in everyday life. A very enjoyable experience, and one I will continue to play for some time.

reviews.title: nanabells's review of Fire Emblem Warriors: Three Hopes

reviewText.content: [23 Nov - 6 Dec 2022, 53hrs, played in 2P] Finished with my first (and prolly last, let's be honest) route of Azure Gleam. I adored Warriors of Hyrule, so I was looking forward to this. I didn't expect to be blown away, and I definitely wasn't. Nevertheless, this is still a sold Musou game, a step-up from the previous Fire Emblem Warriors game, and a nice addition to the Fire Emblem series.

Fire Emblem Warriors: Three Hopes is a very fun hack and slash. It's really cool to see an alternate-reality story of Three Houses, although the story is a bit lacking in a few areas. That being said, the gameplay is fun and dynamic, and the characters and mostly well written.

Overall Score: 7/10

A very fun game that ends up feeling half complete. Sure the story finishes but I feel like there are so many plot points and characters that aren't fully explored. I was honestly surprised when it became clear I was facing the final boss (even most of the way into the mission, I was expecting more)

Thankfully the gameplay is a fun action game with some unique mechanics and a good soundtrack. Don't be put off just because the more anime aesthetic doesn't fit in with some of PlatinumGames' more well-praised action games.

My first Platinum game! I prefer turn-based games over action games, but from all the good reviews of this game, I'm excited to give it a try. | Finished on 1 Nov 20 at 22hrs! I think not binging it really hurt my enjoyment, as I felt detached from the story. | I'm a binge player. I'll play a game for three DAYS straight without taking a break or sleeping. I've always wondered if that hurt my enjoyment of a game since I'm essentially playing the game hungry and sleep-deprived. This time, I'm playing Astral Chain for an hour a day, in between breaks from law school. Let's see if this changes how much I enjoy this game!

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Kirby Star Allies

reviewText.content:
Kirby Star Allies is a decent platformer with great boss fights.

Kirby's moves and abilities feel really epic and fun to plan and experiment with. Finding your favorite ability is a lot of fun, especially when you combine different abilities. That being said, Kirby's movement is a little clunky. Walking is pretty slow.

The allies system is an interesting concept, although it can get frustrating when your allies get themselves killed for stupid reasons. There were a few times when my allies would get crushed by moving platforms even though I was far away from them. With four allies, the screen can also get crowded, especially in cramped spaces, that sometimes makes it hard to keep track of what's going on.

The platforming sections are pretty lackluster. Standard platforming without much interesting or anything of note. Feels like the developers forgot that Kirby can fly when they were designing some sections since there are a lot of platforming challenges that you can just fly over.

The highlight of Kirby Star Allies is the boss fights. The moves are creative and provide a good challenge. The final set of fights is especially well done and feels really epic. The boss fights are what really elevate the game beyond a somewhat dull platformer.

Music and sounds are fine, nothing too special. The same can be said about the graphics, which are good in some parts, although when there are a bunch of entities on screen the frame rate will tank. These situations are pretty rare though.

Overall Score: 7/10

Splatoon 2 is a different fun multiplayer shooter that has great potential except it feels as though Nintendo forgot the "Multiplayer" part.  Cooperative play with friends is incredibly restricting and hidden behind multiple hurdles. If you don't have the correct number of friends to play with (either one or three) then you are stuck rolling the dice in mixed-open PvP.   Your friend may be able to join the same room as you, and then may be randomly assigned to your team.

This is a great game surprisingly spoiled by Nintendo's failure to remember that people may want to play with people they know from the start instead of being forced to play with sometimes frustrating random players.

Siempre he creído que el secreto de una buena secuela es cambiar suficientes cosas de la entrega anterior para ser algo nuevo, pero dejar suficientes para que no parezca una cosa totalmente diferente y en ese punto creo que Splatoon 2 logró el objetivo. Cambiar los ataques especiales, tener un modo Campaña mucho más pulido y la inclusión del modo Salmon Run le añaden horas de diversión a una fórmula que creó toda una comunidad desde cero en Wii U, (eso además de la inclusión de Splatnet 2 que amplía mucho la experiencia). Este es un juego para disfrutar online con amigos o en solitario y creo que es la mejor forma de que jugadores nuevos y con poca experiencia en jugar por internet incursionen en el online sin sentirse frustrados. ¿Recomiendo Splatoon 2? ¡¡Sin duda!!

Soulles megacorporation made a single man passion project into another product. Check out Infernoplus, he made this first. Of cource, Nintendo DMCA'd him and the only way to play a SMB Battle Royale is to buy a Switch and the game.
Nintendo and Arika went all out on it for this. It plays like Tetris 99, and fits the switch hardware so well.

reviews.title: rabadakku's review of Kirby and the Forgotten Land

reviewText.content: The first real 3D Kirby ever. Super cute, great gameplay, touching story, lot of fun! I've played smiling like a 6 years old child the whole time... Loved it!

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Kirby and the Forgotten Land

reviewText.content:
Kirby makes a spectacular 3D debut in Kirby and the Forgotten Land. The game combines great platforming challenges with incredible action and fighting. It feels so natural that it's surprising Kirby hasn't had a 3D game before.

The game has a very unique atmosphere to it. Each level feels unique and offers different challenges. The levels and layout feel very reminiscent of Super Mario Galaxy.

Each boss fight has a great set of challenges that feels very rewarding once you figure out how to best counter a cycle. The final boss fight especially stands out as one of the best boss fights I've played recently.

Kirby's abilities feel responsive and powerful. Each has its benefits, and there weren't any that I felt like avoiding. The new ability in this game, the 'mouthful mode' provides a ton of fun and interesting challenges.

The art-style makes everything pop and the graphics are impressive for the Switch. Music and sounds are a big plus as well. The only issue here is that the framerate of far-away objects' animations is reduced for performance reasons. It isn't a big issue, but it does become jarring sometimes.

Overall, this is a great first 3D entry in the Kirby series and I had trouble putting it down.

Overall Score: 10/10
Nice Game cool mechanics nice game at all it's so good I already play it for around 200 hours
I don't think I need to say anything that others have said. This is a return to form of the OG 3D Marios. I love this game and recommend it to anyone who is skeptical of it.

I-N-C-R-E-I-B-L-E 

Una obra maestra para todos los públicos. No es sencillo quedarte descubriendo todo un reino cuando sabes que hay un mundo totalmente nuevo a unas lunas de distancia. Me encanta que Mario conserva sus controles desde N64 pero le añaden varios elementos para crear algo nuevo. 
Lo único malo es que al terminar la historia principal, te das cuenta que la aventura apenas comienza XD. Los niveles en 2D son geniales, pero no vi venir la parte final en la luna. 

Un indispensable absoluto para el catálogo de Switch.
This is probably the absolute best Mario game I have ever played in my 19 years I’ve been on this Earth.

reviews.title: amsandor's review of Super Mario Odyssey

reviewText.content:
One of the best Mario 3D platformers around, Super Mario Odyssey fulfilled my love of Mario Sunshine and Mario 64 in a huge way. The world is brilliant and often breathtaking at times, with some levels standing out in a huge way. There are many interesting secrets to be found, as you collect various coins and trinkets throughout your journey, and even a fun new game + after you finish the main story. 

This is certainly a modern classic waiting to be archived as such, on par with some of the best Mario and 3D platforming titles available. The ability to possess objects and enemies with your hat is novel and interesting, and leads to a variety of puzzle solving capabilities. The unique costumes add a flair to the game and allow the player some choice, albeit in a shallow fashion, but better than many Nintendo games of the same ilk. I loved playing this game, but would offer that my enjoyment began to flag toward the end, as the repetitive task of gathering coins and power moons began to feel samey. This criticism is personally affected, as this is more of a challenge I face with the 3D platformer genre, and will certainly not apply to every gamer. The very unique and stunning levels did help alleviate this some, as did the interesting puzzles to solve. 

The stunning level design was interesting, with some standout levels that were jaw dropping to view from certain angles. The variety and location of puzzles offered many surprises, meaning excellent level design. One small criticism of some areas was the jarring cut off of the playscape, making some levels feel like zones, which broke the fourth wall for me a tad and reduced my overall enjoyment of some areas. This is a small criticism, as the level design here on the whole is superb and gorgeous from most angles. 

All in all, a wonderful experience and truly a mainstay of the Switch's library of titles. Easy recommendation for fans of Mario and Nintendo fare, and those who enjoy a laid back 3D platforming experience, with wonderful worlds to behold.

reviews.title: nkay08's review of Super Mario Odyssey

reviewText.content:
It's a great game and probably one of the best 3D platformers on the switch.
Mario controls well for the most part, except for the side flip, which cannot be pulled off as easily and quick as in previous games.
The kingdoms provide some nice variety and different themes.
I like cappy as a mechanic for extending Mario's moveset as well as capturing enemies.

However, I do have some problems with the game:
Most of the kingdoms are rather boring to traverse, with large open spaces. 
Moons can often be found when exploring, but there are so many and they are basically hidden under each and every rock. Finding a moon can sometimes happen every few seconds, which means individual ones have no impact. I wanted to complete a world before continuing, which was not possible, since many moons can only be collected post-game.
The game seriously lacks difficulty until post-game and never challenges the player to really show the moves he learned.
Some of the boss fights are cool, but some of them are really boring. All of them are piss easy.
The boring broodals boss fights are recycled so many times.

I had a lot of fun with the game, but did not have the desire to revisit every kingdom in post-game again and look under every rock for moons.

best combo system this game is just so good, just the menu is like "meh" but i think they will improve it later. I'm waiting for cross-play and I hope it's also available between PC and console. For now this is the best mortal kombat ever.

I would give this game a higher score if there weren't as many issues in the game as there is at the moment. I was hoping for Krossplay from the start, and I would like to see more patch updates happening. With that being said I am really enjoying this game and I am having so much fun since this game has released. I would give it a 10/10 if servers were smoother and krossplay was added.

I'm largely unfamiliar with developer Bryce Bucher but this game of his is something else; all too often indie developers try to imitate the old PlayStation 1 look and for the most part a lot of these devs fail but Bryce managed to crack the code and present something that looks and feels like an old PS1 demo. Fatum Betula is a relatively short game with at least a dozen endings and the choices you make during the brief main game determine which ending you will get. Gameplay is centered around collecting samples of liquids with vials and either mixing them or adding the samples to other things to create new mixtures. The ultimate goal of the game is to water the Tree of Life with one of your samples with each sample giving you a different ending. The game is bizarre and while it's listed as a "horror" game I don't feel like the game is actually scary per se, it just has a very unsettling atmosphere. I'll never forget the biblically accurate angel who informed me that I was going to "go to Hell in real life".

reviews.title: owen_lie's review of Trek to Yomi

reviewText.content: It's sword parry and attack game with 2D perspective battle system. Outside from the battle, players can move more freely in 3D perspective. The story and graphics is pretty good. But I think the gameplay is not much having much variety (light, heavy, ranged, attack, and parry with sword)

reviews.title: Petit jeu AA à l'ambiance japonaise très bien réalisé

reviewText.content:
Petit jeu AA à l'ambiance japonaise très bien réalisé, que ce soit au niveau des graphismes en nuances de gris, ou des musiques et bruitages.
L'histoire est un prétexte mais reste cohérente et bien racontée au fil des chapitres.

L'animation est parfois un peu raide mais on s'y habitue vite, rien de choquant ; les mouvements au sabre lors des combats restent elles très fluides.

Le jeu, sur 7 chapitres, se décompose généralement en trois phases : exploration/combats/point de sauvegarde, jusqu'au boss du chapitre, avec au passage des améliorations à trouver (parfois données, parfois cachées) aussi bien pour les techniques de combats (enchainements possibles), que pour les armes ou la capacité de notre personnage (point de vie et endurance/fatigue).

Le jeu est austère malgré tout sur certains aspects :
- sauvegarde uniquement sur des checkpoints utilisables une seule fois ; pas de gestion manuelle des sauvegardes avec plusieurs emplacements possibles, ce qui est dommage car le jeu propose trois fin, qui redemandent à tout refaire (une fin = un run compet)
- pas de new game plus ; une fois le jeu terminé la sauvegarde est supprimée et on ne peut que refaire une nouvelle partie depuis le début, en perdant toutes ses améliorations.
- Le gameplay est très exigeant la mort pouvant rapidement venir suite à qq erreurs ; les succès le sont tout autant : la moitié n'ayant été obtenue que par moins de 1% des joueurs ^^. La difficulté reste cependant ajustable avec trois niveaux proposés.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass

This seemed like it should have been exactly the kind of game for me but I was very disappointed with what I played. I didn't notice much strategy or prowess to the basic combat, you just use your abilities when they're off cooldown to deal more damage to the endlessly respawning bullet sponges. The items I found were not interesting, and I noticed a large amount of healing which meant taking damage was almost arbitrary, so you're constantly taking damage and constantly healing. 45 minutes probably isn't a fair shout, but I really don't want to play any more. I imagine the game is fun with friends, and probably does get better when you find more interesting stuff later on, but it's certainly not enough to grab me right now.

reviews.title: josephdfgx's review of Risk of Rain 2

reviewText.content: Probably my favorite game of all time. If you're a fan of the original Risk of Rain and this looks good, this is probably the game for you.

reviews.title: yorendo's review of Risk of Rain 2

reviewText.content:
Risk of Rain 2 offers an exhilarating gaming experience complete with diverse character styles and captivating music. Boasting 10 unique classes, each catering to different playstyles, whether you're a sword-wielding melee enthusiast, a fan of elemental magic, or you prefer strategic gadgetry, the game provides a path tailored to your preferences. The inclusion of 148 distinct items adds depth to the gameplay, encouraging experimentation and replayability by offering creative ways to "break" the game.

The dynamic difficulty stands out as the game's defining feature. As your run progresses, the game's intensity escalates, with enemies growing stronger and more numerous. This adds a sense of urgency and prompts strategic decisions about exploration, combat engagement, and progression. Notably, the soundtrack is so good that at times, it can sabotage your run, tempting you to stay on a level longer than you should.

Beyond its rich character design, dynamic difficulty, and awesome music, Risk of Rain 2 shines with its seamless gameplay flow, diverse environments and carefully crafted enemies, making it an absolute blast.

reviews.title: amsandor's review of Risk of Rain 2

reviewText.content: A wonderful third person roguelike - in my opinion one of the best of the genre. Their is limitless replicability, and enough challenging gameplay, secrets and unlockables, and variation in item combinations to last. The online multiplayer is a blast, paying with up to 4 others. Artifacts can increase difficulty, as can the looping ability, to keep playing the game over and over again, with harder and harder hordes of enemies. What a blast!

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of Risk of Rain 2

reviewText.content:
In recent years, the genre of rouge-lite games has had many additions. Out of all of them, Risk of Rain 2 is by far the most ridiculous I’ve seen. It’s a game where there are no limits to your potential set, and you can become as overpowered as you desire. 
It does follow the traditional rouge-lite formula. Fight through a level, while collecting as much loot as possible, kill the boss, and continue onwards. The major difference here is that it's actually 3D. 
Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone who is a fan of the genre or just wants a fun time-killer. It also has multiplayer.

Story
You are a member of a spaceship responding to a distress beacon sent from an unknown planet. In an attempt to find any survivors, you get sent down, completely unprepared for what’s to come.
The story is there mainly to set the scene. There isn’t much of any narrative while actually playing the game. Still, for those interested, there is quite a lot of lore, as every item and enemy has a description. 

Mechanics and gameplay
As I said, it follows the standard rouge-lite formula seen in many other titles like Enter the Gungeon, The Binding of Isaac, and many others. It is simple, but highly effective and addictive. What sets Risk of Rain 2 apart from the others, and allowed it to become such a popular game, is its lack of restrains.
There aren’t any limits on how many times you can find a duplicate item or how fast you can clear a stage and so on. Becoming overpowered is the point. Being skilful at this game isn’t just about being able to dodge all the projectiles, it's about being able to maximize whatever loot you are given to create a build that can take you to the end and beyond. 

Graphics/Artstyle
It's simplistic and by no means detailed. Still, I can’t imagine there will be a time when this game will look ugly and outdated. It’s a timeless design that conveys what it has to.

Atmosphere/Immersion  
The atmosphere is all over the place, first, you fight robots and bugs in a tundra, then lizard men and jellyfish in a desert then… you get the idea. Although perhaps because it never takes itself seriously, it works. It's distinctly “Risk of Rain”. 

Soundtrack 
An incredible soundtrack has been made for this game, and I can’t imagine any other that would fit so well. My favourite part is “The Rain Formerly Known as Purple”.

Final Thoughts
Me when the weather reports show that there is a risk of rain.

reviews.title: vizthex's review of A Good Snowman is Hard to Build

reviewText.content: A cute & fun puzzle game about building snowmen. Some of them are quite tricky though.

[ENGLISH]
The first thing is to settle the famous controversy that this title plagiarizes Overwatch. I am a constant player of Overwatch and Paladins. I have played many hours in both games (especially Overwatch). And what's more, I played Paladins, as soon as I came out in the Alpha phase, that is, I saw it evolve.
The two games feel different. And both are good.
Do not take revenge on me that one copied the other, because both belong to the same genre. This category is still being developed, it is called "Hero Shooter". It consists of some kind of game mode (the most common is to conquer a point and escort a load to a certain point on the map), in which we will take different characters, with their corresponding roles (DPS (damage), Tank (defense ), Healer (healer), etc ...) So, why do not we say that Battlefield is copied from Call Of Duty or vice versa? It is very big nonsense. Both belong to the same gender and period.

Now, I will focus on talking about Paladins.
It is an online multiplayer video game that consists of facing a team of five against five on a map. Normally you have to conquer a point.
One of the things I like most about this game is the variety of characters and their roles (already mentioned above). We can find human beings, elves, talkative trees, etc ...), each with a distinct and charismatic personality.
That is, it is set in a fantasy universe (which I would swear, is shared by the other great title of Hirez Studios, "Smite").
It is very fun and full of adrenaline.
The history of the videogame (Lore), is beginning to emerge.
And it is very interesting that most of the characters, obtain their powers through the crystals that carry over (whether in weapons, clothing, etc ...), hence the diamond icon.

Now, it's not perfect. It has lots of bugs (some can annoy you the game experience), there are things that are wrong in some maps (Corners with no way out ...), the characters do not interact well with the environment (for example, if I want to upload to a platform, the character makes strange movements and many times I died for that ...), etc ... I also miss, a physical attack and the ability to duck the character (although this is subjective). The servers of Hirez Studios, have never been very ... decent (However, the company is very good). But what I hate the most about this title, is the hitbox (it's what defines what part of a character can take damage and how much damage can suffer), is enormously broad in all the characters. For example, you can see many times how to kill you, your enemy was not even being accurate against you (that is, I did not hit the bullets but the game detects that, damaging you).

In summary, it is a very funny and frenetic game that I recommend you to try. Total, it's free!


[ESPAÑOL]
Lo primero es zanjar la famosa polemica de que este título plagia a Overwatch. Soy un constante jugador de Overwatch y Paladins. Llevo muchísimas horas jugadas a ambos videojuegos (sobre todo a Overwatch). Y es más, jugué a Paladins, nada más salir en fase Alfa, es decir, lo he visto evolucionar.
Los dos juegos se sienten distintos. Y ambos son buenos.
No me vengáis con que uno se copia del otro, pues los dos pertenecen al mismo género. Está categoría que aún está siendo desarrollada, se le denomina "Hero Shooter". Consiste en algún tipo de modo de juego (el más habitual, es conquistar un punto y escoltar una carga a un determinado punto del mapa), en el cual llevaremos a diferentes personajes, con sus roles correspondientes (DPS (daño), Tanque (defensa), Healer (sanador), etc...) Entonces, ¿Por qué no decimos que Battlefield se copia de Call Of Duty o viceversa? Es una tontería muy grande. Los dos pertenecen al mismo género y punto.
  
Ahora sí, me centraré en hablar de Paladins.
Es un videojuego online multijugador que consiste en enfrentar un equipo de cinco contra cinco en un mapa. Normalmente hay que conquistar un punto.
Una de las cosas que más me gustan de este juego, es la variedad de personajes y sus roles (ya mencionados anteriormente). Podemos encontrarnos a seres humanos, elfos, árboles parlanchines, etc... ), cada uno con una personalidad distinta y carismática.
Es decir, está ambientado en un universo de fantasía (que juraría, es compartido por el otro gran título de Hirez Studios, "Smite").
Es muy divertido y repleto de adrenalina.
La historia del videojuego (Lore), está comenzando a surgir. Y es muy interesante que la mayoría de los personajes, obtengan sus poderes a través de los cristales que porten encima (ya sea en las armas, ropa, etc...), de ahí, el icono del diamante.

Ahora bien, no es perfecto. Tiene montones de bugs (algunos te pueden fastidiar la experiencia de juego), hay cosas que están mal en algunos mapas (Rincones sin salida...), los personajes no interactuan bien con el entorno (por ejemplo, si me quiero subir a una plataforma, el personaje realiza movimientos extraños y muchas veces he muerto por eso...), etc...
También echo en falta, un ataque físico y la capacidad de agacharse del personaje (aunque esto es subjetivo). Los servidores de Hirez Studios, nunca han sido muy... decentes (No obstante, la empresa es muy buena). Pero lo que más odio de este título, es la hitbox (es lo que define qué parte de un personaje puede recibir daños y qué cantidad de daño puede sufrir), es enormemente amplia en todos los personajes. Por ejemplo, puedes fijarte muchas veces como al asesinarte, tu enemigo ni siquiera estaba siendo preciso contra ti (es decir, no te acertaba las balas pero el juego detecta que sí, dañándote).  

En resumen, es un juego muy divertido y frenético que te recomiendo que pruebes. Total, ¡es gratis!

A pretty cool game, But one issue is that the servers are really really bad, I just wish they work on it to make it better and maybe add a server close to Middle Eastern players, but I think it will be hard because the player base is low.

But it really is fun when everything works out!

if the servers were good I would give it a Great review instead of Fair.

If you're looking for a cozy game that's more story driven than Stardew Valley, Wylde Flowers is for you. I love the rich characters and story lines. I love the inclusivity and diversity in the game. You're free to romance your favorite NPC and there's plenty to choose from. 

The farming part of this farming sim is simplified and later on in the game is quite automated. I'm a farming sim fam that doesn't really like the tedious farming parts lol so this was really refreshing. There's fishing and cooking and some limited decorating.

reviews.title: Best Cozy Game I’ve Ever Played

reviewText.content: I wasn’t sure about WyldeFlowers at first, but my friend streamed it on Twitch, and I watched her. I was immediately drawn in by the voice acting and beautiful but simple artwork! The game is bright, easy to navigate, and a pleasure to play! There is a definite storyline, and you will definitely feel all of the emotions. I felt the quests were just quest-y enough without being too much. The characters are perfectly developed, and it really has that small town feel. The witchy part doesn’t bother me (surprisingly), as it is just so innocent and pure as an entire storyline. There are no demons or scary monsters or anything of the sort. You have the opportunity to romance many characters, but if that’s not your thing, it’s ok, since that has no bearing on the storyline.

First played 1 Nov 23 on a plane from Paris and finished 10 Nov 23 with 42hrs & 30mins back in my home country! Went into it blind and was blindsided by how good the game was. Knowing nothing about the game, I was blown away when it started introducing the witches, the coven, and the game features revolving around magic. This was a completely novel combination no other game had executed before so masterfully. However, this is a game you play for the story and narrative, and not for the game features which tend to be shallow.

A 2020 Review - Alien: Isolation (PC, 2014)

Score: 7/10
Mediocrity Score: Not Mediocre
Alien: Isolation is a death-by-alien simulator masquerading as a first-person survival horror game. Dripping with late-1970s tech-ambiance, Creative Assembly has produced a rather safe narrative that closely follows the original Alien's tale of Ellen Ripley. Not falling far from the tree, the protagonist you play is none other than Amanda Ripley - Ellen Ripley's daughter. In what must feel like the family curse, Amanda is stricken with a far-too-similar fate being stuck on a space station trying to survive against aliens. If you aren't a fan of the series or haven't seen any of the movies - don't sweat it. Just bring an extra pair of underwear and dive into this insanely atmospheric and engrossing experience.

Tags: A few words or tags that come to mind are: atmospheric, stressful, powerless, tedious.

Avg. Time to beat: ~20 hours
Quickest Speedrun: ~2.5 hours (even on nightmare difficulty)

2020 Retail Price: $40
Lowest Historical Price on Steam: $10
Lowest Historical Price outside Steam: $7.50

Quick Take: Alien: Isolated is not fun. It is not an enjoyable experience by traditional standards, but it is a horrifically beautiful and a completely immersive one. Kotaku's Kirk Hamilton said it better than anyone else, "While many a video game has been designed for people who enjoy killing aliens, Alien: Isolation can only have been created for people who derive some perverse pleasure out of being killed by an alien." This game in its purest form is an engrossing simulation of how it would feel to try your odds against the alien xenomorphs in a bout of survival. Your odds are very slim. Between the sound engineering and the visual design, the two complement each other like two peas in a pod or...two facehuggers in an egg-sack, if you prefer. Together the two bring about an utter sense of dread, panic, and stress. You can hear the alien scampering through the ventilation; you can see its slimy drool ooze down in wait. You can hear the rich pops and sizzles of the CRT screens and analog devices used throughout the game. From opening production credits to end-game credits, it's a technical marvel...but is it an entertaining one? Well, that's where things get complicated... That's where I begin to feel the ol' quote "I want to get off Mr. Bones Wild Ride" becomes relevant again. At 16 hours in, I decided that's all the thrill I'll be getting out of that ride. Are you ever 100% glad you did or tried something, but wouldn't ever do it again? I appreciate Alien: Isolation for having done so much, so right - but I can't say I enjoyed or had fun playing it. It's stressful. I'm a huge horror film buff, yet this is a much longer and interactive experience - one that did not give me that "just 5 more minutes" feeling. It was more of a "where the hell's the savegame telephone at?"

Concept: Aliens (the movie) themed survival horror game. You're Ellen Ripley's unlucky daughter, Amanda - who also finds herself face to face with the same alien species that cost her mother's life. In a fight for survival, will you lead Amanda to her victory or just die 1,000 times trying? Yes. The answer is, yes.

Graphics: Impressive. Certainly so by 2014's standards but even for 2020 standards, this offers a high bar to pass. Compliments the audio design incredibly - both pairing together to reel you into the space-station, Sevastopol, along with all its horrors. For users looking to play at minimum or low specs, the game surprisingly doesn't look terrible when adjusted down. It holds up well enough, however, my advice would be to hold off until you can play at top specs. A huge amount of the value comes from the visual and audio. Unless you're easily entertained by horror games, I'd wait until you can get the full experience. It's worth it.

Sound: The sound design is killer. It breathes life into nothingness and fills the space with dread. From the menu screen, it is apparent that the audio will set the tone through much of the game. Hearing the alien bang around the ship or scamper about in the ventilation is disturbing when you've been hiding in a locker for ten minutes contemplating what actions led you to this awful place.

Gameplay: In one word - stealth. You will be crouching, hiding under desks, leaning, hiding in lockers, tip-toeing, and generally avoiding anything that moves or makes a sound. This will be much of your gameplay experience for a large portion of the game. Lots of tools and consumables/throwables to aid you in your fight. These won't be useful in killing an alien but should help separate you from the Alien a bit more easily. Unless you've memorized the maps and are an experienced speed-runner - you'll need to take the slow and steady approach. Kicking-down-the-door style of gameplay will get you killed. Although, hiding will mostly do the same. Perhaps my one word for gameplay should have been - dying.

Entertainment: Did you like the movies Source Code or Edge of Tomorrow? Then you'll enjoy experiencing it first-hand in an interactive simulator game, only with Aliens and Facehuggers. I found Alien: Isolation to be akin to a thrill-ride. A lot of fun in short bursts, but it is not something most people would enjoy for long stretches. I could only take so much stress and tension before growing tired of it and wanting to move on. "I want to get off Mr. Bones Wild Ride." comes to mind.

Replayability: How enjoyable is revisiting the same haunted house over and over again? Sure, the actors will always do things a little differently but it's always the same song and dance in the end. For me, it does not have replay value. It doesn't much affect my purchasing-interest if a game isn't replayable, so I'm cool with it. Maybe you are too.

Cheats??: None natively. There are existing trainers that can be downloaded and run alongside the game. I didn't find them to be useful or fun and led to achievements halting early on in my play-through. Use at your risk.


---Full Review Below---


Alien: Isolation is an immersive, first-person survival horror game set in the universe of the popular 1979 movie series, Alien. It provides a linear, puzzle-like progression with sci-fi and horror elements that are reminiscent of the 1999 PC game, Half-Life. You play as Amanda Ripley - Ellen Ripley's daughter. Hunting for answers relating to her mother's disappearance fifteen years ago - Amanda arrives at the retired space station, Sevastopol. She soon discovers the station has been ravaged by the same Alien that her mom had once faced. Going up against the legendary alien Xenomorphs is a terrifying experience to endure. A position you will find yourself far too regularly.

Creative Assembly has created a game true to its source material. Die-hard fans of the series are rewarded with its similar effect on the senses. Its richness and melding of audio, visuals, and narrative are a strong part of what made the original film so great. Alien: Isolation provides a horrifying simulation of facing the alien parasites head-on and struggling for your own survival. The unnerving atmosphere seeps its way through the halls and corridors of the maze-like Sevastopol station. I applaud the creators for doing an excellent job recreating the same intensity and unease as the films. The game surpasses the movies in many regards, including its effectiveness at bringing the audience in for a much closer, more frightful experience. Even in 2020, there is no better way to experience the thrill of being trapped on-board with the Alien Xenomorphs. It's a harrowing engagement to play this death-by-Alien simulator, and as the player, you get a real sense of what it might be like to have to defend yourself and survive against one. 

The story falls a bit flat and too closes mirrors its source of inspiration. I can forgive the creators for not wanting to alter a working story-formula too much. Especially when the original worked so well. But this story feels shoehorned into place. It works, but it's not interesting and takes a back seat to everything else. Maybe it helps the Alien AI and horror elements stay in the spotlight. Maybe keeping a potentially too-radical story from imposing too heavily upon the game's features. I don't know. But to me, a more compelling story would have made for better cohesion thus more driving power during the slower, more repetitive parts. Instead, we have to endure an already long, stressful journey with lower motivation to continue forward. 

Much of the game's effectiveness stems from its sound and visual direction. From the very second it launches, the player is met with a rich, filling audio that tickles the ear with its static hums and hisses. If it weren't for the technical accomplishments of the audio and visual, Alien: Isolation would be far less than the success that it is. Honestly, this might be the most stand-out game in terms of its audio design and ability to draw in the player with sound alone. It's an impressive achievement. The throwback themes of the late-70s technology are strewn about. Looking to the past for inspiration, the Sevastopol space station's design and appearance bring us right back to the same point in time that the original Ellen Ripley found herself face-to-face with the Xenomorphs. Warped CRT screens, static-noise eliminating from the security tuner box, or the beeps and blips from the motion detector are all great examples of the aesthetic the design team worked into the game. I feel like the flamethrower and Molotov could have better flame effects; the flames don't last long enough, the smoke effect is very weak, and could have made for a more serious impact in its use. 

The Alien has both the most advanced and impressive AI designs, as well as the most frustrating ones to endure. It never gives up, it never relents. It's realistic to the series. For sure, this is how the Alien would behave if hunting you - but it is frustratingly difficult to progress the game at times. It is true, no two reloads of a save game are the same. The Alien does not always follow the same path. It shadows you, learning your habits and tendencies. It adapts to your play-style to better get the drop on you. While impressive, this makes for a very challenging experience in avoiding its traps. The other enemy type, Androids, are very thorough in their scans and sweeps when they see or hear you. If you are outside of a vent or locker, they'll find you rather quickly. The Androids, formally named "Working Joes", are the physical form of the APOLLO AI mainframe system. The APOLLO system provides security, communications, monitoring, and Android orchestration to the Sevastopol station. Alien: Isolation fumbles powerfully in its attempt at creating consistent human animations of movement and speech. Non-combative human-AI behavior and mannerisms are uncomfortable and confusing. The humans act skittish to a cartoon extent, just shy of a parody. They wail about in terror, while also frequently getting stuck in place halting all emotion. Cut-scene animations commonly have audio and video synchronization problems with mouth-movements and voices falling out of sync. 

Fear, panic, and stress will be the prevailing emotions throughout playing. This game is about stealth and silence. It's difficult. You'll die a tremendous amount, often in startling ways. You cannot kill the Alien. You can trick it to go looking for you elsewhere (via equipment/throwables) or you can temporarily scare it away with a flamethrower. Rushing the Alien will mostly earn you another death animation. The androids will stop and hurt you before you can land a blow. Rushing around the map will make more noise and attract the Alien to your location all the quicker. This will likely wear down certain players, keeping them from finishing the game. It's frustrating and leads to replaying and re-accomplishing goals until you can hopefully get to the next save-phone. Watch-out! - if you save with the Alien right behind you, guess what will still be behind you once you reload? 

For all the hassle required to finish, I found the end cut-scenes and conclusion to be lackluster. There were several times I felt like quitting out of frustration. It shines brightest within the first 4-8 hours while the horror and intrigue is still fresh and alive, and before any of it becomes tedious or repetitive. As much I enjoyed the many thrills Alien: Isolation has to offer, it was rather taxing on my ability or will to keep playing. Having an unsatisfying story, the game failed to hold-together my motivation to help power me through some of the more difficult or slower parts. Nonetheless, this release serves as a standout technical achievement for the genre. It accomplishes staying true to the movies, being masterfully designed in its cohesiveness between the sound and visual designs, and is powerfully scary to experience. 

The worst thing I can say is that through all its thrills and immersion, I never found it to be a fun experience. It's one I'm glad I had, but not one I enjoyed much. I think this might be the case for many players or potential ones. It's made for a difficult game to review; how do I recommend something that I did not enjoy? My advice is to view i like a thrill-ride. Look for a low price point (have seen it go for $10 on Steam) and keep expectations realistic. I don't see the need to put more than 4-10 hours to really get the full experience. If you scare or get startled easily, perhaps see if any of your friends have a copy you could check out with them. It's absolutely worth experiencing but I'm not convinced the price for admission is priced right for most of the year. At being 6 years old, I feel $40 is quite a reach. $20 seems fairer - but I personally would wait until it falls to $10 or less.


Thanks for reading!

When is it going to end? Please let it be over! But I wasn't screaming this because of scary moments. Instead, it became a nightmare game to finish.

I so wish this game was a quarter of its length. It quickly became monotonous.

I love the soundtrack and the level design. The tension that the game set is unique. But I hate everything that developers forced onto the player. 

Do you want to go at your own pace? No, here's a random teleporting alien that will instantly kill you. Take it slow! And they mean extremely slow. Plus 5 hours of not fun.

Do you want to explore? Guess what we have for you? Forced save system. So every time you die exploring stuff, you will have to start over. Plus 5 hours of unneeded repetition.

Do you believe in second chances? Haha. Plus 5 hours of unskippable routine work. Fun's overrated.

Do you hate traveling? What? We made such *amazing scenery* so there's no waypoint traveling for you. You have to take the corridor route that was predetermined. Plus 5 hours of running around. If you're bad at making alien friends, add another 5 hours.

When to play the game?
- If you enjoy being killed by the Alien. A lot.
- If slow-paced scary games are your thing.
- If you're a fan of the Alien franchise works.
- If you enjoy visuals and sound design more than engaging gameplay.

Verdict: Play it or watch it?
Rather watch it.

Love the attention to detail and the faithful adherence to the Alien series look and feel. Controls are good, tension is super-high at first, but quickly devolves into repetition. The Alien doesn't seem to obey any spatial laws: it's simply able to show up exactly when needed. Really enjoyed the terminals and all the lore, but the hiding behind boxes and in closets got old.

For some people this game can be irritating. Full of jump scares and it will result in instant deaths. Well, that depends on the player. This was my first horror game I've finished. Actually, its enjoyable to play with adrenaline. Graphics looks good and surprisingly optimized well.

The gameplay is decent with a variety of bombs for you to craft as well as the few guns you get being the revolver, shotgun, flamethrower and bolt gun. I mostly stuck to the shotgun for humans and android, and then the flamethrower to scare off the Alien when need be.

Right away though Alien Isolation is a game that really allows you to get immersed with very minimal HUD on your screen, allowing you to get absorbed in the world of Alien. The atmosphere is always tense and you feel like everything wants to kill you from the enemies, to the space station that is constantly falling apart. It also provides some good horror that never felt cheap or lazy, it just felt right.

Story is pretty decent and feels like it fits in well with the movies, with themes of corporate corruption and the people who get caught in the crossfire. The twists can be a bit predictable if your well versed in the movies, but otherwise it was very entertaining. The ending was a big let down though and I can see now why fans of this game have been begging for a sequel. It ends in a unsatisfying way and if they really do never make a sequel (that's not a mobile game) then I'm going to be left feeling very unsatisfied.

There's still useless story and some things make no sense.
