Amazing, fun and funny game, here you can play with your favorite characters from action movies.

I haven't experienced this much enjoyment in a local co-op game since the days of Crash Team Racing on the PS1. The parody of American imperialism in this game is exceptionally well-done. It's challenging to find any character unlikable. The diverse Bros add a level of variety and unpredictability to the gameplay. However, the overall experience is marred by a few technical issues and frame-rate drops, particularly in the final stages.

Прям так, сходу скажу, что игра крутая. Нам предстоит управляя разными персонажами из фильмов 80-90ых годов разбираться с террористами, пришельцами и демонами. Игра местами бывает довольно сложной, ведь мы умираем от одного удара. Здесь очень много персонажей, их около 30, каждый из которых обладает собственным оружием и способностью. Некоторые бойцы довольно имбовые, а некоторые наоборот, только усложняют прохождение уровня. Это был первый плюс - персонажи. Второй - это пасхалки и отсылки, тут их очень много. Третий плюс - это динамичность игры, мы можем разнести на карте все, лишь некоторые блоки не ломаются, а так, можно уничтожить все. Минусов у этой прекрасной игры нет.

Traverse a decaying land filled with wonder and danger as you, Stela, witness the final days of a mysterious ancient world. Explore dark forests, cold snowfields, flammable battlefields, mysterious towns, and subterranean horrors as your race to your destination.

Stela is a side-scrolling cinematic puzzle platformer with an interesting and engaging story through the first and second act. By bypassing creatures, discovering secrets, and engaging in interesting puzzles you slowly begin to understand the world around you—or at least the dangers of this strange and doomed world has to offer. This game is absolutely beautiful—the artwork, music, and puzzles are great and make for a memorable gameplay experience. All of the different parts work very well together with the highlight in my opinion being the music and artwork.

Sadly, there seems to be no motive for the girl running and bypassing obstacles and things that want to kill her. The game doesn’t offer this to us as there is no text and no speaking. This is, perhaps, why I came to the conclusion that Stela didn’t give me any deep emotional connection to the story. Speaking of story, it is the last chapter that seemed to fall flat when it should have been the crescendo of the entire game, and I was left feeling confused about not only the backdrop of the last chapter but what I was really doing there as well. This makes it feel as if the game was more about the graphics and music instead of any real story.

The controls are simple and easy to learn—you run, you jump, and you can push some objects around. The achievements, for the most part, are easy to get as most of them are storyline achievements. There are only two achievements that are harder to get, finish the game without dying and finish the game in under 90 minutes, that will have you play the game multiple times.

Overall, I found Stela to be a good game with amazing visuals, beautiful sound, and engaging puzzles with a hint of horror included. Despite it’s flaws I would recommend this game for those interested in the beauty that can be applied to side-scrolling games, those that enjoyed LIMBO or Little Nightmares, or those that enjoy puzzle platformers in a strange and mysterious world filled with danger and beautiful landscapes.

RECENSIONE (ITALIAN):
È un buon gioco ma estremamente derivativo, senza grossi errori ma che non raggiunge i picchi di qualità dei diretti rivali, uno su tutto Inside.

AUDIO E GRAFICA:
Il comparto audio è quasi assente, c'è una buona colonna sonora e qualche altro suono, ma utili solo per non lasciare il gioco muto, niente di memorabile.

Molto curata invece la grafica del gioco che, come Inside, propone uno stile low poly a scorrimento orizzontale ma in un ambiente 3D.
Il difetto principale sta nel fatto che ogni tanto è possibile interagire con oggetti più lontani o vicini di noi, ma la profondità non è abbastanza chiara e a volte si commettono errori pensando di poter saltare su qualche elemento oppure non scalandone altri.

Buone ma inferiori al titolo Playdead sono le animazioni, abbastanza ricche e dettagliate ma non molto fluide.

Molto bella infine la gestione della camera, che si muove molto per creare inquadrature spesso evocative. Questo a volte inficia la visibilità della protagonista, ma in realtà la situazione rimane sempre sotto controllo. 

GAMEPLAY:
Come già detto il gioco è di base molto simile ad altri titoli. Si sviluppa a scorrimento orizzontale ma senza molte sezioni platform e soprattutto l'ambiente è tridimensionale, quindi dovremo stare attenti anche agli elementi sullo sfondo.

I soli comandi di salto e presa bastano per creare abbastanza situazioni interessanti lungo l'intero sviluppo del gioco, lungo circa 3 ore.

Gli enigmi ambientali sono difficili il giusto da capire, ma alcuni sono piuttosto ostici da realizzare per colpa dei nemici. 

Sono inoltre presenti diversi segreti, molto ben nascosti in quanto il primo l'ho trovato solo a gioco inoltrato (mi stavo chiedendo come mai non ci fossero segreti, visto che sono frequenti in questo genere).

STORIA:
Il gioco non ha una vera e propria storia, cosa che in questo genere si può accettare, però i cambi di ambientazione sono completamente illogici e atti solo a permettere certe situazioni.

Non ho apprezzato come il gioco sembra voler trasmettere un messaggio, a me ignoto, ma fallisca nel farlo e per provare a farlo rovini anche la coerenza delle ambientazioni.

Devo dire però che ogni singola ambientazione è pensata molto bene, con vari elementi e nemici specifici, tutto molto diversi e abbastanza originali.


In conclusione, consiglio il gioco agli amanti del genere perché dura poco ed è piacevole, ma una volta provato Inside si capiscono tutti i limiti di Stela.

VOTO: 7.5/10

reviews.title: Petit jeu d'aventure/exploration, ici pas de combat mais de la poésie :)

reviewText.content:
Notre personnage mi humaine mi oiseau va explorer et redécouvrir les origines "mystiques" de son monde, en alternant voyages dans le ciel et donjons/énigmes à pied.
Le parti pris des graphismes épurés plaira ou pas, mais il reste cohérent avec l'ambiance voulu.
La durée de vie est de l'ordre de 5h en prenant le temps d'explorer.

Joué sur SeriesX.

reviews.title: A fantasy exploration walking and flying simulator game but in Polygon

reviewText.content:
Somewhere in the dev office when this game idea was pitched : Yo dude, how about we make a game about fantasy world without even trying to mesh the game character in 3D with open-world illusion and leave it with polygon shape as art direction style to make a difference than similar game, add elementary school puzzle tier with long backtracking plus make our main character can travel around the world by shape-shifting into a bird while the music consist of sleepy ambient and half-baked chillwave music being played randomly, meanwhile we dont really have too much assets for many characters and care enough about the world building story by putting the main character should save the world because her ancestor did something wrong. Also, dont put any combat, score, item collecting. And make our game as walking and flying simulator.

And that is shortest summary of the game I played that consumes 3 hours for a game that you can play before sleep to experience the greatness of yawning I have got from this game. A potential great indie game but ruined with just simple walking and flying simulator in fantasy world that reminds me of 3D Legend of Zelda game where main objective to finish all floating island in the sky that is pretty cool concept but there are not many things to do after reaching the island except solving the basic puzzle to reveal the plotline about how dark creature will take over the world except main character visiting all the shrine and got the power. The lame thing about getting the power that there is no power at all to use in combat because there is no enemy to face except in the cut scene for each completing puzzle. 

I think it’s not fair though to judge an indie game having combat element and its become full player exploration experience, but the thing game don’t give too much instruction what to do or simple quest tracker is pretty off. There countable NPC in your base that gives the clue what to visit but considering this game is meant to play as chilling session, I end up wandering back and forth and almost made me quit. 

Rating : 5/10
Finished : 22 December 2019
Written : 20 January 2020

This game is so freaking good. Seriously. I'm actually really frustrated with my friends because they aren't available enough to play :) With that said, the primary issues I've ran into were just community issues. They've already announced they're adding surrender into the game for lopsided matches and afk situations so I imagine that drawback will be heavily diminished soon.

As for the gameplay, the art, the skins, the monetization model... it all seems very reasonable and fair and the design of the game looks great. It also plays extremely well on console and pc. Mobile was a little difficult and takes getting used to but it was likely a skill issue.

Game is an absolute blast. Fast paced gameplay thats easy to pick up but hard to master. Its a blast to play, especially with some friends and the different characters will have you hooked for a while.
Bon jeu mais dommage les transactions un jeu  cache un peu le jeu qui est pourtant pas si mal graphiquement et dans le projet
This is too good for the stealth game lover.. i just love this game,

Was this a perfect game? No

However, was it a fun game to be played? Also no

Take the color palette from Mirror's Edge (which is also a big pile of manure as well), put some cell shading from Borderlands (which is also a big pile of manure as well), take a crippled version of Blink and Corvo from Dishonored (alright, this is quite OK), throw them into a melting pot and you have Aragami.

Game plagued by the worst capital (if worst could be capital in the same time) SIN of stealth games - NO F***ING HARD SAVE. Checkpoints horribly placed, if you die (and you will die a lot - because it's 1 hit kill) you are excruciatingly, painfully, horrendously forced to replay the chapter either from start or from the next checkpoint placed in the middle of f***ing nowhere, until you'll learn by heart all enemies routes. See what happened to Hitman Absolutions, Metro 2033, last Splinter Cell Games and how they were criticized because of this idiotic checkpoint system especially in stealth games. 

Reach the next destination, eliminate the light barrier, repeat

To start off, the most striking part about this game is its art style. Its a gorgeous game to look at with its Japanese inspired aesthetic. The way the colours pop and are so striking to look at it, its shame that there's no photo mode, as me and my friend just wanted to take as many screenshots as we could! The cutscenes are also decently animated and more then what I was expecting from an indie title.

The gameplay is very much like Dishonored with a similar teleporting ability and other powers to what you would find in an Arkane game. Some of my favourites were the dagger throwing ability and one that allows you to blind opponents so you can sneak past or run up for a kill. The gameplay just felt very smooth overall for me. The levels are mostly linear but there a couple of more open areas which really let you explore and take out the army of guards in anyway you see fit. Not as large and explorable as a Arkane level, but close enough. And all of this just works perfectly in co-op!

The bosses are also a stand out. There are only a few of them with one reminding me of the Mr. Freeze boss fight from Batman: Arkham City in the best way possible! The final boss worked very well in terms of the story, but is a little simple as far as boss design goes.

As for the story, I was expecting something pretty basic going in, and what I got wasn't anything mind blowing but was still pretty solid and left me satisfied with the experience!

Steep takes you on an exhilarating ride through the snow-covered peaks of the Alps, promising a unique experience in the world of extreme sports video games. With stunning graphics, a massive, vibrant open world, and an innovative approach to winter sports, it stands out as a title that caters to those seeking thrilling adventures in a snow-capped playground. While it may pose a steep learning curve, especially for newcomers, it offers an experience that's hard to find in other games.

A Visual Masterpiece

Steep's visuals are breathtaking, capturing the majestic beauty of the alpine world in all its glory. The snow-covered mountains, picturesque villages, and dynamic weather systems create an immersive and realistic environment. It's a testament to the developers' dedication to delivering a visually stunning experience.

An Immense Playground

The game world is vast, sprawling, and inviting, offering endless opportunities for exploration and adventure. The Alps come to life with its many challenges and hidden gems, providing a diverse and dynamic environment for players to conquer.

Engaging and Unique Gameplay

Steep introduces a unique approach to extreme sports, combining skiing, snowboarding, paragliding, and wingsuit flying. The open world design allows you to seamlessly switch between these activities, making the gameplay engaging and dynamic. Each sport presents its own set of challenges and exhilarating moments.

A Variety of Winter Sports

Steep stands out in the gaming world for its focus on extreme winter sports, offering an experience that's hard to find in other titles. It caters to those who seek excitement in downhill skiing, off-piste snowboarding, gravity-defying wingsuit jumps, and serene paragliding flights.

It's a simple puzzle platformer where you play as a border collie with the second sight protecting their grieving human as she comes to terms with old memories. The puzzles frequently involve finding nature spirits or sprigs of heather to ward off malevolent spirits warping her perception or keeping you on the wrong side of the veil, while a few involve learning how to sheep dog. That's it, that's the entire game. If not you're already sold, it's probably not for you.

reviews.title: orcmondo's review of Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot

reviewText.content: "Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot delivers an immersive DBZ experience with epic battles and open-world exploration. Repetitive side quests and occasional frame rate drops detract, but overall, it's a must-play for fans."

reviews.title: YES_IM_BLAQK's review of Dragon Ball Z: Kakarot

reviewText.content: Overall: I feel like people when playing this game they want to feel like they’re playing their Dragon Ball Z character they love. They want to feel like the Z fighter they spent time watching as a kid. And they want to be able to do all the cool attacks and stuff as the Z fighter does and progress the story as such. The game should have been able to scratch this itch considering it has no competitive online modes. However, it doesn’t fully accomplishes this. It just comes off feeling incomplete or just not reaching its full potential. I see Dragon Ball Z Kakarot as an alright game with massive amounts of wasted potential.

I played Goblin Sword on the NSW, and I loved it so much! The retro graphic is lovely, there's a fair amount of weapons and stuff to unlock, the level design is challenging yet not crazy hard... It's just a really good game, super fun both in portable and dock mode.

Truly inventive game design and fascinating story. The way this game encourages exploration is brilliant. It doesnt sponfeed you with waypoints etc, you just explore a brilliantly designed galaxy at your own pace. Although theres no strict goals as such there is just enough guidance to keep you moving forward at all times. 
The world design is stellar, the use of quantum sci fi, a mystery which was unravelled masterfully (leaving me a little unsure right til the very end) and incredibly unique ideas made for one of the freshest game experiences I've had in a while. 
The best thing I can say though, is that the world is just a joy to explore, the worlds are beautiful, unique and have great depth.

reviews.title: Un juego maravilloso y brutalmente ignorado

reviewText.content:
Jugabilidad: ingeniosa, simple  con pocas mecánicas bien explicadas y que dan mas juego de lo que crees, teniendo giros interesantes de la forma en que las puedes usar, usar el lanzador de ondas para impulsarte en el vacio, todo lo relacionado a los elementos cuánticos que nos dan una forma que no nos esperábamos de usar la linterna y fotografía. nunca desbloquearemos una nueva mecánica para llegar a nuevas partes, solo desbloqueamos información que nos da pistas de como llegar  ciertas partes, la jugabilidad y los controles son minimalistas y cumplen de forma magistral su función.

Diseño de niveles: obra maestra, uno de los mapas mejor diseñados de todos los juegos, todo esta relacionado, encontraras pistas y puntos de intereses en todos lados, y es maravilloso porque no te llevan de la mano, no te dicen de forma directa que hacer, todo lo haces a consciencia, porque tu quieres no porque alguien te lo dijo, la curiosidad es lo que te impulsa, "como llegare a esta zona en x planeta"  no sabes como llegar así que vas  a otro planeta y encuentras un texto nomai de unas personas que hicieron algo en el planta al que quieres llegar y mencionan un dato sobre como llegaron a la zona a la que querías llegar, nadie te dijo como llegar directamente, no es un acertijo ambiguo es una pista directa bien implementada, no se siente que el juego te esta ayudando, se siente que realmente estas descubriendo como ir, que estas desenvolviendo un misterio, y todo es posible por el diseño tan bueno y sublime que deja todo puesto en un sitio concreto de forma que a donde sea que vayas movido por curiosidad encontraras algo para desempolvar mas la historia y como llegar a ciertas zonas, y cuando logras descubrir todo te das cuenta que no desbloqueaste nuevas zonas en el mapa, no te hiciste super fuerte, solo descubriste que hacer y como hacerlo, nada esta cerrado para impedir tu paso, lo único que te impide avanzar es tu desconocimiento de como hacerlo o que hacer, y eso es maravilloso porque es un sentimiento genuino de exploración y de que estas haciendo algo. 

Historia: es muy muy buena, el lore, las implicaciones, todos los significados ocultos, simbolismos, el misterio que se construye en un principio, y es que la historia esta tan bien armada que no importa a donde vayas o en que orden veas todo, terminaras dando con el clavo y armando tu la historia antigua, como si realmente fueras un arqueólogo, como si estuvieras explorando y descubriendo, es una maravilla como todo conecta de una forma o otra y terminas dando a el fondo del asunto, y el final es simplemente maravilloso, raro ambiguo espectacular, una vez entiendes todo no quedaras insatisfecho. 

Graficos: Muy buenos, tiene un estilo muy característico y las atmosferas y diseño de todo el sistema solar es espectacular, cada planeta esta bien diferenciado, cada elemento, nada se siente repetido ni feo ni poco único, la estética del juego es única y bonita acompaña muy bien al sentido de exploración, planetas que te generan curiosidad, otros miedo o incertidumbre, algunos tranquilidad. unos gráficos y diseños muy bien hechos e implementados 

Soundtrack: Maravilloso, el mezclar el folk con el ambient un poco de post rock, no es solo por la forma en que funciona en el juego, es que es una mezcla tan única y característica que este soundtrack es una obra maestra y merece toda una review aparte.

Very interesting way to tell a very interesting story, an adventure like anything else, unique, with smart and satisfactory puzzles. I cannot say anything bad about this game.

Exploration is very rewarding, there are details and clues in every corner of the game, everything is useful either to resolve puzzles or to undestand better the story behind everything that is happening in the game.

Controls are fine with a gamepad, devs recommend using it when the game starts. I didn't play it with keyboard/mouse though.

Interesting story. The game brings up your inner space traveler. But the overall amazing game and the very deep story are killed by very bad controls, especially if you're on PC without a controller. It doesn't have any character development, no skill tree, anything that would make your travels easier the more you try. So you can get into situations where you don't feel any progress at all, just redoing the same thing over and over, diving into depths of helplessness. This is especially painful in locations such as Sun Station or going around the fish. As long as there's forced minutes long wait time between each try, you can get into a situation where you've been trying for hours staring at the screen, waiting, doing the same thing, then failing again. This is not enjoyable at all, considering you can't even alt-tab to the windows while waiting for scripted events, the window has to be active. This is one of the games that are better to be seen as a story video, playing it is not so fun.

Explore space! Solve puzzles! Meet odd characters. Unravel a mystery. 

Die. 

Do it again. 

Die. 

And again.

But that’s how it’s supposed to go. On each launch of your spaceship, you’re going to die. Even if you pilot your ship accurately and don’t fall into a crevasse or run out of oxygen, the sun is going to go supernova. And you’re gonna die. 

But you remember everything when you come back, although your home planet friends don’t notice. 

This loop is the primary hook to Outer Wilds. There’s no saving, except between loops. 

The loops, so far, can be quite fun and the game doesn’t drag out setting up the mystery. It can be a bit tedious doing the takeoff routine and heading back the planet or moon you were last on. You have an autopilot,  but it might steer you into an asteroid on the way. 

On day one of its release, I’m going to call it a good game. If it turns out to be a great game, I’ll say so.

Everybody knows this game has a reputation. I can't say I don't understand why, but I don't share all the excitement. Completing it felt more like a chore than an adventure, but I'm aware I am a very anxious person, and that might have compromised my enjoyment. The amount of backtracking and hours invested in aimless exploration (not knowing what to look for or how to solve a puzzle - or even knowing there is a puzzle to solve) will really test your patience. The ambientation compensates this frustration with amazing soundtrack, a spectacle of visuals and a endearing mystery. Nonetheless, even if you are like me, and quickly gets frustrated, I think this game is worth trying. You will find something here no other game has to offer. For that reason alone, Outer Wilds is worthy of all praises.

A great game where you go at your own pace piecing together the story of the universe as you go. The music is great throughout as well as normal game design. This game is cool in general and that it just sets you in the world and let's you travel wherever you want.

Dissertations could be written about how Outer Wilds handles story delivery and game progression.
A brilliant little sci-fi adventure, filled with awe inspiring moments of revelation and discovery.

Everything here works like clockwork.  Without spoiling much, it is truly incredible that your experience with the game is basically what shapes your progress. There is no hidden new abilities, no secret game mechanics, everything you need to explore the world is given to you in the tutorial sequence. The only thing you gain between the start and end of the game is your knowledge and an in-game tracker, everything else stays its clockwork-self. Do not expect a walking simulator, though. The is very much a video game where you have to be at your best to get the most out of it.

It's impossible to overstate how brilliant Outer Wilds is. Despite only having played it within the past year, I can confidently say that it's the best game I've ever played and I'm not sure how it can ever be topped. That being said, Outer Wilds is not for everyone; players need to dedicate a lot of time and patience to come to grips with the game's spacewalking controls, and the time-loop nature of the game inevitably results in a lot of time spent waiting around for things to happen. The brave adventurers who can overcome these hurdles, though, will be treated to one of the best sci-fi tales ever told, backed by one of the most fulfilling exploration experiences video games have to offer.

Outer Wilds" is a cosmic puzzle where exploration is your only weapon. Each discovery reveals a new layer of mystery in a universe where knowledge is power, and every secret you uncover reshapes your journey.

The main issue I had was that the game got pretty repetitive. It does the papers please style 'throwing an unmanagable amount of work at you' gameplay really well and mechanically it works well. I just started to get bored of writing tickets and the main plot was moving really slowly. When a plot beat does happen, nothing really changes, you get a few lines of text in a phone call and then you just go back to the same jobs youve been doing so far. It is a really good idea I felt it had a limited lifespan without throwing in some more varied content.

reviews.title: Un bon jeu d'aventure à l'ancienne

reviewText.content:
Un bon jeu d'aventure à l'ancienne, au premier degré dans un univers Fantasy
Et donc GO pour la suite : Memoria !

I remember playing Super Meat Boy when it first released, it ran on my potato computer, and I had a great time. It was hard, but I was able to make solid progress, and it wasn't frustrating for a while. With the sense of nostalgia, I turned on Super Meat Boy Forever, and man, this game is something else. Even level 2 is hard to pass. This game is only for hardcore gamers full of patience, time, and persistence.

A really solid Roguelike

You don't need to be "good" at poker to play and you'll learn the hands/combos as you go to help you pass the bigger blinds.

Endless mode can REALLY kick your arse.

It has really good cross platform support and is a tiny game disk space wise.
Replay value is immense with a lot of cards/tarot/modifiers/etc to discover
One of the best and very difficult game of 2020. Big up for Chasing Rats Games!

Enter a strange world full of puzzles, disturbing visuals, and oddness as you take part in four experimental chapters that explore 80’s nostalgia, horror elements, and intensive puzzles.  Take part in Stories Untold to uncover the truth, the dread, and the mystery of four different stories intertwined into one game.

Stories Untold is an anthology of four chapters that, while different from each other, are brought together in the final chapter for a conclusion that creates cohesion out of the different parts of the whole.  Stories Untold focuses on text-based adventure/horror  games and point-and-click to solve puzzles.  When the puzzle is completed the game progresses the slowly unfolding story along.

I appreciated the collection of stories and was pleased with the connections made in the final chapter—something that anthologies, especially horror anthologies, usually have a hard time doing.  The addition of very meta parts in the fourth and final chapter made it fun.  However, the problem with Stories Untold is that while the four chapters are well crafted and tied together nicely; the story itself is quite tame. The story was good, a bit predictable, but okay.  It didn’t have anything clever or unique or subversive beyond the final “twist” and left the overall experience of Stories Untold with a story that wasn’t very memorable.

While a good game; Stories Untold is not perfect.  The text-based portions were not “mind bending” nor were they thoroughly enjoyable (perhaps touching on 80’s games a bit too much).  Stories Untold tends to lean too much on the 80’s nostalgia especially with the equally ancient text parser…the game was released in 2017 and I am sure there was better parsers available to use.  This issue makes me feel that the nostalgia theme of the game was used more as a crutch than a style design.

As an important note:  If you are hard of hearing you will have difficulty with Chapter Three.  Being able to hear the numbers and codes given over the radio was especially difficult.  Even with subtitles on they will not display the numbers as text.  I do not expect the game to subtitle the codes and numbers but felt that others with a hearing disability should know about this beforehand.  Additionally, there is an epilepsy warning on this game which you should take seriously if this is something that will affect you.

Overall, an okay game that has no replayability besides getting the hidden achievements.  While I did like some of the elements of Stories Untold there were parts that were not enjoyable.  I will still recommend this game however, if mostly for the horror elements over gameplay…extra points for getting it on sale.

Very cool horror game. It heavily taps into the 80s/stranger things/ twighlight zone nostaliga vibe and pulls it off well. The game has four individual stories in which you interact with 80s technology (old computers, scientific equipment etc) in scifi horror stories. Theyre very SCP style horror stories which arent really trying to make you jump, more give you that sense of dread from experiencing something unnatural. It pulls this off brilliantly and at the end goes down a really clever route with some pretty heavy plot content.

Who doesn't want to fight cute little monsters with a broom and meet other adventurers who ride motorbikes in dungeons? Try out this Zelda-like pixel art game and enjoy the solid quality of gameplay and childing vibe.
It's an interesting game, but it's more of the same. Good if you want a fast game, since it's very short

reviews.title: alalearl's review of Flynn: Son of Crimson

reviewText.content:
This game has a good potential. 
You can upgrade your skill, find hidden item each stage.
But the game is too short and cannot get back to find hidden item when you reach to final boss.
and the way you change your range skill is a problem when you are in combat and you muse change your skill or weapon.

It's another telltale game. I love them but some people just don't.
This one is a fantastic batman story, they played around with a few of the characters and did some really interesting stuff. The characters are all well written and the story is exciting. You get a good amount of agency over what type of batman you want to be. They added a few mechanics mostly relating to bat-tech which make you feel pretty bat-like. 
I just wish I'd had more chances to fight from the shadows rather than get in open fist/firefights. 
The main problem was that its the same engine telltale use for everything. The models and scenery look great but animations are stilted and I dropped frames a fair bit. Also theres not challenge in it. If you miss QTE prompts it either just sits there waiting for you or you suceed anyway. No actions ever seemed to have negative consequences which took away some of the imprtance of decisions and fights.

Una grandiosa película interactiva que intenta crear su propia mitología de Batman con una historia original llena de buenos giros e increíbles personajes. Con esto dicho, este tipo de videojuegos no son para todo el mundo, ya que carecen de acción desenfrenada o desafíos a nivel de Gameplay. Si no tienes paciencia para experiencias que se cuecen a fuego lento, huye de este título!

A new and fresh representation and portrayal of classic DC characters, a great story in which your choices, even the most little ones, have consequences. This looks straight out of the Dark Knight trilogy.

reviews.title: the_last_b's review of Batman: The Telltale Series

reviewText.content:
Un juego interesante solo si eres Fan de Batman, no veo mucho valor aqui, encontraras muchas mejores aventuras graficas en el catalogo de Telltale y como fan casual de batman hay mejores alternativas en la Saga Arkham

Pasado esa barrera si eres un loco de Batman como yo aquí tienes un toque interesante, las reinterpretaciones de personajes clásicos lo mantienen fresco de otras interpretaciones, así como el toque que le dan las interacciones de las decisiones del jugador sin duda te harán disfrutar y sentir bastante la historia de un nuevo modo.

Tuve barios Bugs y problemas de rendimiento, pero nada que lo vuelva injugable

reviews.title: Petit jeu AA dont le faible budget se fait sentir

reviewText.content:
+ graphismes et ambiance particulièrement travaillés
+ univers inhabituel qui dépayse
-/+ level design assez réussi mais parfois bien foireux sur les phases de plateforme (sauts approximatifs qui font atterrir dans le vide et mourir)
+ gameplay très approximatif, notamment contre les boss, avec certains passages très crispants.

A noter que ce n'est pas un jeu pour enfant, nombreuses scènes violentes/trashs.
L'histoire a un fil rouge pour les chapitres sont plutôt constitués autour d'une "fable" différente, ce qui donne un ensemble avec "le derrière entre deux chaises".

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

The idea of another game like that seemed amazing, and I was constantly recommended the Golden Idol. I tried it, and I really, really liked it. It is its own kind of game, only slightly inspired by the masterpiece mentioned above. Golden Idol is somewhat more approachable as it is level based, and doesn't require your whole life until you beat the game. I was hooked on it for a while, but two things ended up bugging me after I beat it. First, the Epilogue inclusion seemed like a bad idea. Second, the words that you "collect" to then use them later are sometimes not at all connected to how they are actually used.

reviews.title: razieligor's review of The Case of the Golden Idol

reviewText.content: It's like a logic puzzle/hidden object/deductive reasoning game with an interesting story. I loved it.

Jeu d'énigmes type poin't click, durant une dizaine de chapitres il faudra récolter les indices et les relier entre eux pour comprendre ce qui s'est passé.
Car chaque chapitre tourne autour d'un lieu (réparti sur quelques écrans), de quelques personnages et objets, et surtout d'un meurtre qu'il faudra élucider.
Une fois les indices glanés et ajoutés à notre dictionnaire, il faut ensuite remplir un texte de synthèse, à l'aide de phrases à trou et des mots tirés de notre dictionnaire justement.
Les scènes sont bien étudiées, la traduction français fait le boulot, ce qui est important car tout le jeu est porté par son écriture.
La direction artistique pourra prêter à débat, en tout cas cela reste lisible et cohérent durant tout le jeu.
Compter 6 à 8h de durée de vie, ceci variera beaucoup d'une personne à une autre, difficile de ne pas avoir envie d'enchaine avec les DLC en tout cas :)

Joué sur PC via game pass.

reviews.title: thexder0's review of Felix the Reaper

reviewText.content:
This game has everything to be great -- a sardonic plot with an extremely likeable main character, a very twisted sense of humor, and puzzles which are quite hard and original in their design. Even Sir Patrick Stewart lends his voice to the narration.

But somehow, it feels grindy. While the puzzles are somewhat original, you see almost all their mechanics in the first few levels. And then most of them consist in moving barrels step by step across the environments to create shadows, which isn't that much fun. And then if you really want to get all "stars", you have to redo the level but now without making mistakes, and very fast and efficiently. It does not help that the interface is quite fiddly and you often end up clicking in the wrong places (by the way, mouse was much better than a controller for me).

But I am being too harsh -- on the other hand, the game has an in-game hint system which I did use for the last harder puzzles. And some of them are very clever -- many times I had the "this is impossible!" feeling, only to have that "a-ha!" moment later when figuring out what could be done.

Anyway, it was an interesting game, it just should flow better (though honestly I do not know how this could be done with this game concept).

Score: 62/100.
The puns are strong with this one!!! And the easter eggs too.  The puzzles are quite easy for someone who has played a lot of point and clicks, but I think it's great for a beginner

reviews.title: Excellente aventure type point'n click à l'ancienne.

reviewText.content:
Univers fantastique humoristique et décalé, ne pas s'attendre à une histoire philosophique sur le sens de la vie ! Beaucoup de second degré et de références, le jeu est découpé en 6 chapitres/enquêtes principaux indépendants, plus 3 bonus, pour une dizaine d'heures en tout.
Le jeu est plutôt facile même si certaines énigmes demandent un peu de recherche, ca dépendra de chaque joueur/euse.
L'ambiance est très soignée, pixel art bien fichu, traduction française très bonne des références et jeux de mots en tout genre.
Une démo est disponible pour se faire son avis.
çok güzel ve eğlenceli bir oyun. 100 saatten fazla oynadım ama hikayesini daha bitiremedim çünkü map büyük ve şurada ne var burada diyerek gezdim. Ve canım sıkıldıkça 1 tane evi yok ediyorum

A little rough around the edges at points but generally really fun. Has a good sense of humour and the strategy for combat is barely varied and deep enough for the length of the game. Issues with pacing, seems like for hours your grinding the same stuff then suddenly you power through story beats. Probably only worth one play through but I sank a good 15 hours into that so a good purchase overall.

reviews.title: Not a fan of this one at all sadly.

reviewText.content:
To start with the positives, the movement is improved as your character feels much better to control. Also you can knock out enemies and not just be forced to kill them which is great for a passive run. I also like that you can select classic mode as a difficulty which is more akin to the first game where you can't really be spotted by guards as its a one hit kill if they catch you.

That's sadly it for my positives. This game while not a live service has the stink of that genre all over it, from the terribly designed Destiny like UI with that stupid mouse cursor like interface (thats always terrible to use with a controller), the home base where you accept missions, has that MMO like feeling with the way you interact with NPCs and just the very multiplayer focus of this game. While the first game had co-op it was done in a fun drop in, drop out sort of way which is my preferred style. This game just has that more live service multiplayer feel and I don't think it served this title that is a mostly stealth game. They also added in combat so you can take on enemies directly but I didn't really like the feel of this at all and like I said classic mode makes this mute anyway.

Otherwise they introduce cosmetics in this game rather then just having the skins you unlock after completing challenges like in the first game. The cosmetics just look awful imo and don't make sense in the context of the game. Much of them are these very bulky looking armours which I'm just like why would I wear that if I'm supposed to be a ninja assassin? The game's artstyle is also a bit of a departure from the first game which was made on unity like this one, but it had that cool water color, cell shaded artstyle that still looks very visually striking today. In this game it just looks like a generic unity engine game, with some of the artstyle retained, but characters just look unfinished and rough looking especially your main character. Its like if the first title was a cool looking PS2 game, this is an early, ugly looking PS3 game where they didn't know how to take advantage of the hardware properly.

The story also just fell flat for me and it plays into the Destiny style presentation that I touched on earlier. It just doesn't work for me. I bought this game to play in co-op with my buddy as him and I both love stealth games, but even that wasn't enough to save this one for me. It's a shame the devs had to close their doors as they could have made some great future games, but the direction they chose for this title is just disappointing.

Certes le jeu n'a pas la plastique d'un 2D HD à la Octopath Traveller, mais les petits sprites sont quand même dessinés avec amour.
Le jeu se boucle en 60h environ avec pas mal de quêtes secondaires scénarisées, de rebondissements and co.
Le système de combat à pied ou en armure volante est fun à joué, pas de chargement d'écran on combat directement sur la zone de jeu, et on voit les ennemis parfois esquivables.
Le jeu est très riche et très bien pensé, pas de fedex inutile ou de grind/farming si on prend le temps de tout explorer, donc on a vraiment un boulot de qualité proposé, y compris sur l'aspect sonore.

PS : je n'ai pas compris le commentaire de "necrocosm Le 20 déc. 2022 sympa les ennemis invincibles dans le jeu?", je n'ai pas eu de bug comme ca.

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

Нам повествуют об истории Стрелка, который потерял память и попал в труповозку, но благодаря удачному стечению обстоятельств его спасли и он со временем пришел в себя. Теперь он думает, что его зовут Меченым, а его главной целью является убийство Стрелка, то есть самого себя. По мере того, как он приближался к следу самого себя, как бы странно это не звучало, он начинал понимать, что этот Стрелок не просто какой-то там сталкер. Он был одним из немногих, кто смог пробиться на север Зоны. Ближе к концу игры он узнает, что он и есть этот самый Стрелок. Теперь нам предстоит узнать как мы потеряли память и как получили эту амнезию. Для этого нам предстоит проделать тот же путь, что и до потери памяти - на север Зоны. Оказывается во всем виновато Осознание - группа ученых, которая хочет изменить мир. Так, в разговоре с одним из ученых мы узнаем как потеряли память и как получили тату на руке S.T.A.L.K.E.R. , а также как попали в ту труповозку из начала игры. Так как я пошел по истинной концовке (их тут семь, если не ошибаюсь), мне предстояло уничтожить эту группу ученных. После этого мы получаем концовку, в которой Стрелок ложится на траву и задается вопросом, правильно ли он поступил. Раз уж я недавно сказал о концовках игры, то давайте о них и продолжим. Я считаю их первым плюсом этой игры. В игре есть два типа концовок: истинные и неправильные. Сначала о неправильных, их больше всего. Все они завязаны с Исполнителем Желаний. Игра определяет как мы вели себя на протяжении всего прохождения, после чего выдает определенную концовку. Одну из таких концовок я и получил при первом прохождении, тогда я не знал о истинных концовках. Теперь о них и поговорим, их две. В первой, как я и говорил ранее, Стрелок убивает ученых, ну а во второй присоединяется к ним. Вторым плюсом я засчитаю сюжет игры. Мне он очень понравился. В своем обзоре я многого не упомянул. Хоть это не влияет на сюжет игры, но зато дополняет атмосферу игры. Собственно она и является следующим плюсом. Зона полна поджидающих в кустах мутантов и бандитов, полна опасностей и секретов. Она живет своей жизнью. Отряд бандитов может появится просто так, все благодаря движку игры. Песни и анекдоты у костра надолго засели у меня в памяти. Пожалуй все минусы этой игры связаны только с самой реализацией. Первым минусом является BugTrap. Он пострашнее всех мутантов, которых тут можно встретить. Приходится очень часто сохранятся, дабы не проходить огромный кусок игры после появления BugTrap'а. Вторым минусом является - ИИ. Он сделан просто ужасно. То противники выходят к тебе спиной, то сидят и смотрят в стену. Как бы, если это играет нам на руку, то бывают и случаи, когда противник играет не по правилам, то через стены начнет стрелять, это без шуток, он просто высовывает дуло через забор-стену и стреляет в нас, то смотря вообще в другую сторону стреляет и попадает в нас. Так, играя на максимальной сложности получаешь больше проблем от аномалий или от перегруза, чем от здешних врагов. Третьим минусом является главная фишка сталкерства. Практически все сталкеры отправляются на Зону, чтобы разбогатеть. Сделать это можно при помощи добычи артефактов. Тут добывать их можно, но все они появляются заскриптованно, то есть только в определенных местах и они будут там всегда, даже после того как вы их подберете, достаточно просто подождать пару игровых часов или же просто перейти с одной локации на другую. В Зове Припяти все было реализовано куда лучше. И последним минусом я посчитаю тайники в этой игре. Сами по себе они хороши, никогда не помешают пара лишних аптечек или припасов. Очень часто я находил тайники и они были просто напросто пустыми, а все потому, что я не убил определенного человек и не получил информацию об этом тайнике из его КПК. Просто представьте себе, что вы самолично, без чьей либо помощи находите клад, но ничего за это не получаете, а все потому что вы не получили об этом кладе никакой информации. Это просто бесит на протяжении всей игры. Первые часов 5 игры все тайники, которые я проверял были пусты, а уже под конец игры, когда я возвращался к ним, там был лут.

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Shadow of Chernobyl

reviewText.content:
STALKER: Shadow of Chernobyl is loosely based on the film “STALKER” and the novel “Roadside Picnic”. The only things it shares with them are the anomalous artefacts, the existence of an exclusion zone and a dreary atmosphere.  There is no point in beating around the bush, STALKER: SoC isn’t an uplifting or forgiving. Technically it's survival action, but looking back, I could classify this as survival horror with the number of times I thought to myself – I do not want to be here any longer. Don’t take that as a negative, after finishing this game, I couldn’t wait to play the rest of the trilogy. I would recommend it to anyone who wants a punishing open world action game set in a kind of post-apocalyptic environment with great atmosphere. Also, it’s made by Ukrainians, so don’t expect the best English voice acting.

Story
As the title implies it's set in the Chernobyl exclusion zone where a totally different disaster from the one, we know happened. It caused reality altering anomalies to appear, mutant to start roaming the surface and horrors to lurk in the shadows. Many go there, against the government's wishes, seeking riches or salvation via the rumoured wish granter located at the power plant. 
The character you play as is an enigma. He was brought back from the centre, remembers nothing, and his main objective is to kill some guy named Sterelok. It’s not the best storyline I’ve played, but it was enough to keep me engaged.
Obviously, that’s not the only thing you can do. There aren’t as many activities as some other games of the genre, but still there are interesting things to do and explore.

Mechanics and gameplay
Survival horror, FPS, open world, are all genres STALKER SoC is a part of. I am going to be honest, most of it is kind of meh. Shooting is okay, but it’s clearly outdated. The open world isn’t bad, but it’s the one you can go through twice before it starts feeling small. Artifact hunting is fun, but it’s done so much better in later titles. Gameplay wise, there isn’t anything I can point to specifically and say that it was done exceptionally well. But still I had fun and it being semi short it didn’t get boring or annoying.
I have heard some complaints about bugs and glitches, but I never had much of a problem with them.

Graphics and artstyle
This is where STALKER: SoC can turn off a lot of people. A 2006 game made in Eastern Europe doesn’t scream high quality. However, anyone who has got used to the low quality of the early 2000s won’t find SoC off-putting. It at least never breaks the atmosphere it tries to build.

Atmosphere/Immersion  
By far the best part of STALKER is its dreary, suffocating atmosphere. Everything from the environment, the colour pallet, the around design is made to build it up. It’s so well-crafted that I can totally see this world as existing on its own. I was totally immersed to the point where I was looking at random NPC’s and wondering why are they here, could the zone really be a better alternative to the normal world.  

Soundtrack
All the STALKER games share has similar soundtrack, so you might hear one ost in two or even their games. In any case, it's almost exclusivity dark ambience, so you would need a keen ear to memorize them. My favourite part is “Dirge For The Planet”.

Final Thoughts

reviews.title: Unlock the Enigmatic World of Owlboy: A Genre-Bending Adventure of Stunning Art and Puzzles! 🦉🎮 Explore the Unexpected in This Pixelated Masterpiece

reviewText.content:
Owlboy is by far the strangest game I have ever played. It's stunningly beautiful but seems unsure of its own identity. You come in expecting to play an adventure and platformer, only to find a dual-stick beat'em up with metroidvania elements that incorporates stealth phases. The most surprising aspect is that it's hard for me not to recommend it because it excels in the most unexpected genre: puzzles. In Owlboy, every confrontation and problem-solving task is logically achieved by leveraging your abilities and positioning. The story is decent, with a very satisfying climax, but it's odd that it leaves you wanting to play more. The difficulty balance is nonsensical: enemies kill you in 3 hits, but you have a checkpoint every 3 seconds. If you can overlook its shortcomings, the brilliant moments it offers are worth it.


Highlights:
Stunning Art and Animation: Owlboy's pixel art is exceptional, standing out in both static illustrations and animations. The game provides a visually stunning experience that captivates from the start menu.
Simple and Effective Controls: Despite spanning various genres, the control of the character Otus is superb, especially in flight, dash, and parry. The sense of responsibility for failures contributes to the positive experience.
Focus on Puzzles: While covering multiple genres, Owlboy excels in puzzle-solving, with these moments being highlights in the game. Logic and the use of abilities and positioning are crucial to overcoming challenges.
Epic Boss Fights and Hordes: Boss battles and hordes offer intense action and follow a style similar to The Legend of Zelda. The patterns aren't complex, but strategy is key.
Appropriate Soundtrack: The soundtrack appropriately accompanies exploration, reflecting the adventurous spirit of the game.

Worst:
Lack of Genre Direction: Owlboy spans multiple genres (metroidvania, adventure, platformer, dual-sticker, stealth) but fails to fully excel in any. While puzzles are strong, the lack of focus may confuse the game's identity.
Unengaging Narrative: The story and characters may not be captivating enough for some players. Despite a notable ending, achieving emotional connection can be challenging.
Ambiguous Difficulty: Owlboy presents contradictory difficulty. While enemies are tough, the generosity of auto-save points diminishes the challenge. It's challenging to recommend to those seeking either a challenging experience or a more relaxed adventure.
PC Configuration Issues: In the PC version, key layout can be problematic, especially with the combination of parry and shoot on the same button. Using a gamepad or adjusting the configuration is recommended.
Undertale is a good game (A solid 8), but not a GREAT game. I really thought about uninstalling it a lot of times when i was playing, but i wanted to make this review.

I totally don't understand all the hype over this weird game. It's linear, boring and convoluted. It has a few interesting characters and dialogues and... that's it. It feels like some twisted love letter to classic RPG/JRPG fans with lots of specific humor and cryptic references.

If we consider it as indie it is a good game, but to be an RPG it has too many shortcomings. it's extremely overrated, and I don't understand how it got all this success, a lot of things are taken from EarthBound

Undertale is probably the game that most people think of when somebody says "Indie Game". And that's for good reason. There's a ton to love about Undertale, and my gripes are few and far between.

First of all, the narrative is told pretty well. The story delivered here is very intriguing and thoughtful. The characters, especially, shine in Undertale. Everyone you meet is an interesting and dynamic character that has their own personality, wants, and thought. You find yourself sympathizing with almost every enemy, and the game does a great job of making you question why you are even fighting them.

The game also gives you a real sense of consequence to your actions. Every victory is very drawn out, really trying to show the world from the monsters' point of view.

It would also be remiss of me to mention the incredible soundtrack. I cannot stress enough how great the music in this game is. There's so many unique sounds and tunes that it really does an incredible job of pulling you into the game. I found myself just stopping to listen to the music whenever a new track started playing.

Back to the mechanics, though. Movement around the world feels very retro, in a good way. Until you reach the later portions, this game really could have been pulled right from the 90s. This has good and bad aspects, with the most obvious drawback being how linear the world feels. The fighting mechanics are unique and fun. Every boss and enemy has its own fighting pattern and the game is constantly introducing new mechanics to the combat to keep it fresh.

With all that being said, I think the place where Undertale has some issues is with how the endings work. There are three major endings, and the game really encourages you to play all three to get the full story. Just finishing it once made me feel like I was missing a lot of interesting stuff. I wouldn't have a problem with encouraging you to play all three endings if it weren't for how much dialogue this game has. Having to click through hundreds of lines that I've already read doesn't sound very appealing. Unless you are going for a specific ending, there isn't a whole lot of replayability.

Overall, though, Undertale is a very thoughtful, interesting, and humorous indie game that has definitely earned all the recognition that it has received.

Overall Score: 8/10

I played this game on February 2017 (After the trend has ended basically) and I think the game isn't bad at all.
There is few actual gameplay and many (often boring) dialogues, but I think that if you take the game chill without thinking about the big amoung of people who idolize the game, it can even surprise you.
The story is very basic and with almost 0 narrative cues, but I really appreciated the lore of the Underground and of the main characters, which is way deeper than it looks.

This is the best game I've ever played. The ability given to the player to decide the fate of enemies is very cool on top of the game judging your every choice without you realizing it until the end of the game. Only con is Alpheus being a kinda annoying character everything else is great from music to just random interactions with items.

i knew from when i started undertale that this game would be different from the rest, the atmosphere when you first hit the title screen is scary almost unmatched. through out this game toby fox proves time and time again that he knows how to write perfect likable (or intentionally unlikable) characters even with some of the characters screen times being much less than 1 hour. this game is a masterclass in character writing, even if killing doesn't affect the story much technically as you just get neutral unless you kill everything, it feels like it does. the phone call at the end of the game is always so haunting after doing a neutral run. true pacifist is where this games plot shines, determination, the constant 4th wall breaks, the experiments, the main villain reveal, all of it is just so interesting and good. undertale neutral gives you a feeling of emptiness after beating it that i dont think any game has given me before, i felt even emptier than when i did my genocide run. it feels so bitter sweet, which im sure is the intended feeling. you escaped the underground, but at what cost? genocide is pretty fun, the bosses are really cool and some of the best boss design ive seen out of any game, but only sad moment for me was just killing papyrus but what alot of people say about genocide being soooo sad and just making them cry didnt happen to me. true pacifist gave me a feeling of hope after beating it, it made be realize that everything will be okay, as long as i work for it and hope. i dont want to spoil to much even though this review is really spoilery but true pacifist is absolutely beautiful.
No other moment in gaming has ever come closer to destroying my soul than "Then why did you kill my brother?" did.

reviews.title: I didn't wanted to do this review, but I am determined to make you play Undertale!

reviewText.content:
Okay, enough with the odd call backs.

Here's the deal. You probably  saw those kind of reviews tons of times, so I'll make it straight:

You want to play the most interesting indie in the recent years?
See for yourself why the VGAs adwards make no sense?
Perhaps you are kind of tired of JRPGs and you want to see something... different?
Or maybe play something with a very good OST?
Then congratulations, I think you are in the right place. Let's see if the Undertale story fits you, though...

Are linear, but well-explained stories for you?
Do you like the flavour of a classic story? (You know, you end up in a random place: get out. Videogame-y enough for me).
Do you like stories with a lot of humor?
Do you like stories with a lot of drama?

Or, perhaps, you would like a story with some shades of horror?

If any of the answers is yes, then you should definetly check Undertale.

Even worse than Amnesia 1 and 3

The gameplay is sluggishly painful and yields little to none involvement at times, your goal is to go to point A to point B and solve scarcely interlaced puzzles. In A Machine for Pigs, you backtrack for an item, bring it to something you interact with, then move on.

Not to mention, the 'threat' in this game is VERY underwhelming. Not once in this game did I feel pressured or concerned about the Pigmen that roam the maps. The pigs themselves (with how few there are in the game) have dumb as heck AI, and are easily bypassable. You'll see one roaming a small corridor on one point, then never appear for the rest of the ten minutes while you sluggishly march to the next area. There's no sanity to manage, no lantern oil meter to cope with, and the damage the enemies deal is pathetic, it's something like seven hits for you to die to the standard pigs. 

The game also bombards you with visionary blurs and flashbacks which became extremely monotonous and felt like their intention was to slow the pace of the game down for you to 'soak in the atmosphere'. The flashbacks in this game are usually so bland and hardly explore much detail into which was going on. I didn't really understand much at all about the main plot even given the notes I had to find dotted around the map. The main character just ended up talking about his children for the majority of the game (and I get that's one of the main points of the plot) but they could've at least explored some other parts, instead of leaving the plot focused on a single point for a while.

There's also a few occurrences that cause the game to hitch and lag badly in some areas. Something my PC should definitely be able to run smoothly, but it's thrown around into a choppy mess. Takes away from the actual 'gameplay' and makes it more of a slog than usual.

reviews.title: ravendoom_2023's review of Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs

reviewText.content:
Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs, developed by The Chinese Room and published by Frictional Games, is a chilling and atmospheric horror game that serves as a spiritual successor to the critically acclaimed Amnesia: The Dark Descent. Set in the Victorian era, this psychological horror adventure is a haunting descent into madness that will leave players on edge throughout their harrowing journey.

The game excels in creating an eerie atmosphere that permeates every corner of its world. From the hauntingly dark environments to the hauntingly melancholic soundtrack, A Machine for Pigs masterfully sets the stage for a nerve-wracking experience. The sound design, in particular, plays a crucial role in building tension, with subtle audio cues heightening the sense of dread as players navigate the twisted narrative.

The story, though cryptic and surreal, is captivating and well-written. As players assume the role of Oswald Mandus, an industrialist tormented by feverish dreams, they embark on a quest to uncover the dark secrets lurking within his own mind and the mysterious machine he has constructed. The narrative is intricately woven, unveiling layers of psychological horror that delve deep into themes of industrialism, morality, and the consequences of unchecked ambition.

A Machine for Pigs incorporates more narrative-driven gameplay compared to its predecessor. While some players may appreciate the increased focus on storytelling, others may find it lacking in traditional survival horror mechanics, such as limited resources and intense moments of hiding from enemies. Nonetheless, the game's focus on psychological horror and its unsettling exploration of the human psyche make it a unique and thought-provoking experience.

Visually, the game delivers a grim and gloomy world that is both beautiful and horrifying. The dark and grimy environments, coupled with the hauntingly grotesque designs of the machine's creations, instill a constant sense of dread and unease.

However, the game's lack of challenging puzzles and occasional linearity may leave some players yearning for more engaging gameplay mechanics. Additionally, the limited interactions with the environment might diminish the overall immersion for players seeking more interactivity in their horror experience.

In summary, Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs is a haunting psychological horror game that stands apart from its predecessor with a focus on storytelling and atmospheric immersion. While it may not cater to players seeking intense survival horror mechanics, its evocative narrative, chilling ambiance, and nightmarish themes make it a worthy addition to the Amnesia franchise. Fans of psychological horror should not miss the opportunity to venture into the unsettling depths of A Machine for Pigs.

The game is pretty solid and classic. Exaclty like Mario! It has interesting options even tho some are pretty confusing and their experimental controls that I needed like 10 minutes to understand what is even going on. Has interesting story and is great to play. Isn't that much addictive and a bit hard even

Pizza Tower is an exhilarating gaming experience that blends speedrunning excitement with a generous dose of memes. This pixelated masterpiece serves up a delightful combination of challenging levels, quirky characters, and a sprinkle of humor that keeps you engaged. The speedrunning community has embraced Pizza Tower for its fast-paced gameplay and intricate level design, creating a dynamic environment for competition. The incorporation of memes adds a lighthearted touch, making every playthrough a joyful journey. Get ready for a slice of gaming heaven with Pizza Tower, where speed, skill, and laughter converge in a deliciously entertaining adventure!

A short but intense puzzling game. I didn't know what to expect of this game, to be honest, but i ended up liking it very much.

It's very interesting how the 60 seconds of life mechanic is integrated in some of the puzzles and the world. The puzzles that doesn't work around time, some of them are very intuitive, some of them are very rewarding and satisfactory when you find out the solution.

I cannot say anything 'bad' about this game.

Pretty poorly designed game. It's as if they first made the game and after seeing how short and simple it was, they decided to add the countdown mechanism. It's badly or not at all incorporated into the "puzzles". Wouldn't say it's worth playing.

Minit is a very inventive game, respawning every 60 seconds creates some unique and engaging puzzles. It has a fun and simple style and you kind of explore the world in a metroidvania style, using new equipment to get past a barrier in a previous area and then obtaining a new shortcut or item. Its a very short game, but its a tightly made game and doesnt really repeat much. The puzzling isnt super hard, in fact it was quite intuitive. I mostly got through things pretty quickly but felt statisfied by finding the solution. I really appreciated how fresh minit felt, how different it was to most games. Definitely worth a try.

The 60s timer brings the players unique fast pace gameplay. It combines the item collection system and the home unlocking system to provide a well-balanced reward loop. Mint makes its players feel proud of themselves when they figure out a puzzle even after many times of death and expect the next exploration.
This game is love. Awesome gameplay,graphics and i really love the story-telling of this game.. Everyone should must give a try.

Call of Juarez is a troubled franchise that had no reason to spawn a fantastic shooter such as Gunslinger. It's a short but sweet game that absolutely nails everything it sets out to do. The stylized visuals are great and make the game stand out from other similar shooters. The story is also told in a very fun and engaging way. There's a narrator telling a story, and you're basically playing through what he's narrating. Sometimes the narrator makes a mistake or remembers something incorrectly, and the world changes around you to reflect that change in the story. The plot itself is also very interesting. Your character is essentially a Forest Gump of the West who ends up meeting all sorts of legendary gunslingers and even participating in crucial events in the history of these characters.

Gameplay-wise, the game is a 10/10. The shooting mechanics are flawless, with every action having clear and satisfying feedback through visual or audio effects. There's a decent variety of weapons you can use, the action is fast-paced, and the slow-motion ability just makes everything better. The game handles "boss fights" with a standoff minigame, where the player has to juggle hand movements and a speed meter in order to be able to draw faster than the opponent when the time comes. While not as exciting as the regular run-and-gun gameplay, it is way better than the classic "enemy with an extra large health bar" approach.
The gameplay is fun and challenging, but the bright colors kind of hurt my eyes and the UIs are not super clear.

A beautiful, zen, minimalist rogue-lite that feels most like a mix between FTL map progression and mitigation of damage, and a sort of Total War/ RTS approach to tactics where positioning of units is the main decision you need to make.
Fun simplified RTS game play that is replayable with great rogue-like randomly created islands. Repeat runs make for a slow start and a I still haven't been able to beat the game. But fun for a run.

A somewhat oddly satisfying game to play. At the current state I don't really have much reason to play multiple times. It currently feels like a beta of a game and don't know if it will its concept will ever be realized enough for it to feel like a full game.

Inscryption is messy, ambitious and endlessly creative deck-building mystery. The story's twists and turns won't make everyone happy, but those who stick with it will be rewarded with deep, puzzle-like card-play. Inscryption frightens and unsettles without a single jumpscare, and although it teeters precariously on the line between style over substance, it ultimately sticks the landing in the end.

reviews.title: Pulls the Rug, then shits the Bed

reviewText.content: Inscryption pretends to be a Roguelike with many interesting choices and really solid deck building mechanics. What makes it truly great: this game of cards is set inside of an escape-room style cottage, where a lunatic dungeon-master keeps the player locked up and forces them to play his sick game. Between runs, the player explores the cottage, manipulates objects and solves puzzles. There's nothing quite like Inscryption, it's completely unique and insanely polished. 10/10, a masterpiece. Nothing else happens in this game................................................................or so I wish. After you beat a run once (long before the game explored all of its potential), the concept of this ingenious gameplay loop is completely discarded. In its place follow two more acts which not only move on from, but recontextualize the first one. Act 2 is way too easy. Act 3 is a tedious copy of Act 1 without any stakes. As a whole, Inscryption is framed by a meta-narrative, sometimes told through live-action videos with very little creative quality, but a certain Youtube-2010-amateur-charm. Inscryption is bold, experimental and unique...but not always good.

reviews.title: A card game that more than what you think!

reviewText.content: I love this game so much, more than I realized at first until I watch a friend play through it a couple of years after my first play through. I really enjoyed the surprised Inscryption has stored for the player. There are some pretty goofy bits, but if you get past them and appreciate that the dev team was a pretty small team for what the player gets - the game itself is very enjoyable. The mechanics are challenging enough but easy to follow along and piece together as you progress - the story has a pretty good flow to it as well.

Everyone has to play this game
also, all game companies should learn from this game because it's  a lot better than many AAA games

I bought this on the Switch because I never knew the game existed until the Indie World presentation. I loved the original and had to pick this one up to see how it compared. A great evolution of the original concept.

The first two games were riveting with great pacing and great illusion of choice. Even if there wasn't much actual story branching, you at least felt like you were a part of a living world and actually influencing it. Clementine drove those stories, and you really felt connected to the people in them because of her. A New Frontier throws you into the middle of a family you don't know or care about with obnoxious characters, all of which are not tortured or conflicted like in the first two games, but rather just assholes, irresponsible, or cocky jerks. There's no one to relate to, and Clementine is barely in the picture. Every time you start to want to get into the story and advance you're thrown into a crappy flashback with no bearing on what's happening. Then there are the sequences that are "it's time to press X now, we'll wait". Literally no other option. Just. Press. X. Ugh. 

Do yourself a favor and play the first two seasons (they're great), but avoid this one like the plague.

This is the first time during playing The Walking Dead series I felt a little "cheated" by the game. I didn't feel my choices represented what I wanted to convey by the choice, and the lack of clarity made me make some decisions I did not want to make. Some would argue that's like real life, though, so it seems like a choice by the creators. The story is very much standalone, Clementine is a side character in this one, but her story is intertwined with the main narrative. The characters are not as likeable as in the previous installments, their fates mattered less to me than ever before. However, all this criticism stems from the expectations set by the first 2 games, and other Telltale games. The Walking Dead: A New Frontier is still a really good game which made me excited for the final installment, and is probably a necessary side step in an already legendary franchise.

Dans la suite logique de la saison 2 pour l'histoire, et la suite technique de Michonne pour le moteur du jeu actualisé.
Quelque soit la fin de la saison 2 on arrive vite au même point, et l'aventure se déroule ensuite avec une nouvelle communauté et ses nouveaux personnages.
L'histoire est prenante, mais moins que celle de la saison 1 avec Lee qui reste pour la moi la référence.
Malheureusement des vieux bugs graphiques d'écran qui grignote et de texte non traduit reviennent dans le dernier chapitre, ce qui doit l'impression d'une fin un peu bâclée techniquement.
L'histoire elle se termine de façon plutôt cohérente (même si certaines actions sont très discutables!), avec une grosse porte de sortie pour une saisie 4 à venir.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

Bon petit jeu, énigmes relativement simples en se posant, ambiance zen et très soignée, level design bien travaillé.
Durée vie courte mais prix en rapport.
Un beau moment de jeu !

(joué sur Xbox Series X via le Xbox Pass)

Really fun party game. Kind of like Cards Against Humanity but based on creativity rather than pre-set cards. Requires phones for all players and internet connection. (In fact, you can have people play from across the internet if you send them the game room code. They cannot see the scoreboard or final winners.)
One Word - Meow 5/5. The graphics are very weird and different. It's very very hard to play and mouse precision requires more accurate, one wrong move and your cat is dead. Recommended.

reviews.title: One of my favorite Metroidvanias ever

reviewText.content:
Ender Lilies is such a compeling game where you have to travel across a ruined kingdom and survive deveral dangerous hazards and enemies. However, even In a fallen world like that, there is still place for kindness. Lily, the protagonist, is just a Child and even though she's fighting to survive, it's her compassion that helps her save the souls of the knights she encounter. 
Every major boss can form a pact with Lily after they're defeated and several other enemies can do the same, giving the girl an amazing army of "weapons" against the bliss. And you WILL need this army, because the game is not a walk in the park. It's not as hard as Sekiro, but several bosses will need more than 1 try to beat.
The exploration is also really fun, since Lily unlocks a lot of traversal skills along the journey to help her reach even the most unorthodox path she can find.
Story-wise it takes a lot of inspiration from Souls, telling it's tale by the environment and journal entries, and also from item descriptions. And the stoy of it's kingdom is such a tragedy that will definitely make you wanting more.

Minimalistic horror game, where you play as a convict, who can earn his freedom in exchange of completing mission on a submarine.

You will need to learn how to navigate your submarine through the depths of the Blood Ocean, so you can find exact locations, using x y coordinate system, and make photos.

Iron Lung uses fear of the unknown, thalassophobia, claustrophobia, so player can feel really desperate with all this creepy atmosphere. The sounds of the ocean around you are ranging from calm to disturbing as you begin to understand there are creatures out of the submarine. You can also hear the breakdown of your ship as it continues to fall apart under the pressure of the Blood Ocean.

Grimy feelings, blurry images, clunky buttons - this all will make you feel like you're in your last rusty death coffin.

It's a short and unique experience, game about 70 minutes long, depending on how fast you will navigate your submarine.

For me it was kinda interesting, but I don't feel like it's a really very good game.
But many people think about this game as a masterpiece.

I rarely play horror games, mainly because most aren’t that scary. IRON LUNG was a welcome exception. Even thought it's just an hour long and has very simple gameplay, I found it very enjoyable. I would recommend it if you want a short and sweet horror experience.
Story
In the future, all planets and star mysteriously disappear. The only things left are space stations, asteroids and moon. Some of these moons have a very peculiar feature – blood oceans. You are a convict put in a tiny submarine that is of questionable quality and tasked with exploring these blood oceans. There is some more lore in a terminal in the sub, but other than that, there isn’t any storyline that takes place during the game. 
Mechanics and gameplay
Gameplay wise, it's very simplistic. You have a map with coordinates where you have to go. After reaching the given location, you have to take a picture. Moving the sub is just four buttons – forwards and backward, left or right.
Graphics and artstyle
It uses minimalistic, low poly graphics that work very well for such a horror game. The pictures from the camera are very grainy and slightly distorted, making them feel realistic even in this kind of game.
Atmosphere 
IRON LUNG is all about atmosphere and building tension. It shows the player more and more unnerving images, making them question whether they are truly alone. Also, by having the sub start to slowly break down combined with the note, it gives the feeling that no matter what you are not making back home.
Soundtrack and sound effects
SFX are incredible. Hearing something move from left to right makes you freeze up. The ost is mainly ambiance that adds to the tension.
Final Thoughts
Me playing this game has nothing to do with recent events.
This is good fun in the style of Jumping Joe, Asto Bears and other couch party games. It's fun to play for 5 - 10 minutes between more serious, or complex games.
This Fun, Frustrating at times, well designed game with sharp graphics is a must play for both cat and jumping puzzle lovers!

reviews.title: gabethecrow's review of Across the Grooves

reviewText.content:
Across the Grooves is an excellent game for anyone who wants, or needs, to be reminded of the infinite possibilities of an eternal present.

Across the Grooves takes us through Alice's story and alongside her we discover how much magic there can be in life by exploring the mundanity of her life and her relationships.
For this, we, the players, make our first trip back in time by being exposed to numerous musical references, with the right to direct recommendations made by our "game dictionary", the Lexicon.
The rest... Well, the rest is history and I have no intention of telling.

In terms of gameplay, Across the Grooves is almost a visual novel like any other. Its biggest highlight is, undeniably, the way the game uses music as a narrative engine linked to the gameplay. It's sparse but well-used, and for me, it's one of the most interesting things about the game.
Small choices abound here and the game's 8 different endings won't let me lie.
Whether the endings are good or bad depends solely on how the player wants to interpret them.

The music recommendations and soundtrack of the game are excellent and very well complemented by the beautiful artistic direction.
