The only caveat, unfortunately, is in the way the game decides to handle its progress.
After 4 chapters engaging with the characters and their stories, the game decides it's time to throw a plot-twist and a huge exposition dump into the players' laps.
An unfortunate choice, in my opinion, but one that doesn't stop the game from closing in the 6 chapters it promises us.

Finishing Across the Grooves left me wanting to go back and try again, to see every change, to see a new world build before my eyes.
It's certainly a journey worth cherishing, just as this game deserves to be cherished.

reviews.title: toniopanxon's review of It Takes Two

reviewText.content: Cheo de orixinalidade e super xogable. Divertido e con cambios no xeito de xogar en cada fase

I played this game with my GF, and we were absolutely blown away by the game design and how fun it was. The story itself was also really interesting and we learned something.

Hazelight studios you are awesome and I can't wait for your next titles 💓
Amazing gameplay and environments weakened by a schmaltzy story that had no grit,

reviews.title: dandydoomag's review of It Takes Two

reviewText.content: Best single player game, especially coop game on pc I ever played. Story is Hollywood level, every part has some lessens. Gameplay is one of the best, not too easy not too hard, just perfect. Mini games are adorable and competitive. Had lots of fights with my girlfriend when I managed to beat her. Animations are really nice and original.Lots of fun and it takes long time to finish which is good. Would love to play sequel and I hope they make it. 10/10 Dr. Hakim is the best!

reviews.title: keyduq's review of It Takes Two

reviewText.content: Amazing game, has multiple game modes, mini games and a great story. I played with my partner and got a lot of fun from it. I totally recommend it.

reviews.title: tanonero's review of It Takes Two

reviewText.content: This game can only be defined as the definitive couch co-op experience. It runs, feels, plays, and looks amazing.

Inicio del juego: 10/09/2023
Fin del juego: 28/09/2023

Este juego de inicio a fin toma toda mi atención, trata un tema muy hermoso y tiene una ambientación increíble, conecto con los personajes, desde la niña, los padres, el libro, hasta los objetos que toman vida en ese mundo fantasioso. Me hace sentir empatía por las cosas olvidadas y me hace pensar en como van mis relaciones con otras personas. Este juego lo jugué con mi novio y fue simplemente increíble, a pesar de que los minijuegos sacan lo peor de cada uno, al final disfrutamos lo positivo (que es casi todo el juego). Agradezco vivir en un mundo en el que existe este juego, es simplemente una obra de arte maestra personal. Estoy feliz de haber conocido a personajes geniales (de diferentes formas) como: el mono espacial, la elefanta adorable (me quería suicidar luego de esa escena), el libro, las avispas, los pueblerinos de la ciudad de hielo, los pueblerinos de la ciudad de juguete (a pesar de que les arruinabamos la fiesta), las tortugas, los topos, las lindas arañitas y las ranas taxistas, al final cada uno de esos personajes son parte de esta maravillosa obra. También una mención a los bosses, como la aspiradora, la caja de herramientas, el reloj cucu, las avispas, las ardillas, alegría (la planta infectada), el kraken, y seguro alguno que otro que se me escapa.
Faced many bugs which prevented an enjoyable experience

reviews.title: ondra1611's review of It Takes Two

reviewText.content:
It's hard to find anything negative to say about It Takes Two. The game really brings out the feelings you had when you first started playing games. The developers really bombard you with their ideas and different inputs. As the environment and mini-games change, you as a player have to adapt as much as the characters.

The gameplay is really well paced and there were only a few times when we had to think about the next step and what to do. Most of the time we were surprised with clever ideas where to take the game next (the tree, the plane, Cody's garden). Honestly, I can't imagine the game getting much better, with the exception of the ending, which could use a better punch line. I would definitely recommend this game/experience to anyone.

An enjoyable fast-paced game where you take control of a shark that needs to take revenge on a hunter who killed your mother. 
The game is fun for a bit, but gets really repetitive, really fast. Especially if you're playing more than an hour at a time. The "fighting" mechanics are intuitive and fun. There is a wide range of enemies spread on a big open world map. 
One of my main problems with the game is the glitches. It didn't happen that often but sometimes the enemy or I would glitch trough a wall.

Apart from the glitches a fun experience. I would recommend buying the game on a sale.

reviews.title: A shark RPG for the ages!

reviewText.content:
The story has you play as a shark, who's mother is killed by a shark hunter, which puts you on the path of revenge. The story is pretty basic, but good enough to keep you going and I liked the reality TV/documentary style they told the story through. It also helps that this game is narrated by Chris Parnell who voices Jerry on Rick and Morty! He adds a lot of funny quips and he definitely made the game a lot more enjoyable for me!

Maneater builds on the concepts of Jaws: Unleashed, where you start as a baby shark, and have to evolve your shark eventually to a megalodon level shark, by eating everything you can and battling other apex predators! It also throws in RPG mechanics where you level your shark, and equip different evolutions (in place of typical gear) that buff your shark in different ways. I like that this game had a very Arcady nature to it, in that you can just cause so much mayhem and destruction. You even get an evolution that allows your shark to jump onto land, and eat people for an extended period of time. Its stuff like that just adds to the fun factor of this game! Music as well was also really good with my favorite track being the track that plays in the grotto, which is your sharks lair, where you can save, fast travel and upgrade your evolutions.

I also just enjoyed that the map was small, being split into different zones. It made the world not feel bloated that so many other open world/RPG games can feel at times, and with it taking me only 16 hours to complete everything (though some I heard have done it a shorter time) it felt like a nice pallet cleanser, in between bigger games. There is also the infamy system which is basically like the wanted level system in Grand Theft Auto, where when you caused enough chaos, you get shark hunters after you, which are like this games police. This also unlocks special bounty hunter bosses for you to fight, however its pretty easy to beat them as all you have to do is pull them into the water and eat them, and they have no real defense against you. Its fun to fight them and easy to escape them which I like, since many of the more recent GTA games made it hard to escape the police, to the point of it not being fun anymore for me at least.

Combat is fairly decent as you pretty much just have a bite attack and tail whip to knock enemies away. It would have been nice to have a lock on feature, specifically when going up against other apex predators. But at the end of the day, it didn't bug me so much to the point of the combat being frustrating or anything like that.

Some negatives, the enemy A.I. can be a bit dumb at times, particularly with the shark hunters, but like I said earlier, I prefer it being easier to escape them and then come back later to cause more chaos. The game can also be a bit too easy at times, as I wish there were different difficulty modes to pick from, as there is only one default difficulty. While performance was smooth with no major bugs, there were some humans enemies that would float in mid air, doing T poses, as well as on glitch, where I would break open a grate to get into hidden areas, only the grate would stay in place and not let me progress. It happen to me a few times and I had to quit to the main menu and reload to fix it.

Party Hard is fun, won't deny that. The concept is pretty entertaining. The issue is that you want a lot more from it than what i has to offer. After a couple of level i realised i had seen pretty much all of it, there aren't nearly as many environment interaction as i wanted, and the "strategy" is very simple (referring to avoiding the cops).

If you're going into this wanting a Hitman type of game, probably rethink since it's very light on the crowd and environment interactions. What Party Hard does well is showing the potential if would have it is were to be more fleshed out.

An Overcooked clone which is easier, more approachable, and less hectic. In my books, that is a good thing. You can either approach it the harder way (look at the plan, and start doing the work), or the easier way (start the level, figure everything out, and restart it then). If you've already played Overcooked and want some more of the same genre, Tools Up! is a great alternative.

A solid metroidvania, in a era where it i's already saturated.

I've known Timespinner for many years, way before there was lots of pixel art metroidvania indie games on the market. The game has been in development for years so they just launched it too late.

It's a pretty fun metroidvania with a lot of influences of symphony of the night and order of ecclisia, sometimes making direct references that doesn't always work. It reminded me of bloodstained: ritual of the night but not fully resting on the creator's older titles. I liked the time system, going on the same environments but in different times. Although they could use it with more impact in some areas.

The story tries too hard to be serious, it has a nice touch of representativity although it feels a bit forced in some moments. One of the plot twists of the game almost dismantle the story because it doesn't add anything to it.

The game is short, and I'ts a good think because It manages to end almost at the perfect time as the fun in it. The game could use a few more bosses, less use of the time freezing mechanic and more enemy variety. Also, the progression system is kind of strange. In the beginning of the game, you get a few new powers and weapons but by the end of it, you get so many weapons that you just doesn't have time to use. It's a consequence of the leveling system, demotivating the player to change his weapons.

In my opinion, I'ts a game worth played made by new devs that put a lot of effort on it.

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Lawn Mowing Simulator

reviewText.content:
Lawn Mowing Simulator is a simulation video game developed by Skyhook Games and published by Curve Digital. The studio is also responsible for other simulation games such as Tracks: The Train Set Game and Car Trader Simulator. The game was directed by Paul Bates, who previously worked on titles such as F1 2019 and Project CARS 3. The script was written by Ben Roberts, and he previously worked on writing scripts for games such as The Walking Dead: Our World. The music was composed by Daniel Pemberton, who also created soundtracks for films such as Ocean's 8 and The Man from U.N.C.L.E.

Regarding the graphics, the game uses the Unreal Engine 4 engine, which allows for detailed and realistic representation of different gardening tools and environments. The overall quality of the game is quite good, although some players may find the gameplay experience a bit repetitive. 

In summary, Lawn Mowing Simulator is a fun and relaxing game that offers a unique gardening simulation experience.

To start with what I enjoyed, I liked the addition of you having a party of characters as opposed to Slay the Spire's single hero combat system. It felt more like an RPG which has always been my favourite genre. You start with two characters and can recruit more as you go along, with you being able to eventually unlock more heroes to have at the start. I also like the equipment system and being able to equip your characters with different armour and weapon cards was very cool. And like Slay the Spire you can run into various different random events as you play which I liked as well.

The negatives really are just the game got tedious for me after a while with a lot of the runs starting to feel the same. There was also one specific boss that I could not for the life of me beat, no matter how many times I tried. The bosses you get per run are randomised and if I ran into that specific boss, it was basically a game over for me before the fight even started. I'm also not a big fan of the ruin and banish system in this game. Slay the Spire has its own similar system but I feel it was implemented better then in this game. At one point I was in a boss encounter in which I had already killed the boss and most of his minions expect for one. I could not kill the final minion because all of my attack cards had been either banished or ruined making it a situation where I just had to abandon the run and lose all the XP I had gathered. I think this was due to one of the heroes I had recruited secondary ability, which is on me for not understanding, but at the same time it just shows how broken some of this games mechanics can be at times. I also prefer Slay the Spire's approach to characters, as each of the heroes have their own special deck of cards, encouraging you to almost change your play style depending on who you pick. This game sort of has that with the equipment system and a few unique cards for each character, but it just didn't feel as satisfying to play and unlock everyone.

Petit jeu sympa de rythmique.
Pas si facile que ca heureusement le niveau de difficulté est ajustable via différents paramètres (conduite auto de la voiture, niveaux de difficulté jouant sur le nbre d'instrument, vitesse du tempo, ...).
Le pixel art est sympa et reste propre et fluide.
Par contre se concentrer sur les notes à jouer monopolise l'attention sur la partie basse de l'écran, ce qui gêne la lisibilité de la partie supérieure, nécessaire pour savoir quelles notes/actions réaliser (tirer en haut ou en bas, lancer une grenade ou attendre un moment plus opportun, etc.)
Le scénario de la partie histoire est un timbre poste rempli de dialogues lourdingues et clichés, plus ennuyeux que rigolos ; qq clins d'oeil dans les décors et les PNJ à reconnaitre rajoutent un peu de fan service :)
Les musiques explorent un peu tous les type de métal et sont très bien écrites/interprétées.
Un bon moment mais il manque un enrobage à la Taiko no tatsujin pour y rester/revenir plus longtemps.

Obtenu gratuitement via les jeux Gold.
Joué sur SeriesX

Just finished part 3 of this trilogy (Deponia, Chaos on Deponia and Goodbye Deponia) and decided to write a review for the whole series. Of course it's only right to place it here, where the story starts.

At heart this is a classic point and click adventure. A genre claimed to be dead, but getting "ressurected" from now and then by talanted indi-storytellers. This time it's Daedalic, a company of which I've never heard before (though they do seem to have several pretty critically acclaimed games out at this point, so it might be just my ignorance) with their take on humour, creativity and random fun. =)
This game reminds me of the Runaway series, witty and charming main protagonist goes through unlikely events during a trilogy growing up and becoming a bit better.

Actually, just play this game if you miss the point&click fun, you won't regret.

PS. The ending somewhat... left me hanging. >_<

Alors c'est un vrai point'n click à l'ancienne, dans la lignée des Lucas Arts.

Plus :
- graphismes très jolis, vraie touche artistique
- dialogues avec de l'humour second degré bien senti, bons doublages (VO)
- histoire qui semble bien construite, à voir la suite de la trilogie
- interface minimaliste et bien pensée
- durée de vie honnete (surtout pour le prix : 5 euros lors d'une promo Steam)

Moins :
- certaines énigmes dans la première moitié du jeu trop difficiles, avec des indices qui manquent voire qui donnent de fausses pistes (j'ai du utiliser une soluce plusieurs fois, pas cool voire énervant)
- animations peu détaillées, et souvent génériques & trop recyclées
- 2 ans après la sortie du jeu il reste des petits bugs mineurs qui font taches (ex: intéraction non prévue entre 2 objets de l'inventaire, qui affiche un commentaire "0")

Madison is a terrible game. At first it looks good, but don't let that fool you. The gameplay mostly consists of solving bland, unoriginal and absurd puzzles. Besides being a boring chore, not a single puzzle fits with the narrative, consequently their completion feels detached and mechanical. (To give you an idea, one of the puzzles has you running back and forth around the house grabbing items one by one to put them in the necessary order - after you solved it, doing the extra leg work is a bore). Puzzles vary between mazes, locks, finding keys and taking pictures to open doors. Real original.

The limited inventory space is just an annoyance that has you running to the safe to store your items just so you can go back and grab the item it wasn't letting you before. It doesn't add anything to the experience aside from general annoyance.

And the problems don't stop at the gameplay. The Camera controls are weird and every time you sprint (more like jog), the camera shakes uncontrollably up and down. It made me sick.

The story is a pastiche of horror clichés. Nothing to be said about it. Maybe it's the least awful thing about this game, even though it doesn't add up to anything at the end.

The vibe of the game is creepy, but nothing new. It has a few cheap jumpscares, but no real threat. After a while it just feels annoying.

Looks poor, plays poorer and crashes in a few screens from the start. Most of the graphics are far beyond minimalistic and going full steam ahead towards clip-art, animations are so short that they are almost indistinguishable, especially from the walking (or rather seizuring, from the looks of it) animation. And it crashes. A lot.

However, this is not the main problem of the game by far. The main problem is difficult to name properly, but personally, I am leaning towards calling it lack of respect. Why can't you change language in-game? Because eff-you-thank-you-very-much-please-buy-our-next-game. Why does it crash oftenly and unpredictably? Selfsame reason. Why is there a poorly thought message for people with mental problem a bit beyond title screen? Same. This does not feel like it was done with true intent to do good. This feels like it was done with an intend of looking like intention to do good-ish. Kind of.

Overall, this game is a good picture of everything that is wrong with modern game development, if not with IT in general. The recipe of disaster we have here is as follows: slap together some shit and sell it under the guise of do-goodiness, so that the potential buyers may feel bad about themselves if they don't buy it, poor edjits that they are.

reviews.title: The Force Is With This One

reviewText.content: This is not a Remaster or a Remake, but a HD Port. The resolution has been upped significantly, making the textures and surroundings really pop. There are some limitations showing that, at its core, it’s a Nintendo 64 game but it’s all the little things that have been polished/streamlined/fixed that make the game, not only look the best it ever has, but run the best it ever has.

If you're a fan of supernatural and urban fantasy, this game is for you! Possesions, ghosts, genies, demons and so on, in a very interesting storyline that will make you loose your sleep for a few nights untill you have all the answers. Strong, indepented female characters and great race divercity, well-written characters with interesting back stories. I hope we'll see more of them in the future. I can't wait for Logan to meet Rosangela from Blackwell series!!

Unavowed is a point'n click game that has a structure similar to mass effect, separated in missions. In each mission we choose 2 squad member to bring with us. Every member has a unique skill that will determine how we are going to solve some puzzles. For example, Eli is a fire mage that can set fire on things and acess a thing called fire dimension, so he can get documents that were burned. Or Mandana, a Jinn that knows when someone is lying and can't lie herself.

The game starts with your exorcism, asking you your background and your genre, which will determine some parts of the story and can add to replay value. You are then recruted to Unavowed in a quest to discover what the demon did with your body over a year that increased the supernatural events in New York City. The story looks simple in structure, but it was the game's purpose as It has some interesting twists and plays with some point'n click cliches.

Each mission brings It's own story, which is also amazing as It starts simple but escalates in a bizarre way. It feels like you are playing a short story in this amazing universe. The game also has some really morally challenging choices, which is a nice thing nowadays where most of the games just bring the usual good and evil, even though 92% of the people who played mass effect went the paragon route.

The game was made to be played multiple times not because of the endings, but because of your different backtories and who you bring to the missions, which unlock new dialogues with the character cast and new interactions and puzzle solving.

For me, the positive points of this game are Its amazing universe, atmosphere and It's empathetic characters. The art is also great, evoking a really good noir feeling, even though the game doesn't go in the detective cliche of cynism, which is a good thing.

The negative points are the animations that are lacking and repeat a lot of the times and the engine is kind of clunky. Also, talking about the story, some Unavowed members are underdeveloped, unidimensional and some feels like only a trope, like the recovering alcool addiction.

The negative points, as I sa

Interesting game that could have been so much more. The idea is simple: You go through the same loop, finding the differences, and if you do, you go back, and keep going until you leave the endless loop.

Now, the idea is fun and the whole concept of finding 'anomalies' is interesting, but I think this piece falls short of other 'discover anomalies' games in that you're moving through a fairly boring loop that you can complete in like, five minutes and there isn't a lot of variety to really push you for a second or third run. The 'anomalies' only appearing once until you complete them all is a neat idea, but about a fourth of them are really interesting, which does make sense, but the rest, which you'll see more often, just isn't particularly engaging, and overall, makes the game really... Dull, I suppose.

All in all, it's an interesting idea and the game is visually pretty neat, but I don't think it's a game that work for multiple playthroughs, even if it feels that's the intention.

This game is one of its kind. It falls under the cathegory of rythm games, but conveys a completely different atmosphere than any other rythm game I've ever played. The sounds and colors suck you in in a very strong way and don't let you go. It gives you a weirdly unpleasing feeling. The hard nature of the game strengthens that feeling even more, and when you fight the first boss you really feel as tiny as you are in this huge universe the game represents. 

The best summary I can think of would be: This is a horror rythm game.

Hugely recommend to play this game, it is worth it.

I am not that much into the "crafting" genre, but this was good. There is quite a bit of light combat (not that varied for one single run, but I found it fun anyway), tons of light side quests and many small worlds to explore. And you might want to dig to find some secrets.

I did not get into the whole building aspect of the game, but if you do, you will probably have lots to do here. And I played solo -- this could be more fun with the right friends.

A few annoyances:
-- Inventory management should be a lot better (sorting options?) for a game with so many items you want to keep (hint: build chests!);
-- Button placement was odd! In general, button placement should mirror the location they show up on screen... so, if there are two tab menus on the screen, I expect the top one to be LT and RT and the bottom one to be LB and RB, am I the only one whose brain is wired this way? Another example: a shop menu has me pressing "X" to sell, but the X button shows on the right side of the screen... why?
-- The crafting interface could have been streamlined somehow; I accept this is a crafting game where you have to build items A and B to later combine them with C to finally get D, but I hate having to fight menus to get all of this done (especially when button placement is odd!).
-- There should be an option to break down an item into components! There were a few times where I crafted the wrong items (button placement!), losing precious items, and I could not undo the operation... :(

But these are all minor -- as I said before, the main game loop was fun, you can feel the character progression (especially when you get better items), and the whole thing was charming (think Lego aesthetics).

Score: 78/100.
Its ok, it doesn't have a map so you just need to sumarize certain points. Still better than minecraft. Dragon Builder 1 and 2 are the best block builder games.
Not a great farming game imo. A lot of others do farming better. The characters felt kinda bland and didn't feel like a lot to do in the game that was fun. Would refund if I could.
I came into this not expecting anything, and was pleasantly surprised! At 80hrs, and I haven't finished the main storyline yet.

6/10

Good game overall with an impressive visual presentation and style (there's still not enough art-deco Bioshockey visual style things in the world), well voiced and good sounds. However for me the story, atmosphere and intrigue begin to falter once you the main plot arc is revealed and the characters potential leanings become somewhat predictable.

For it's presentation and setting, you'd be forgiven for expecting more from such a game with such aesthetics, especially with it's focus on narrative and lite puzzles and less mechanics to manage, but it really ends up being just a good, slightly more involved, walking simulator; one of the better ones though.

reviews.title: VidyaGaemAwards's review of Monster Hunter Rise

reviewText.content:
Even since the PS2 days, Monster Hunter has always been centered around hunting with the lads, whether online or offline. It's fun enough to hammer smash a monster in the face alone, but there's something special about putting it to sleep while everyone drops down Mega Barrel Bombs and blasts it to hell. There's plenty of games where you can work together and/or compete against each other, but most characters in those are generally kept equal, or at least balanced. In Monster Hunter, any player can specialize in wildly different specialties, despite using similar weapons and armors.

When the name of the game is hitting some giant lizard with your grug stick, you don’t need to keep reinventing the wheel, but you can bring your friends and your well-done steaks along to the barbecue. Especially when everyone brought their Spider-man web-slingers and each lobby is packed with pets

Share a pint of Tanzian ale as you chow down on some of our master chef’s delicious berry safe dango, because a new game means new ways to get your ass carted back to the weenie teepee.

One of a kind MMORPG. Some of the best movement i've experienced. They weren't lying, you actually feel like a ninja in space, except when it slows down because it's a MMORPG of course theres going to be a lot of farming. The game's arbitrary timers can be skipped with plat but the entire game can be enjoyed without buying in game currency (except if you need slots farm and trade prime parts).
The game Idea is fantastic and the gameplay is awsome. I love the in-game marketing system.

reviews.title: A free to play game that actually is free to play!

reviewText.content:
I've been playing it for a few months now, and I have to say, in these few months, it has outdone any other games I've played for the same time. 

The Community, for the most part, is awesome, newbie friendly, and overall very generous and helpful.

The variety of gamemodes is overwhelming, to say the least. Or it would be, if the game threw all of them after you at the beginning. But they slowly introduce you to more modes, the more you progress.

The start of your journey as tenno might look a bit easy, meleeing everything, jumping around...but you'll definetly get a severe damage check pretty quickly, when you realize, that just spamming melee won't do the job.

There are a few things that narrative centric games should have: great characters, interesting setting, and a captivating story.

The first two Oxenfree delivers plenty! Quirky coming of age characters, set in a spooky mysterious island? check.
The story however.. is complete lackluster. unfortunately.

To put it in perspective i don't even remember much of it to go into details (even though i played it in one sitting!). Something about sailors, submarine, ,something something.. spooky island?

Unfortunate for a heavily narrative driven game :/

Other than that i was really taken by the presentation, both the artstyle and even the sound design were great i though! it was spooky, eerie and still colourful, a surprising fit.

A nice short story. The visuals are really cool (lots of crazy effects and nice vistas) and the sound design is great. It's got a bit of a life is strange vibe with a gang of young people and their relationships being the main focus, with a backdrop of supernatural going on. You make choices about how you interact with others and how you progress the story. I felt like I had a lot of control over what kind of person the main character is. You start out with basically no idea whats going on but as you progress the mystery unravels nicely.
The devs clearly intended it to be a game you play multiple times but honestly I don't feel that draw. I don't think if I played it again I would get enough new content to justify another 4 hours, just a slightly different ending.

reviews.title: Petit jeu très travaillé, sur le fond et la forme

reviewText.content:
++ Direction artistique
++ Fluidité très réaliste des dialogues
~ chargements un peu long
~ nos choix de dialogues ont finalement peu d'impact
-- on ne peut pas passer les dialogues, même pas en new game plus, le jeu étant assez bavard

It's a really good game. I do recommend this game for having fun and playing with friends online. It's challenging solo, but it can be enjoyable, especially as the killer. Playing with people is great, so I recommend that a lot more. Also, this game is a grind to get perks, and you have to pay for DLC, but it's really fun

reviews.title: s3ymur's review of Dead by Daylight

reviewText.content: i am so like this game, This game only old man. i am so like this game, This game only old man. i am so like this game, This game only old man

Dead by Daylight is a fantastic multiplayer horror game that truly shines with its licensed collaborations. As a horror games/movies fan, I love the crossovers with iconic franchises like Silent Hill and Resident Evil.

Initially, I enjoyed playing as the killer, but lately, I’ve found myself playing as a survivor more often. The gameplay is always thrilling, whether you’re hunting or being hunted.

Behaviour Interactive’s consistent support and updates keep the game fresh and engaging. For any horror fan, Dead by Daylight is a must-play, offering a unique and immersive experience.
Almost the best game I've ever played. Must be played everyone.
Most artful games top #1. If you played the first game, you need to play this one.

reviews.title: Une référence du genre (comme l'épisode précédent)

reviewText.content:
Suite directe du premier Ori, le gameplay a été modifié en profondeur, avec plus de pouvoirs et donc de variété dans le gameplay, mais aussi avec la perte de pouvoir créer ses check point "où on veut quand on veut".
Globalement le jeu est plus grand au niveau de la carte, avec des quêtes annexes en plus, etc. il y a un vrai travail de fond fait sur le gameplay qui donne vraiment l'impression d'un Ori 2 et non un Ori 1.5
Toujours un plaisir en fin de jeu de parcourir ce monde pour y chercher toutes les améliorations :)

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

reviews.title: jocket's review of Ori and the Will of the Wisps

reviewText.content:
Literally my favorite videogame ever!
Touching story, good characters, amazing setting and WONDERFUL soundtrack. 
I first played it at its launch during the first lockdown in 2020, and I'm not gonna lie, this game is one of the reasons I fondly remember that period.
This game will be a swing of emotions, I'm not gonna spoil anything, just go and play it. totally worth it!

reviews.title: seanmallonofficial1976a's review of Ori and the Will of the Wisps

reviewText.content:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a spiritual successor to the award winning game Ori and the Blind Forest. What stands out with this game is it's graphics and award winning score. 

The controls on the PC version is lock tight and really responsive. The graphics are top notch and look very good on 4k UHD devices.

The story is very good and rivals the story telling in the original game. 

I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a good platformer and immersive story.

Having just finished it yesterday it's a top 10 MV for me. Besides great platforming and movement options you have backtracking to progress, non-linear progression, and various sequence breaking opportunities meaning, so exploration is rather satisfying. Combat is also more prominent, something that's more give or take for me as I think the prequel's approach suited the player character better and made you think differently about taking on enemies while also making you feel more vulnerable. But this game also creates that vibe in the beginning, the chases and in mouldwood in particular. And the bosses were also good, if somewhat few, with some challenging ones but the forgiving checkpoint system let it avoid the frustration of Hollow Knight (except for the chases ironically as they didn't have them and also killed you in one hit). I mention HK as it's an obvious inspiration for certain aspects such as the shard slot system and how healing works, though the game also borrows from games like Guacamelee and Sonic Colors. I mostly didn't mind as it's generally done well. 

I do wish the optional dark cave was more fleshed out, and maybe the sand area "dungeon" as well. Some other things could be tweaked like the seed rewards (mostly pointless to me), and being able to trade in unwanted shards for something else, among some other minor things like some shards working better as permanent abilities. I also liked having a teleporter beacon in the first, and being able to change difficulty on the fly, so those features were missed.

I guess there could've also been an optional battle arena gauntlet like in Darksiders 2, for those who really wanted a combat challenge.

If you're into the sequence breaking aspect of MVs I would recommend looking up sentry jump/super jump and skipping buying the maps from the map maker, it makes the exploration (even) more satisfying. You can also get Launch early but that pretty much breaks the game.

8/10 or 8.5/10 on a better PC and with all bugs fixed. Which is between great and amazing on my scale.

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Ori and the Will of the Wisps

reviewText.content:
"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a visually stunning action-adventure game released in 2020 for various platforms including PC, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch. Developed by Moon Studios, the game falls into the Metroidvania genre, emphasizing exploration and intricate platforming challenges. 

The game was directed by Thomas Mahler, known for his work on the original "Ori and the Blind Forest." Moon Studios has also worked on titles such as "Ori and the Blind Forest" and "Gris."

The game's emotional narrative was penned by Anne Toole, who has contributed to other game scripts like "Horizon Zero Dawn." The enchanting musical score was composed by Gareth Coker, known for his work on the first Ori game and "Minecraft Dungeons."

Powered by Unity engine, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" showcases stunning visual effects, bringing its magical world to life. Unity has been used in a variety of games, offering flexible graphics capabilities.

The game excels in sound design, immersing players in its atmospheric and emotional journey. The combination of visuals, music, and sound effects creates a captivating ambiance, drawing players into Ori's world.

Deserving of a perfect score on PC, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" delivers an impeccable blend of storytelling, gameplay, and aesthetics. Its intricate level design, emotional depth, and seamless gameplay mechanics make it a standout title.

In conclusion, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a masterful achievement in the world of gaming, deserving of a perfect score on PC due to its exceptional design, emotional resonance, and captivating gameplay experience.

reviews.title: nathnaeldesta's review of Ori and the Will of the Wisps

reviewText.content: one of the best metroidvainias, got me into the genre. 9/10 :)

reviews.title: Anonymous's review of Ori and the Will of the Wisps

reviewText.content: It is unusual when a game can hold the level it set with a previous installment, and elevate it. Even if you play The Blind Forest and play The Will of Wisps after a while, it reminds you of its game mechanics gently, and expands on them in a way that it doesn't feel like the same game. There are tough parts in this game as well, but they don't feel impossible anymore like they used to. The save system is much better, and difficulty curve is much more in the hands of the player now. And boy, the story. I really hope they make a third game!

When I saw this in the Xbox Store earlier, I thought it was a joke. I laughed reading the description. But I had to admit, it was definitely an original idea. I went ahead and bought it, figuring if it was bad it was only $5. But luckily, it wasn't a bad game. It's very buggy and the camera keeps jumping around, but it was clearly a cheap game from a small developer, so for what it is it's a well-made game.

I played several rounds, and it's more intense than you'd expect. For starters, there are boxes everywhere, and any one of them could be another player. You have no idea which one is a person unless they move around. Usually there's a ten minute limit, and the first five minutes, no one wants to move. Everyone just looks around and slowly moves. Unfortunately, when you look around the box moves, too. But the last few minutes, it usually delves into chaos, everyone running around trying to kill each other. But it's actually kind of funny , seeing a bunch of boxes going at each other with box cutters.

I think my favourite moment while I played was actually a bad moment for me, but it left me impressed. I was chasing a player from room to room, but then I lost sight of them. I walked around and then he killed me. I went back and reviewed the gameplay footage afterwards and they had simply stopped moving. They'd blended into the other boxes so well that I didn't even notice, and in the heat of the moment I thought they disappeared.

I think this game is good, but also that it could do with a bit of work. The biggest thing being fixing the glitches. Either a patch or a bigger budget sequel. Either way, this game is worth the $5.

reviews.title: tinfinity8's review of Oxenfree II: Lost Signals

reviewText.content:
Inicio del juego:31/10/23
Fin del juego: 17/11/23

Jugué Oxenfree original y es un juego grandioso, hermoso visualmente, con buena música, buenos personajes y buena historia que te mantiene intrigado durante el transcurso del juego. Cuando supe que saldría Oxenfree II estaba muy emocionada, y ahora que lo jugué estoy muy feliz, aún sigo prefiriendo el primero, pero este no es una mala continuación. Abarca temas familiares, no saber qué es lo que quieres en la vida, fracasos, decepción, y superación, perdidas familiares, enfrentar a la vida aunque no estés preparado y no sepas qué es lo que te depara.  
El juego es hermoso en prácticamente todos los sentidos, amo este estilo de juegos, el arte, los paisajes, las conversaciones, el misterio, la música, siento que todo encaja y todo está donde debe estar, no hay nada fuera de lugar, y eso es hermoso. A pesar de que el arte es el mayor fuerte de este juego, debo admitir que su historia es muy buena, y además tiene mecánicas interesantes y diferentes, la radio es mi cosa favorita, y el walkie talkie es un buen recurso, no sabes cómo se ve Maria o Evelynn, o Nick, pero sientes su compañía y a veces es hasta reconfortante hablar con ellos, no solo para buscar información, sino simplemente, hablar, ya con eso el juego se siente más vivo, y me gusta. Como dije antes, prefiero el primer Oxenfree, pero es porque fue la primera experiencia, aún no sabía de qué trataba el juego y descubrirlo mientras jugaba era mágico, no por eso este es malo, sino que simplemente ya sabía más o menos de qué se trataba.

En conclusión es un muy buen cierre a lo que es Oxenfree, y tiene obras de arte muy hermosas.

Musica/Audio: 8/10
Arte: 9/10
Historia: 8/10
Personajes: 8/10
Gameplay: 8/10

Floppy Knights is a turn-based strategy game developed by Rose City Games. It was released in 2022 for the PC platform. The game combines elements of tactical combat and deck-building mechanics, offering a unique gameplay experience.

The director of Floppy Knights is Adam Robinson-Yu, who is known for his work on the game "A Short Hike." The game features charming pixel art and a whimsical visual style that adds to its appeal.

The game's script was written by Daniel H. Wilson, an author and robotics engineer. Apart from Floppy Knights, he has written several books, including "Robopocalypse" and "Amped."

The music for Floppy Knights was composed by Fat Bard, a musical duo known for their work on various indie games such as "Sundew" and "Fossil Echo." Their compositions help to create an engaging and immersive atmosphere in the game.

Floppy Knights is built using the Unity game engine, which is a popular choice among developers for its versatility and ease of use. Unity has been used in a wide range of games, including "Cuphead" and "Hollow Knight."

In terms of graphics, Floppy Knights features charming pixel art visuals with vibrant colors and detailed character designs. The effects graphics used in the game enhance the gameplay experience, adding visual flair to the battles and special abilities of the characters.

The game's sound design is well-crafted, with distinct audio cues for different actions and abilities. The combination of sound effects and music helps to create an immersive atmosphere that draws players into the game world.

In conclusion, Floppy Knights is a delightful turn-based strategy game with an appealing art style, engaging gameplay mechanics, and a captivating atmosphere. Its combination of tactical combat and deck-building provides a fresh take on the genre, making it an enjoyable experience for strategy game enthusiasts.

Je trouve les critiques des joueurs assez dures avec ce jeu : zelda-like très joli au niveau des graphismes et de l'animation, il blablate pas mal comme tous les jeux du genre, mais c'est loin d'être le pire il est dans les standards.
Le scénario a quelques rebondissement et tient bien en haleine ; après on reste sur du zelda-like au niveau de l'histoire et du gameplay, c'est assumé et très bien fait, il ne faut juste pas s'attendre à jouer à Witcher 3 en 2D.
La durée de vie d'environ 25h est bien remplie, et la difficulté bien dosée : on peut acheter des plats ou les cuisiner à partir d'ingrédients (craft simple pas prise de tête), pour récupérer des coeurs en cours de jeux ; si on joue correctement pas de raison de se retrouver bloquer avec un coeur, au pire il y a toujours les sauvegardes (manuelles ou automatiques) pour revenir en arrière et mieux se préparer.
Tous les classiques du genre sont là, avec différents armes à upgrader (pistolet, bombes, ..) les coffres au trésor, les morceaux de coeurs pour augmenter ses PV, ...
La dualité des deux personnages avec chacun leurs pouvoirs fonctionne bien et est très intelligemment exploitée, avec certains phases "puzzle" où les deux personnages sont séparés à la manière d'un lost viking.

Joué sur PC via la game pass.

I have to admit, the game is super intriguing. The game-play is easy to pick up and understand from the start, even though you might want to read the "guide" that comes with any new treatments. The core game-play loop, however, gets tiring very quickly, and is frankly confusing (you will see what I mean when you get messages at the start/end of each day). For me, in order to want to play and finish this type of game, I have to absolutely love the story, which did not happen in this case. Still, I will recommend this game to try to anyone. It might just be your cup of tea, and if it is, you are going to love it.

Something is in the house!  With the power off and only a candle to light your way, you must creep through your own home and look for your daughter.  Paranormal and spooky things are happening and its up to you to face off against an ancient evil to save your daughter…just remember: don’t knock twice.

The game Don’t Knock Twice is loosely based on the 2016 British supernatural horror film by the same name.  While labeled as a first-person survival horror; the game is basically a haunted house walking simulator with no survival elements.  Don’t Knock Twice is an interesting, albeit short, game where there you will travel through the house looking for items and solving several puzzles to attain your goal—to rescue your daughter. 

The spooky atmosphere is elevated by the dark, mysterious interiors of the house, the sound effects that manage to thoroughly spook you, and the occasional jump scare or two.  Overall, the atmosphere is the real gem of this game and very memorable and creepy.

Sadly, Don’t Knock Twice is far from perfect.  The story seemed poorly conceived and the game has little to no substance…if you saw the movie you kind of know what was going on but the game does not add anything to the story.  The game is visually dark, too dark—even after upping the lighting it was ridiculously hard to see anything.  Additionally, there seemed to be sound cues for creepy things happening but I didn’t see them—either the location was extremely dark or I was facing the wrong way or the sounds were just there for creepy atmosphere.  Last, but not least, the text messages from the daughter are not only annoying but remind me why I don’t carry a cellphone with me all the time.  I want to explore the house, not have some annoying teenager text me more than a political campaign asking for donations.  

Using the controller was maddening and it was not intuitive nor was it fun.  I ended up using the mouse and the keyboard and, with the exception of having a difficult time opening doors, there was no issue.  Since the game was originally developed for VR; I can see why the controller is an issue, and I recommend using the mouse and keyboard if you are going to play this game.

Achievements, however, are fun and relatively easy.  You will need to play the game at least twice as there is two different endings.  Because the game is relatively short I did not mind playing Don’t Knock Twice a second time to get all the achievements I missed the first time through.

Don’t Knock Twice is not a bad game, but I have a hard time recommending it—especially for full price.  While it is very beautiful and dark and very atmospheric there is really no substance to the game which makes Don’t Knock Twice rather unremarkable and forgettable in the end.  I am, however, glad that I played it and would urge you to wait until its on sale if you are interested in this game.
Great jokes, characters and art style! A must-play game for fans of the old LucasArts point&click games like Monkey Island!

If you love the classic graphic adventures of the late 1980s and early 1990s, you can't miss this video game. Knowing that it is a creation of the authors of Maniac Mansion and Monkey Island I was forced to try it. But when I played it I was hooked. It seems to me a masterpiece of the genre. I think the creators have achieved exactly what they intended. They have brought to the 21st century a game with all the ingredients of the referents of the pure graphic adventure genre.
Great atmosphere, very interesting riddles and plenty of chacaters to play as. I wish every character had  a little bit different dialogs tho, just to make it a bit more funny.
A great game I'd highly recommend! I was utterly engrossed whilst playing!
A great exploration of the mistery genre, completly breaking the norms of the genre! Complete Review forthcoming.....

It is very hard to review this game without spoiling the series' plot. Comparing to the predecessors (please, don't play this game without playing the first two first), it contains new mini-games (which aren't necessarily better), has the same structure (you know what I mean if you played the first two), has the same cliches and awkward moments, but mainly, it is still SO MUCH FUN. Danganronpa V3 builds upon the set world while standing on its own feet as a great, great game. In addition, it contains meaning(s) that can be extended outside itself - just play the game to understand.
Danganronpa V3 is even better that the other games. And without a doubt one of my favorite games.

RPGolf Legends melds two distinct elements into a fairly cohesive experience. Combining a golfing mechanic with an RPG is an interesting and unique idea. However, blending these two together causes the game to stumble in some aspects.

Firstly, there's golf. The golf mechanic is very enjoyable and somewhat relaxing. There's an assortment of different clubs to choose from, and, in true RPG fashion, you can even buy upgraded sets of clubs as you progress further in the game. These upgrades can boost your range and your attack damage (since you'll be hitting enemies with the clubs in addition to golf balls). Each hole has a par, as you would expect, and you get rewards for achieving or outperforming par.

The second aspect, of course, is the RPG mechanics. The game consists of a segmented open world that will open up as you progress further. Each area contains 9 golf holes for you to try to beat to get to the next area. However, since it's an RPG, you'll have to unlock the holes, either by killing monsters or by completing quests. The quests are pretty uninteresting, mostly fetch quests or kill quests, although there are some interesting ones in there as well. Additionally, there are bosses and dungeons that you will have to beat in order to progress.

Dialogue is pretty well-written, and contains a lot of good humor. The music is relaxing and fits well, and the pixel-art graphics are nice to look at.

Combat is decent. Basically, you can either swing your club to attack or use it to block an enemy's attack. There's also special attack powers that you can obtain. Unfortunately, many of the boss battles are lacking. Bosses tend to have a bunch of hit points and only one attack phase, so you'll be constantly dodging the same attacks and then going in for a couple of swings every once in a while. There were a few boss fights where I wondered if I was even doing them correctly, since it took so many hits to kill them.

The problems with this game mostly arise from areas where it blends golf into the RPG. Unlocking holes is sometimes pretty tedious, where you'll be farming enemies, then running to the next hole to play golf, then back to farming enemies. In fact, by the last two areas, the game seems to become somewhat self aware of how tedious it was getting and the requirements to unlock the last 18 holes were dropped, meaning that you could play straight through the 9 holes in each area before having to go back to the RPG. That made these areas much more enjoyable to play.

Despite its flaws, there's still quite a lot of enjoyment to be had here, and I found myself getting engrossed in both the RPG elements and the golf elements.

Overall Score: 6/10

Animal Well was a mesmerizing journey of discovery. Each new area felt like uncovering a secret, the puzzles were clever without being frustrating, and the atmosphere was a beautiful blend of cozy and unsettling.  Hours melted away as I explored every nook and cranny, eager to see what secrets lay hidden in the darkness. I can't wait to dive back in and discover what I missed.

reviews.title: codeman_17's review of Bendy and the Ink Machine

reviewText.content: Un muy buen juego con una ambientación única y característico de la saga, el mapa parece grande y laberíntico pero es sencillo, con secretos y minijuegos lo cual le da vida al mapa, un par de sustos bien puesto que te pone en situación, la historia es muy buena e interesante a la cual se le puede sacar jugo, las mecánicas son simples pero encajan con el juego, los diseños de personajes en su versión animadas son muy característicos y su versión en 3D o monstruosas son muy buena.

reviews.title: pawlo83's review of Kao the Kangaroo

reviewText.content: It's fine to be honest but does not have the amazing spirit of the OG Kao. I do not know what I was expecting but ended up a little disappointed.
Interesting story but quite simplistic gameplay. It has sapce and aurora borealis tho, and I can never say no to wither of them.

Contra todo pronóstico, nos encontramos frente a un grandioso juego para los que aman el género de estrategia por turnos. La adición de los Rabbids nos da grandiosos momentos de humor y los desafíos le dan un grandioso factor de rejugabilidad. Mi única queja es que a veces el juego se freezea, pero para ser un trabajo de Ubisoft, es una muy buena incursión a la híbrida de Nintendo

This could have been an outstanding adventure game, if it weren't for some of the worst game puzzles I've encountered in my adventure gaming career (and it's been a long one). It's such a shame..

Also, there are two piano/music puzzles identical to the rest of the dozens of the commonplace piano/music puzzles in other adventure games. Enough with the piano puzzles already!

reviews.title: metlebeard's review of For The King

reviewText.content: For the King offers a unique experience for those who love RPGs and games like DnD. It offers a range of different stories you can play through with your friends, and the procedurally generated world with leave you with a new experience every time. Upgrading your skills and gaining loot to work towards an ultimate goal is the perfect fit for this game. Can definitely sink some hours into it.
42 FoV, don't really need to say anything else.

911 Operator is a game about the difficult work of people that manage emergency lines and services. Main task is to answer incoming calls and to react properly - give first aid instructions, advise, dispatch correct...

911 Operator is a tense game. I can only imagine those calls in real life, how stressful they were.

reviews.title: Maxim_Nazarenko's review of Behind the Frame: The Finest Scenery

reviewText.content:
It's not just a game. It's an art.
The concept of beauty and sophistication, transferred to the image of a video game.

A relaxing, eloquent experience that can be played at any pace.

Behind the Frame: The Finest Scenery shows genuinely impressive animation, which is likely the first thing you'll notice when you see the first footage of the game.
Overall feeling of "lo-fi alike" atmosphere and coziness will keep you through the first part of the game.

Combining animated interludes and interactive scenes, the art tells the story about a town and the apartment of a young artist, who finishes final piece of a gallery submission. Music accompanies the mood of this game upon pressing play on an old cassette player.

Gameplay is kinda like "escape room". Puzzles are so light, that you will feel almost no resistance to the current of the story, and the visual and audio parts are so abundant that there is never a feeling of drying out an environment, before having option to see something new.

reviews.title: twobears79's review of Arise: A Simple Story

reviewText.content:
The end of a life is not necessarily the end.  Waking up from what you assumed was your last moments you find yourself going back through your life; from your youth to your old age alongside the woman that you love.  Here you remember your journey and make sense of life before the final goodbye.

Arise A Simple Story is a narrative third-person platforming game which focuses on a very human story.  You play as an old man who dies and finds himself in Limbo where he goes back through his life chapter by chapter.  You follow his memories of his one true love, his triumphs, his sadness, and the eventual end of his life in a fantastically powerful game that tugs at the heartstrings.

Games can be art and Arise A Simple Story is a great example of this idea.  The world is beautiful and done is a stunning art style that is both angular and soft.  Throughout the game you will find Memories that tell the story within each chapter and expound upon the tale.  Each level is a look back on the protagonist’s life, starting from early childhood to old age and are brilliantly themed, colorful, and emotive.  Additionally, the soundtrack throughout the entire journey is impactful and works well with the story presented.  These items, in conjunction with the wordless story, make Arise a true work of art and one that will stay with you for quite some time.

The main game mechanic of Arise is the ability to move time forward or backward and each level has its own reason to do so.  For example, progressing time forward in one chapter changes the season from winter to spring and opens paths that might not normally be accessible while in another chapter time forward or backwards controls a raging fire that devours all within its path.  Coupled with simple platforming; the game becomes a little more intricate as well as interesting as your progress through the story.

If one negative thing can be said about Arise A Simple Story it would be the platforming.  Arise is a beautiful game to look at but it can be a chore to play.  While the main game mechanic is exciting and feels fresh, the platforming mechanic is frustrating and feels rushed.  With the fixed camera system, and a camera that sometimes moves while you are leaping, you end up dying a lot while jumping from area to area which slows down the game as well as the story of the game.

The achievements are not only challenging but fun to get as well.  While there are achievements for completing each chapter; the vast bulk of achievements will be attained by finding all the memories as well as completing certain tasks in each level.  These special tasks range from jumping a hundred times or collecting dew drops to not freezing to death or touching fire.  All the achievements in Arise feel as if they are a part of the story and not just something thrown in there…a definite bonus especially for achievement hunters.

Arise was a wonderful and heartfelt story from its grand opening to the moving final credits and an experience that I am sure to remember for quite some time.  From the epic environments to the sweeping musical score; Arise offered a beautiful story told without words in which you can take part and experience alongside the protagonist.  I wholeheartedly recommend this game to everyone, no matter what genre or style game that you may play.  Arise is a simple story well told and one that should be experienced.

I have always considered dating sim a weird idea for a game. I do not think I would ever play one by myself. Boyfriend Dungeon was recommended to me through a podcast as a spin on dating sims and dungeon crawlers, and I was curious how it could work together. Honestly, the result is much better than I expected. The dungeon play was fun, the dating sim part was just fine, the overarching narrative was interesting enough to keep me going, and all of this mixed together made for a fun snowy afternoon. Despite me treating this game as expanding my gaming horizons, and I wouldn't actively look for games of this type, I enjoyed my time with Boyfriend Dungeon. Kudos to the devs for pulling this off!

++ Très belle direction artistique
+ Peut se jouer avec des personnes 'non gamer' voire avec des enfants
+ Demande de la concentration car parfois difficile mais jamais impossible (pas besoin d'utiliser l'aide)
- Concept simple qui reste toujours identique

Great little puzzle game that thoroughly challenges your wits. Truly, at about one third into the game, it starts to get extremely tough, and you cannot be sure of any single action. Golf Peaks has more than 100 levels, out of which some are truly impossible. Each stage introduces a new mechanic, and in the end, it creates a symphony of ideas that is impossible to beat. Literally.

Very nicely drawn game. Lots of puzzles to solve, but the story gets very cryptic towards the end. Some dialogs are unnecessary long. Also encountered some minor bugs - like mouse pointer stopping to work from time to time.

I am not sure on this one.
It's a decent "puzzle/platformer/adventure" with a kind of interesting control scheme and some nifty gameplay mechanics. Art and style design is perfect, so is the sound.
But remove that and the game is kind of boring. It had it's moment, but for the most part I wasn't that much engaged. And for seemingly emotion-oriented game it failed to move me at most important times.
Also, very short. 4-5 hours of gameplay time.
Also, seems to be designed for gamepad. Played it on one, but didn't like it.
I guess I should not recommend this.

Un petit jeu sympathique, très "3D unity" dans son design, classique mais avec qq très beaux passages.
Le gameplay est simple : un stick pour bouger et une gâchette pour interagir, pour chaque personnage ; il est suffisant pour les actions à réaliser : explorer et résoudre des petites énigmes sans grande difficulté.
La durée de vie est de l'ordre de 5h, avec des situations et des environnements qui se renouvellent bien.
Pas le jeu du siècle, mais un moment agréable et relaxant entre eux gros AAA, avec un tarif en cohérence (3 euros en promo).

Joué sur Series X.

It is a game that can appeal multiple audiences.
I played with my cousins, my brother, and even with my mother (story of the game touched her more than any of us.).
The controls were good and the graphics were above average...

I had a good time playing your game. Thank you...
I do not understand how this game could create a followed comunity. I do not understand where the fun is, really

It’s a good hack and slash game for spending your time mindlessly, but not much more than that. RPG elements are minimal and story is underdeveloped. Leveling and inventory are also straightforward. It’s a fairly big game, but it can get boring and repetitive after more than an hour of continuous gameplay. It took me over 10 hours to finish it, over the course of 6 months.

Grimvalor is an action RPG game for PC, released in 2018. It was developed by Direlight. The studio is known for their work on mobile platforms and previously developed games like Devious Dungeon.

The game was published by SureFire Games.

The director of Grimvalor is Mika Karras, who is primarily associated with Direlight and their mobile game projects.

The script for the game was likely handled in-house by the development team, as specific screenwriters are not widely credited for Grimvalor.

The music for Grimvalor was composed by Scott Lane, and he is recognized for his work on several other mobile games, such as Shadow Bug and Raid Manager.

The game utilizes the Unity game engine, a widely used engine in the gaming industry. Unity has been employed in various other games, including Hollow Knight and Cuphead.

In terms of graphics, Grimvalor features detailed 2.5D environments with dark and atmospheric aesthetics. The character designs and animations are smooth and fluid, contributing to a visually engaging experience.

The game's sound design and music help create a dark and immersive atmosphere. The sound effects are impactful, enhancing combat and exploration. The music by Scott Lane complements the game's tone, contributing to the overall ambiance.

Overall, Grimvalor offers a fine action RPG experience with solid graphics, sound design, and an engaging atmosphere. Sadly, it gets too frustating and repetitive in the long term.

Maybe I hyped it too much before playing, but I got a little disappointed.  The game is a nice roguelike with some interesting mechanics, but lacks something to really differentiate it from the other dozens of roguelites that are being released every year. If you're a fan of roguelite or roguelike games you're probably going to have fun, but if not I wouldn't recommend it.  The combat mechanics don't feel as good as it should, I felt it's just various mechanics from other games being brought together. I felt the game was longer than it should be, but that can vary from person to person.

reviews.title: pepito_128's review of 13 Sentinels: Aegis Rim

reviewText.content:
An intriguing sci-fi novel with tactical gameplay elements.

The Story is the stronger point and probably responsible for the high estimation of the public, making sci-fi is hard, it is because the plots (in most cases) have logical holes that are not obvious to the creators at first glance, in contrast, 13 sentinels  is brilliantly written, each complains or nonsense you will see during your journey will be resolved, many times with a wow moment that let you amazed and some times clapping figuratively or literally.

This story is filled with intervals of gameplay where you can find a merge between a tower defense and a tactical turn-based game, pretty fun, with interesting interactions that will deep into the relations between the characters and deep in the lore of this universe.

In summary, this game makes everything good, the only downside -and it is not so- is the reuse of assets and locations, probably because of budget limitations, making the 60 dollars price tag feel a bit high nevertheless any discount is a no brains choice to get.

I started to play without any knowledge. The first thing I noticed was the very Éric Chahiesque art direction and rhythm. Which is a great thing! As a huge fan of Heart of Darkness & Another World, I felt great. But the best part wasn't that! 
The feeling of being on an adventure is everywhere... The places you have to visit are well-detailed, highly grotesque, and full of discovery potential. I have to congratulate the game designer(s) of the game. There are lots of well-designed moments in the game, that make it much more deeper. Also, the narrative is blended masterly with art style and gameplay. 

OK, there are not very polished animations here and there, some UI/UX elements could have been thought better. But trust me, you won't think about them twice. It's not a long game but totally satisfying. I can't wait to play another game from the same hands.

Fun little game with interesting puzzles. I was hoping for more to be honest. I managed to get all achievements on Steam in nearly an hour. It wasn't very long but if you can get it for pretty cheap it is a fun game.

This game feels like I’m eight again and playing Wolfenstein 3D. It’s hard to replicate this feeling, but in Boltgun you’re gonna feel almost like invincible god cleansing the whole universe. Gameplay is addictive as hell if you are a fan of FPS. The graphics looks gorgeous within the limitations of the whole pixel art stylization. For my taste the game could have been even a bit a shorter and more condensed, as the bosses and enemies are reused multiple times. The last few levels feels just like a buildup for the final battle and my dear it is brutal. When I have finally beated the game I felt true relief and satisfaction. The story itself could have been structured a bit better to deliver the punches, but that’s not the most important thing in this game.

𝟕,𝟐 🍹 𝐓𝐇𝐄 𝐑𝐄𝐓𝐔𝐑𝐍 𝐎𝐅 𝐕𝐈𝐒𝐔𝐀𝐋 𝐓𝐎 𝐁𝐎𝐎𝐌𝐄𝐑 𝐒𝐇𝐎𝐎𝐓𝐄𝐑
The incredible visual of this project deserves any praise and attention, but for some reason (most likely due to the fault of the publisher) it is forced to carry a huge stretched campaign for 15 hours, consisting mainly of "ctrl+v" sections with a weak level design and a monotonous setting, only just in the 3rd act does the game open up a "second wind", the arenas become at least large enough to make it interesting to jump around in a circle, but at the end the problem of sponge-bosses arises even more.. In short, there are only about 3 types of bosses, you will defeat all of them already in act 1, but then you will meet them again and again, mixed up, only the levels will be higher.. levels - this is a facepalm for a boomer shooter, small enemies don’t have levels here, everything is fine, but why did they have to be made for big ones.. when they already demanded 5 clips each, and there were no interesting tactics for fighting them.
But Boltgun could become the right "Doom 3", all modern "old" shooters for some reason forgot that the original Doom had awesome memorable designs of weapons and enemies, remakes, for example, generally ignore this part of the legacy of the originals, and relied only on cor. gameplay, in Boltgun everything is fine with this + colorful effects of shots, the aesthetics of "Warhammer" fits perfectly into the concept, and this is the only thing that connects the game with a huge series, don`t be afraid, there is no lore here, the plot too just get from point a to point b and kill the heretics, and the flying-head companion only serves as a source of a couple of jokes and guides. There are some sober ideas in the gameplay, for example, we are very fast, but at the same time the character feels rather heavy, which, it seemed to me, a little, but fresh, there are "super" clips for the machine gun, but their differences are microscopic, gigantic keys amused, corresponding to the spirit of gigantism of locations, but there is also a bunch of shortcomings, again, the uselessness of the assistant head, the lack of interesting secrets, which is extremely necessary for this genre, all the secrets are ordinary rooms that are just a little harder to notice, about some mini- games/puzzles, I generally keep quiet, even no platforming, 1-minute section in the middle.. from what I remember, fast mini-bosses are not slowed down by any type of damage, which could also significantly reduce irritation from them, gunplay good, but every chapter the entire arsenal is reset without explanation, and then the same guns for some reason get into other places in the slots, which creates confusion when you need to quickly select a weapon.
In general, I like the approach of the Warhammer publishers, which gives money for experiments in the universe in various genres, which expands the overall fan base very well and allows you to reach even those players who have never touched this series at all (like me), but why was it necessary to force the developers to make of an ordinary boomer shooter such a long and expensive product, forcing them to copy-paste a lot and not pay enough attention to the gameplay? They didn’t even have time to come up with music, only some kind of beats. 🧡Boltgun is forever in my heart, but I don’t advise anyone to play it for more than 2 hours)

😊Subscribe on my Steam`s Curator`s page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550/
///
Невероятный визуал этого проекта заслуживает любых похвал и внимания, но почему-то (скорее всего по вине издателя) он вынужден тащить на себе огромную растянутую кампанию на 15 часов, состояющую преимущественно из ctrl+v секций со слабым левел-дизайном и однообразным сеттингом, только лишь в 3 акте игра открывает "второе дыхание", аренки становятся хотя-бы достаточно большими, чтобы по ним было интересно скакать по кругу, но в конце ещё сильнее встаёт проблема боссов-губок.. Крч тут всего где-то 3 типа боссов, всех их вы сразите уже в 1 акте, но потом они будут вам встречаться ещё и ещё, вперемешку, только левелы станут больше.. это вообще фейспалм для бумер-шутера, у мелких врагов тут левелов нет всё нормально, но зачем надо было делать их для больших.. когда на них итак по 5 обойм уходило, а никакой интересной тактики сражения с ними не было.
А ведь Болтган мог бы стать правильным Doom 3, все современные "олдовые" шутеры почему-то забыли, что оригинальный Дум имел офигенные запоминающиеся дизайны оружия и врагов, ремейки, например, вообще игнорируют данную часть наследия оригиналов, и, тащат только кор. геймплеем, в Болтгане с этим всё прекрасно + к этому ещё и красочные эффекты выстрелов завезли, а эстетика "Вархаммера" идеально вписывается в концпепцию, и, это, единственное, что связывает игру с огромной серией, не бойтесь, лора тут нету, сюжет тоже просто дойди из точки а в точку b и убивай еретиков, а летающая-башка компаньон служит только источником пары шуток и гайдов. В геймплее такэе есть здравые идеи, например, мы очень быстрые, но при этом же персонаж ощущается достаточно тяжеловесно, что, мне показалось, немного, но свежо, есть "супер"-обоймы для автомата, но их различия микроскопические, позабавили гигантские ключи, соответствующие духу гигантизма локаций, но тут же есть и ворох недочётов, опять же, бесполезность головы-помощника, отсутствие интересных секретов, что крайне необходимо данному жанру, все секреты - это обычные комнатки, которые просто чуть сложнее заметить, о каких-то мини-играх/пазлах я вообще молчу, даже платформинга нету, 1-а минутная секция в середине.. из того что я запомнил, быстрые мини-боссы не тормозятся ни от какого типа урона, что тоже бы могло бы существенно снизить раздражение от них, ганплей хороший, но каждую главу весь арсенал сбрасывается без объяснения причин, а потом те же самые пушки почему-то встают на другие места в слотах, из-за чего создаётся путаница, когда тебе необходимо быстро выбрать оружие.
В общем, мне нравиться подход издателей Вархаммера, который даёт деньги на эксперименты по вселенной во всевозможных жанрах, что очень хорошо расширяет общую фан-базу и позволяет дотянуться даже до тех, кто вообще никогда не касался данной серии (как я), но зачем было заставлять разработчиков делать из обычного бумер-шутера такой длинный дорогостоящий для своего жанра продукт, заставив их много копипастить и не уделить должного внимания геймплею? Даже музыку авторы не успели придумать, просто биты какие-то. 🧡Болтган навсегда в моём сердечке, но играть в это больше 2 часов никому не советую)

Подписывайтесь на Кураторство в Steam: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/37365104

A fun game to play with friends but wouldn't play alone. The game feel very repetitive because is it is. Not enough added things between runs to make it feel different everytime. Still fun to play with others though.

Portal - PC (Windows 10) - 1080p - 120 fps - Max Settings 

My Playthrough lasted 3 hours, divided roughly in 2 parts: 
- 90% for puzzle solving
- 10% for loading elevators

The Story is almost non existent and pretty straightforward: solve testing areas and try to escape. The portal gun, however, is a blast to use. If not for the clunky gameplay and repetitiveness, this would be a masterpiece.

For future references: 
- Original concept
- Good puzzle design

This is my favorite game of all time. Yes it's short but it's perfectly paced, and has the best writing I've ever seen in a video game. I've beaten the game multiple times over the years, and it's a game I never get tired of.

It's a legend. It spawned a thousand memes. Cake jokes STILL turn up, 12 years later. That aside, it's one of the most surprising and awe-inspiring games I've played. Is it just a simple physics-based puzzle game? PLAY IT AND FIND OUT.

It is incredible that Portal is a 15-year-old game, since even today it still feels refreshing when it comes to confront its challenging situations. The visual style that it contains is minimalistic yet very effective, and so is the excellent music and sound design.

Its original use of physics, clever puzzles, and it's hilarious and fun story round up this real masterpiece!

The masterpiece that is portal, being honest the game does kind of feel a little bit empty but even than it manages to get you into it. The progression and the genius tutorial is mind boggling, the game acts as a tutorial in its whole play.

Portal is broken up into two parts. In the first part you have to solve puzzles in test chambers and in the second part you're trying to escape from the facility. For my first playthrough the first part didn't give me too much trouble, because the difficulty curve is very well done. However, during the second part I often didn't know how to progress. This is because the exits are often hard to find and because I'm used to modern games who don't allow you to destroy parts of the environment.

Мы играем за подопытную, которой предстоит пройти 19 камер испытаний. Проходить мы будем эти камеры с помощью портальной пушки. Поначалу мы можем стрелять лишь одним порталом, но через несколько уровней нам дадут модифицированную версию пушки с двумя порталами. Игра находится во вселенной Half-Life и является спин-оффом, я надеялся найти тут отсылки к халве, но ничего не заметил, может во второй части будет хоть что-то. Единственной схожестью я могу засчитать пушку, ведь у Гордона есть грави пушка, которая выглядит примерно так же. После того как мы пройдем все камеры испытаний ГладОС, искусственный интеллект, который все это время наблюдал за нами, попытается убить нас, сделать это у нее не получится, ведь мы сбежим и финальной схватке одолеем ее. Концовка у игры была сделана с завязкой на продолжение, нас утаскивает какой-то робот. Теперь поговорим о плюсах и минусах этой игры. Первый плюс - это ее разнообразность. Все благодаря наращиванию сложности испытательных камер. Чем дальше мы идем - тем сложнее нам становится. Вторым плюсом я засчитаю головоломки, они были сделаны тут очень хорошо. Третий плюс - это фразы ГладОС. Хоть она и является нашим врагом, таковой не ощущается. Мне и многим геймерам она запомнилась благодаря своим фразочкам и шуткам. Минусов в этой игре нет. Игра была сделана с душой, именно поэтому она и понравилась тысячам геймеров.

reviews.title: Fun first-person ray-gun based puzzle game

reviewText.content: A really fun first-person ray-gun based puzzle game. Best one I've played so far. The setting and dark humour really work to make the game enjoyable. The cake is a lie.

I have to say, I was impressed by this game. It was a lot of fun and probably one of my favourite puzzle-solving games I've played it.
