The puzzles were just the right difficulty when it came to solving them and the game was simple to understand and quick and easy to learn. It's a rather simple game really with a boomerang of a story that I was not expecting but really liked how through your playthrough, if you decide to take your time to explore each area you get a bit of an idea gradually of what type of game you could expect. Portal from the beginning had that uncanny feeling of being alone with the music setting the atmosphere and the juxtaposition of acting like a friendly puzzle game but being much more than that.

reviews.title: A masterclass in puzzle game design.

reviewText.content:
Most of the areas felt just the right amount of challenging while also being very fun to go through. There were a few areas that stumped me, but I felt really proud of myself when I was able to get through a tough area without looking up a guide. The level design is crafted well, and it just felt like a fun world to explore.

While you don't you get any weapons aside for the portal gun, the game still has combat to a degree, as you are sometimes dropped in these areas where there are turrets everywhere, and you have to use the portal gun in creative ways to sneak up behind them, or drop them in a portal to somewhere else. How Valve was able to approach combat situations with puzzle solving was a masterclass in creative level design!

I also really enjoyed the story and Glados as an antagonist with her sarcastic commentary as you play through the game. I remember playing through the training levels until I found the first room outside of the training course that hinted at what was really going on and I just loved it!

The game is very short though, but I have heard that like Left 4 Dead, the first game is really just a demo and a foundation that the second game expands on, so I look forward to playing Portal 2 now!

The game set the wrong expectation of being one of the best games of all time in multiple lists. It is still a blast, short, but sweet. I still think it is bit over-hyped for what it is, but at the time, it must have been legendary.

Portal is an all-time classic puzzle game - so much so that many others try & fail to copy what made it successful.

And as a game itself, it does stand up to its reputation. The UIs are quite janky in terms of design (though they are quite functional), but that and the bullshit that is gold on all challenges are really the only problems with the game.

The artstyle is great, GLaDOS is easily one of the best villains of all time, and the puzzles are expertly designed. New mechanics are introduced at a great pace - even at the end of the game.

And for those who want more Portal, there's 6 advanced puzzles (one of which is utter bs, but the rest are great), challenges, and a sequel with way more content.

I'd definitely recommend this game.

And I'm making a note here - huge success.

The game has it all. Puzzles, setting, good mechanics and a most curious story. It is short, but it lasts. It also has some bonus phases and challenges to round it out. I think everyone should play it.

Essential. 9/10

Regards.

Тут нам предстоит играть за планету, которую засасывает в черную дыру. Путем нажатий на ЛКМ, мы отталкиваемся от центра, но стоит учитывать различные метеориты, при врезании в которые мы проиграем. Основной целью игры является сбор наибольшего количества очков, на которые потом можно будет купить скины. Нормально оценить у меня эту игру не получится, потому как если я не ошибаюсь, она есть и на мобильных устройствах. По меркам мобильных игр - это неплохой таймкиллер, но вот по меркам компьютерной игры - она жестко проигрывает по всем фронтам, поэтому я пожалуй остановлюсь на 5/10, это будет более-менее справедливо.
Recommended for people who like troop management real time games like Pikmin, Overlord, Batallion Wars II or Little King's with puzzle and battling.

reviews.title: Jolie petite histoire, rien de révolutionnaire mais bien racontée :)

reviewText.content:
+ Graphiquement joli, animation soignée
+ Naïveté de l’héroïne qui arrive à rester digeste
+ Durée de vie très correcte pour le prix
- L'histoire aurait pu être plus poussée, ça reste assez simple (le prologue en bonus gratuit n'apporte pas grand chose)

reviews.title: The dreaded Elder Scrolls mobile game no one likes to talk about.

reviewText.content:
As someone who enjoyed Fallout Shelter on PS4, and that's big for me since I play almost no mobile games, I enjoyed this one as well when it actually ran smoothly. I was surprised at some of the RPG depth the game has as you can create your character, pick your race as they all have certain perks just like in a traditional ES game. I also like the leveling system even though it is similar to Fallout 4 in that its just a big skill tree. You can pick abilities from either a magic tree, a stamina tree which are your weapon abilities and then a more general perk tree which is handy. You can also build up your town with houses, as well some service places like a blacksmith or alchemy shop to make you potions. That is where the timers for this game come in, but it honestly doesn't bother me. I only ever sit down and play 20-30 minutes before setting something to build and logging out.

I was also just surprised at how generous the game is with gear, as I was constantly picking up good weapons and armor to swap out, or I would just improve the gear I had at the blacksmith. I also love the music of this game even though its a shorter OST. They can't really use Jeremy Soule anymore for reasons I won't get into, so Inon Zur composed it who works on the Fallout games and now Starfield. I do love his music but I don't think he's the best fit for Elder Scrolls. However, if they got him to do this mobile game I imagine he will probably do ES6, but that's just my speculation.

As for combat, its decent for a mobile game, however I definitely would have preferred to play this on a Switch if I had one, as I am not a fan of the touch screen to use your weapon. It can be very unresponsive at times, as your character will cancel their strike rather then execute it. I do hope they bring this game to more platforms as right now its only on mobile and Switch. A PC port on steam would be way preferable in terms of performance which I will get into shortly. The graphics are decent and I do love how in most levels you can find secret areas for extra loot.

To quickly touch on the story, its okay and some of the missions in the quests tab, are very cool with me recently doing one where I had to clear spiders out of a village and then take on their queen. They can be fun at times, and since this game is set in Cyrodiil your character was formerly of the Blades which I loved. You also get to explore Aeylid Ruins which was a nice call back to Oblivion. Overall though, the story is average and nothing that really kept me playing, or want to finish it before writing this review.

My main issue was the performance. I don't know if its just me having a lower end model phone, but this game ran really bad most of the time. Sometimes it would run super smooth and I would really enjoy my time, others the framerate would drop to like 5 frames a second when in combat or even when just walking around. It made getting through a lot of quests very unenjoyable even though I enjoyed the gameplay loop. Either way, if their putting this game up on the Google play store, then it should run well for everyone regardless of what model of phone they have. Thankfully this game is free to play, because otherwise I would deduct more points.
original and clean level design, really fun to play with a friend, innovative and creative puzzles. super fun!

reviews.title: Très original sur le fond et la forme :)

reviewText.content:
Très original sur le fond et la forme :)
++ Direction artistique "Origami" superbe
++ Gameplay très original aux petits oignons
+ Environnements variés
+ Durée de vie très correcte pour le prix
+ mode Arène ("survival") pour après la campagne solo si on souhaite continuer à jouer
~ Histoire en fond très présente (narration) mais finalement peu développée
~ Petites baisses de framerate lorsque les décors "se déplient" (ce qui arrive assez rarement)

This game was offered on sites that give keys to streamers in exchange for showing the game on stream. But later they revoked access to those keys. Until today, in more than 200 games that I received in this way, it was the only developer that presented this reprehensible conduct.

Esse jogo foi oferecido em sites que dão key para streamers em troca de mostrar o jogo em stream. Mas depois eles revogaram o acesso dessas keys. Até hoje, em mais de 200 jogos que recebi dessa forma, foi a única desenvolvedora que apresentou essa conduta reprovável.

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Milk outside a bag of milk outside a bag of milk

reviewText.content:
As a sequel, Milk outside a bag of milk outside a bag of milk improves over its predecessor in a number of ways to create a much more engaging and interesting experience while painting a very unique story.

The art style is much improved, taking on a much clearly, yet equally mysterious, tone. Seeing the main character also helps to humanize them a lot more.

Once again, the story told is incredibly engaging, dealing with heavy concepts in a very abstract way. Each of the endings really makes you think, and each gives a unique perspective on the main character's struggles.

The soundtrack really complements and adds to the whole atmosphere of the game. Visuals are very creative, and I like that each ending uses a different art style.

Overall Score: 9/10

Indie games with surrealistic touches are usually eye-catching, and 'Back to Bed' was no exception, although it could have stood out more in the graphical department. For example, the 30 levels in the game are based on the same concept, not differing much from each other, making it seem somewhat simple.

The isometric view is fixed, limiting our interaction to only being able to zoom in or out on the scenario without affecting gameplay much; nevertheless, the gamepad fits perfectly with the game mechanics, but on mobile devices or with a mouse, it may require a bit more skill. The difficulty is not very high (😊👍); I was able to easily complete it in normal mode, while it took me a little more time in nightmare mode, having to resort to YouTube to solve some puzzles, but overall, the experience is pleasant and smooth.
Overall a good game with nice story and unusual gameplay. Relatively short, but still overstays its welcome a bit.

I found this game thanks to a Youtube channel called HeavyEyed which I think very highly of his opinions. 

When I started the game a nice tune started playing and I was intrigued to start playing. The game started off with baby-steps tutorial (or should I say baby crawls...:P). The developer of this game understood how to mimic a real snake movement into a game controller binding keys. Thanks to the lack of lives (tries) and unlimited time the game lets you explore the levels as much as you like. Plus, it won't punish you for failing.

As I was saying, gameplay wise, the control of the character (his name is Noodle) is unique and satisfying with a level design that will challenge your skills and adaptation to those unique mechanics. 

The level design is good initially and with every world, there is a new element added to it (Lava, rotating poles, wind etc). With that being said, the levels become more and more mundane as they don't add enough to hook me up for long.

If a story is something you were looking for, you will find almost none of it, just a generic adventure with a mute protagonist and its sidekick without any twists nor character development.

Overall is a very likeable 6 hours game in order to beat and probably few more hours in order to collect all the collectables. Hopefully, it will get a sequel which will live up to its full potential

I just reactivated my Game Pass to play this game, because it looked really fun and unique. It's a very interesting concept, but it didn't take me long to rage quit and uninstall. I couldn't even get through the tutorial. In order to pass it you have to collect everything in the level. But one of the coins you have to collect is under a bridge, and it's literally impossible to navigate. I watched a walkthrough of someone doing it, and even he said it took hours of practice to get it right. IN THE TUTORIAL LEVEL!!! That is simply unacceptable! The character is near impossible to fully control, because his whole body wants to move in other directions while climbing.

The best thing about Snake Pass? The controls.
The worst things about Snake Pass? The controls.
Contradictory? yes a little :D

It's hugely innovative in the sense playing a slithering snake never felt so accurate, but damn can it be infuriating...
Poor gameplay. Need to have a gamepad to play it. And I have no idea what is happening in the game, I could not play it with keyboard.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Adventures of Chris

reviewText.content: Truly a tough platformer that doesn't overstay its welcome. Cute little game which can be very hard, but has nice difficulty options, including a "story mode". I wish I could change the difficulty mid-game to challenge myself a bit more (or overcome a tough part a bit easier), but the story makes up for it. If you are a fan of 90's hard platformers, this will be right up your alley.

Una gran entrega del género Musou para los fans de los combates innecesariamente espectaculares.  Si bien no es un Fire Emblem tradicional, toma varios elementos como el triangulo de armas y una parte de estrategia para sacar adelante un buen título.  Si están esperando un táctics por turnos, huyan lejos de este título.
A beautiful simple puzzler that had me gripped and wanting more when it was over

O objetivo do jogo é embarcar em uma jornada com sua locomotiva, percorrendo um mapa vazio, enfrentando alguns obstáculos e buscando melhorias para o veículo.

Durante essa viagem, além de superar os obstáculos mencionados anteriormente, é necessário manter a locomotiva em bom estado. Isso envolve queimar itens para gerar energia, liberar fumaça enquanto se move, apagar pequenos incêndios e reparar componentes que podem quebrar durante o percurso. Esses elementos adicionam complexidade à jornada, tornando-a interessante e evitando que o jogo se torne monótono.

FAR: Lone Sails oferece uma jogabilidade extremamente relaxante, com ambientes belos e trilhas sonoras envolventes. É o tipo de jogo que me proporcionou uma imensa sensação de paz e que eu poderia jogar por horas sem nenhum estresse.

Minha principal dificuldade com o jogo foi a incerteza em relação a tudo. Joguei sem ter a menor ideia sobre o meu progresso ou se estava fazendo as coisas certas. O jogo mantém os jogadores um pouco às cegas, exigindo que sigam adiante. No entanto, quando alcancei o final, percebi que todas essas incertezas valeram a pena.

reviews.title: alexharford's review of FAR: Lone Sails

reviewText.content:
I loved FAR: Lone Sails at first, with the beautiful dystopian world and the satisfying clunky sounds while controlling the vehicle.

I became bored after a couple of hours. But found playing in shorter spurts enjoyable.

Most of the puzzles weren't very challenging, but there was satisfaction in solving some.

It only took 4-hours to complete the game, which I felt was slightly too long for what it is. But it was a nice experience overall, and the ending felt satisfying enough.

reviews.title: Sympathique jeu d'aventure très 'chill' et contemplatif

reviewText.content:
Sympathique jeu d'aventure très 'chill' et contemplatif : on prend plaisir à regarder notre bateau voguer, de temps en temps il faut intervenir la maintenance, régulièrement des puzzles tous différents viennent sans stress nous faire travailler nos méninges et parfois apporter des améliorations à notre navire.
Réalisation soignée, une poignée d'heure passée avec plaisir :)

Joué sur SeriesX.

reviews.title: A must play for JRPG fans from PS1 era

reviewText.content: Over 100 characters to interact, play with and collect, town building, brutal yet doable fights, and various voice acting clips, this kickstarter game made possible by the creative mind and director of the original Tsuikoden series will scratch your itch of nostalgia and give you hours of entertainment with similar features but a whole slew of content. Enjoy siege battles, card games, spinning tops, collecting tops, farming monsters for rare gear and items, spend a decent amount of time getting that one character that needs a very specific timing window, build your town, and run through all your emotions on this beautifully crafted JRPG. On the PS5 works fantastic, there are some overworld sections that had some fps drops, but nothing game breaking, no crashes or bugs. I have been playing it since release, enjoying and savoring every bit of nostalgia satisfying morsel this game has to offer. Even though I do not have the time I once had in my younger years to play games for long hours, every time I run this game, I am left with a sense of accomplishment, satisfaction, and immense joy that was put in it by the developers.

As a huge Suikoden fan and someone who has played all parts of the series, I was eagerly awaiting Eiyuden Chronicle 100 Heroes and it did not disappoint.

From the beginning, the game felt like Suikoden because the developers did not try to invent something fundamentally new, but rather to give JRPG fans, and especially Suikoden fans, a game that they would love immediately.

The characters, the music, the story & the fights, everything felt like Suikoden and that's why the game was so brilliant for me.

I also liked the mini-games, even if I sometimes wished for a better explanation.

The theatre plays in particular were a great idea. Unfortunately, it is not particularly easy to find all the scripts, which I think is a shame because it was not really necessary to make it so difficult.

reviews.title: Il y a mieux dans le genre...

reviewText.content:
+ pas cher, 70 puzzles
+ gameplay qui évolue durant la partie
- level design qui exploite mal le gameplay, répétitif
- demande plus de la patience que de la logique
- contrôles parfois imprécis/peu réactifs

reviews.title: amsandor's review of The Last Campfire

reviewText.content: A tight little indie puzzler about a small being helping those who have succumb to depression and sadness make their way to the afterlife. The game has a dark story, but a lovely and light tone about helping those in need. You do so by entering the mind of others, and helping them work out their internal puzzles. The puzzles themselves are quite interesting, and reminiscent of the Breath of the Wild shrine puzzles. Some are quite easy, and some can present challenges, but all told none were overwhelming. This was a laid back gaming experience - short and sweet, and engaging while it lasted. I certainly enjoyed my time with it, even if it ended fast.

Petit jeu d'énigmes, d'une durée de vie de 5h.
L'univers est tout choupi, c'est tout calme et relaxant, et très bien animé ; les énigmes globalement faciles se renouvellent bien, sans recyclage.
Donc jeu court, divisé en 3 chapitres, mais agréable (joli DA, ambiance soignée, ...) et bien conçu (level design OK).
Le prix étant bas le rapport qualité/prix est très bon pour les amateurs du genre.

Joué sur SeriesX en mode rétrocompatibilité.
This has to be one of my all time favourite games. As chilled and relaxing as it is stressful and frustrating, it perfect.

Hidden Folks is a hidden gem. When it comes to these type of games, I honestly couldn't tell you how to make a game like this better. It suffers from occasional hiccups and trying to do too much at once (which purists of this genre won't appreciate), but Hidden Folks' charm, atmosphere, music, wit, and style trumps over anything similar.

Jolie histoire, qui alterne une dizaine de fois entre deux phases :
- une phase 'journal intime', avec quasiment pas de gameplay mais une présentation artistique au top, qui parle de la vie personnelle du personnage et façon très touchante.
- une phase 'jeu de plateforme' qui parle de l'histoire d'aventure inventée par le personnage. Le gameplay est simple, sans difficulté, et la narration par notre personnage continue (à la façon d'un typing chronicles), par contre c'est un peu gnangnant 'mon premier roman d'ado'. La gestion de 'mots' sur les décors est intéressante sans être foufou et sauve cette partie.
Au final un jeu agréable à parcourir, avec une préférence pour la partie journal intime artistiquement très développée, l'histoire de la partie 'jeu' étant trop enfantine et typée 'mon premier roman' au niveau de la narration.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass

Pra quem gosta de jogo com uma boa história e vários turnpoints, Beacon Pines é esse jogo.
Com uma arte visual diferenciada e bonita, uma gameplay simples mas  com uma narrativa que envolve diversas decisões para se achar o caminho correto. Beacon Pines te envolve de maneira que você precisa saber o que realmente está acontecendo.

Petit jeu mignon d'aventure en 2D, avec de jolis graphismes et une petite historique sympa.
L'intérêt vient des embranchements de l'histoire dont les branches se débloquent avec des badges que l'on débloque au fur et à mesure ; ca reprend le principe des "livres dont vous êtes le héro".
Tout est en anglais, parfois pas si simple que ça, mais ça passe pour un adulte ; dommage car le jeu est assez enfantin et cible aussi les plus jeunes.

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

What an interesting game. Nothing too out of this world, this game is essentially a point and click game, if even that, but the humor and visuals, both extremely grounded in this parody of northern England it presents while also being a psychodelic, metaphorical nightmare, make the game an extremely unique experience that I enjoyed a lot.

It's not a game for everyone, but it's a darn well-made game.

reviews.title: This is one of those games where no matter where you go - successfully flow in the direction of the plot, it`s linear + 1-button, but very funny (18+), with an interesting style ala `Frobisher Says!`

reviewText.content:
like watching some Netflix cartoon series that doesn't shy away from black humor and 18+ hints in lines and signs, although it's more of a collection of loosely related sketches, where the maximum sudden absurdity occurs, personally I laughed 7 times, but two jokes was repeated 2 times; English is very difficult with some incredible accents, so the presence of subtitles is pleasing.
Gameplay literally 2 buttons - jump and hit (pokeformer), practically no sections where it was necessary to at least combine buttons; We control a strange pokerface very small man, and every normal sized character we meet asks us to launch/bring/find something, and we just smash everything with 1 click and willy-nilly this is the solution to each problem, that is, as linear as possible, wherever you go - you always successfully "flow" in the direction of the plot, although from the middle of the game we will have to backtrack a little along the same routes, yes, new secrets for achievements always appear in the city, you can "knock out" new lines from the residents, but still a little "stifled", the game almost turns into a classic quest "pixel hunting" in the end, but doesn`t have time, the total duration is 2-3 hours, optimal for such a thorough concept.

😊 𝗦𝘂𝗯 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝘆 𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺`𝘀 𝗖𝘂𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗼𝗿`𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝗴𝗲: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550
//
Прекрасная рисовка аля "Frobisher Says!" с Playstation Vita, в Стиме до сих пор не так уж и много подобных игр, в отличии от "Гуся" - это прям качественная британская комедия, как посмотреть какой-нибудь анимационный сериал Нетфликса, не стесняющийся чёрного юмора и 18+ намёков в репликах и надписях, хотя это скорее набор не особо связанных скетчей, в которых внезапно происходит самое асбурдное что могло произойти, лично я раз 7 смеялся, но правда 2 раза шутка повторялась; Английский очень сложный с какими-то невероятными акцентами, так что радует наличие русских субтитров.
Геймплейно буквально 2 кнопки - прыжок и удар (тыкалкоформер), практически никаких секций, где надо было хотя-бы скомбинировать кнопки; Управляем странным покерфейс оченьмаленьким человечком, а каждый встречаемый персонаж обычных размеров просит нас что-то запустить/принести/найти, а мы просто колошматим всё 1 нажатием и волей-неволей это является решением каждой проблемы, то есть максимально линейно, куда бы ты не пошёл - ты всегда удачно "течёшь" по направлению сюжета, хотя с середины игры нам придётся немного побэктречить по одним и тем же маршрутам, да, в городе всегда появляются новые приколюхи для достижений, можно "повыбивать" новые реплики с жителей, но всё же немного "поддушило", игра чуть ли не превращается в почти классический квестовый "пиксельхантинг", но не успевает, общая продолжительность - оптимальные для такого тщательного концепта 2-3 часа.

The characters were funny, the game was unique and quintessentially British. 

You see enough of the characters to build an attachment to them, but aren't forced to spend too much time with anyone so that they become annoying.

The comedy in the game is absurd, and very much in line with early 2000s British TV comedies.

One of the scariest games out there, it does everything right.  Great story that pulls you in and makes you want to find out more.  Amazing atmosphere - sounds and visuals.  It really knows how to make things creepy without overdoing it.  Having to manually open doors while being chased really gets the adrenaline up. But I love that most of it is exploring and figuring out how to get to the next area.

reviews.title: ravendoom_2023's review of Amnesia: The Dark Descent

reviewText.content:
Amnesia: The Dark Descent, developed by Frictional Games, stands as a true masterpiece in the realm of survival horror gaming. Released in 2010, it redefined the genre with its intense atmosphere, innovative gameplay mechanics, and deeply immersive storytelling, cementing its place as one of the most terrifying and influential horror experiences of its time.

The game places players in the shoes of Daniel, an amnesiac who wakes up in the eerie halls of Brennenburg Castle, clueless about his past and the horrors that await him. Armed with nothing but a lantern and the instinct to survive, players must navigate the darkness while struggling to maintain their sanity.

One of the game's most brilliant aspects lies in its psychological horror. The atmospheric design, chilling sound effects, and subtle psychological manipulations conspire to create a sense of dread that gnaws at players' minds long after they've put down the controller. Amnesia expertly employs a unique "sanity" system, where witnessing horrifying events or staying in the dark for too long causes Daniel's sanity to wane. This, in turn, distorts the player's perception of reality, making them question what is real and what is a manifestation of Daniel's unraveling mind.

The gameplay mechanics are designed to induce fear and vulnerability effectively. Unlike traditional horror games, Amnesia discourages combat, leaving players with no choice but to run, hide, and outsmart the relentless and otherworldly creatures that stalk them. This emphasis on helplessness intensifies the feeling of terror and survival, making every encounter with the unknown a heart-pounding experience.

Beyond its terrifying gameplay, Amnesia: The Dark Descent boasts an intriguing narrative that unfolds through the discovery of journal entries, notes, and memories scattered throughout the castle. As players piece together Daniel's past, they become deeply invested in the character's journey, further immersing themselves in the chilling atmosphere.

The game's visual and sound design deserve immense praise. The dark and hauntingly beautiful environments, combined with the haunting soundtrack, create an atmosphere of palpable dread. The attention to detail in crafting the castle's architecture and the hauntingly grotesque creatures only adds to the overall sense of immersion.

While Amnesia: The Dark Descent is undeniably a gripping and unforgettable horror experience, it may not be suitable for all players. Its intense and psychologically taxing nature may be too much for those sensitive to horror or jump scares.

In conclusion, Amnesia: The Dark Descent is a true tour de force in horror gaming. Its atmospheric brilliance, psychological terror, and innovative gameplay mechanics set a new standard for the genre. If you're looking for a deeply immersive and terrifying gaming experience that will keep you on the edge of your seat, prepare to enter the darkness of Amnesia - you won't be disappointed.

What this game gets right is that creepy atmosphere, having to manage limited resources and seeing some truly messed up things. This is illustrated very well with the sanity mechanic where your character can't even look at any of the enemies without having a nervous breakdown, or seeing things that aren't really there if your sanity level is too low. Couple that with how light is your most valuable resource, through tinderboxes to light torches and candles or having to find oil for your lantern. Its just all the ingredients that make this a fantastic horror game. The Soundtrack as well is fantastic with some great themes. The puzzles as well are very good and I loved the very Resident Evil style approach of having to combine items in your inventory to solve most of them.

I also quite enjoyed the story, as it a mystery in the beginning but as you slowly uncover what the protagonist and antagonist were up to before hand, and their relationship, it becomes a lot deeper and very disturbing. The story was pretty cool and had a lot of fantasy vibes to it by the end.

Only real issues I had was not the story itself, but more just how it was delivered. There are no NPCs to have face to face conversations with for the majority of the game, so often you'll come into rooms and the game does this thing where the screen gets a dark filter on it, and you hear voice over to serve as a flashback. During these times your movement is slowed down and you just have to sit and listen until its over. Its an okay storytelling device but after a while it got annoying. I much prefer to listen to voice over while I'm playing normally like in the Bioshock games. There are a lot of notes to read but I didn't have an issue with it since the majority of them are voiced, with only a handful requiring you to actually read them.

The other issue is the enemy AI can be a bit dumb. Since there's no combat you have to hide from enemies, but most of them were never really a threat, as they always make a loud noise whenever they spawn in, to which you can just run back to a previous room, and hide in a corner until the enemy despawns which most of the time happens pretty quickly. I was almost never discovered other then one time where I tried to run past one of them (and died), or if it was a scripted sequence.

I've been a fan of the series for almost two decades now, from that fateful day in elementary school when I picked up a copy of Pokemon Emerald. This game feels like the culmination and peak of the series, everything I've ever dreamed of when I was a wee lass with my Gameboy. This is a step in the right direction and hopefully the beginning of more games in this same approach. Began on 28 Feb Jan and couldn't put the game down until 1 Feb, logging in 44hrs (although I couldn't defeat the "true" boss.)

I really enjoyed Arceus and it was a refreshing update to the Pokemon franchise. I really hope they bring a lot of the mechanics into other core Pokemon games, or at the very least make more Legends games!

reviews.title: dekeffer's review of Pokémon Legends: Arceus

reviewText.content: ik vind het een leuke game die je ook na het uitspelen kan blijven doorspelen en niet alleen door de zij opdrachten die je kan doen maar ook door het verzamelen van nieuwe pokemon die je ook weer kan verder trainen!!!

reviews.title: maxyfran73's review of Pokémon Legends: Arceus

reviewText.content: Honestly, some of the best fun I've had with a pokemon game in a while. The way in which you capture and research pokemons is genuinely interesting, and the world as well as the plot are really fun to walk through; an excellent mix of old and new ideas coalescing to create a really a vibrant world and an overall great experience. I think the battle system's a tad flawed, although I can't blame it too much; it definitely was a gambit, to add the styles, and I think it worked decently well. I think it has some issues, especially regarding grinding, which feels more counterintuitive than in other games, and the characters, which are rather forgettable, if not annoying, but past that, it's a solid entry with a good premise that I enjoyed a lot. Def worth playing.

Pokémon Legends Arceus makes a lot of changes to the core Pokémon formula, following what feels like a natural evolution for the franchise that fans have been envisioning and waiting for for so long. A common complaint many people have with open world games is that there isn't a whole lot to do in the vast spaces these games tend to provide. And while it's true there isn't much to fill the world, it honestly doesn't matter. The Pokémon, environment, and crafting materials are more than enough to give the player plenty to do. The mechanics that Gamefreak has introduced are absolutely brilliant and are the highlight of the entire game. Despite the story being quite boring and poorly written, it has never been more fun to battle and catch Pokémon. The UI is informative, looks sleek, and is well designed. However, the organization of the menus is atrocious. Why the menus are spread out over 3 buttons is a mystery to me. There are a lot of things this game does right, and a lot it does either ok or just wrong. Even elements of the story are very interesting, but the way its told is so bland and boring. One thing I really don't get is why so many textures are ugly and blurry. I just don't understand if that was a stylistic choice or if someone messed up the texture import settings or what. Regardless, the game is still fun to play and many of the texture issues aren't present while out in the field catching Pokémon, which you will spend most of your time doing. If Gamefreak took the time to refine and polish everything here, Legends Arceus would itself be a legendary game.

To start off with the visuals. The game reminded me a lot of the Resident Evil 1 remake in its lighting and visual design of the environments. The fact that the game takes place mostly in a mansion definitely adds to that and I quite enjoyed it. The only thing that isn't the best are the character models that look a little too uncanny valley, but it is a AA title so I'm not going to knock it too much. While the game makes you think it will be like Resident Evil it actually quickly turns more into Silent Hill as you unlock the later areas with blood soaked walls and an excessive amount of gore in the environment. You always just feel uneasy as you're moving through the rooms, like something is going to pop out at you and with the fixed camera angles, it adds to the uncertainty as you don't know what will be waiting for you in a room when you first enter it. While I tend to prefer the over the shoulder, third person or first person camera styles in horror games generally, I do admire how they used the fixed camera angles here and some of the angles they chose when in certain rooms added to that uneasy feel. Kind of like the bathroom scene at the beginning of Silent Hill 2.

The atmosphere has this oppressive feel as you feel trapped in this large mansion with no one to really help you. You will find plenty of dead bodies lying on the floor or on operating tables throughout the mansion/hospital as well as blood and guts in various corners. You can clearly see the bodies have been butchered and messed with, making you wander about who or what exactly did this. The game also features a couple of jump scares throughout the game and while I am usually not a fan of jump scares personally, but they were pretty well done here, happening when you least expect them. One of them in particular definitely gave me a jolt when it happened.

Next we have the music and sound design which is really well done overall. The OST has a lot of beautiful piano melodies while also having a lot of screeching intense tracks that really build up the games atmosphere and make you feel like you're in a hostile environment. The sounds the monsters make are disturbing and the loud moans they scream out when you kill them really sends a shiver down you're spine. The voice acting though isn't the best with their only being a few characters with dialogue, including your main character. While I would have preferred better voice acting, it added to the nostalgia a little as these types of games never had the best voice acting to begin with. The sound design overall is very well done.

Moving onto gameplay, it plays very much like Resident Evil and Silent Hill, with its gameplay loop of exploration, combat and puzzles. I enjoyed exploring the mansion with all of its nooks and cranny's, finding secret passages and plenty of things in the environment. The puzzles were enjoyable too with some pretty brain buster ones to solve. While it does get a bit much towards the end, I found the puzzles to be another great aspect of the game. The combat plays very much like I said before, akin to Resident Evil and Silent Hill in that you ready your weapons before attacking. The weapons you find feel very makeshift and unconventional because there are no traditional weapons lying around. You a get a nail gun in place of a pistol, a shotgun which is literally just some pipes duck taped together, an electric lance that can be used to shock enemies from close range and a good old fashioned crowbar. Unlike Silent Hill, you can't really get through the game with just the crowbar as most of the enemies are melee based in their attacks, and your character can only take a few hits before dying. The best strategy is to often shoot the enemies and when their down, hit them with your crowbar to finish them off. The weapons overall felt good to use, especially the shogun which has a nice punch to it whenever you fire. Your inventory is also thankfully unlimited and with clear categories of key items, resources and files. I also like how the map of the mansion is an actual physical map you have to select in your inventory and rotated around to read. While the map does mark some key items, I feel like it could have also marked things like ammo or health items you missed which is a QOL feature that many modern horror games use.

The enemy design is another thing I want to talk about before the story section. The enemies all look like Frankenstein like monsters with various blades and spikes stuck to their arms and bodies. At the same time their torsos and faces all look butchered and mangled like their barely holding together physically. While the various enemy types look samey after a while, towards the end they do introduce some new ones that look very different which I appreciated. Some enemy types feel redundant though like the wall enemies who have such giant blades for arms that it doesn't take a rocket scientist to figure out that you shouldn't go passed them. Dealing with them is as simple as walking up next to them and just hitting them with you're crowbar until they die, and they can't fight back from that angle, so their inclusion in the game feels very pointless. About halfway through the game they introduce a stalker enemy. The design just looks really lame and I didn't find it intimidating at all. You do find out later the story reason, why the stalker enemy is there which I won't spoil, but overall it just felt redundant from a gameplay perspective. The best thing to do is when you enter a room and hear the stalker enemies theme is to just go out and come back in again, as they usually will disappear. It just a waste of resources fighting it.

Finally we can talk about the story. Caroline receives a weird photograph of two twin girls, addressed to her. She travels to the mansion from where it was sent only for her to be knocked out and then wakes up in a bath tub naked and hooked up to a machine. She must now find the missing girls and escape! As you explore the mansion you will find dairy entries and files from the family members that used to live in this mansion. The story they tell is very sad and disturbing and it adds context to much of what is going on. The notes are short and don't feel long winded to read, so I recommend reading all of them as it enhances the story overall. It gave me a lot of Silent Hill 3 vibes as you learn about a cult that controlled this family and their intentions that are evil in nature. Overall, I really loved the story as it took elements from many horror games but did its own thing with it. It makes me excited for the sequel they announced and how that game could play out.

Never before had an Indie game been so hyped on Twitter as SBS&SEP. The game itself, once released, followed through with a longtail of mysterious clues as to how to unlock more mysterious clues. What actually manifested on screen was a somewhat melancholy mood, but also a game that had very little substance. Superbrothers has fewer enemy encounters than you have fingers on your hands, and just a few tricky puzzles. The flavor text is very flavorful, though. The music is pretty flavorful as well. There's definitely some sworcery going on to get so much enjoyment from a game that doesn't have very much going on in it.

I rarely find myself gravitating towards the puzzle genre. While I’m fine with them breaking up the action, I generally stay away from games primarily focused on hurting my head. Well, that was the case, until I picked up Luna: The Shadow Dust. This 2D point-and-click puzzle adventure is a tale full of mystery and wonder, presented in beautifully hand-drawn graphics and animations that I adored.

Luna: The Shadow Dust presents a very curious world. You begin in a Dark environment, that looks almost like a desert. While you explore, you meet a ghost who guides you to a Tower where the rest of your journey takes place.

Along the way, you meet a small furry companion who helps you progress through anything that stands in your way. Slowly but surely, you reveal the wonders of this strange place, all done through cutscenes without dialogue. This creates an interesting sense of immersion for the player, and embodies the saying “show, don’t tell”.
The game plays in a very “off-handed” manner, where player interactions and puzzle design detail the narrative. While this way of storytelling works for some games, I had trouble trying to piece together this world. The puzzles give you glimpses into a culture that values art and music, a land full of magic and mystery. However, I left with only a small understanding of what this world has to offer.

The biggest bonus to this kind of storytelling is being able to display the bond and connection between two characters. As you progress the story, the bond between our two main protagonists strengthens. The way their interactions pair with one another to make solving puzzles feel natural adds to the game’s enjoyment.
One of the major features of the game is the stunning hand-drawn graphics and animation. These animations have been drawn frame by frame and it shows during gameplay. This level of detail creates smooth, beautiful looking animations that helped tremendously with the game’s immersion. Even at only 12 frames per second, all of the walking, climbing, and interaction animations are impressive.

The soundtrack is also favorable. The music is light and lovingly composed. It wraps you in a world filled with mystery and intrigue as it is winds-focused, with a strong emphasis on flute, as well as harp melodies. The music overall adds character to a game that has a lot to show for itself.
Now, what about the gameplay and the puzzles? Honestly, it’s what you would expect from a classic point-and-click adventure, clicking to move around the level to interact with objects is what you’ll find. This is standard fare, and I personally found no issues at all with this gameplay. It was simple and straight to the point, and playing as both characters is fluid with the press of a button.

In regards to the puzzle design, I found a lot of them to be entertaining, as it becomes more challenging as you progress. It’s the kind of puzzles that forces you to take some time to plan out an approach. There are unique ways to get through levels, such as having you mess with the lights in a room, alter color patterns, and many others. Overall, it is an experience that is worth having.

Luna: The Shadow Dust is a nice nod to classic point-and-click puzzle games. Everything melds together beautifully, and it provided me with a solid puzzle experience. Despite my aversion to this genre, I found the experience pleasant overall. Some of the puzzles left me stumped, but after getting through them I felt accomplished in their defeat.

Gorgeous looking game. They nailed norse fantasy setting. Great story and strong characters. The combat is fun with decent depth but not very varied so I would get bored of it on a second playthrough. I really loved making decisions for my caravan and trying to balance supplies, morale and combat, but it did feel like I was never in any danger of actually losing. That said, its an amazing story experience. Can't wait to play the second game.

Music and visual design are pretty great and fits the setting, voice acting for almost all characters are exceptional. Even the dialogues feel natural and well written but makes it all the more surprising that the whole experience never quite hits the mark. 
The story moves at quite a fast pace and thus you don't get enough time to soak in the atmosphere. Despite the well written dialogue, the character doesn't feel interesting. Also whatever "gameplay" is there might as well be non existent. The game expects you to do 2 playthrough, but I never felt compelled to play more after I got my first ending. 

I feel this would have been better as an animated movie.

Cool but, their managing sucks. The game itself is really awesome. Can't find a replacement. And this holds Blizzard's basic stance to their game. Easy to access, hard to play great. But if you work hard enough, everyone can go up to GM or Top 500. I myself was typical Gold on Season 2, become Top 500 on Season 21.

This game is so cute. I dont know why it has a score this low here - but personally i really enjoyed it.
The concept its very simple, you are an anthropomorphic bird who needs to reach the top of a mountain, and to do so you'll have to take a short hike. Or that's what your aunt said, at least.
You are going to walk a lot (duh), explore, and make some friends along the way. 
Think it like a veeery small Breath of the wild x Animal Crossing.
You have to kind of like the genre, i guess. Which i do. eheh

In conclusion i think that it has veeery nice concept, and hypothetically, if expanded, (both sidequests-wise and world-wise) It could turn into one of those amazing game where you lose track of the time, but it's not, so it's just a short game, about a short hike.

The title says it all, It's game for people who want a simple short experience. 
	
	The art is cute and beautiful. The 3ds games influenced It's visuals, looking like a low-res zelda game. It uses a pixelated vilter to simulate a 3ds game, but the devs give you the choice to turn it of, although they don't recommend it. I'm glad the devs gave us the option to turn it off, although it'snt recommended by them.
	
	The soundtrack is also amazing, giving a good atmosphere for the game. The dynamic soundtrack gives a good amount of variation, so you don't feel sick of hearing the same song.
	
	The core mechanic in the game is hiking. Your main goal is to climb to the top of the mountain. The task itself is quite easy, being able to it in less than a couple of hours. The main thing is that will probably want to explore the island, collect everything and meet It's people. I'ts quite refreshing, it doens't feel like most games that have a artificial way to increase It's length.
	
	You will meet a lot of funny characters asking for help, inviting you for events inside the game and so on. Everything in this game have e upbeat tone, like a minigame that you can't lose because you are both playing for a common goal. You can also chill fishing while hearing the game's soundtrack. The upbeat tone also goes to the game's challenge, having no death penalty. The challenge itself is the climb and to find hidden treasures through the island.
	I recommend this game for people who are'nt familiar with videogames in general, or people who want to have a short experience. Be sure to exaust the dialog with the npcs, sometimes even if you already met them.
	
	A Short Hike was a impressive game that has a beautiful art as well as Its sountrack. The npcs could be more well developed, but I understand as the game's goal is to be short.

reviews.title: Un petit jeu tout mignon tout calme :)

reviewText.content:
Pendant une poignée d'heure ce jeu zen propose d'escalader une montage, la "capacité d'escalade" étant proportionnelle au nombre de plumes du personnage, à gagner autour de l'ile via des quêtes secondaires.
La direction artistique fait mouche pour ce type de jeu un peu enfantin, la maniabilité et planer sont très agréables.
Pas de point de vie, on ne se blesse pas et on ne meurt pas, que de l'aventure zen.
Niveau prix idéalement à prendre entre 3 et 5 euros max (perso jeu gratuit via les offres hebdo Epic Store sur PC)

reviews.title: amsandor's review of A Short Hike

reviewText.content: A Short Hike is a lovingly animated little game about a young bird on a camping trip with their aunt. The game has a sole focus; climbing to the top of the Provincial Parks highest peak. Along the way, you can help local campers and citizens with tasks and engage in fun exploration mini games that reward the player with a stronger flight ability. The gorgeous animation and engaging narrative, with the added bonus of some very free movement, makes this quite the fun little title. This is a short and sweet title that I immensely enjoyed over a sitting, and I can easily recommend this to those looking for a laid back gaming experience on a rainy day.

A short hike is a game about not letting the stress and anxiety take over you, simply going for a hike, exploring, enjoying the view, meeting people, making friends, playing, racing, and enjoying life.

reviews.title: yorendo's review of A Short Hike

reviewText.content: A Short Hike is a game that lets you take a break from saving the world, managing cities, or competing. It's a simple but well-thought-out experience that doesn't overstay its welcome.

reviews.title: pacoliyo420's review of A Short Hike

reviewText.content: Short but sweet. The pixel art style suits it perfectly. It gives off the same warmth as Animal Crossing or Stardew Valley, but condensed into a couple of hours. A game with soul. Not much more to say. Perfect for spending an afternoon.

You can probably spend several hundred hours easily if you like its game-play. I used to play the original N years ago, and I was very happy to see it had a 2015 sequel. It is much faster than I remembered, but also very polished. I love the simple game mechanics and controls, which are easy to learn, but difficult to master. The game gets very tough very easy and you have to get good to enjoy it, but when you do, it's a blast.

A rare gem. 
If you're really into classic metroidvania and/or platformers - this is exactly for you.
Even if you're not - this will be very pleasant new experience.

Jawbreaking gameplay, crushing bones of your enemies, putting them ouf ot their misery.
Different choices, different endings, replayability, retro/nostalgic music, cutscenes, gore, jumping over obstacles, bloody fights - this game has it all.

You're playing as Alcedor, who returned to his homeland and finds it in really bad state - unholiness, death, occultists and death everywhere.

Good amount of interesting quests for you to decide how to accomplish them - want to be a good guy? Or do you want to be the bad guy, who carves his path with blood and guts?

You can improve your skills, find new equipment, new abilites, decide which side you want to help.

What about endings?
There is an interesting one. How about getting into different time and using a big gun to destroy final foe?

Cocoon is definitely one of the best indie games to come out in 2023. With its marvellous game design, soothing synth background music and fun yet simple puzzles, it is a recommended game for folks who enjoy playing games to relax. As much as I loved almost everything about Cocoon, there were some pointers due to which I was still on the fence about whether it really deserves a high score. No story or non-defined motive and it's short gameplay time, you can wait for a sale to pick it up (or play it on Game Pass).

reviewText.content: good game, fun to play and verry cool for the people who like MHA

My Hero Ultra Rumble is the latest addition to the ever-expanding lineup of My Hero Academia video games, and it's safe to say that it doesn't disappoint. As a dedicated fan of the series, I couldn't wait to dive into the world of quirks, heroes, and villains in this new release. While it may not be perfect, My Hero Ultra Rumble offers an engaging experience that will keep fans and newcomers alike entertained.

Graphics and Presentation (4/5):

Visually, My Hero Ultra Rumble delivers the vibrant and dynamic style fans have come to expect from the franchise. The character models are faithfully recreated, with each hero and villain exuding the same charm and personality seen in the anime and manga. The environments are well-designed and packed with details that immerse you further into the My Hero Academia universe. However, there are some occasional frame rate drops during intense battles that could use some optimization.

Gameplay (4.5/5):

Where My Hero Ultra Rumble truly shines is in its gameplay. The core of the game revolves around fast-paced, arena-style battles that capture the essence of the series perfectly. The combat system is easy to pick up but offers depth for those who want to master it. Each character has a unique set of moves and quirks, and you'll find yourself experimenting with different heroes to find your playstyle.

The inclusion of various game modes adds to the game's replayability. The story mode, while not groundbreaking, offers a satisfying narrative that follows the events of the series. Mission mode provides diverse challenges to tackle, and the online multiplayer mode lets you test your skills against other players. However, it would be nice to have more offline multiplayer options for local play.

Story and Fan Service (3.5/5):

My Hero Ultra Rumble attempts to retell the story of My Hero Academia, which is a tall order given the complexity of the source material. While it does a decent job of summarizing key moments, it feels rushed at times, and newcomers might find it hard to fully grasp the narrative. However, for fans of the series, it's a fun way to revisit familiar events and see them from a new perspective.

The game excels in its fan service, with a wide roster of characters to choose from, including both heroes and villains. Playing as your favorite characters and unleashing their quirks is immensely satisfying, and the attention to detail in their moves and abilities is commendable.

Audio (4/5):

The soundtrack of My Hero Ultra Rumble captures the energy and excitement of the series, enhancing the overall experience. Voice acting, too, is top-notch, featuring the original Japanese voice cast. The only minor drawback is the limited number of voice lines during battles, which can become repetitive after extended play.

reviews.title: butter_dawgs's review of My Hero Ultra Rumble

reviewText.content:
My Hero Ultra Rumble is the latest addition to the ever-expanding lineup of My Hero Academia video games, and it's safe to say that it doesn't disappoint. As a dedicated fan of the series, I couldn't wait to dive into the world of quirks, heroes, and villains in this new release. While it may not be perfect, My Hero Ultra Rumble offers an engaging experience that will keep fans and newcomers alike entertained.

Graphics and Presentation (4/5):

Visually, My Hero Ultra Rumble delivers the vibrant and dynamic style fans have come to expect from the franchise. The character models are faithfully recreated, with each hero and villain exuding the same charm and personality seen in the anime and manga. The environments are well-designed and packed with details that immerse you further into the My Hero Academia universe. However, there are some occasional frame rate drops during intense battles that could use some optimization.

Gameplay (4.5/5):

Where My Hero Ultra Rumble truly shines is in its gameplay. The core of the game revolves around fast-paced, arena-style battles that capture the essence of the series perfectly. The combat system is easy to pick up but offers depth for those who want to master it. Each character has a unique set of moves and quirks, and you'll find yourself experimenting with different heroes to find your playstyle.

The inclusion of various game modes adds to the game's replayability. The story mode, while not groundbreaking, offers a satisfying narrative that follows the events of the series. Mission mode provides diverse challenges to tackle, and the online multiplayer mode lets you test your skills against other players. However, it would be nice to have more offline multiplayer options for local play.

Story and Fan Service (3.5/5):

My Hero Ultra Rumble attempts to retell the story of My Hero Academia, which is a tall order given the complexity of the source material. While it does a decent job of summarizing key moments, it feels rushed at times, and newcomers might find it hard to fully grasp the narrative. However, for fans of the series, it's a fun way to revisit familiar events and see them from a new perspective.

The game excels in its fan service, with a wide roster of characters to choose from, including both heroes and villains. Playing as your favorite characters and unleashing their quirks is immensely satisfying, and the attention to detail in their moves and abilities is commendable.

Audio (4/5):

The soundtrack of My Hero Ultra Rumble captures the energy and excitement of the series, enhancing the overall experience. Voice acting, too, is top-notch, featuring the original Japanese voice cast. The only minor drawback is the limited number of voice lines during battles, which can become repetitive after extended play.

reviews.title: reaperll1crimson's review of My Hero Ultra Rumble

reviewText.content: it's a gooood game i guess with your friends hope they add more villians though

This game is a rare occasion. Usually, when I see a game with a potential to be a masterpiece but failing at it I get mightily upset, but this time that is not the case. Spiritfarer is just good enough to forgive it all it's lost potential. Not a masterpiece, but the next best thing.

It's quite useless to point out it's every strong point (main of which is it's graphic design – it's an outstandingly beautiful piece of game art), so I'd rather just point out it's main failure, and it is narrative design. Given the (small) number of characters, they are very sparingly detailed, and involvement with them is suffering for this. There's simply too little narrative content per character, and given it's small volume, it's weak interaction with the rest of the game is especially noticeable.

However, despite weak overall narrative, you shouldn't beleive some things you may read about the game's ending. The ending is actually good, if not great. I'd dare anyone to make a better one, and even would bet money on their failure.

1. GAMEPLAY
	Left, right and jump is all you need to know control wise, for the whole of the game. Boss wise is the same way excluding jumping sometimes. Making sure you jump and move to the Electric rhythm that the stages give you is a great feeling, especially when the music starts off with just a few beats and hitting checkpoints gives the music more life, adding even more technologic groove for your ears to hear. From point a to point b there really isn't much fault and learning the timing for the level plus the boss is a fun time and great accomplishment. Then heading into the mirror levels, which is the previous levels with the added factor of new colors and one life. A testament to trial and error and getting *gud*.
	
	2. STORY
	I...Hmm, well the story of 140 is nonexistent. But for this game it really doesn't need that, though if you wish to have some sort of story for this game then you play a transforming geometric shape on a stroll through some dope electronic music. 
	
	3. SOUND
	Another section where everything slaps really, the music is beat-tastic, and the little bleeps and bloops from movements you do is par for the course. The low hum when you step into a checkpoint or level and the after affect sound is a great little transition sound effect. Not much here again to talk about besides simple things.
	
	4. MUSIC
	Now for the heavy hitter in this section! The music is top notch, the opening track for the startup of the game is a great start to what you'll hear and get into, Once into a level I enjoy the fact as to how the music presents itself with just basic notes that coincide with one another until you checkpoints that fills the void with more and more fantastic beatsies. Each level has a great track and each boss has that same feeling too. Besides the *Title* track the first level Pt.1 and Pt.1B are fan-fucking-tastic, especially when it hits you with that consistent stabbing notes at the end of Pt.1 to lead into Pt.1B. The wubs and kick basses in Pt.1B are a nice groove when "shooting" the moving sphere Boss and that disorienting note that hits when the music gets sinister and calm. All in all I could go on and on about every single track in this game about what parts I enjoy the most and make a list on which tracks I like from least to best but you're picking up what I'm putting down, a masterpiece electronic soundtrack.
	
	5. ART DIRECTION
	Geometry, geometry everywhere. From your little shapeshifting…shape, to the cool backgrounds of each level that gives you those sweet blocky soundwaves. Again in this section there really isn't that much to talk about, the music fits perfectly with the aesthetic of geometry and nothing really is out of the ordinary besides Bosses giving different type of gameplay.

I absolutely love this game. The music is astounding, and the art style is unique, yet pleasing to the eye. The whole game provides a proper challenge, never too easy or too hard. I still have yet to beat the mirror levels, but here's to hoping!

Finished 22 April 2021, obtaining all the endings and True Ending, as well as replaying some routes on Revelation mode. Played it after Gnosia, since I saw on reviews that they had the same werewolf/ mafia themes.

This isn't a game for everyone. I know because my boyfriend hates this VN with a passion. But I found it really rewarding in a manner in which I hadn't seen in a while. Even then, however, the game is not without its flaw.

The main plot and the concept of the game (Werewolf game and the loops) are the main charm of the game, and in this regard, the game has a very well defined, well crafted mechanical execution. The story, at a glance, is really damn good as well (Until the ending anyhow...) but the characters, especially the main ones, are hard to love at best, and consistently pulling the game down at worst.

As an experience and a VN, I highly recommend the game. I think playing the full game once will not waste your time, even if you don't end up liking the thing. A second replay on revelation mode/the extra content might, however, as one of my harshest critiques of it is that a lot of the things that would make the plot/characters better/bearable are locked behind new game plus.

A turn based roguelike that feels as if each of the team had an idea for a game mechanic and they decided to put them all in - and I enjoy them all. 
The combat has a timeline to show when attacks will happen, if the player attacks before an enemy some attacks can push the enemy attack back as far as the next turn. This is key for negating damage. You can enter 3 areas per day and then at night recover around a campfire. Here you can also build relationships to improve stats, unlocks combo attacks and between certain characters become lovers which will unlock a new character that can be used in subsequent runs.
This is a game I will get 100s of hours out of.

A good RPG Roguelite mashup with nice visuals.
However, the Game Overall wasnt for me. The meat of the Game its Combat system, which is interesting and allows for some tactical Battles.
The Area between the Fights is sadly mostly empty. It only serves as a node based map with only one or two Points of interest per node, but disguises itself as an Open Area.
I Had the expectation, Like in other Roguelites, that an Single Run will be rather short, but in this Game a Run can be 5-9h!
I think this Game would have been better as a Story based RPG with No Roguelites Elements. Each Run can feels repetitive and feels far too Long for me. Therefore I Had to abandon the Game.

TL;DR

One of the best modernized SNES-era-JRPGs out there. Comes very close to a masterpiece, but falls just short.

General Thoughts

This is everything I wanted FFXV to be. This game is a shining example of how to take an SNES-era style JRPG, bring it up to date with modern JRPG mechanics and mix in a few Western-RPG game mechanics. It's a perfect mix of charming story telling from Dragon Quest, Sprite/Character art from SNES-era Final Fantasy, Press-turn-like battle system from Shin Megami Tensei, and Class system from Bravely Default. It may seem like I wrote a lot about what I didn't like, but this is I enjoyed the game so much and found that it did things so well that it was obvious to point out where it fell flat.

The Good

Graphics and art style

I'm always a fan of very stylized graphics/art style (Wind Waker, DQ8), as I believe these hold up much better than standard graphics/art style. The character sprites look great, monster and boss art is interesting, environments are beautiful.

Battle system

The battle system as a whole is really satisfying. While I do think it is a step down from Bravely Default, I still think it's a great take on a modern turn based system. The boost/break system allows for some really challenging and almost puzzle-like boss fights - where you have to balance between using your BP to break the boss faster or save it to deal out the most damage after you break the boss.

Quest system

As someone who gets overwhelmed by all the quests and collect-a-thons in modern console games (Wither 3, Assassin's Creed, Horizon Zero Dawn), I found it really refreshing how bare bones the quest system is. I love that there's no way points to lead me to the next step in the quest. I love that you actually have to read what the NPCs are saying to know what to do for the quest. I love that you have to think about which character's field ability you have to use to solve a particular quest.

Class system

I'm a sucker for games with classes (like FF5, DQ7, Bravely Default, Etrian Odyssey) and this game does not disappoint. There's not as many classes as in something like Bravely Default, and you can't customize each character as much (you can only change their sub class and 4 passives), but the classes are well balanced and each one is useful in battle in some way. There's still enough customization that you can build your party to defeat challenging bosses in different ways to capitalize on your party's synergies.

The Not So Good

No overarching or central plot

Story-wise, the main problem with the game is that there is not really a central plot. The driving force of the game comes from the player's interest in the 8 mini-stories. The mini-stories are not terrible, but they are not great - and most definitely not on par with even the side stories of characters in games like FFVI or DQ7. For people who value a great narrative, I could see how this could be a huge turnoff. Unless people are drawn to the gameplay mechanics, I imagine most people will just complete the stories of the few characters they like.

Main characters don't interact in a meaningful way

Plot and character interaction often go hand-in-hand. The fact that there is no central story to bring all these characters together means that they don't have the chance to have arcs together. The force of change in each character is the series of events that happen to them in their mini-stories. There are some mini-scenes similar in form to skits from the Tales series, but they are often only between two characters, we never learn anything new about the characters, and even the characters don't really learn anything new from these interactions.

No boosting into debt

You start off each battle with 1 BP and you can only boost by as much BP you have. This is my main major complaint with the battle system. I really wish that they would have taken the Brave/Default system from Bravely Default. This makes random encounters a slog, since you can't just 4x boost every character and defeat the enemies in one turn as you can in Bravely Default.

No encounter rate slider

One thing that I really would have loved is some way to completely turn off the random encounters - ideally the encounter rate slider from the Bravely Series. There is a character ability to reduce the encounter rate, but I really wish that I could get rid of them completely. I enjoy the environments so much that I really would have liked to walk between most locations, but I found myself fast travelling to avoid random encounters.

No beastiary

There's really no excuse for a modern JRPG to not have a beastiary of some sort. It's good that the enemies have their weaknesses displayed under them in battle, but I would have preferred an in game compendium containing more info about each enemy.

The way H'aanit talks

One of the 8 characters talks in what seems like an attempt at Old English(?) and it just makes things harder to understand and adds nothing to the character. It's enough to make me never use her in my party and only begrudgingly go through her chapters.

End game battles rely on RNG too much

(Note: I'm just getting to the end game, so I may come back and update this)

My main complaint is with how the end game treats physical attackers. So the general strategy against bosses is this: attack their weakness until they break, then unload all your damage. The quickest way to break bosses is with many attacks. The only good passive skills that align with this strategy for a physical attacker are "Second Serving" (50% chance to attack again after a basic attack) and "Patience" (25% chance to act again at the end of a turn). The other way a physical attacker can perform multiple attacks is though boost-attacking or using multi-attack skills like "Thousand Spears" or "Arrowstorm" but these attacks often miss - even with accuracy boosting buffs. This makes fighting bosses very frustrating as I've often found myself failing to break a boss when I was planning to because RNG made me miss more than I expected, or I've been able to save myself by randomly getting an extra action. Living/dying by RNG is never satisfying to me

I have played lots of RPG turn based since final fantasy VIII and Chrono Cross, I had ups and downs till the day I decided to give the Octopath Traveler a try, at this time I never imagined the game could give me anything new, but surprisingly the game is well executed and best designed to give you the joy while playing and keep you on the edge in its storyline and battles, good thing about it is its way of telling the story and keep it simple no matter how things might get complicated, we RPG gamers were craving for this atmosphere in RPG genre since ever, and I assure you that once you finish the first chapter you will want to complete the whole story of the 8 protagonists who really shine each one in his/her own story line.

reviews.title: Un RPG à l'ancienne dans l'esprit des anciens FF et autres références.

reviewText.content:
Le jeu se découpe en deux partie : une première où on va débloquer au fur et à mesure de nos voyages les 8 persos de notre équipe (dont les initiales donnent les 8 lettres OCTOPATH) ; pour chacun des persos on retrouve 4 chapitres sur leur histoire personnelle. Dans cette première partie c'est assez redondant en terme de structure : on lance le chapitre, un donjon, son boss, puis chapitre suivant. Il faut compter facilement 40/60 heures de jeu avec les quêtes annexes pas super palpitantes mais nombreuses et variées.
Une fois ces chapitres passés commence la seconde partie, qui malheureusement n'est pas 'guidée' et où il faut chercher pas soi même. Reste donc à faire des donjons optionnels avec leur boss, les 4 jobs secondaires optionnels pour nos personnages, les quêtes secondaires à terminer, et enfin le donjon final avec huit boss recyclées et le boss final, pour voir la vraie fin du jeu.
Il faudra compter en gros 100 heures pour tout faire sans rusher.

Au final un bon jeu, avec un gameplay end game très plaisant sur les combats une fois les persos bien développés.
Malheureusement le scénario est en retrait, avec une première partie où il n'y a pas d'interaction entre les histoires des personnages qui en plus n'avancent pas vite, et une seconde partie de jeu avec des réponses intéressantes mais expédiées en qq écrans de texte.

Au final un jeu plaisant, mais lent et avec un scénario trop en retrait pour devenir une référence.
A réserver aux amateurs du genre.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Gigantosaurus: The Game

reviewText.content:
I played this game on PC with my children, and we had fun with it. Colourful graphics, fine music and simplistic controls. Four characters to choose, every one of them with an special ability.

A flawed one, but good for the family nonetheless!

Take part in a tale of love and loss in a heart-driven quest to change the past.  Time appears two dimensional but in order to change the past a tangled web of actions and consequences must be navigated carefully, or the past can’t be fixed.  Is it fate, or can fate be changed?

Last Day of June is a beautiful game, full of color and vibrancy, memorable characters, sadness, and love.  Inspired by Steven Wilson’s song “Drive Home” in more ways than one; we take part in an interactive story and try to change the past through various characters intertwined with that fateful day.  The limited amount of characters are styled as what looks like wooden puppets, and the lack of facial expressions or spoken words lends to an interesting style that works very well.

The world of Last Day of June is beautiful, and I found the environment delightful and I eagerly explored every nook and cranny while thoroughly enjoying the scenery. The blurred painting effect of world in the background made the game feel like a dream and was impressive but was sometimes distracting as well.  The music goes very well with the theme and tone of the game with the only problem that I had being the music in the epilogue where a change in musical style from the rest of the game felt a bit jarring.  Additionally, some people may find the game agonizingly repetitive, but this is part of the narrative of the game.  Since there is no skip feature; you will be stuck watching the same scene play out if you messed up somewhere along the road.  This can be annoying but its not a game breaker.

Last Day of June touches on a subject that many of us wish not to think about, but the way the game delves into the subject is impressive and memorable.  The story is deep and told in an interesting way.  The characters don’t speak but instead make sounds which easily convey the story.  This device is so well done that you can still tell what is going on even though the characters don’t have facial expressions or even speak.  

With the story, the style, the gameplay, and the music; Last Day of June will stick with you for quite some time.

The achievement system is good, with only three or four missable achievements which are easy to go back to and attain.  The achievements are satisfying and feel like a part of the story; making it a real joy to go after them even though you will get most of the achievements for simply playing.  Additionally, the controls are easy to pick up no matter keyboard or controller.  I ended up using the controller throughout the game as it seemed a bit more natural.

Last Day of June is a heart touching game that you will enjoy and, perhaps, it will even rank up there as one of your favorite games played this year.  I enjoyed my time with the characters, experienced a wide range of emotions, and sat back with a long sigh when the final credits rolled.  I wholeheartedly recommend Last Day of June for those that enjoy graphically beautiful games with touching stories.
It's good. the game was very fun for me and my friends and I would love a 3rd one

La evolución del intento de innovar en la Wii U llega para recuperar la gloria que no tuvo en su primera entrega. Con millones de niveles por delante, es posiblemente el mejor Mario 2D que existe ya que las sorpresas están a la vuelta de la esquina. La imaginación es el límite.

Let people make their own levels and you can get inifinite possibility what to do, you can either do vanilla, hard vanilla, kaizo or even like music levels from composer. I'm in 0% team that is trying to win every level ever made and it's so much fun to play.

Nintendo stepped right way with this game.
Letting people make your levels was good idea.
