One of my top Switch games. I love the world builder and all the new things added to this release.
It's okay. Hard to find normal levels online. Online creations are creative but are trying to be something other than skilled based SMB games, or are extreme hard.

reviews.title: amsandor's review of Lil Gator Game

reviewText.content:
Lil' Gator Game is a sweet little tale about a child growing older, and missing the time spent playing with his sister. As his sister navigates college, Lil' Gator wants to recapture the glory days of fantasy summers with his sister, and sets out, with the help of the whole town, to turn the island they live on into a fantasy land, complete with cardboard "monsters", quests, and a rockin' fort in the centre of the island. The game consists of you, as the Lil' Gator, roaming the island, helping friends, and building the coolest fort anyone has every seen, all to try and get your sister to stop writing papers, and to hang out, one last time. 

This was a fun little game, very reminiscent of A Short Hike, with gameplay that focuses on helping others. The game is nonviolent, unless you count destroying cardboard cutouts as violence. Instead, it captures the grand fantasy games we all dreamed of playing as kids. The animation is cute, if a bit clunky, but the music and gameplay are solid. The game is also quite short - I 100% the game in just a few hours. Even so, I really enjoyed my time with this game.

If Playdead's Inside was Jumanji, Planet Alpha is Zathura. Same amount of curious happenings going on in the background, same amount of limited 2D movement, mild puzzle solving and dangerously sneaking around, but crank the color saturation up to 1,000,000.

reviews.title: fl4shp01nt's review of Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown

reviewText.content: Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown is a standout metroidvania title, offering a fun and rewarding experience. With its well-crafted mechanics, challenging encounters, and captivating world, the Prince of Persia franchise has once again captured the hearts of players old and new alike.

Metroidvania à la Ori, je m'attendais à un jeu AA relativement court, mais au final il est plus grand et plus long qu'on pourrait le penser.
Très bien pensé, très bien réalisé (certains décors comme la mer déchainée sont à tomber par terre) tout est parfaitement bien huilée, avec une carte à parcourir très grande (parfois trop, donnant l'impression que le jeu est sans fin). Le personnage est bien réactif, les doublages VF excellents.
Compter 30h pour faire le tour du jeu.

Joué sur SerieX via UbiSoft+

It is a good game although I would say that it lacked the essence of the old installments, I did not really like the fact that it is a 2D like the previous ones that were 3D but the idea is not bad, but it is a good game it makes you spend time with puzzles They remind me of the old telephone deliveries, on that side the nostalgia returns, I think without a doubt I recommend it if you have it to buy

reviews.title: evinyx's review of Prince of Persia: The Lost Crown

reviewText.content: Pretty good metroidvania. Combat was tremendously good but for some reason, I enjoyed my time with Metroid Dread more than this.

visually this a very nice game however it feels extremely under developed and uncomfortable to control. the puzzles are frustrating not because they're challenging but because they are poorly designed. its unfortunate as this game clearly has potential it just needed more time in development, i hope this game isn't its creators last and i also hope that this game isn't the creators passion project.

A very atmospheric puzzle game where you solve intricate and well designed puzzle boxes. If you found yourself enjoying the weird out of place puzzles in Resident Evil then you'll enjoy this game a lot. It takes that idea and puts more depth into it than that series ever managed to. The story of the game is sparse but it works well to drive you forward as you wonder what the purpose of solving these boxes is. The incredible presentation and design of these puzzles are really what's going to push you through this game though. I heartily recommend this game.

An excellent puzzle game. I recommend buying the bundle that has all 4 games in it - especially when it's on sale.

Although the game is short, it's very intriguing, and there were only 2 or 3 instances of me asking "wtf am I supposed to do" and having to look it up, rather than just rely on hints or click randomly.

There's not really much else to say honestly. The graphics are great, and the gameplay is solid.

If you're into puzzle games, buy this. And even if you aren't, it's a good introduction to the genre.

My only real complaint is that the "clickable thing" collision sometimes isn't very accurate, and the lack of proper settings (all sound is tied to the same bar, for example - hate when games do that). But, that's probably due to this being the studios' first game (or first PC port), and it's not that big of a deal in the long run.

So, in conclusion: Buy the entire Room series. They're all great.

reviews.title: he Room 4: Old Sins ist eines der Guten!

reviewText.content:
For enthusiasts of short, simple yet spooky puzzles, this game is an absolute must-have. It's evidently crafted with great attention to detail and offers an excellent value for money. Three aspects deserve special recognition:

The clever structuring of game areas: Once you complete a specific area, it gets closed off to prevent you from getting lost. This clever approach ensures that the player always keeps track and can prepare for the next adventure.

The captivating environmental design: The game feels like a gigantic dollhouse waiting to be explored. Alongside the challenging puzzles, there are plenty of interesting places to discover, perfectly balancing the scope of the game and making the experience even more immersive.

The enhanced freedom of movement: Thanks to the direct connections between rooms and the main area, players can now navigate from one place to another with just a few clicks, without having to struggle through endless corridors. This seemingly small change significantly enhances the gaming experience and makes exploring the environment even more enjoyable.

reviews.title: Basic concept but very well executed

reviewText.content: Very well executed game with a very basic concept - puzzle boxes! They have managed to wrap so many complex ideas into 1 fairly short game. They even managed to essentially throw in some decent backstory as to why we are solving these puzzle boxes. I really appreciate how they executed this so effectively. It pulls you into the story from the first note and you find yourself excited to solve the next puzzle and find the next note to know what happens next. The difficulty of the puzzles gradually increases rather than going from 0 to 100 which is appreciated. I like that they laid the game out into chapters with different puzzle boxes in each chapter to also provide that feeling of progression as well. This game very quickly became one of my favourite puzzle games of all time for its simplicity. Not to mention, literally the easiest 100% achievement run ever! I'm sure some people would wish for the game to be longer but, honestly, since there were sequels made, this is actually the perfect length to introduce the basics of the backstory and how the game works.
Pretty solid coop game, it's not a masterpiece, but it's impossibile to say that it isn't funny.
Basically Left 4 Dead with updated graphics and bigger hordes of zombies. It's fun. That's all there is to say.

reviews.title: gatorbox's review of Goosebumps: The Game

reviewText.content: This is a game that doesn't seem to have a target demographic in mind. It's not going to scare older players and younger players who are in the age range to read the Goosebumps book series might be too young to fully understand how to play it. Some of the logic required to advance onward seems like it's too "out there" for youngins to understand (puzzles about Chess, developing pictures, etc). This puts Goosebumps: The Game at a weird crossroads where it won't give the thrills and chills that people who would understand how to play it want. That said as a fan of the book series I found this game to still be enjoyable. You do not need to have read the books to understand this game but if you are familiar with the source material then you'll recognize all the references and callbacks, some of which are necessary to advance through the game. The "moon logic" issue only cropped up a couple of times and I'll admit I had to look at a guide to get myself unstuck because the solution definitely wasn't obvious. The worst part of the game is a scene where you are aimlessly running away from a monster in the dark; I could not for the life of me determine if there was a hint as to the directions you're supposed to go or if it was just sheer trial and error.

It just straight up wouldnt work. I was enjoying the game a fair bit until the third case where it jsut crashed constantly. Tried everything to fix but no luck. I'm a big sherlock holmes fan and felt like it was pretty faithful up to that point so if wasn't so buggy I'd probably have really enjoyed it.

This game is absolutely fantastic, from the clean quality of the graphics as well as the intricately thought out cases. What I love most about these instalments is the ability to make your own deductions and choose your own solution for the case, even though it may be wrong. In this way, you feel like a more active presence in the overall decision-making.

Great game, really enjoyed it's aspects. Profiling of people, connecting clues and creating deductions and conclusions to cases is fun and very satisfying. The possibility of multiple endings and moral choices sometimes leave you in doubts if you really did the right thing. Luckily the game offers you to replay the ending so you can make different choice without playing the case all over again. There are interesting cases, beautiful locations (I loved the Kew Gardens case) and a great overall atmosphere. However, the loading times are annyoing even when played on newer hardware with SSD drive and since you change locations quite often it can get quite annoying.

reviews.title: alalearl's review of Sherlock Holmes: Crimes & Punishments

reviewText.content:
This game is very deep case and puzzle more than other 's Sherlock that I've played.
but main story is worse.

Welcome to the Penrose Hotel! Enjoy your stay in this beautiful art deco hotel that is staffed by robots. Explore your surroundings and uncover the secrets of not only the strange Hotel, but the reason of your stay in The Spectrum Retreat.

The Spectrum Retreat is a narrative-driven puzzler. Part of the game you will explore the Penrose Hotel and solve some puzzles to find a code that allows you to advance to the secondary part of the story—a color coded puzzle game. The puzzle part of The Spectrum Retreat is intriguing and the difficulty level scales rather well making sure that, when completed, you are rewarded with a sense of satisfaction. It is here that you will spend the most amount of your time solving color coded puzzles and experiencing some minor physics challenges. By completing these levels, you will progress into the story and unlock harder puzzle levels.

The story revolves around finding out what happened to you before your stay in the Penrose Hotel. It is only somewhat interesting as you start to learn more, starts losing interest in the middle, and then falls flat towards the end. The story and the hotel ultimately become a clunky narrative device for the puzzles, which probably could have been made into its own game.

Half of the achievements are easy to get as they are part of the story. Additionally, if you want all of the available achievements you will have to play the game twice as there are two different endings—you cannot revert to a previous save to complete it and this type of system, forcing you to replay the game for the last achievement, is rather frustrating. I was severely disappointed that second half of the achievements for The Spectrum Retreat are not working…from two years ago! The fact that they are listed in the Steam Achievement list but not activated is very disheartening and, in all honesty, even if they were put into the game tomorrow I probably would not play The Spectrum Retreat again just to get them.

All in all, The Spectrum Retreat is a decent puzzle game but the lacking storyline, unnecessary addition of politics, and the missing achievements compel me not to recommend this game. While the puzzles are mostly fun and challenging and the Penrose Hotel beautiful to look at; there are too many “mehs” that makes me say: give this game a hard pass and do not look back.

Tragedy has struck Youropa!  The Eifel Tower is now…up in the air?  Using your special powers to walk on any surface you set out to save the Eifel Tower by walking right up it.  Explore a shattered cityscape and solve puzzles to move closer to your destination.  With some brainwork, some skill, and perhaps a bit of luck you can help save the famous monument from this strange anomaly.

Youropa is a third-person puzzle/platforming game with a fun set of gravity-defying rules where you play as a Youropean and progress from one floating island to the next looking for doorways to the next level.  Some doorways will need to be powered up, some are guarded, and others seem unreachable, but rest assured there is always a way and all you must do is think outside the box for the solution.  As you progress you evolve your abilities, such as being able to run, jump, and other skills…each skillset designed to help you with your exploration and progression.

While the game is beautiful to look at, the real gem of Youropa is the playstyle.  Looking for a solution in many games means simply looking around, but in Youropa you need to think a bit more and do some exploration as many of the solutions are cleverly hidden and many of the solutions have multiple parts to figure out as well.  Finding out how to safely get to different places in the zone is just as fun as finding out what you need to do to move forward, and this made each level of Youropa a real gem.

The game is fun, but sadly there is no replayability besides the three difficulty levels and the workings of a system to build your own levels.  While the technology is there for designing interesting and exciting user-created levels it is not intuitive nor is it fun to work.  Perhaps, in the future, this will be a viable way to expand the life of this game.

Achievements are split into two main sections: story and collectibles with some special achievements for doing game-related things.  None of the achievements are difficult and all achievements can be easily completed in one playthrough.  The game has a plethora of collectibles and finding and getting these collectibles becomes a game within a game.

I found Youropa a fun experience and enjoyed it quite a bit.  I found myself becoming excited every time I entered a new area and a sense of completion every time I figured out a puzzle and moved to the next level.  The game does a great job in challenging you but not making it extremely difficult.  I recommend Youropa to those who love platforming games, for those who like puzzle games, and even for those who just want to play something a bit different.

I am absolutely stunned by how good this game is. I honestly did not expect having such a blast. I have never seen a game that rewards exploration so much, and ties the narrative and player freedom so much into it. Go play it, it's included with you GamePass subscription!

One of the best indie games out there. I really like the concept of being given a setting and told to explore that setting. The over arching story to this world is very compelling. not really any negatives in this game. music slaps.
The Cutest game I have played, has a very engaging story. 10/10 would recommend.

Primitive and repetitive gameplay.

There are some different types of quests, four different weapons, but everything feels so bland and effortless.

I finished the game in about 2 hours, but it felt like I lost this time for no reason.

Hmm, I was ready to forgive everything for the unique gameplay concept, but.. there is absolutely nothing to praise here, I understand that the game was made by 1 person, tried to at least somehow poor, but tastefully arrange inventory and other stuff using hand drawing, and it seems, in general, everything works, and I understand that the game will be liked by his fans or those who just want to support him for the work, but the game can still be improved,
I'm really disappointed I was waiting for the game, the developer did it for several years, and for what? It turned out to be a simple joke for YouTube, just a joke that lasts for a couple of seconds or for 1 screenshot, there is a really good concept of an open world, where if you move far away from the train, you will be devoured by a monster that can also attack your train on the go,
But everything is done as primitively as possible, all the tasks of the open world - it's just bring thing from one place to another, click along the way, farm the rubbish scattered everywhere, you can also upgrade damage/armor/speed of train - that's it, that's the whole gameplay) It takes 2-3 hours to complete.
That's it, Absolutely all the tasks - are just a walking simulator with a couple of scattered props+1 mouse click, and you can also open chests in the simplest "get in the circle" mini-game. The plot: you came to the island to kill a strange creature, in the end you learn about 3 eggs that are guarded by Charles's cultists, which you need to collect and summon the boss on the altar.. it's even ridiculous to talk about characters and notes.

And the last nail in the game`s coffin - is that fights with Charles do not cause any FEAR, 0 fear, PEOPLE, no atmosphere, by the way, either.
What, 20 dollars, man, developer, are you ok? You are a youtuber, so you have the opportunity to advertise the game well, why so limit the audience of the game? I would recommend this maximum for mobile phones or in free form.
Poor optimization and microfreezes are also present, if that makes any difference besides all this.

Subscribe on my Steam Curators page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550/

This game is bad. I hate golf games when they are trying to be realistic. I was hoping this was more fun and RPG. It's not, you still have to aim with a giant circle and time two "spots" to hit the ball and it goes wherever the hell it wants. Who wants this? I wanted to play a fun game, not a horrible excuse for a bad golf game.

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Bud Spencer & Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans

reviewText.content:
Bud Spencer and Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans is a video game that was released on April 20, 2017, for PC, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One. The game is a side-scrolling beat 'em up and features iconic characters from the Bud Spencer and Terence Hill movies.

The game was developed by Trinity Team, an independent Italian studio. Bud Spencer and Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans is their most notable release, capturing the humor and action-packed style of the famous duo's movies.

The director of the game is Maurizio Barolo, who has also directed other titles developed by Trinity Team. The game's script was written by Giancarlo Ferrigno, who successfully captured the essence of Bud Spencer and Terence Hill's movies in the game's dialogue and interactions. 

The music for Bud Spencer and Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans was composed by Simone Cicconi, creating a nostalgic and upbeat soundtrack that pays homage to the movies' original scores. 

The game utilizes a custom-made engine for its graphics, and specific details about the engine or its usage in other games are not readily accessible. Bud Spencer and Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans features a retro pixel art style, capturing the essence of classic beat 'em up games.

In terms of sound design, the game incorporates punchy sound effects and humorous voice acting, creating a lively and nostalgic atmosphere that immerses players in the world of Bud Spencer and Terence Hill's movies.

In conclusion, Bud Spencer and Terence Hill: Slaps and Beans deserves a rating of 7 due to its faithful recreation of the iconic duo's movies, capturing their humor and action in an enjoyable beat 'em up experience. While it may lack depth in terms of gameplay mechanics and variety, fans of Bud Spencer and Terence Hill will appreciate the nostalgic charm the game offers.

reviews.title: Quel jeu, Klei a fait encore fort !

reviewText.content: Tout le détail est dans les points positifs et négatifs ci-dessous ;)

reviews.title: MalachiWalker's review of Return to Monkey Island

reviewText.content: Monkey island used to have some of the most beatyful graphics in p&c games. What kind of atrocity is this? The character design is awful. And the riddles? These series used to have some of the most interesting and hard so solve puzzles. I played the hard mode and it was rediculously easy. Was is made for 10 year olds? All it's worth is the nostalgia.

reviews.title: Quel plaisir de retrouver l'ambiance des point'n click des années passées :)

reviewText.content:
Quel plaisir de retrouver l'ambiance des point'n click des années passées :)
On retrouve l'ambiance sonore et l'état d'esprit de cette époque, mais avec des graphismes et une interface aux goûts du jour.
Tout est fluide et permet de profiter de l'histoire qui fait honneur aux attentes créées par une nostalgie souvent abusée.
Le scénario est bien pensé et bien présenté, plein de petites énigmes bien dosées ce qui donne un grand plaisir de jeu.
A recommander sans hésiter aux amateurs du genre !

Joué sur PC via le game pass.

One of the most beautiful games I have ever played. It is simple to learn and understand. I like the eerie atmosphere of the game induced by various sounds. Initial puzzles are trial and error which makes the game a bit tedious. One failure can reveal the solution, so there is no need to think. The second half of the puzzles are more impressive and requires more thought and skill to solve.

So I'm a little late to the party but Limbo is fantastic. Whenever a game comes out (and this is true of books and movies as well) I am always a stubborn ass and don't believe the hype. Mostly because it seems like when I do I'm always disappointed. So it happens sometimes that I wait to play/watch whatever it is and end up finding out that I love it. Such was the case with Limbo.

I love, love, love the art in this game. It's very minimalist with only black, whites and grays. Even when you get to the inevitable (and often) squishing that inevitably happens to little Bo (that's what I named him, your tiny little squishable is unnamed as far as I know) it is weirdly graphic and yet not at the same time. If you're an uber-player you can probably make it through the first time without getting smooshed but a lot of the puzzles aren't obvious until they kill you. 

The puzzles are environmental and very fun. They're challenging but you can usually figure them out by thinking long enough or experimenting with the objects/surroundings. Gameplay is relatively simple but fun. The platforming parts worked well and were enjoyable. Bo moves easily and fluidly and the physics are nicely done.

There isn't much of a story but it's a strangely compelling game. And generally I prefer story-rich games so I was actually surprised how invested I got in my little 'Bo's journey. He was tiny, he was small and everything was so big compared to him. I really, really wanted to take him safely through the game. 

I can't really spoil the ending as there really isn't one but the cycle is a bit depressing. I know there are theories out there on what is actually going on in Limbo but I haven't really looked into them yet. I didn't want them to color my review and interpretation of it. If I had to I think it's all summed up in the name - Limbo. You're stuck in a limbo cycle for whatever reason. All in all it's a fascinating, fun game with some replay value.

Enter the truly terrifying world of LIMBO as you escape all manner of fatal devices, murderous locals, and ingenious traps as you make you way to discover the fate of your sister or, perhaps, even yourself. 

Morbid and lethal puzzles abound in this game—all the more to suck you into the stark and deadly world of LIMBO.  The lethality of the traps and enemies in this game is heightened by the various visuals of you dying in a variety of different means which no doubt make this game memorable if not disturbing.  

LIMBO is a puzzle platformer with a stunningly simplistic and beautiful setting, impressively diabolical traps and puzzles, and plenty of gruesome demises.  Do not expect to live but don’t take it too hard as the developer’s state that the game is a “Trial and Death” style game—you are expected to die but somehow it isn’t frustrating.  There were several times where my mind was blown away by the intricacy of the traps and my death count soared; but I felt highly rewarded when completing sections successfully.

The story was somewhat muddy as I was unsure what exactly was going on even though I understood the title of the game.  However, and this is a rarity for me, the confusing storyline wasn’t too much of an issue with me as the gameplay was very engaging.  The mystery of the world and the story is what keeps my mind coming back to LIMBO.

The controls are simple and easy to learn, and the achievements were not easy but completable with a bit of thought and dexterity and, perhaps, a bit of luck.  Overall, a good game that I recommend for those who like puzzle platformer games, those who’s sense of morbidity is heightened, or those who wish to test their mettle against this type of game.

1.	Limbo has a different story concept.
2.	Solving puzzles and moving through, this is the first 2D game I’ve played of such a kind.
3.	Playing as a character of Silhouette or dark shadow, this black and white game is intense, suspenseful and surprising. It also involves spooky, scary and creepy elements; this may depend from person to person. 
4.	The game-play is simple and good, but one needs to solve puzzles while proceeding. At some parts, I got stuck and took breaks. Then, later on, I tried again and proceeded.
5.	To summarize, one may try Limbo if they like 2D games.

Nice little puzzle game. 
The look of the game is great, black/white with dark vibes where we control this really weak character.

The majority of the puzzles were not that complex except for a few but I would still recommend to try out this game!

I love this game as a tabletop, and this is an extremely efficient digital version of it. The backgrounds, effects, and birds make up for a very pleasant, competitive, and rewarding experience. Online settings let you have short games with friends, or long ones with people who can take it at their speed, which is great imo. Easy recommend, regardless of if you're familiar with the original version or not.

Avoid like the plague, unless you like:
- epic gunplay
- gorgeous graphics
- good environment and level design
- interesting lore

For you own sanity, try to avoid everything else this game throws at you.

A hilarious work of perfection. The puzzles are just hard enough, the mechanics are simple but employed to devious extents. The voice acting is absolutely superb, notably Stephen Merchant as Wheatley and J.K. Simmons as Cave Johnson. And GlaDOS. Can't forget about GlaDOS. It's laugh-out-loud funny at the same time as being a one-of-a-kind brainteaser.

Portal 2 takes some steps forward and some steps backwards. The setup is pretty similar to Portal: test chambers and environmental puzzles. However, Portal 2 adds a great story to the mix. For the most part the difficulty of the puzzles is on point, but some elements weren't explained well (like the gel can kill turrets). The environmental puzzles are also better than in the original, though there are still some obscure parts. The singleplayer is twice as long as the original, which also great.

Portal 2 - PC (Windows 10) - 1080p - 120 fps* - Max Settings - Singleplayer mode

My Playthrough of the singleplayer mode lasted 5 hours, divided roughly in 2 parts:
- 90% for puzzle solving and turret killing
- 10% for loading and corridor walking

The Story is divided in 4 acts. It is very well written, although I wish the game invested more time in telling more about the old facility and lore. Overall the level design and the puzzles are beautifully interwoven, and the voice acting is both humorous and explanatory.

For future references:
- Great puzzles, levels, and environment design
- Engaging story
- Interesting sci-fi lore
A classic for a reason. So good at comedy and puzzles, I wish I could play it for the first time again.

As you progress through the game, you encounter innovative puzzle elements that are introduced subtly, allowing for organic learning and constant engagement. The clever blend of direct narrative and environmental storytelling enhances the overall gaming experience without overshadowing the genre's main focus.

GLaDOS, the witty and sarcastic AI, drives the main plot forward with humorous remarks and unexpected twists, while the hauntingly beautiful Aperture Science facility provides a captivating backdrop, teeming with clues and history through meticulously crafted environments.

Portal 2 also features stellar voice acting from J.K. Simmons, Ellen McLain, and Stephen Merchant, adding remarkable depth and charm to their characters. Their performances elevate the game's storytelling, making the journey through Aperture Science even more unforgettable.
One of the best puzzle video games out there with both story and immersive gameplay.
Portal 2 is an incredible gaming experience, worth every moment of your time.

reviews.title: One of the best video games of all time.

reviewText.content: the portals are really cool like there blu and orang and is very cool (:

Starting with the good, the storytelling and writing is a big upgrade from the first game, which had a simple story and twist but was still fun and enjoyable. This game's story is a lot bigger and more engaging throughout. Glados is just as awesome as ever and I loved the companion Wheatley, voiced excellently by Stephen Merchant!

They also add in a lot more puzzle solving elements with the portal gun, adding in a lot more environmental tools for you to use to solve the puzzles with which I appreciated. The gameplay definitely has more variety then the first game.

My main issue is that the campaign I feel goes on way too long for me personally. I'm not that into puzzle games, and the first game took me 4 hours to beat, which was the perfect length for someone like me. This game just went on and on at times and I feel like the story could have resolved a lot earlier. The gameplay is improved but after a while it was dragging on and I just got bored which is why I took a break for a few months before finally coming back to finish it. The story is what made me want to come back but I was glad when it finally concluded.
Its really bad. it was a little joy at first but then i started to hate it.

Overall Great Free To Play Battle Royale Game with Unique Building Mechanics .
Fun To Play with Family & Friends.

reviews.title: Fortnite is fun when you let it be fun

reviewText.content:
I started playing back when the game was released on the Nintendo Switch, so around midway through Season 4. I enjoyed the game, and I continued to play it a lot through Season 4 and the last season of Chapter 2, but for the most part, the game started getting boring when I was not having fun with it. My friends started to play less and less, and the game started to feel stale. I can't say I'll ever go back because, over time, I started to dislike the Battle Royal gameplay.

The gameplay started to fade as time went on. I started disliking the flow of drop in the world, land, search for a gun, maybe kill someone in the area, then look for enemies on a huge island, and repeat till you win or till you die. I much prefer the gameplay of Team Fortress 2 or Overwatch 2, where you have a team and have guns on you already.

The art style the game has is nice. It has changed over time, and it was much better back when I first started playing, but the change is nothing to complain about. With the more 3D cartoon art style, it can be really pleasing on the eyes and make for cool events, which are shown through in-game live events.

Overall, Fortnite was a fun game. I enjoyed the time I spent on it and the time I spent with my friends. Now-a-days, Fortnite seems more like a promo with fan-made and official game modes in it. I'm not saying the promo skins are bad; Epic Games did good on them. I just feel that they focus more on promo skins more than their own original work. and it became hell to go through the game mode selection screen because of all the fan-made modes that Epic, for some reason, put all into one small area.

This is a review for "Battle Royale" portion of the game, I haven't played the "Save the World".

Pretty fun as a free to play game, a bit too easy for my taste, but still blows out the competition out of the water.

I'm sorry to say it but... I have to rate it a 10. Fortnite in its prime was the most fun I've ever had playing a game to this day, it also changed the gaming world forever, and even in its current state today is still playable. Just not nearly as good or as fun.

10/10 for prime time 
I had a brilliant time with this game!
I will always keep this in my mind.
Great game on PS4 Pro. With the launch of season 3, the framerate is fantastic and they have lots of variety on how you want to play the game and approach fighting scenarios.

i love this game. I have this game 7 years ago.Fortnite is the completely free online game where you and your friends fight to be the last one standing in Battle Royale, join forces to make your own Creative games, or catch a live show at Party Royale.
Easy to pick up and have fun every time whether you're a beginner, intermediate, expert. Great social aspect and community.

The game used to be good, but the crossplay balancing is poor. PS5/Xbox players have an in-game aimbot against mouse/keyboard players and, at the same time, receive significantly less damage. There are other issues compounding these negative effects. You need to be about ten times better than PS5/Xbox players... But nowadays, people don't invest as much time in practice as they did 3-4 years ago. That's why I don't play it.

It is such a classic. I have been playing for 2yrs and it's the best game ever.
I first joined in Chapter 3 Season 2/3 (I don't remember) and now it's the middle of Chapter 5 Season 1!
It has changed how we look at gaming nowadays and bought many creators like Ninja, Nick eh 30, Mongraal etc. into success.

Chapter 5 is absolute garbage. Before this season it was a pretty chill game with easily playable lobbies and a fair amount of wins but now it's absolutely unplayable on an enjoyable level. It seems they want to make this game more "competitive" but now it's just lobbies that dwindle down to 10 players within 5 minutes, maybe 1 or 2 kills, then getting dropped by the dominating team. Previous seasons I'd get 20-30 kill games and would be able to play with less skilled players without having to carry the whole team but now I get 2-3 kill games and have to either carry or be carried.
People in the game our friend disrespectful me crude can’t really play as a team.

Very Good Game First of it's kind the bad reviews are just bots who can't commit the brain power to learn a new mechanic for new style of fighting. Saw one review that said bad framerate for a negative point but their clown ass has a trash set up apparently lmao- very easy to run game with variety of settings to ease framerate
This game is very fun! There so much to do every season!! Everything is always fun, except when they unvault something that everyone dislikes.
i honestly think that this game can go along way! i hope to bring more positivity !

While still embracing its NES/SNES era influences full-hardheartedly, Shovel Knight stands out massively amongst other retro-inspired contemporary titles.

Not only does it pull off its revivalist qualities masterfully, but it does so without shying away from blending a myriad of modern mechanics into its arsenal. Not only that, but its short runtime is packed to the brim with charming characters, solid level design, a fittingly cute art-style, catchy tunes and creative enemies (emphasis on the amazing Megaman-like bosses).

The silly tone of Shovel Knight's world is infatuating, making every interaction throughout its runtime an absolute treat. However, this silly tone does come at the price of a somewhat minimal and predictable plot- although that's a minor point of contention, considering how Shovel Knights seems to lack any other short-comings.

If you're looking for a goofy yet challenging experience to sink some hours into, this game is a great choice. Plus, it's main campaign is nicely adjusted for co-op - which, in the many years since the first time I picked it up, has proven to be one of the main reasons I periodically find myself revisiting it.

Shovel Knight is an alright action platformer. My main point of critique is that the game is a massive grind, because the levels are all about memorizing. Each level is centered around its boss, resulting in each level being very different and showing lots of interesting mechanics. However the levels are designed in such away that you have to move in a very specific pattern. Which takes all of the fun out of the levels. You can finish each stage in 10 minutes, but on your first time it will take around an hour. In total it takes about 10 hours to finish the main game, which is a good length (but short for the price).

reviews.title: MotherofDataDragons's review of A Memoir Blue

reviewText.content: I was looking for something short to play and was delighted to learn that this was finally out. I've had my eye on it for a while now, but if I'm not mistaken, it was a previously cancelled game brought back to life? Anyway, this is a sweet little narrative about a hardworking girl who recalls her youth with her mother. It's an emotional roller-coaster with fantastic animation and a really nice soundtrack. I like how the game has such a deep link to water. I read somewhere that 'A Memoir Blue' was like a clickable poem, and I believe that's a fantastic way to look at it. When you're short on time and want to explore another side of gaming, this is a fantastic little gem :)

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of A Memoir Blue

reviewText.content: Without spoiling anything, A Memoir Blue is a story with a single theme and focus, shown to the player by a series of mini-tasks and an accompanying melancholic music. It isn't a happy game, but rather a very reflective one, and you have to be in the right kind of mood to play it. That being said, it's a very short experience, which will appeal to people who struggle(d) with the theme of the game.

reviews.title: De bonnes intentions mais de gros défauts

reviewText.content:
Petit jeu narratif, qui pendant une à deux heures nous fait voyager dans le rêve d'une jeune championne de natation, qui repasse sur son passé et plus particulièrement sa relation avec sa mère.
Malheureusement si on sent les bonnes intentions, l'émotion et l'empathie pour le personnage ont du mal à être présents.
La réalisation reste cheap même si on sent un effort artistique.
Au niveau de l'histoire malheureusement on évite pas le cliché de la pauvre mère qui se sacrifie corps et âme et du méchant père rapidement aux abonnés absents.
A jouer éventuellement avec le game pass sinon à acheter lors de très grosses soldes.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.
That was FUN! Interesting plot, smart puzzles and finally, a game I didn't finish in 6 hours.

3D precision platformers are hard to do... Blue Fire nearly nails it -- the controls are tight, the speed is palpable, and when the "jump / wall jump / dash / another wall jump / double jump / double dash / wall run" combos work, it is an incredible rush. But for each great set of moves you pull off, a stupid death follows, usually when the perspective (or the camera) fools you and you realize too late not to be quite on top of that platform... :(

At least the purest platform sections (the so called "voids") are semi-optional; they provide you with upgrade slots, but there are enough not-too-hard ones anyway. There are also a few dungeons with lots of platforming, and a couple of such challenges are timed, but I found the timing fairly relaxed if you planned out your path beforehand, and these designs are actually the smartest part of the game.

There is also a bit of functional fighting, but it feels a bit underdeveloped -- after a while, I found more productive just to avoid enemies instead. Boss fights, in particular, are serviceable but uninspired, relying more or less on the same tactics for each one.

The second half of the game, in particular, feels a bit rushed, as if the developers ran out of resources to produce good dungeons. The whole world hints at something greater (the whole game has this Hollow Knight vibe, a sense of sadness that permeates a doomed world), but at the end there are too few characters and their stories feel incomplete.

I am also pretty sure the music was inspired by Hollow Knight's moody soundtrack, and this is actually a high point -- the calmer tunes are very nice, if not as memorable. Graphics are nice enough, if you enjoy the stylized minimalistic style, and some of the architecture is impressively vertical (especially when you realize you will have to somehow climb that whole thing).

At the end of the day, despite a few shortcoming, I had fun with the game, and I still remember those cool double dashes and wall jumps in 3D. Score: 77/100.

Довольно таки неплохой файтинг, в котором нам предстоит стоя на месте отбиваться от подходящих со всех сторон врагов. Из плюсов выделю боевую систему, и вправду, получаешь удовольствие от побоев. Ну пожалуй, это и все плюсы игры, к счастью, тут нет минусов. Но есть одна проблема, оценки слишком завышены, потому как ни сюжета, ни чего то кроме бесконечного боя тут нет. Поэтому ставить сильно высокую оценку я не буду.

reviews.title: Armacalagon's review of Mother Russia Bleeds

reviewText.content:
I used to finish all the games I started but now don't have enough time to play games anymore. So, have to be thoughtful of what I play.

The art style is amazing, the sound design is perfect to the point where you can feel every punch hit or weapon used and there were zero bugs or glitches.

Played 5 Chapters. I wasn't interested in the story, the gameplay and didn't felt any desire to continue playing it.
Игра Очень интересная, каждые пару месяцев прилетают новые вторжения (иногда с задержкой). Но ничего с кем не бывает. Главное, что людям Нравится;)

The game just hasnt aged that well. It feels pretty clunky and for a cyberpunk style game it doesnt look good. The story was okay but nothing inspiring. I felt like the choices I made about my character had little effect on the story, the world or the gameplay. That said there was nothing especially bad, so for someone who enjoys these types of games its worth playing but not a standout game in any way.

To start with the good, the story was interesting for the first half as it was this cool detective story, until the plot takes a new direction which I didn't like but that was about the time when I hit the bug wall. The character progression is basically the same as Vampire the Masquerade Bloodlines, in that instead of you gaining XP and leveling up, you just get skill points straight away from completing quests. It helps simulate the tabletop style of gameplay which I love. The game is also very linear with you basically going from mission to mission. I didn't mind this and found it refreshing compared to many open world game now a days.

reviews.title: gamejoypod's review of Master Detective Archives: Rain Code

reviewText.content:
[NO SPOILERS]
I enjoyed my time with the game and it made me realize in retrospect what the special sauce was for Danganronpa.
 There's a lot more tension & drama added to a usually dry format (debating the details of an event) when you're trying to cut through all the noise a dozen emotional, stressed, and screaming teenagers hell-bent on pointing fingers anywhere but inward
Rain Code abstracts a similar system somewhat, and it cuts a lot of that tension & drama from the equation. 
Luckily the enjoyment we got from trying to stay at least a step or two ahead of the mysteries presented made up for it
I found it best to think of the game as an elevated visual novel with extra features rather than a very linear dungeon crawler/exploration game

Overall a good title that carries on the momentum from DR, exchanging some of the edginess for relaxing vibes & worldbuilding intrigue

Harry Potter Quidditch Champions is exciting, fast paced and fun. the gameplay feels smooth and the movements are fluid. i will say all the indicators can potentially be overbearing, but you do get used to them. i know a 6v6 is in the works witch leads me to my main complain. players don't want to play with bots. in my opinion the game should have released with the full team 6v6 matches, but that's just my opinion it is still a great game. I also would have liked to have seen the seeker as a full time position, with the same rules applied to actual quidditch 150pts and the ending of the game. maybe have the 2 seekers do laps around the field and compete in a race the first 3min of the game to build an extra boost meter then when the race is over the player whom won will have a slight advantage on catching the snitch, which i think should be a little more difficult to obtain. other than that the AI keeper has some questionable habits like straying to far from the posts or behind them. The beaters and chasers mechanics are absolutely beautiful, and i have zero complaints or suggestions regarding them.

reviews.title: Placid Plastic Duck Simulator: the best game you cant play

reviewText.content:
Let's keep it nice and simple. In this game, you look at a pool and watch ducks. That is wholly it. every 5 minutes, a new duck spawns in. Clicking on a duck will let you spectate them, and clicking again makes them quack. You can also give each rubber duckie a special name in the collections menu. Some of the ducks do special actions every few minutes, like the Dragon duck breathes fire, and the propeller duck can fly. I can't stress enough that that's really it. Ducks spawn in, they float in the pool, and you watch them fuck around. It's so simple and there's, debatably, no game play at all, and yet I've put in over 10 hours while writing this.

Since there's nothing much to talk about with the gameplay, then I'll move on to talking about the maps. With the DLC, there are 3 stages, Infinity Cool, Quacking the Ice, and Hippospace Download (inspired by the game Hypnospace Outlaw). Infinity Cool is my favourite. It's a basic pool with a few floaties on the side that can actually fall in. The top pool has a slide leading down to a hot tub area, which has a vacuum tube leading back up to the main pool. not too much there, but it's nice and simple. I didn't like Quacking the Ice initially. The upper pool is just a longer version of Infinity Cool's upper pool with a bit inside a ski lodge cabin, and a slide leading down to an Icy pond. I didn't think there was a way back up to the top pool, until I was utterly delighted to see a Zamboni come out of the shed and push the ducks into a mini cable car.  Hippospace Download is my least favourite map. It has a massive pillar in the middle with another pool on top, a lazy river section, and more than a few slides. there's a lot of duck based play features, and even a hidden usable catapult, but it's just too cluttered. With a massive spire in the middle, the camera gets caught way too easy.. 

The negatives, of which there are only a few, need to be talked about. Once a duck spawns in, there's no way to despawn it, and the special and event ducks that can spawn in go away after the map is reloaded or quit. The camera can be difficult to say the least, getting caught and zooming in without input. I know part of the point is you have no control, but the inability to drag and drop ducks out of stuck spots and back into the pool is a sticking point for me.

To my particular tastes, it fails to entertain. I enjoy a good, in-depth narrative to give purpose to the gameplay and weight to the consequences of combat. Choosing not to focus on that, World of Horror relies solely on its visuals and gameplay. However, to give credit where credit is due, the art style and overall atmosphere is phenomenal.

On the other hand, the core gameplay loop felt repetitive and boring to my tastes, even though it offers replayability in the form of a "quick play" mode, which deals you random stats to you and your enemies and a "challenge" mode, where you have a specially unfavorable scenario to play through. On top of that, the game opens the doors to modding, leaving room for a community-powered foutain of creativity to quell one's thirst for more turn-based combat against eldritch horrors for a long time to come. Despite being a praiseworthy gesture, I can't evaluate the game based on third-party creations, so I have to focus on what the game has to offer by itself: The "main story" of World of Horror consists of a group of 5 random investigations which are, by themselves, each an unique "story". They are all very short (10~15 minutes long), making the overall gameplay loop no longer than an hour.

Listen listen listen. I don't do turn based games. I don't do critter collection games. I don't do card based battle games.
Moonstone Island is a critter collection, turn based, card game battle game and I AM OBSESSED with it. How? Idk. Please play this game. It's amazing. ALSO, all the NPCs are romanceable!
Very boring, same dialogs are repeated, don't bother with this

Hollow knight succeeded to beat Ori in my heart. It is the best game I played these last years. It starts quit slowly but little but little I was astonished by the gameplay, the animation and how the game started to become beautiful. Before buying I thought I would not like the arts that much but the animation looked great on the trailer so I tried it. I ended up to love the art, the music, the gameplay, the atmosphere. 

The first negative point is that when reaching 90% or above the game become insanely difficult for me. The second negative point is a region that is so well hidden that you can complete miss out of quite some great content.

But knowing that the cherry team kept giving awesome DLCs, and that the price was so cheap for ages compared to other games, I give it 100%. 

Completely deserved. 

I love this game.

I played over 60 hours my first run, and currently am on my second run- which has already accumulated over 10 hours.  

The game is so immersive with amazing graphics and lore that you figure out through your own exploration.

I would say that this game is my perfect 'difficulty' for exploration in  a metroidvania. There were quite a lot of times where I hit dead ends but the beautiful art always left an impression reminding me where secrets could be. There are a couple of problems with the game that culminate at the ending with a large difficulty spike into a different genre, which I can't imagine many people have completed without cheesing with the help of some charms. I also found the final boss to be quite annoying and let down my experience in searching for the true ending. Still recommended but It may be good enough to get the normal ending and leave it at that.

I loved this game very much. The game pulls off the metroidvania genre so well. I loved the way the story was fed to the player. The player can just simply go through, get a vague understanding of the story, or they can really dig deep to understand what happened and why your character is doing what he is doing. 

The difficulty builds up, but only gets too hard if you are going out of the way to challenge yourself with some of the side areas, especially the Path of Pain. (Probably one of my favorite areas of the game because it really pushes your ability over the mechanics of the game). 

The music really enhances the tone of the game. It's beautiful, haunting, and intriguing. The art is cute, but works so well. I'd also say that I loved the interactions with the world, the characters, and how cohesive the world felt. Team Cherry did a great job here.
A blend of eeriness and floridity that has captivated me for hours without losing its charm and essence. Spectacularly challenging creation by Team Cherry!

This game should be the reference to follow in any upcoming games of similar style.

In general as a game, it has so many details and content it is outstanding.

The gameplay, controls and movement, are quite smooth. Adding to this the base powers, it gives a very satisfactory feeling of movement and platforming, which leads too to great challenges across the game.

The story may be a bit obscure, maybe a bit open to interpretation, but in the end, it's very understandable as a hole with the many pieces you get exploring the world and throughout the game. 

On the art aspect, it's very detailed in general, but the strong point here i would say is that every pathway is different, except for those one that make sense to be equal, and even in that case, there are different details. Great work.

On the music part, i think it's the weakest point of them all. Actually, I don't think the music is bad at all, but it is the part of the game that shines the least. Music fits in the game, but I don't recall any remarkable and unique song, and I think this is wasted opportunity and a bit sad.

On the sound part, again is great, you can recognize every thing just by its sound. This is very important, it gives an unique identity to everything that's going on on the screen, which many times is helpful due to the intense battles.

As a metroidvania, it has everything you would expect and further beyond. Powers, collectibles, side quests, challenges, remarkable NPCs, multiple endings, boss rush ... It is just incredible how much content there is in the game.

Of course, it is not an easy game, it is challenging by default, but at the same time it's very rewarding,

***Fantastic level design.
It feels great to acquire new abilities and unlock new pathways/upgrades.
The world is fully interconnected and you can choose your own path through many different areas. It all depends on which abilities you find first.
Every playthrough can follow a different progression order and that makes the replayability very high.


***Very tight and balanced gameplay (combat and platforming).
The controls just feel so good when walking, jumping, slashing and navigating the world.
Everything feels extremely polished, more so than many AAA titles.


***Beautiful, beautiful music and sound effects that give you a high level of immersion.


***Amazing art style, charming particle effects and atmosphere. Every area has a charm of its own and they blend into each other naturally in a realistic way.
Character designs range from cute to creepy to gross to hilarious. But mostly cute. All of them look unique and interesting.


***Challenging but fair bosses (except for the last DLC, that sh*t is impossible to 100% but it's optional. You can get through the main story with no problem).
You will have to practice and learn enemy attack patterns, and it feels very rewarding to get good at it.


***Deep, mysterious story that you have to piece by yourself.
Hallownest is a fully-realized world with its own past, heroes and gods; it's an abandoned treasure trove of secrets.


Hollow Knight is one of my favorite games of all time. Up there on the same level as Dark Souls, The Witcher III and Zelda Breath of the Wild.

Get it now. It's obscenely cheap for what you'll get out of it, even when not on sale.

TL;DR Best $15 I've ever spent.

Very well-made metroidvania, and although there are a few QoL issues I found; the game is still very good.

It's fairly easy to get lost, but that's part of the fun. Just being in Hallownest, wandering around finding stuff while listening to the soundtrack.

I strongly recommend buying this if you love metroidvania games, and/or games with deep lore and story (and interesting world design). Even if you're new to the genre, it's still a great purchase.

This (alongside the Ori games) are essential buys - especially for metroidvania fans.
Easily one of my favorite games of all time. The art, sound and gameplay are all sublime and there isn't a single dull moment.

Hello, I'm just starting to do game reviews and even I'm new to the platform and maybe this review will be very bad, but I'll try.

Hollow Knight is a metroidvania, very good, TOO good I would say.
The OST is one of the best I've heard in any game, the level design like almost any metroidvania game is excellent and its atmosphere is incredible.
In my first playthrough 43 hours very enjoyed I have reached God's Home, killed radiance and having a 96% completion I can say that it is the second best game I have played.
It may be a difficult game for some but I can say that it's worth it

Hollow Knight is a great game, the best 2D indie soulslike and Metroidvania there has ever been, and it's also a good way to get started with this game because it was actually the easiest soulslike I've ever played

very good world design, but with a lot of input handling issues in my opinion. 

absolutely terrific piece of art, less good in terms of being a game, but still satisfying in-spite of some infuriating flaws; inconsistent input buffers being one huge one, both for optimising for speedrunning, but more importantly for moment-to-moment casual gameplay. 
the amounts of times i would heal then press jump just to have my jump "eaten" mid bossfight due to the otherwise sizey jump buffer being disabled was way too large, and resulted in deaths more often than i'd like to admit.
these basic issues and annoyances did lead to a more "deep" gameplay, and more rewarding feeling once you come to grips with it, but it severely limited my enjoyment casually.
probably the most fun ive ever had playing a video game. this thing is perfect. please play it. you will enjoy it. if you dont enjoy it then why do you even enjoy playing video games in general.

Hollow Knight is a great game, the best 2D indie soulslike and Metroidvania there has ever been, and it's also a good way to get started with this game because it was actually the easiest soulslike I've ever played

Just perfect loads of gameplay very deep lore (thats the thing that kept me going) good animation and sound effects. 100% recomend. May be a bit out throwing and confuzing at the start but once you start  getting to the deaper levels you'll suck right into the game.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of A Little to the Left

reviewText.content: The execution of the idea is really good. You make yourself look for patterns and then you make the patterns happen. However, it starts to get boring after a while, especially with levels that are abstract. The DLC's will rectify that, as this game has a lot of potential, but the vanilla game can get boring if you want to have your brain occupied to the fullest while gaming.

reviews.title: laladypanda's review of A Little to the Left

reviewText.content: An adorable aesthetic pleasing puzzle game. Super satisfying and challenging.

I can absolutely see how this game makes sense. It is primarily focused on multiplayer, local or online, for Switch. Simple controls, difficult to master, lots of "mini games" to explore, and with other people it must be quite a lot of fun. I played on PC and alone, and that kind of tells you my level of enjoyment. Still, I don't regret playing this, and Tokyo 2020 definitely has some potential for the right target group.

Another Vampire Survivors style game, this time with several twists. The biggest gripe for me is the lack of meta-progression. Each run is separate from another, the motivation is achievements/unlocking new characters, and you getting better at the game. Brotato is original enough to give it a few tries and hours to try and get better and hooked, but it did not happen for me. It is still a good time for the hours you give it.

reviews.title: justaskingsomequestions's review of Planet of Lana

reviewText.content:
Beautiful game with awesome story. Visuals are superb for the platform/puzzle game. Soundtrack is touching and story is presented without excess words. Puzzles are interesting, some of them are not so easy, some of them are irritating, but overall they are good.
My only negative point is QTE-s, which is anticlimactic.
Scenes with huge robots are just breathtaking!

reviews.title: weltas_'s review of Planet of Lana

reviewText.content: Decent puzzles, beautiful art... Planet of Lama is also emotional in a way that it touches you. Negative side is somewhat so much do-nothing walks.

reviews.title: Petite perle dans ce genre de jeu

reviewText.content:
Graphismes, animation et DA en général vraiment superbes, parfaitement renouvelés tout au long du jeu (compter 5/6h ) !
Il s'agit d'un jeu à la limbo avec des énigmes alternées avec des phases avec qq ennemis à dépasser en toute discrétion.
La narration et le gameplay sont plutôt minimalistes comme toujours dans ce style de jeu ; quelques énigmes sont un peu recyclées mais ca va.
L'univers raconté en "fond de tâche" donne quelques informations, et notre compagnon-chat est parfaitement intégré au jeu.
L'ambiance sonore est également très soignée, et globalement zéro bug rencontré.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

Planet of Lana is beautiful in its artwork, the theme that juxtaposes nature and technology is carefully crafted and draws you in from the first moment. The puzzles are relatively simple and repetitive, which is not a big problem. For me, the problem was how slow some puzzles were to solve. And by slow, I mean how much time you need to go from figuring out the solution to actually solving it. This is a bad game design choice, but I cannot be too harsh on an indie studio's debut game, especially since this is my only problem with the game. The story pace is also very good, instead of slowing down towards the end, it does the exact opposite and for good reason. I cannot recommend this enough to fans of the genre.
Not an enjoyable game. Neither simulation, neither arcade fun.

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of Ace Combat 7: Skies Unknown

reviewText.content:
Ace combat is one of those rare franchises that manages to deliver good to amazing games even more than 2 decades after its beginning. Ace combat 7 is no exception. It is a flight sim that presents flight in a very unrealistic manner. You are able to do impossible stunts, carry hundreds of missiles and other physics defying stuff. If you are a diehard player of realistic flight sims like DSC then I don't recommend AC 7, but If your knowledge of fighter jets is “they are cool” then I highly recommend you give it a try.
Story
Unlike a lot of other modern flight sims this one has an actual story and fairly engaging one at that. Shortest way I can describe it is Metal Gear Solid, but worse. Storyline is set in a war between two countries in an alternate universe. It isn't your regular cookie cutter war story. By this I mean that it has some weird elements and a deeper moral message if you're willing to look for it, but it can also be very campy at times and that weirdness can go both ways. The worst part is the way they handle the characters. Some get replaced too quickly while others seem useless.
Gameplay
It is an arcade flight sim where as I said before you can do impossible maneuvers and can carry dozens of missiles. This applies to all the planes in the game of which there is a wide variety. They range from popular ones (F-22, F-15, Su 27) experimental (YF-23, Su 47, FB-22) to completely fictional (ADFX-01, X-02, Darkstar). You acquire them with points you earn during the missions. Grinding will be required if you want all the planes. In addition to aircraft you can also get special weapons, like missiles with very long range, extra guns and more.  Gameplay pacing is really good, as the mission you are playing is rarely similar to the previous. Bosses are okay, although they are rare. Returning players will notice one big addition to the mobility - PSM (post stall maneuver). They turn the previously improbable mobility to downright silly. Overall I would describe the gameplay as fun. There is also multiplayer but I couldn't be bothered with it.
Graphics and artstyle
Since you won't be looking at the ground at a very close range it can get away with lower quality textures while still maintaining AAA levels of graphics. Other than that everything else - plane models, weather, cutscenes make the game look very beautiful.
Atmosphere 
It did make me feel like an unstoppable ace pilot at times.
Soundtrack
Probably the best in the franchise thus far. The latin adds a level of mysticism that is just right for AC 7. Favorite part is “Archange”.
Final Thoughts
dog.jpg

Some levels got really hard, but infinite restarts made success almost inevitable. The challenge of trying to get 2 or 3 stars can get tedious. But there are so many levels it's really fun to get through them all.

Some may like that you can make your own objects and characters, but I wished it had a cleaner look and dropped the 3D aspects.

reviews.title: bugondesk's review of Long Gone Days

reviewText.content: A must-have for the players who enjoy military topics and anime-style visual novels. Long Gone Days has very high-quality work on its cutscenes, character animation, combat system, and pixel art. And most important: the story is very catchy.

Si bien puede resultar algo repetitivo, Dragon Ball Xenoverse 2 es una buena alternativa para revivir la historia clásica de Dragon Ball con un giro de tuerca. En estos días es posible conseguirlo usado a un buen precio.

Pretty solid game. It has a nice pulp sci-fi aesthetic and some good humor to accompany you while exploring the world. Open-world exploration isn't exactly my cup of tea, and the way they incorporate guidance is far from perfect until you get the gist of it (it took me 12 hours to finish the game for a 6 hour campaign, because up until the first half of the game I was almost always lost as to what to do next - but maybe that's just me).
The story is also nothing too spectacular, but keeps you entertained enough. The world was build carefully to make you backtrack after upgrades if you want to discover everything but by the end of the game you realize it is smaller than you initially thought, and the "secrets" aren't that much worth sweating over.
The main questline, though, is incredibly enjoyable, the bosses and other enemies are fun to play against while still challenging you. Combat, shooting and platforming are all on point, carefully crafted to feel satisfying.
While still having its flaws, I think it's overall an enjoyable experience, doing better at the stuff that matter the most in this genre. If you watch the trailer and looks like something you'd enjoy, you'll almost definitely not regret playing it.
its good but its hella P2W and scripted
Amei a nova dinamica do jogo e como está a jogabilidade, um pouco dificil a marcação mas as atualizações novas ajudaram a melhorar a gameplay.....................................

reviews.title: griha24's review of Little Kitty, Big City

reviewText.content:
𝟳/𝟭𝟬
Expecting a competitor to "Stray" from a former Valve developer, we actually get the another low-polygonal "Untitled Goose Game" (even at this level the cartoonish visuals are spoiled by the red outlines of all models why?), this is a good platformer-collectathon, and here at least you can jump on the ledges yourself, The mechanics are not very dynamic and smooth, but when you get used to it, it’s still quite pleasant, but this opens the way to technical problems of the game - there are a lot of places where you can abuse the system by overjumping in inaccessible spaces, for ex. I lost the opportunity to complete the quest with the phone, because I didn’t pull the box out of the hole in the wall, and on the other side it was already impossible to get there. Because of this, it’s not always clear where you can jump and you can even run into an invisible wall and fall from some kind of roof (you can’t walk on wires either, although for some reason you can on very thin ledges), one time I actually flew through the wall, also from little things: people get stuck, and once I had a can stuck between a trash and a vending machine, but I managed to get it back to put it in trash - this is also a strange mechanic, because recycling cans allows you to farm a lot of shiny things, this very monotonous, but I want “money”, at the same time I opened all the purchasable hats, accumulating more than 100 pieces of garbage in stock, why did I do this? - You catch yourself asking this question, it`s not a tech. problem, but also a kind of ill-conceived game design,

Naturally, there is no depth in the mechanics, the gameplay - is fetch something, sneak up, stroke, knock a person down, lie in the sun, and a lot of repetition tasks, a standard set of what you can imagine in a game about a cat, in Stray there was no depth of gameplay either, but there were many other unique features,
and Little Kitty simply has nothing to highlight and nothing to recommend - only if you are a fan of opening platinum in cartoon worlds of standard quality,
I still expected more from the former Valve developer, I wanted a real challenge to other animal games, and not just another “cozzy” indie eexploiting the cat theme (although personally, even the main cat model doesn’t seem cute to me),
For certain types of tasks, you will only improve your climbing skill, which will allow you to climb higher on buildings, eventually climb back to the window of your apartment and complete the story, once again having a final conversation with the current set of animal characters, there seems to be good humor in the dialogues, most of the game can be completed in 5 hours, thanks to Xbox Game Pass, because the price on Steam cannot be considered a plus either,

p.s. By the way, here you can slide down the wall with your claws and jump in the other direction (like the mechanic of jumping from wall to wall), but I found the use of this only once on the final building, why at least this mechanic was not used a couple of times??

😊 Sub to my Steam`s Curator`s page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550
//
Ожидая конкурента "Stray" от бывшего разработчика Valve, получаем на деле малополигональный "Untitled Goose Game" (причём даже такого уровня мультяшный визуал портиться красными обводками всех моделек зачем-то), это неплохой платформер-коллектатон, и тут хотя-бы можно прыгать на уступы самому, механика не очень динамичная и плавная, но когда привыкаешь всё же достаточно приятная, но это и открывает дорогу к тех. проблемам игры - очень много где можно абузить систему перепргнув там, где ещё по идее должно было быть пока что недоступно, например, таким образом я навсегда потерял для себя возможность выполнить квест с телефоном, ибо не сдвинул коробку с прохода, а с обратной стороны уже никак было не зайти. Из-за этого же не всегда понятно, куда можно запрыгнуть и вы можете упереться в невидимую стену и упасть с какой-нить крыши (по проводам ходить тоже нельзя, хотя по очень тонким уступам почему-то можно), а куда-то я впообще попал пролетев сквозь стену, из совсем мелкого люди застревают, и у меня 1 раз застряла банка между мусорницей и вендинговой машиной, но я умудурлися достать обратно, чтобы выбросить - это тоже странная механика, ведь утилизация банок позволяет нафармить крайне много "блестяшек", это очень однообразно, но хочется же "денег", при этом я открыл все покупные шапки, накопив ещё больше 100 мусора в запасе, зачем я это делал? - Подловите вы себя на вопросе, не тех. проблема, но тоже этакая непродуманность геймдизайна,

В механиках, естественно, нет никакой глубины, геймплей что-то принеси, подкрадись, погладь когот, сбей с ног человека, полежи на солнышке, и много заданий-повторений, стандартный набор того, что вы можете представить в игре про кота, в Stray глубин геймплея тоже не было, но было много других уникальных фишек,
а Little Kitty же просто не за что выделить и не за что порекомендовать - только если вы фанат открывания платины в мультяшных мирах стандартного качества,
от бывшего разраба Valve я всё ожидал большего, хотелось реальный вызов, а не просто ещё одну "cozzy" индюшку, выезжающей на котике (хотя сама моделька мне не кажется милой),
За определённые типы заданий вы лишь будете улучшать навык карабканья, который позволит забираться выше по зданиям, в итоге забравшись до окна своей квартиры и завершив сюжет, ещё раз финально поговорив с нынешнем набором персонажей-животных игры, вроде неплохой юмор в диалогах, но крайне не хватает русской локализации, большая часть игры проходится часов за 5, спасибо Xbox Game Pass, ибо цену в Стиме тоже нельзя отнести к плюсам,

p.s. Вот, кстати, тут можно скатиться когтями по стене и отпрыгнуть в другую сторону (типо механика прыганья от стены до стены), но использование этого я нашёл только 1 раз на финальном здании, почему хотя-бы эту механику было пару раз не заюзать??

reviews.title: jignjorf's review of Little Kitty, Big City

reviewText.content: Think 'Untitled Goose Game' except you're a cat. Adorably charming and relaxing, with a fun loop of exploring, collecting, and doing tasks/distractions on your quest to get back home. Definitely can tell it's an indie though, as technically it isn't the most polished game. Still a fun game to play if you're in the mood to just unwind and do cat things in a city sandbox.
Interesting but also a difficult game. Passed all levels except 10-6, 12-1, and 14-9.

reviews.title: This game fundamentally does not understand the original Life Is Strange

reviewText.content:
Double Exposure takes the dual endings of the first game and decides that Max ended up in basically the same place a decade later, which is absurd and takes away the impact of the player's choice in the first game. It furthermore disrespects the fans who chose to save Chloe by separating Max and Chloe for no reason other than it would be inconvenient to include Chloe in the game (and according to a former Deck Nine employee, higher ups in Deck Nine and Square Enix do not like Chloe). Effectively, this decision takes away all of the agency players had in making the final choice in the original game and does not restore any agency by giving players the option to reunite Max and Chloe. The game does absolutely nothing interesting or substantial to justify their separation.
Even if you don't care about Max and Chloe's relationship, the breakup serves little point in the narrative. It’s all setup with no payoff.
Instead, this new game tells a mediocre story with choices that do not matter and an edition of the game that costs an extra $20 for little more than a few bonus scenes. It also attempts to treat Life Is Strange as an MCU story, when the whole point of the first game was to subvert superhero tropes. It's so bad that it's funny, until you remember that the game was made under toxic working conditions where Nazis attempted to include white supremacy symbols in the game.
I will give the game a few points because it is far more explicit with its LGBT inclusion than previous entries in the series. But ultimately that rings hollow considering how they treated Max and Chloe's relationship.

The game's core mechanics are a good evolution of the those presented in the original trilogy, but the game falls down when looking at other components. Crash 4 tries to stand out from it's predecessors by including brand new gimmicks to the mix, including  Grinding, Wall Running, the 4 masks, 3 extra characters, unfortunately I ended up only being a fan of about half of these, whilst the others sit made the biggest flaw of this game even more aggravating, box hunting. 

To premise this, I have 100% the trilogy multiple times for fun, both OG and N.Sane trilogy. But something about Crash 4 frustrated me enough that not only did I start to actively skip boxes but even optional levels to try and finish the game as soon as possible. 

Box volume and placement seem to not be placed in mind of being fun for the player but to entice re-playability. On basically every stage there are boxes hidden off screen in order to stop you from grabbing all the gems. Spending double to triple the amount of time on a level due to the sheer length of each, only to be off by one or two get's old real quick, and the notion of playing a half hour level in the hope you don't miss that box the second time is un-appetising in comparison to an OG crash game, where most levels are finished in 3-10 minutes for a non-expert player.  This is not helped by grind sections which almost always play as a guessing game, to figure out what's next, forcing you to kill yourself to restart (making 3 deaths or less almost impossible first try if you are looking at bosses. What should be fun characters in place of Dingodile and Cortex become chores since gathering those boxes takes an even larger amount of time (whether that be hoovering or specific platform placement) an even bigger chore when you die and realize you have to grab hoover up 100 boxes before the first checkpoint once more. Tawna on the other hand is just a strange character that feels off in the worls and feels incredibly bugger, with her wall jump and hookshot which seems to only work about 75% of the time. 

And then half way through the game,you are told you have to play through every level again to grab all the boxes with a skin change? I'm Okay, thanks.

Toy's For Bob, clearly put a lot of effort into trying to make this game live up to the original trilogy but, in my opinion, try to lengthen the game to fit "modern length" levels has put in incredibly strong strain on each and although I was ready to 100% this game when it was announced, at this point I am happy to leave it after the credits and move onto something else.

I was so hyped for this game before the release, being a PlayStation child in the 90's and early 2000's. In fact, this Crash Bandicoot 4 is the first game I've ever bought for the retail full price. I am not disappointed. The game keeps all core elements of the original trilogy, and most resembles the original. I keep thinking whether the developers really captured the feel of the Crash series. In the "modern" style, there are no "lives", but you get a death counter. To balance this, we got a more difficult game.

There is a lot of content here: original levels, inverted levels, flashback tape levels, multiple gems to collect (6 per level). The levels are long and HARD. This is not a game you just pick up, play, and finish. This is hard work.
