I don’t know what I was expecting. The well-worn pun in the title should have tipped me off that Dust: An Elysian Tail wasn’t going to be a work of narrative excellence. Still, when the first five minutes, the poor plotting and terrible voice acting knocked me back. It’s a problem that the astounding visuals exacerbate. When something looks this beautiful, it makes every flaw more readily apparent.

Dust: An Elysian Tail is a side-scrolling combo-based action game. If you’ve played Muramasa: The Demon Blade for the Wii, then you should know exactly what to expect. The developer lifted most of the game’s structure directly from that Vanillaware-developed title. Dust, the hero in An Elysian Tail, is capable of 1,000-hit combos. Each level is a series of connected arenas, and the overworld map allows you to select your next destination in whichever order you choose. Non-player characters who provide Dust with information and quests reside in peaceful towns. All of these design decisions are implemented almost exactly as they are in Muramasa.

Not that there’s anything wrong with an indie game taking a familiar formula and expanding on it. Unfortunately, that’s where developer Humble Hearts fails. Dust: An Elysian Tail is a beautiful but poorly paced mess with eye-roll-inducing voice acting and dialog.

Dust: An Elysian Tail more combat

WHAT YOU’LL LIKE

Hyper-smooth animation and gorgeous visuals
From a technical standpoint, Dust is possibly the best looking XBLA game. The animation has a buttery-smooth quality that surpasses just about anything Cartoon Network is airing on Saturday mornings. The characters and enemies move with a fluidity that gives the undertaking a mesmerizing swirl that is difficult to look away from.

The sprite work and background art are both highly detailed and crisp looking. This is incredibly important when the action gets especially frantic. Despite dozens of enemies, scores of projectiles, and hundreds of melee hits all simultaneously flying around the screen, the action is still discernible thanks to the polished graphics.

A fun, high-energy combat system
Stabbing, slicing, and electrocuting is Dust’s bread and butter. The game is never better than when you have a fully powered-up protagonist taking on legions of sword fodder. Deftly switching back and forth from direct-combat melee attacks to projectile assaults with the help of Dust’s sidekick character Fidget looks and feels very cool.

Humble Hearts instills a bit of strategy by forcing players to keep an eye on a single meter that multiple skills communally draw from. Too many indirect attacks will wipe out the meter quickly. To replenish it, Dust must successfully land a handful of sword strikes. The dodge move also relies on that same meter. Going into a battle without the ability to dodge increases the likelihood of a negative outcome for the player.

It’s a constant game of balancing attacks. A variety of moves is especially important if you want to get 1,000-plus hit combos which is kinda the whole point of Dust.

WHAT YOU WON’T LIKE

Absurd voice acting, silly narrative tropes, and questionable character design
In the opening moments of the experience, the protagonist discovers he has amnesia, he gets a magical sword, and he acquires a wise-ass sidekick. It all occurs because that’s just what happens in these games. That’s enough for the developer, and the developer assumes it’s enough for the player.

Fidget, Dust’s flying nimbat (a mix between a cat and a bat) cohort, has a shrill voice that takes a while to get used to. Dust, meanwhile, speaks with that common-in-games inflection of a teenager who is wise beyond his years. It’s not annoying to listen to, but it did make me roll my eyes. Although, that is nothing compared to some of the townsfolk, who all speak in wildly random cultural accents. The first town had characters that spoke with Australian, Italian, and eastern-European twangs.

I could forgive a lot of that if the story was worth giving a damn about, but it isn’t. It’s a standard hero’s journey. Most story beats are very obvious and swamped in melodrama. Spoiler warning: If you meet someone who is ill in a town with a graveyard…well, you probably know how that quest ends.

The look of the characters is very hit and miss. Everyone in the game is either an anthropomorphic mouse-rabbit-type thingy or lizard. Dust looks cool with his shrouded face and blue, wavy clothing, but I was off-put by Fidget’s design. She has wide hips and an unnatural bustline that gives me the willies. I understand some people are into that (and I’m not judging), but it just made me uncomfortable. A lot of the friendly cast looks like Care Bear rejects. At least most of the enemies — outside of the common grunt types — have an interesting and sinister look.

Boring exploration, frustrating platforming, and broken pacing
As fun as the combat is, it buckles under long spells. It’s great in short bursts but fighting enemies is not something I wanted to do for an hour straight. It doesn’t have enough variety, so it gets very repetitive. Humble Hearts realized this and attempted to break up the combat sections with exploration, platforming, and challenge arenas.

This is where the game comes unglued. The exploration is boring. As Dust collects more abilities, he has the ability to find more secrets. It’s something that props up an entire genre of Metroids and Castlevanias, but it doesn’t have the same effect here. Where Super Metroid feels exquisitely planned out, Dust’s exploration feels slapped together. I was never proud of myself for figuring out where something was, I simply went through the dull motions.

The platforming is something that suffers in comparison to the combat. When the protagonist really gets going with his attacks, he zooms across the screen like a locomotive. It feels magical. Jumping over spikes, on the other hand, feels inaccurate and silly — especially when those spikes can cause such massive damage.

It’s all very boring, and it destroys the pacing.

A 10hour platformer which is not groundbreaking in any aspect, but still is pretty enjoyable, especially if you like easy games to relax with your gamepad. You follow around a dude with the classic case of amnesia, with a classic funny gimicky companion while doing classic jump and attack stuff.
The story is decent, while it is kind of childish (it does seem like a game is geared toward the younger audience, there is not much text in game, the quests are straightforward, even the "hidden/secret" puzzles are extremely basic, and most of the time are just solved by getting further in the story and getting that upgrade to your jump that you were missing)
The fighting system is responsive and fun, though it is pretty basic by most standards, there are basically 3 types of attack + 3 projectile attacks and 2 combos. That's it. The timings are forgiving, the opponents are mostly tank-n-spank with some variations.
There is leveling and equipment system in place, which is robust enough for a platformer game, still in itself it is again very simple at it's core (items do not posess much unique qualities, if the armour costs more and was found later in the game it gives more defence and is straight up better, same for the rest of the items.) There are crafting materials and crafting, though to craft highest end stuff in the end of the game - you actually have to grind materials (which I wouldn't expect to find in a platformer and was never inclined to do so)
The art in the game is awesome, characters are monsters have decent design effort put into them, though most of the time the designs were reused throughout the game, which is not that great for such a short game anyway.

All in all I don't think I personally would recommend this game over, say, Guacamelee. But it is still quite ok if you liked what you have read.

PS. ♥♥♥♥ unskippable credits at the end of the game so hard.

This is an example of a game which I can objectively classify as very good, but also, one that I cannot play. I expected this to be a goofy adventure where you can make your own trail from top to bottom, ignoring real life physics, pedal to the metal stuff. It is the exact opposite. You have to be patient, learn the controls, get accustomed to a level, and then beat it again and again. It is not the way I play games, but there are plenty of people who are going to enjoy this, I am sure.

I am loving this game and I just started playing it two days ago. I've put in probably like 8 hours of playtime and I cannot get enough of how extravagantly gorgeous some of the areas that I have died in are. Truly, this game is beautiful and if you play it, you should expect to die. A lot. A fu*KiN@ lot okay. But it's all worth it to unlock another trail or mountain (or hopefully in the future another bike??.. 4 bike parts right now seem like a task that is very far away and I am a gay that cannot drive..) that is riddled with plenty of curves for you to pump your brakes on. I'm playing it through the Xbox game pass but also adding it to my Switch wishlist because I want this one on the go.

As a Ghostbuster fan I can be a bit biased but we all know that some of the previous games did not make us feel like Ghostbusters this game does with the  4v1 a symmetrical lay out you can also be the ghost which is quite fun.

reviews.title: koktoo's review of Immortals Fenyx Rising

reviewText.content: Immortals Fenyx Rising catapults players into a mythological world brimming with beauty and challenges. With its enchanting graphics, captivating gameplay, and a fresh take on Greek mythology, it delivers a gaming experience that's nothing short of extraordinary. This open-world adventure offers a picturesque, colorful world to explore, complemented by demanding puzzles, robust character customization, a lovable narrative, and humor that will keep you grinning from ear to ear. The game's approach to Greek mythology feels rejuvenating, and its compelling mix of combat and exploration makes it an irresistible journey. With exceptional puzzle design and a lack of serious drawbacks, Immortals Fenyx Rising emerges as a gem that's well worth your time.

A Visually Stunning World

Immortals Fenyx Rising is a visual masterpiece that seamlessly blends the vibrant hues of its open world with awe-inspiring landscapes. The game's world is a sight to behold, and it's evident that the developers poured love and creativity into every corner.

A Unique Mythological Experience

The game's fresh approach to Greek mythology provides an engaging backdrop for the adventure. Players will find themselves immersed in a world filled with larger-than-life creatures, mythical beings, and divine interventions.

Robust Character Customization

Immortals Fenyx Rising offers players an extensive array of character customization options, allowing you to craft your hero to your liking. Whether it's altering your appearance or refining your playstyle, this level of customization is a welcome feature.

A Lovable Narrative with Humor

The game's narrative is endearing, laced with humor that brings the story to life. Immortals Fenyx Rising strikes a balance between grand mythological tales and light-hearted moments, creating a narrative that's both epic and enjoyable.

Exceptional Puzzle Design

The puzzles in the game are thoughtfully designed, offering a fair share of challenges that will stimulate your problem-solving skills. They add depth and variety to the gameplay, making the exploration all the more rewarding.

I do not play platformers often, so this was very hard. It reminded me of supermeat boy in how its a fast platformer which requires perfection and you will die over and over to reach that. The art style is gorgeous. Its got a real lovecraft aesthetic which works brilliantly paired with just endless death. So many times i just kind of marvelled at how good the backgrounds looked. The story is pretty thin but the cutscenes between each level look great. The music is intense and fits well with the vibe. If you dont mind being a bit masochistic this game is a lot of fun.

reviews.title: Good game, but too hard for me

reviewText.content:
On my 3rd level on Standard Difficulty, I figured this game was too hard for my old bones. But once I switched to Novice, I actually started to have fun; the game still requires some hard moves, but now there are so many checkpoints, you feel you are facing only one challenge at a time. I was still missing too many tricky double jumps, but a little persistence got me to "The End?".

Thing is, the game has directional controls, a "jump" button and an "action" button -- that's it. The action button may attack, or dash, or dash-attack, or kick to the side, or kick upwards, or kick-flip a switch, all depending on how long you hold the button AND what direction you are going. At first, I cursed this design, often trying to attack an enemy but instead dashing towards deadly spikes... But going into "Novice", I learned to appreciate its elegance -- once you get used to the controls, you barely move your fingers around, and the game gets into a nice flow of its own. I imagine that good players will be able to pull amazing sequences on Standard, thanks to this.

Also, the pixel art between levels is lovely, cute and creepy all at once. The cutscenes manage to tell the (simple) story with nearly no words.

Pity that the game seems to lock one whole chapter and some sort of true ending behind the Standard difficulty (on Novice, the last screen literally said "The End?")... but that's a reward for players more skilled than me. :D

Anyway, a fun platformer, even if quite hard. Score: 76/100.

Rainbow Billy: The Curse of the Leviathan is an absolute gem, especially in this day and age. 

The game is a creature collection game where you have to bring back colour to the creatures and the world by confronting them, aka talking the critters through their anxieties and other often mental health related situations. Later on you'll deepen your friendship through gifts and more talking to hash out whatever they're going through.

The topics are very varied, there's some bullying (from both a bullies perspective and a victims), an artists anxiety about creating the best they can to be remembered, a prankster needing to learn the difference between a good prank and truly hurting others, break-up guilt, depression, lgbtqia+ matters.. There's definitely something for everyone's struggles in here and the way these are handled in conversation options and the way Billy talks through them is fantastic. 

The game is very accessible to kids as a form of learning empathy, to deal with grief, to put ones struggles into words and more, so I'd definitely consider showing it to a young one. As an adult many of the topics may hit harder due to having gone through a lot of them oneself, but the game never really leaves a comfortable space in how the themes are explored. There's also a good amount of humour and, well, colour and cute visuals to balance out heavier moments. All in all, it's a great feel-good game.
La trama y los diálogos ponen a prueba tu paciencia pero fuera de eso el gameplay es tan pero tan bueno que realmente cubre por eso, es genial en tantos sentidos y me encanta

Neon White is a first person shooter with platformer elements and speedrun core.

Incredible level design, fast-paced gameplay, different weapons and skills, highly replayable.

You will need to complete the level as quickly as possible, and also try to get gifts and other things in each level.
Dialogues are kinda meaningless, but the storytelling is not what this game about.

Great music, shoot and run, trying to think how to finish everything to fast.
Easy to understand and hard to master.

very addicting gameplay loop, top music, and in-spite of the mostly awfully cringe characters and dialogue the interactions and storylines were often charming and funny!
some of the larger levels showed some rather tedious issues with the gameplay though. the quick-reload level takes a good 2 seconds which adds up quickly when going for top times. the fact you can only max-jump, and the floaty slow gravity takes multiple loooong seconds to land one of those jumps, which further accents the 2 second reset wait as the jump key is also the 'start level' key.

overall very worth a try, at the very least.

Suite du premier jeu, s'il n'est pas indispensable d'y avoir joué c'est tout de même fortement conseillé pour comprendre tous les clins d'oeil.
Le jeu débute d'ailleurs directement par un niveau entier et complet, avec juste un "rappel du dernier épisode", mais pas de niveau didacticiel.

On retrouve donc notre binôme de "flics du paranormal" sur 9 enquêtes/niveaux séparés, avec tout de même quelque références entre eux pour la cohérence de l'univers.

Toujours basé sur un humour bien senti et des clins d'oeil à plein de références, le gameplay reste du point'n click classique à la DayOfTheTentacle and co.

Les décors sont variés, le pixel art toujours propre, et le jeu tourne sur un vieux PC à 120 fps sans souci :)
Le jeu est porté par ses dialogues et histoires très bien écrites, on prend un plaisir à cliquer partout pour lire les remarques ; quelques énigmes demanderont parfois un coup de pouce d'un guide, mais ça reste très occasionnel.

I've played the demo of WLITM one day, and I immediately feeled that I'd have loved the full game.
Yes, the gameplay isn't particularly creative... it's a quite linear puzzle platformer,  not really hard... but...

The story is great! Fun and random in the beginning, but deep and more and more touching as you progress... with really good musics that match perfectly the mood of the moment and the nature of the characters.
And the characters... they're all very well written, with feelings and backgrounds that make them so alive, so human!
If you're the kind of person who doesn't fear your own feelings and emotion, and you're searching for a moving story, this game will not disappoint you!

, from former devs of Sonic games, which, in principle, is visible to the naked eye, as well as a strong emphasis under the “Switch” console, which is why you will always see pixels in objects that are slightly at a distance (e.g. it`s difficult to distinguish water from the blue earth's surface), in short - technically they decided not to finish the game for "large devices", but okay, these are all complaints against the terrible publisher - 2K, which for some reason made a subsidiary publisher of platformers, but do not give them any promotion,potential indie hits remain unnoticed at the bottom of Steam,
And like the previous “Rollerdrome” from Private Division, this game deserves your attention, If you like short arcade levels that you can replay to find 3 “coins”, for which you can open secret tasks for 1 minute of gameplay, or, complete 3 simple extra tasks from characters - they are almost always on your way and most often it’s just to brimng something with a timer, collecting all the ordinary coins that fall out of boxes is pointless, because with them you can buy only 4 consumables, and each in 1 quantity, for example - fall protection, this is done so that it is impossible to be reborn without losing points 2 times for 1 level (you can’t die, you just lose all points), but byw there is a small bug with this - consumables may not be purchased, and you have to buy it before each level,
In general, the game is very unfriendly to exploration, the world is not particularly detailed, as soon as you stop, you often run the risk of being caught by the local police - penguins, who begin to stick to you more and more until they put you in a net,
And instead of finding a secret place, you are more likely to fall into a cliff or go to a place where there is nothing, because the authors forgot to put up an invisible wall, and the neural network could have generated the replicas of the people living here,
You can use our “yo-yo” to hit the same penguins or boxes, rotating it in any direction or around you, there are all sorts of “power-ups” when our toy (by the way, it’s alive) turns into a huge ball, or stretches behind a palm tree to make a long jump, or is used as a boat, but these mechanics are not enough, at the end of the any level there is a small "qte game" that gives extra points.
The plot set-up is cartoonishly cool, but the whole script consists of only 2 lines, and the world doesn’t provide enough lore to “believe” in it,
This is why the levels lack visual variety;; I only remember the water locations,
And the bosses are visually just the opposite: it`s funny, easy, perhaps even too much, not deep, but not stressful.

😊 𝗦𝘂𝗯 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝘆 𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺`𝘀 𝗖𝘂𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗼𝗿`𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝗴𝗲: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550
//
Лёгкий аркадный, не самый плавный в управлении, но концептуально интересный платформер, где можно летать на ЙО-ЙО! Кто-то ещё помнит, когда эта игрушка была популярна?)
, вроде от бывших разрабов игр про Соника, что, впринципе, видно невооружённым взглядом, также как и виден сильный упор под приставку "Switch", из-за чего вы всегда будете видеть пиксели в объектах, находящихся немного на отдалении (например воду сложно отличить от синей земной поверхности), короче - технически игру решили не доделывать для "крупных устройств", но ладно, это всё претензии к ужасному издателю, к 2K, которые зачем-то сделали дочернего издателя для платформеров, но не дают им никакого продвижения, потенциальные инди-хиты на релизе остаются незамеченными на дне Стима,
А как и предыдущий "Rollerdrome" от Private Division, эта игра заслуживает вашего внимания, если вы любите короткие аркадные уровни, которые можно перепроходить, чтобы донайти 3 "коина", за которые можно открыть секретные задания на 1-минуту геймплея, или, довыполнить 3 лёгких доп. задания от персонажей - они практически всегда на вашем пути и чаще всего это просто что-то отнести на время, а собирать все обычные монеты, выпадающие из ящиков бессмысленно, потому что на них вы можете купить лишь 4 расходника, и каждый в 1 количестве, например - защита от падения, сделано это чтобы нельзя было возродиться без потери очков 2 раза за 1 катку (умереть нельзя, просто теряем очки), но кст есть и баг, в том плане, что расходник может не покупаться, а покупать придётся перед каждым уровнем,
Вообще игра очень недружелюбна к исследованию, мир и так то не особо детализирован, как только остановитесь, зачастую рискуете быть пойманными местной полицией - пингвинами, которые начинают налипать на вас всё больше и больше, пока не закуют в сеть,
А вместо нахождения секретного места вы скорее провалитесь в обрыв или зайдёте туда, где ничего нет, ибо авторы забыли поставить невидимую стену, а реплики обитающих тут людей могла и нейросеть сгенерировать,
Вы можете использовать нашу "йо-йо", чтобы бить тех же пингвинов или ящики, вращая её в любую сторону или вокруг себя, есть всякие "пауэр-апы", когда наша игрушка (кстати, она живая) превращается в огромный шар, или растягивается за пальму, чтобы сделать дальний прыжок, или используется как катер, но механик достаточно мало, в конце каждого уровня есть небольшая "qte-игра", за которую дадут доп. очки.
Завязка сюжета мультяшно-прикольная, но сюжета в 2 строчки, а миру опять же не хватает лора, чтобы в него "поверить",
Поэтому же уровням не хватает и визуального разнообразия, мне запомнились только водные локации,
А боссы визуально как раз наоборот забавные, лёгкие, возможно даже слишком, не глубокие, зато не напряжные.
A worthwhile experience if you like walking sims, but it shows that it was a first go at it from indie devs.
Great narrative and subtly atmospheric. I loved exploring a queer womans childhood through a game, something completely underserved generally.

After finishing the game in about 2 hours, I would say it wasn’t great. Cool features of walking through the house. But the story line was lacking. And the game itself was cut incredibly short. There was an opportunity for side achievements that apparently were over looked. 
It felt as if the developers rushed to release the game.

Gone Home released during a very "culturally tumultuous" period. Being a game that focused on LGBT matters meant this game was going to get praise from one side and be absolutely smashed by the other. "It's a walking simulator," said critics. Yeah, you do a lot of walking in this game but that's because it's simply an exploratory experience. The player character has just come home from studying abroad and her family has moved into a large inherited house. Your sister should be there but she isn't and as you progress through the game you'll uncover the truth behind her disappearance. I know that sounds like a true crime sort of thing but Gone Home is anything but. There's no grisly murder and despite the eerie atmosphere of the game there are no monsters or jump scares whatsoever. It's safe to just relax and get lost in the minutia of this world. The more you explore the more you'll uncover about the plot through letters your sister has written for you. It's important to be thorough while exploring the house because it's full of props and mementos that further explain the story alongside the completely separate B-plot as to why your parents aren't home either. Gone Home tells a story in a manner unlike any other game out there and it's a story worth experiencing.

Fantastic game! Neat story and nice variety in levels. It requires absolute precision at times to reach certain areas, which can be frustrating at times, but it never feels unforgiving. Also soundtrack is great, as in all Sydney Hunter games.

I really enjoyed Still There. It was an interesting concept to just be thrown into the game with almost 0 idea of where you are or why. Purely in that I didn't think there was much of a story or background explanation given at the start. Unless there was and I was just blind to it but I don't remember there being any real proper setting the scene. Being made to do work in a game was... interesting XD And the cocky, sarcastic computer companion was very funny to deal with but still not as awesome as the little lizard friend! It felt very technical, though maybe that's because I kept forgetting to open up the manual to try and decipher what I might need to do (sounds like me). It is a LOT of buttons/knobs to control and it looks very overwhelming. Definitely a puzzling aspect to the game. I'm still not 100% certain why the only process where each step was explained to you every single time was making water, I don't need you to tell me what to do with the pee every time XD There were definitely some... questionable.... items included in the game seemingly just for the lols. Which is fine and it kinda linked into the story (in the time before you were here) but still seemed like it was just added because the devs could. The storyline does eventually develop more and you do start to learn why you're there, where you are, and your sad back story that led you to this point. The game does smack you in the face at the end with the final piece of your backstory so be aware of that but overall the story development was good. The art was great and the music was alright too. Would play again, will likely go achievement hunting to finish it off.
So weird, so cool. It is fun to find a way to trick our assignment AI. The colors are a little bit too bright to look at for a long time.

My interest in Telltale games had dwindled a lot because the walking dead season 2 and GoT not nearly approached the impact that twd season 1 had on me. I was even actively annoyed by GoT for lacking any satisfaction storywise. So I was happily surprised that tales from the borderlands is a fun ride with interesting characters and nice humor (if you like the absurd borderlands humor). Special mention for the incredible musical opening credits that open each episode. They made me laugh and get more invested in the story at the same time.

Jogo excelente , extremamente divertido e engraçado.
Até hoje me lembro da cena dos fake shoots na empresa, rir pra krl

reviews.title: Western JRPG, and it plays like a boardgame!

reviewText.content:
I got really into into Battle Chasers, especially on the go with the Switch it was a perfect companion for travels and long flights. It takes a some great elements of JRPG and give them a western touch to keep things fresh! While it can be a bit grindy (that's the jrpg part..) making the whole thing feel like a tabletop/boardgame was really neat for me. Switching constantly between the various 'modes' (Worldmap, dungeon crawling, and fights) really kept things fresh.

Sadly i didn't finish it, mostly because the story really didn't keep me too engaged. The artstyle and animation at top notch, but the world and story felt pretty cliche and unoriginal. Nothing really terrible mind you, but i wouldn't put it as one of the main point of praise. 

Fighting mechanics were pretty clever, and quickly becomes challenging. Each character does feel very unique with their abilities and you end up having to try specifics ways of using each of them, love the strategic aspects of some tougher fights.

De beaux graphismes bien animés, un gameplay sympa, une interface très bien pensée.
Et c'est tout.
Scénario timbre poste, juste une suite de combats, avec des périodes de farms et d'autres subis et inutiles d'ennemis 10 niveaux plus bas.
Je n'irai pas au bout des 40h de jeu nécessaires pour voir les crédits de fin, ce jeu est un beau potentiel gâché, dommage !

(Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass)

Amazing additon to the Mega Man line-up, the flow can be a bit weird but it's still a fun time. Good amount of replayability and another nice ode to 8-bit platformers of yester-year. A 'modern' retro classic. Not quite as good as 9 but still a great game.

Нам рассказывается история Шрама - человека, который остановил Стрелка. Как мы помним, Стрелок по сюжету Теней Чернобыля попал в грузовик смерти, а как он туда попал, нам не говорят. Чистое Небо это предыстория к Теням Чернобыля. Шрам - наёмник, который пережил два выброса и был найден группировкой Чистое Небо. Дабы не затягивать обзор, расскажу вкратце. После того, как Шрам очнулся на базе Чистого Неба, он узнал о том, что некий Стрелок пытается пробраться в Центр Зоны, из за этого происходят частые выбросы. Чистому Небу и Шраму надо это прекратить, на кону стоит множество жизней. Так и начинается наша погоня за Стрелком, мы будем переходить из локации в локации, все ближе к Центру Зоны. Когда мы все же до него доберемся, нам предстоит уничтожить его пси защиту. После этого происходит мощнейший выброс, в ходе которого по всей видимости погибает начальство Чистого Неба. Нам показывают Стрелка который не может двигаться, вот так на него подействовал выброс. Ну а с Шрамом что-то случилось, из за чего выбросы действуют на него не так сильно. Он начинает осматриваться и видит темный коридор, в котором куча сталкеров, в том числе и Стрелок. Титры. Это и был первый плюс - сюжет. На самом деле в игре еще много интересных вещей, так была добавлена война группировок. Задумка интересная, но реализация ужасна. Вся война сводится к захвату опорных точек противника, последней точкой является база врага. Так, начиная войну за Сталкеров Одиночек против Бандитов, в связи с багом войну завершить невозможно. Для захвата точки, необходимо, чтобы на нее пришли дружественные войска, вот только на базу Бандитов Одиночки не идут. Поэтому Бандиты просто постоянно там спавнятся и этим не дают завершить войну. Или же ситуация между Долгом и Свободой. После захвата базы Долга, я заметил, что они просто отспавнились в главном здании. Нормально, да? Это и есть первый минус - баги. И это лишь мелкая их часть. Но с другой стороны, война группировок - это плюс, мне было очень интересно отбивать контратаки Долга и штурмовать базу Бандитов, это было круто. Третьим плюсом является поиск артефактов. По сравнению с первой частью, где артефакты просто лежали на определенных местах, тут их надо искать с помощью детектора в определенных местах. Четвертым плюсом является большой арсенал. По сравнению с первой частью было добавлено много новых пушек. Пятый плюс - модификация оружия и брони. Теперь у мастеров можно починить сломанное оружие / броню, а также улучшить их. По сравнению с первой частью, где улучшенное оружие можно было только найти где-нибудь - это огромный плюс. Шестой плюс - быстрые перемещения. Ну серьезно, куда без них.

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Clear Sky

reviewText.content:
STALKER: Clear sky is the second in the STALKER trilogy and a prequel to Shadow of Chernobyl. Honestly, and many will agree with me, this is the weakest in the series. It’s a rehash of the previous game with slightly better graphics, some new areas and a new but worse story. Still the core of STALKER is there so I can’t call it bad, it’s just mid. It’s not required to play to be able to understand the next game. I would only recommend it to anyone who just wants more STALKER.

Story 
Same setting as the previous game with only minimal differences. The story itself is worse. 
You are part of an organisation trying to stop people from going to the centre of the zone in the guise of - very bad things will happen. It’s mostly just doing the same as in SoC, but without the magic of experiencing it for the first time.

Mechanics and gameplay
Gameplay wise there are multiple improvements, but it’s overshadowed by the next game in the series, Call of Pripyat, that does everything even better. 
My biggest problem is that 80% of the map is the same. Playing this right after SoC makes both blur together. It could have been used to good effect if the storyline was better, but it isn’t so.
There is one thing I wasn’t included in the next title - faction warfare. It was in SoC, but it didn’t have much depth. Here you can join your faction of choice and fight for them, even taking territory. I wasn’t interested in it, so ignored it, however if you do want to spice up your playthrough, consider it.

Graphics 
Improved compared to the previous title. I mainly remember the lighting being better. 

Atmosphere/Immersion
Even with all the criticism I dished out, I was still mostly immersed in the world of Clear Sky. So I can’t say anything bad about the atmosphere, it has even improved in some parts.

Music 
These games share many of the songs in their soundtracks. They are almost exclusively dark ambience. Clear Sky does have exclusive songs in each of the faction bases, the bandit radio being very popular to the point where I had no idea it was even from Clear Sky. My favourite is “Loner Radio”.

Final thoughts 
Ever heard that very popular “Cyka blyat” sound bite, I believe it comes from this game, or at the very least from the STALKER series.

Gameplay wise this game plays like any classic survival horror game, taking cues from both Resident Evil and Silent Hill. You have a fairly large weapon line up, with a pistol, shotgun, revolver, flare gun (that can also use grenade shells as ammo), rifle and sub machine gun. I honestly just expected a pistol, shotgun and revolver but this game really over delivered on its weapons line up and I love it. However, you also get a list of secondary items you can equip like a stun prod (which is basically like a defensive knife), thermite flares you can use to burn enemy corpses, so they don't come back (very RE1 remake), a flashlight etc.. I like that the game gives you so many options and the tools to deal with the threats. Combat uses a twin stick shooter system, which I hate playing on controllers in general, but on keyboard and mouse its very accurate and responsive. Overall, I liked the combat and the game has enough enemy variety that you often can't guess what will be waiting for you in the next room.

Puzzle wise, this game actually has some really good puzzles. Very old school in their design, but none of them felt obscure and hard to solve. They also include a radio in this game, but unlike in Silent Hill where its used to detect enemies, in this game you use it to solve many of the puzzles by listening to certain frequencies. I thought it was a clever integration of the radio and there's even a specific enemy type that you need the radio to fight, which I thought was cool, although those enemies did get annoying after a while.

Sound design is also perfect from the monsters making very unsettling noises down to the sounds the weapons make, as they sound very punchy when you fire them which adds to the satisfaction. The music is also amazing, with some very melancholic tracks that reminded me of Silent Hill, while still doing its own thing. This all adds to the games incredible atmosphere that really makes you feel isolated on this desolate planet.

As for horror, this game doesn't try as hard to scare you with jump scares or anything like that. The atmosphere does help the game, but I never felt as scared as I did playing games like Darkwood or Lost In Vivo where even an abandoned subway station scared the hell out of me, despite not much happening. The gore is used very well in this game as the mixture of anime and a PS1 art style adds to the unsettling nature of it, but its never over done that you become desensitised to it. The cut-scenes also use a lot of unsettling imagery that I will talk about more later. Overall the game has a good atmosphere and some good scares, but it wasn't as well done as I would have liked.

The story though was just beautiful. Its done in a very minimal way, as most cut scenes last less then 30 seconds, but its the imagery they use that communicates a lot without saying much. Its got a very European art house film style to it which I liked with a lot of German language and imagery, which connected with me personally, since I studied both German language and history in high school. There's also plenty of notes scattered around for you to read that does a lot of world building about the different Replika units you encounter and the setting they live in. However, these notes are vital to read to understand characters backstories and motivations as they don't outright tell you in cut scenes. There is no voice acting aside for some audio on the radio that's in German, but honestly the story was still very effective and I don't feel like it really needed voice acting to tell it.

As for complaints, I don't have that many really. I originally had issues with the inventory managment but the devs have since patched most of these issues out giving players more options of how they want to play. So that takes care of all my complaints really.

I wanted to like this a lot more than I did. The gameplay and setting takes some obvious inspiration from franchises like Dead Space, Resident Evil, and Silent Hill. The story is something akin to an H.P. Lovecraft short mixed with a little bit of Dead Space.

I had some issues with gameplay. Text can be extremely hard to read and this can make your ammo situation harder. Sometimes I'd have difficulty aiming at an enemy if there were multiple in a room. There were moments where the game emptied my inventory before a boss fight and I wasn't aware, so I entered a boss fight without a gun. 

The story is intentionally confusing. Without getting into spoilers the entire game is a mess of connected events and distorted reality. Even after the game ended I was confused as to what I just witnessed. There are 5 endings in total that help shape the narrative but unfortunately I don't feel motivated enough to play through this that many times.

Signalis is a pure perfection, a masterpiece of horror and deep story.

Try not to spoil anything for yourself. Just start this game.

It's a classic survival horror with many resemblance to original Silent Hill and Resident Evil.
You can also see inspiration from Ghost in the Shell and Blame!.

Plot with a deep layers will keep you on a hook through all the game.
Signalis has 5 different endings, which will show you some interest twists about human's consciousness.
You will get information piece by piece through many documents and dialogues with different characters.

Various arsenal will help you get through the enemies - Pistol, Shotgun, Rifle, Revolver and other useful stuff.
Don't forget that not all enemies should be exterminated. Save your resources.

Beautiful OST and sound effects, which helps a lot to keep the game atmosphere surreal and grim.

Puzzles. Yes, puzzles. It's not just going guns blazing through the story, you will need to think a bit.
Morse code and radio signals.

...wake up.

Signalis is an absolute masterpiece of retro-style horror. The atmosphere is incredible and the game is perfectly designed. Puzzles are difficult, but not frustrating. You can either fight enemies or try to run or sneak around them to save on ammo. The music and sound design is phenomenal and really brings the whole atmosphere together. The story, as well, is the perfect blend of depth and intentional vagueness to completely captivate you. It's a must play game.

Overall Score: 10/10

A desperate plea for help sets Shadow, the sole survivor of his clan, on one last mission to uncover what started the path to perpetual ruin.

Retro platformer with a clear resemblance to the classic Ninja Gaiden will dive your right away into the hack 'n' slash action, leaping through the ruins of Mekacity.

As the sole survivor, you must take down more than a dozen apocalyptic bosses and rescue your clan to unlock permanent Ninjutsu skills and abilities.

Experience a story - told in-game and through animated cinematic scenes between the action.
Authentic 8-bit presentation with handcrafted sprites, a detailed pixel aesthetic.
Pokemon Quest is a very simple but fun "Action" RPG that plays rather similar to Book of Demons.

This game had potential as a Switch game, but it just falls short. Way too short. Everything is grind-filled and just the controls are annoying as hell. I do not reccomend picking this up except on mobile. It fits more there than a console game.

Очень увлекательная игра , особенно после рабочего дня-расслабляет. Очень понравилось летать под дождем по городу представляя себя одним из доставщиков, которые да же не смотря на пандемию и погоду, доставляют посылки людям, это создает еще большее погружение в игровой процесс .Буду непременно следить за дальнейшим развитием проекта! Рекомендую
Хорошая игра для расслабления. Интуитивно понятный игровой процесс, но есть небольшие проблемы c игрой вдвоем. Музыкальная составляющая огонь, буду дальше следить за проектом)
хорошая игра для того, чтобы расслабиться, залипал в неё пол дня, очень интересно. Рекомендую!
Игра создана, чтобы позалипать и отдохнуть от всего. Круто. Разработчикам желаю успехов в развитии проекта.
Я бы назвал эту игру - "Игра на раслабоне". Доставляешь посылочки , получаешь деньги, повышаешь уровень и переходишь на новые локации. Все просто и лаконично.
Good game! Really want it in category! pls twitch help w/ it! good luck to creator!
Игра чтобы почилить после трудного дня на работе. Мне все понравилось.

There is no denying Five Dates is an incredibly creative game. A lot of choice-based games are criticized for choice not really mattering, and with this one, you can't really say that is the case. In contrast to another Wales Interactive FMV creation Late Shift, this feels more like a game than a film, and that is certainly good. However, after playing I couldn't have shaken off a feeling that the whole thing had no satisfying ending. It just kind of ends. Considering that modern FMV games are still being figured out, I can still absolutely recommend Five Dates as a fun Friday night thing, though.

I absolutely love The Longing because the game principle hits my nerve, the topic is exciting and "different" and I can combine this game principle with my way of streaming. Because I am very interactive with my viewers, I can continue to communicate with them while playing The Longing. In the last few months I was able to introduce the game to several people and the feedback was also very good.

Pedestrian presents a lot of challenging puzzles as easy for the average player, and a good entry for neophytes of this genre. 

The idea of exploring architecture and public spaces through transitions between signs is interesting and charming, however, the use of resources such as the train to define chapters is counterproductive... it cuts through the sequence and the dynamics of the game didn't need those "breaks".

Instead, His final stage greatly improves the level, I would have liked to have more of this type of mixed 2D-3D puzzle.

Des énigmes bien équilibrées, ni trop simples ni trop tordues, pour une durée de vie de 5 bonnes heures environ, le jeu se joue bien par petites sessions grâce à son format 'tableaux'.
Le gameplay et surtout la mise en scène sont originaux, un petit vent de fraicheur bienvenu, avec une réalisation soignée, aussi bien au niveau graphiques que musiques.

Joué sur SeriesX et PC via le game pass (sauvegarde partagée, c'est bien pratique !).

Great, great, great example of a game that is (almost) flawless in its genre, but you have to be able to enjoy the genre to enjoy the game. If you want to turn off your brain and just sit in front of the computer and play, this isn't it. Within its first 30 minutes, The Pedestrian just is already tough, and you have to think how to approach a sequence. However, it's a beautiful game with clever design worth playing.
The Pedestrian is a 2D puzzle platformer with a 3D backdrop. The puzzles are great, but there are a couple of frustrating platforming parts. Overall a pretty good game; it took me 5 hours to finish.

.Possitive points:
.Maincast
.Plot twists
.Battle system
.Secondary missions
.Incredible Hero Quest
.Fucking Nia

Negative Points:
.The villain
.

Le jeu nous place dans la peau d'un détective à la recherche d'Ethan, et nous devrons donc avancer de lieu en lieu pour résoudre différentes énigmes ( normal pour un détective ;) ) afin de nous rapprocher d'Ethan.
Le jeu nous l'indique dès le début : nous ne sommes pas pris par la main, il faut nous débrouiller. On découvre donc le gameplay à l'ancienne, en tâtonnant.
Etant donné qu'il s'agit d'une aventure narrative, rien de bien compliqué sur le principe, par contre parfois on se demande ce que le jeu attend de nous. Même si sur le principe cela fait parti du principe du jeu, les distances de marche étant longues, même en courant, cela devient parfois irritant lorsque l'on fait des allers/retours dans le vide.
Sans spoiler l'histoire, le fil conducteur entre les énigmes est clair, l'univers même si un peu vide (aucun PNJ) est cohérent, et la beauté des paysages dans ces endroits abandonnés donne un jeu agréable à parcourir.
Les énigmes ne sont pas très compliquées, donc on avance de façon assez fluide dans le jeu.

Joué sur SeriesX en mode rétrocompatibilité, aucun bug rencontré.

NB : Joué sur xbox, il s'agit de la version sous Unreal Engine 4, donc l'équivalent de la version Redux sur PC.

reviews.title: ondra1611's review of Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus

reviewText.content: It's still good game, but compared to New Order and Old Blood, we are getting downgrade. Feels like the developers were rushed to make a sequel and the whole game is not really thought out that well. Gameplay consists of just a lot of corridors, where the stealth sections are thrown and that's it. I would really appreciate more memorable events or fights, but I'm afraid, that after couple of days, you won't be looking back at this game at all.

reviews.title: manservant_claude's review of Wolfenstein II: The New Colossus

reviewText.content:
Very enjoyable single player FPS, although i enjoyed New Order better. While the themes of alternate history remains, the plot feels a tad weak, and i wasn't a fan of all the characters as some felt kinda like out of place shoved in comic relief.

While gunplay is very solid, the guns were a tad boring in my opinion. but then again i thought the same with the 1st one so fair i guess. 

Level wise some are great, others are a bit heavy on the corridors, and even one of these is a level reused you return to.. i would have been happier with a tad less levels for more variety.

All in all, if you're after solid single player FPS, this is a no brainer, even though it may not be the best in its category or even in the series.

reviews.title: Une suite solide mais qui manque un peu de folie

reviewText.content:
Beau et complet, la durée de vie plus importante que "l'épisode1" souffre d'un rythme moins soutenu.
Suite de l'histoire du #1, on retrouve notre personnage dans une histoire plus longue et structurée, mais paradoxalement avec moins de moments 'défouloir', quasiment tous les niveaux pouvant se faire en mode infiltration ; ce qui est plus intéressant mais vu le nombre de niveaux épuisant au bout d'un moment.
Les armes and co fonctionnent de la même façon que le #1, gameplay identique, armes très proches également, nouveaux ennemis, et graphiquement petite remise à niveau bien venue.
Une suite solide donc, mais qui manque un peu de folie (sauf le passage de l'audition ^^).
En post game les missions permettent de refaire les niveaux avec des nouveaux objectifs, souvent en repartant de la fin pour aller au début du niveau, ce qui n'est pas forcément plus simple :)

Joué sur SeriesX via le GamePass.

reviews.title: Very clever gameplay wrapped in a fantastic presentation

reviewText.content:
The gameplay is incredibly in depth thanks to the wide variety of mechs to unlock leading to dozens of way to approach a campaign (making for excellent replayability), and yet it's very basic and approachable. there are no endless hour long tutorials or anything. literally drop into battle and fight. 
Each mech sets leads to very different approaches on the battlefield (i liked the sand ones best so far), and in each situation you will end up calculating your moves turns in advance. This is pretty much chess :D

I loved the presentation overall, from the isometric map to the retro scifi designs. Quality pixel art will remind some of Advanced Wars probably, which isn't a bad thing ;)

It is so great to see a game about depression that doesnt involve running away from a shadow momster then destroying it at the end. I think the theme of depression and self acceptance is explored with a lot of nuance here. There characters are really empathetic and well rounded which helps sell the plot.
The gameplay is feels great. Its got a fairly simple movement system but which still has a lot of depth and seemingly exponential difficulty and replay value. 
The visual style of the game is a lovely pixel art aesthetic and some of the mountain vistas in it are seriously beautiful. Theres a few sections with a lot of repeating textures which looks pretty bad but overall very nice.
There were two points in the game that I really did not enjoy, one was called the mirror temple and the other is the games only boss battle. Both of these jsut dragged on and on and involved some combat (ish) mechanics that didn't suit the game at all. While the change of pace is probably necessary, this was really the wrong way to do it and not only put me off playing the game further after the credits rolled but massively blunted the sense of accomplishement and attatchment to the story as I progressed further and finished the climb up the mountain. 
All said it's a really unique game with a powerful message behind it, excellent gameplay and art, but with a couple of sections that soured the experience ever so slightly.

It's a flawless game. The controls, music, aesthetic, story, presentation, and direction all fit together in just the right way to make one of the most memorable experiences you could have with a game.
A really fun platformer with a nice story in the background to set your mind at ease from the hundreds of deaths you have each level. The music is also perfect for the pace of each level.

Celeste feels great while also hurting so bad. I knew this. Every review I read before I started explained how people wanted to break their controllers in half, and I agree. No game on my HDTV has ever made me question so harshly how many milliseconds of latency there, how I could be losing a precious more millisecond or two my controller by wire, how I could really use new rubber on my joysticks or even that fancy pro controller that's probably over $100. ...for a 2D platformer? Yes. Why? Why bother? Because it's beautiful.
Very good platformer. Awesome visuals, character mechanics and decent storytelling!
Incredibly hard, incredibly well-designed, incredible. If you are a game designer and want to learn how to improve the "teaching" design in your game, try Celeste.
This game needs to be played by all. I bought this on the switch when it was $5 and never hated a second. It can be frustrating, but push through, you will make it.

I acknowledge that the game's challenging nature was intended to symbolise the difficult journey of overcoming mental health issues. However, the difficulty balancing may have become somewhat excessive. This is my sole reason for not giving this amazing game a perfect score.

Celeste is the ultimate in modern platforming. Everything about the game is well-polished and designed for creating an incredibly difficult game that doesn't dissuade you from continuing to play.

Celeste is all about persistence. The game frequently encourages you to keep going. That you can do it. Even though the game is very hard at times, you constantly feel like you are getting better at it. You feel that you will always be able to overcome any obstacle as long as you stick to it.

The gameplay is perhaps the most polished of any platformer in recent memory. Movement is precise while giving you a massive amount of freedom in how you complete each screen.

The story deals with heavy concepts in a way that is truly touching. For many people, it will hit incredibly close to home. Even if it doesn't, it will give the player a strong sense of motivation and positivity.

The soundtrack, of course, is one of the best video game soundtracks ever created. It is truly unrivaled, matching the tone of the story as it progresses and keeping you engaged to the gameplay.

Overall Score: 10/10

I found it to be a beautiful game, with an inspiring message. It deals with themes like anxiety and depression and portrays them mastefully. It's a platformer game where you have to climb a mountain called 'Celeste,' and the climbing of it is used as a metaphor to overcome the difficulties of the protagonist mental state. 
The artistic style is pixel art and while it's nothing new, it's still good nonetheless. The soundtrack is great. Gameplay-wise, it's nothing out of this world and I found it tedious at several points. At first, I was motivated to collect the secondary collectibles, but after a while, I stopped because it seemed like a waste of time to me.
 In summary, this game stands out for its message about the protagonist's mental state and her way of making peace with herself.

Du très beau pixel art, et surtout un gameplay et un level design aux petits oignons.
Tout l'intérêt du jeu réside dans ces deux points ; pas question de jouer vite il faut surtout être précis et maitriser.
La difficulté est bien dosée, et chaque tableau demandera son lot d'essais, et de morts. Même si on rage on sait qu'on est jamais loin de passer, et que ça sera "pour la prochaine fois" :)
Les checkpoints et sauvegardes sont bien pensés, le jeu n'est pas punitif en soit.
Pour les sous doués de ce type de jeu comme moi il y a également une option "assistance" qui permet de débloquer des aides pour réussir à avancer quand même.
Chaque niveau possède ses spécificités, ce qui renouvelle l'intérêt du jeu, qui a une très bonne durée de vie (surtout avec les FaceB, niveaux bonus très difficiles).

Joué sur PC via la game pass (pas mal de crashs pour lancer le jeu et arriver à l'écran titre, ensuite aucun pb)

reviews.title: paivafamily's review of Gas Station Simulator

reviewText.content:
Jeu addictif doté d'options de personnalisations et de choix dans l'aménagement de la station.
Les activités sont divers et ne se limite pas à la tâche de "pompiste". Nous gérons également les stocks (carburants, denrées, produits divers), il y a même un garage où nous effectuons de légères réparations de véhicules ! ( pneus, vidange, batterie et bien d'autres!). Nous pouvons aussi gérer plusieurs employés que nous recrutons par CV ! Le scénario principal est bien rédigé, car oui en plus de ça il y en a un ! Le jeu ne se limite pas a la gestion et aux tâches. Je vous laisses le découvrir par vous-même. 
Pour conclure, excellement jeu de simulation, un de mes préférés dans ce qu'il y a de disponible sur console.
Vous pouvez y aller les yeux fermés il en vaut largement la peine.

i played this game back when i used to play on my ps3 and this was my fav game. i used to play it on my summer break and completing all the story and all the sidequests was something so cool. i still wish they would added new content to it tho, or at least make new games inspired on the 2 movies that came out after the events of jurassic world.

reviews.title: griha24's review of LEGO Jurassic World

reviewText.content:
𝟔,𝟖/𝟏𝟎
It's an ordinary conveyor Lego-game, but you can feel a bit of the atmosphere of "old movies", like in Lego Indiana Jones or Lego Star Wars, there are all 4 films, but the levels are boring and unmemorable, half of the characters are also the same.
The level structure is a bit different, there are scripted short story levels between which you go through separate sections of the open world, where you need to find some small items in order to open access to the next level.
Of the distinctive features - here you can play for dinosaurs, and it's pretty cool. But in the story locations, they don’t feel any danger, they just growl intimidatingly in one place, while you can wander around for at least an hour and look for what needs to be done. We generally calmly kill small dinosaurs with our fists, we could at least shoot from a machine gun, and there are characters with a firearm, but they are not given at locations where you need to fight, they only need to shoot at targets. You can also ride cars in the open world.

Subscribe on my Steam Curator`s page:
https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550/

reviews.title: ancestorprime's review of South of the Circle

reviewText.content:
Despite being labelled as a game, this title is nothing more than an interactive animation. Making matters worse, the available choices lack clarity and fail to have any real impact on the outcome.

Gameplay: 1/5
Visuals and sound: 3/5
Story and writing: 3/5

A really good scifi short story. The gameplay is a sidescroller/shooter with point and click style puzzles. These puzzles generally centre on strict protocols that AIs have and finding exploits and workarounds for them, this was inventive and created an interesting story. Some of these puzzles were far too obscure and just unsatisfying to solve because I found the solution by chance or trial and error. The game looks pretty good but definitely nothing impressive. The voice acting was well done. The story was really interesting, it revolves around artificial intelligence and one robot's quest to save its master, but it is short and doesn't show off much variety. The story that was there was entertaining and some of the writing made me laugh out loud. Well worth a play.

So I've been playing Return of the Obra Dinn this week, staying up way too late trying to finish it. I identified just half of the dead people, and the game has pretty much told me that it will give me no more information than it already has. I suppose it's all there, but damn it's hard to piece together. Like doing a 2000 piece jigsaw.
Super boring, the only excitement to discover fates (after the first 3) is that you know you don't have to do it again later.

Great detective game in which you have the ability to get a snapshot of the last moment before one person's death. By interpreting the scene and the voice acting you have to identify each member of the crew. Some identifications are pretty easy, but there are a lot of crew members that can only be identified using very tiny details. So, completing the story is not that hard, but getting 100% in this game may take ages if you don't find the right hints.
The atmosphere is great and the story is interesting. The graphic is fitting, but perhaps not everyone's cup of tea.

This is the most detective-y detective game made yet. There's multiple ways to figure out each person, but they all require attention to detail, so the game genuinely feels like you're making the deductions, not walking the path laid out for you.

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of Return of the Obra Dinn

reviewText.content:
(Takes around 6 - 8 hours to complete depending on how good you are)
This is probably the best detective game out there. With an amazing artstyle, good story and an incredibly satisfying gameplay loop it is a game you should definitely pick up.  
Story
You are an insurance investigator tasked with finding out what happened to the crew of the ship Obra Dinn, with the help of a magic watch that shows the last moments of someone's life. Because of this you play the role of an observer looking at all of the trials and tribulations that the ship went through. They are told to you in a non-linear manner, oftentimes you will see the end of a chapter before the beginning. This might seem confusing, but due to this being a detective game you will always be paying close attention to whatever is happening.
Gameplay
The gameplay consists mainly of figuring out the fates of the crew (what was their name, how did they die). This is done perfectly with almost no hand holding allowing you to fail endlessly. It might seem like this would just end with frustration, however the game gives you enough clues to figure out the fate of everyone. Also the “Aha” feeling of finally figuring out the fate of someone, through a series of deduction and exemption, is unmatched by anything.
Graphics
Don't be put off by its black and white aesthetic, this is a very beautiful game. Paying homage to older video games while also looking like it was made in this decade is pulled off perfectly here. Never was I confused or missed something because it was in the shadows. Also great sound effects and voice acting.
Soundtrack
Nice classical music that fits with the aesthetic of the rest of the game.
Final Thoughts
Some of the most entertaining 8 hours of my life. Lucas Pope can make games like this one until the end of time and I will be there to play every one of them.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Return of the Obra Dinn

reviewText.content: I did not expect the game to be this good, especially when done by only one person. Similarly to Forgotten City, Paradise Killer, or Outer Wilds, the game does not hold your hand, and you have to figure everything out yourself. The writing, the story, the intrigue, the mechanics, the puzzle, all amazing. Truly one of the best games I have ever played.

After finishing this game, I had only one thought: will I ever play a game so good as this one?

This game does everything it wants incredibly well, graphics, story, characters, narrative, game design, everything.

I have to be honest, after playing a few couch co-op games, Overcooked! 2 is probably the best. Also, after playing a few couch co-op games, I really don't like couch co-op games, but that's a separate issue. Overcooked! 2 took what worked in the first installment, and made it more accessible for both new and veteran players. It is nice to see that developers take feedback and improve the game to be better: more recipes, more chefs, online play, arcade mode... Overall, Overcooked! 2 is a must-play if you like couch co-ops, and if you have never tried them, this is a good place to start.
Truly a masterpiece! This is the best kart racing game of all time.

I give it an 8/10. It is my favorite of the whole franchise: good levels, good gameplay, the characters are still well characterized and maintain that charisma, in addition to very good soundtrack. Due to his difficulty he is the best to start in the franchise, although Pirate`s Curse (8.5 / 10) did some things better like: a better story to tell us the past of Risky and Rottytops, see Shantae and Risky collaborate together and The well-designed Dungeons, unlike the Half Genie Hero where there is no right, so I consider Pirate`s Curse the best of the series, and Half Genie Hero the second best.
great game, great graphics, great handling, good idea..love to play with it

Very Good Graphics and Great Handling

One of the standout features of CRSED: F.O.A.D. is its impressive graphics. The game takes full advantage of modern hardware, delivering stunning visuals that immerse players in its unique world. The handling and controls are precise, making it easy to jump into the action and enjoy intense battles.

A Great Twist on Battle Royale

CRSED stands out in the crowded battle royale genre by infusing unique elements into its gameplay. The various character abilities and weaponry options add a layer of complexity and strategy, keeping players engaged and excited throughout their gaming sessions. It's a welcome breath of fresh air for those looking for something beyond the usual battle royale experience.

Good Idea and Enjoyable Gameplay

The concept behind CRSED: F.O.A.D. is intriguing and well-executed. It offers a blend of competitive and cooperative modes, allowing for a variety of gameplay experiences. The result is a game that many players find easy to love and enjoy, whether they're playing solo or with friends.

Wandersong is about spreading happiness and love and getting to see the best side of people (and animals, and monsters) whenever possible. The main character ("the bard") isn't a hero, but just someone who wants to make people's lives better mostly through the use of music -- and, hey, maybe saving the world, since this might make people happier too. Actually, the game makes a point that "heroes" aren't always the nicest people, or whom you should strive to be.

The game is infused with cuteness and uplifting moments, but it is not a sugar fest -- there are negative events, there is war, there is decay and maybe the impending end of the world. The most important characters are full of self doubt and fear of not-fitting, so the game seems to imply that these are common and natural feelings, and what matters is what you make of them. But the bard reacts to all of it always expecting (naively?) the best of others, and it works.

Gameplay has two "modes" -- walking around town, talking to tons of people and solving light quests; and a few more "platformy" sections, almost all based on some music mechanic, but all of them sharing the same control (right joystick to select 1 out of 8 possible notes). Though most of the music mechanics have to be figured out as the game goes, absolutely no music knowledge is necessary, everything can be solved by experimentation and observation of how the surroundings react to your moves. Death is never a problem -- when it happens, you restart almost instantly pretty much right before you died.

I also loved how often the game twists videogame expectations -- you may or may not be "The Hero"; you cannot even handle a sword; you are not supposed to kill all bad monsters in sight; sometimes your actions do not produce the expected results; and a few other clichés (even achievements!) are subverted like this.

All in all, if you spend your time to know the vast character ensemble, this is a 10-12h game which is sure to inject a hopeful smile into your heart.

Score: 88/100.

This game just isn't fun for me. I very rarely leave games unfinished and this is one of them. Of course you can praise it for being different and I appreciate it, but the game lacks of fun and clear guidance.

If you like watching your characters die, setting a new team every few quests, looking for quests and stumbling upon extreme difficulty because you shouldn't be there just yet, annoying enemies that are overpowered and easily kill you (oh yeah, because you always have some spare team members) - then go ahead. Otherwise - again - it's just not fun.

I write it, because you can find many reviews that praise the game for a lot of things, but failed to conclude that in the end - the games have to bring you joy and this one doesn't (at least for me).

В этой игре очень важна реакция и внимательность. Нам предстоит отработать 7 недель. Играем мы вообще за Жнеца, которому предстоит выбирать, куда отправлять мертвецов: в Рай, Ад, или Чистилище. Чем дальше мы идем по сюжету, тем сложнее играть становится. Появляется все больше и больше условий, с учетом которых надо распределять мертвечину. В игре очень много отсылок на другие игры, на фильмы, и на многое другое. Тут можно встретить Гендальфа, Терминатора и многих других персонажей. Это и есть первый плюс этой игры - пасхалки. Скажу сразу, минусов у этой игры нет. Второй плюс - это черный юмор. Он просматривается даже в названии игры, наверное только русский человек поймет к чему я веду.

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Cogen: Sword of Rewind

reviewText.content:
Cogen: Sword of Rewind is a fast-paced, action-packed, 2D platformer.

Movement is super fluid and you have access to a ton of different moves and attacks. The highlight feature, of course, is the ability to rewind time up to three seconds. This works surprisingly well and makes you consider strategies completely differently than you would with a simple health bar. It's implemented in a way that makes it super intuitive to reverse time to certain points after being hit. The sword moves, as well, are intuitive and easy to understand.

The difficulty of the game is also a point where it stands out. Cogen is a super hard game. Normal difficulty is so hard that about halfway through the game it recommends turning down to casual right before it ramps up even higher. My main issue is that there isn't really an in-between for Normal and Casual difficulty. Casual is a bit too easy with the buffs it gives you, and Normal is a bit too unforgiving after you are no longer able to regenerate time rewinds at that halfway point.

The boss fights are all put together very well. It feels incredibly satisfying to learn the boss' patterns and get better at fighting them.

The story, while a bit over-the-top sometimes and at other times generic, is pretty endearing, as are the characters. The voice acting is surprisingly good and characterization is very clear.

Overall Score: 8/10

An amazing interactive noir story and RPG. The world is dripping with style, which is one of my favourite parts of the game. The RPG mechanics are excellent as well, allowing a variety of playthroughs and interactions that change depending on how you develop you character. The characters are excellent as well, with a few notable individuals who excel at showing complexity in terms of their ideology. 

And this game is all about ideology. The alt-universe world allows for completely new history, but grounds its politics and philosophy in real world ideas. You can be a communist and support a workers uprising, a pragmatist cop, a hedonistic libertarian, or a far-right fascist, and can mix and match these ideologies as well, leading to many different combinations of events, conversations and outcomes. 

The ending of the game really got me as well; without spoiling, I felt a physical withdrawal from this world, and a part of me would have loved to see a longer game, although the game itself took me 30+ hours to playthrough.

Stylishly done, with a touching story, and a highly variative gameplay even despite a heavily deconstructed traditional RPG mechanics. This is simply an RPG mastepiece of our time. Never thought I'd see another one, and yet it's here. Could be a bit text-heavy for some, but personally I can't view it as a drawback.

I loved everything about this game from start to finish. The first play through I went for the empathetic character and really explored every discussion branch available. The second play through I went full out right wing brute. Both play throughs felt completely different.

I will go for the third play through soon and take a completely different approach again. Its the game that just keeps on giving.

If you start playing this game with a hangover, it might feel a little too real!

I am still playing this game but i find this game really intellectual. So if you go play this game with the mindset of "hack and slash or shoot them up", you will be really disappointed and this game will be a 1/10. This game is a book, and an audiobook. And I  haven't completed it (maybe 2 hours in) but the vibe, i.e., music, art direction, and the overall feeling of this game is just great. If you are looking for a dire, philosophical game - this might be it. 
I will update when I am done with this game.

reviews.title: Text-heavy, serious RPG with dark humor and splendidly thought-out gameplay

reviewText.content:
I first started the game as a hyper-smart detective who morally and physically resembled a wreck. Woke up, jumped on my fan to fringe my tie and died of a heart attack. 
10/10 would jump again.

But seriously though. The game offers an immense depth in the character development that takes place continuously while playing. The start attributes are not negligible, from my point of view it is not possible to maximize your character in every skill. Nevertheless, you get so many points that you make good progress. The great thing about it is that you actually notice how your character is changing and the environment is doing the same. The way in which you react to unconscious decisions is great.
For example, in one day I quickly ran everywhere and clicked my way through because I didn't have much time in RL. When I reloaded the game and ended the day ingame, someone made a snappish remark during a conversation to draw my attention to the fact that I am simply impatient.
Such things subconsciously give you a great feeling while playing and also some memorable moments.

The game takes place quite slowly and is very text-heavy, only a few (important) passages are actually voiced. You have to deal with that. 
Actually such games aren't my favourite playground either, but this made me curious about the first trailer back then and I wasn't disappointed. I rate it a perfect 5 out of 7.

reviews.title: Disco Elysium: la única vez en que me he alegrado de que un juego sea puro texto

reviewText.content:
Apartado Gráfico: Es inusual, no es algo que sea bonito, no es feo estéticamente pero tiene un arte peculiar, los personajes en su mayoría son feos, el mundo es simple, y hay varias cosas que hacen que se sienta único, se siente como revanchol, el arte esta muy bien hecho, cada cara es diferente, puedes diferenciar a cada persona ningún npc es repetido, el diseño del mundo esta bien hecho, puedes notar detalles en los escenarios, la basura, la decadencia la pobreza, los fondos tienen mucho para contar y dar aun mas ambientación, sin contar lo bien diseñada que esta la interfaz, combina con todo, el tipo de fuente usada, el menú de los diálogos, todo, todo combina sigue una misma estética que es única de este juego que realmente logra contarte lo que te quiere contar y no se deja nada, no se deja a un personaje con el que puedas hablar sin cara, no deja detalle del escenario que no puedas examinar, lo apuesta todo y consigue un arte verdadera mente identificable y único que logra que puedas sumergirte en el mundo sin necesidad de que sean los gráficos mas realistas o inmersivos.

Apartado sonoro: También destacable, empezando con los efectos de sonido están muy bien logrados, cuando fallas o logras una tirada, cuando te cambias la ropa, cuando abres una puerta, cuando seleccionas algo, cuando ganas experiencia, esta repleto de efectos de sonido simples y bien puestos, dan mucho gamefeel y da mas satisfacción cuando ganas experiencia o haces algo ya que lo puedes escuchar y sentir. En cuanto a las voces son increíbles, todas, no hay ninguna voz mala, todas representan bien las emociones, son identificables, hay personajes con hasta acentos diferentes y lo puedes notar y comentarlo, no es un “mira este nuevo personaje es de una región extranjera con una cultura y personas totalmente distinta y acaba de llegar pero habla exactamente como todos aquí”, puedes notar cuando alguien es extranjero, cuando esta feliz, decepcionado, cada personaje tiene su voz y su forma de hablar que los hacen identificables, no son muchos personajes pero considerando la cantidad de diálogos que tienen cada uno, el lograr tan buenas voces es algo destacable. Y  el soundtrack, es maravilloso, identificable, se me queda pegado en la cabeza el tema de will in rags, se siente verdadera emoción cuando estas teniendo un dialogo emotivo o tenso y la música lo acompaña perfectamente, según donde estés, o con quien estés hablando la música cambia, se ajusta en el momento perfecto, no es una música altamente detallada y espectacular pero es la indicada, no te distraerá de los momentos pero tampoco es tan olvidable como para que no la tomes en cuenta y puedas jugar con la música apagada, es el soundtrack adecuado, muy identificable, va con la estética del juego, se siente realmente como la música que escucharías en este mundo distopico, remarca bien los sentimientos y da un muy buen ambiente.

Gameplay: Vamos por partes 

1 Los Controles y Como se juega: Disco Elysium es un juego de dialogo, aquí vienes a hablar, se siente bien porque no es pulsar A todo el tiempo y que pasen los diálogos, es un rpg de mundo abierto, tienes que ir de un lugar a otro, puede que alguien con quien deseas hablar solo este a ciertas horas o en cierto lugar, puede que se te hizo muy tarde y las calles están vacías y no tienes donde quedarte a dormir porque te quedaste sin dinero, puede que tengas que caminar por varias partes para conseguir algo que buscas, El gameplay esta centrado en el dialogo pero también en la exploración, en moverte por el mundo, que veas los escenarios y hables con las personas en su sitio. Todo esto se controla usando solo el mouse, es lo mas cómodo, puedes seleccionar mejor los diálogos, clickar por donde moverte, equiparte las cosas, todo esta fácil y accesible, la interfaz donde ves tu equipamiento, tu inventario y tus aptitudes esta en un mismo lugar, compactada para no quitar mucho espacio y bien puesta para que sientas que realmente estas viendo tus voces internas tus ideas y lo que traes equipado, todo esta a una distancia prudente para poder ir dando clicks y moviéndote, no hay muchos elementos y es un juego pausado, tienes que tomarte tu tiempo para leer, para caminar, para hablar, para ver cada cosa, es super cómodo de navegar, no es como Grim Dawn que supuestamente lo puedes jugar solo con el mouse pero tiene tantas cosas en pantalla que si no te mueves con el teclado vas a terminar es jugando osu de lo tanto que mueves el mouse por todos lados. Ya hablando de esto, Disco Elysium son solo diálogos, ya estamos acostumbrados a juegos que son puro texto, pero ¿como es que construimos una mecánica alrededor de hablar con las personas en un mundo abierto? Pues de la siguiente manera
