I guess the way this could have been avoided is by just making the game shorter, since as of now it's long, like very long.
Another variation to the formula is the way weapons are handled. There are a lot of them, but instead of having a slot for each one, you have to choose two or three and discard the rest. Weapons are found through levels, either being dropped from monsters or just found randomly on the ground. They come in various rarities and the higher the rarity, the more quirks they have. This is great and all, but there is one problem. Once you find a high-rarity weapon, replacing it becomes difficult. Since if you were to replace it with something worse, you suddenly made the game much harder.
There are other gamemodes like minigames and an arena, but none of them caught my interest. 

Graphics/Artstyle
2.5D graphics are similar to old FPS games like Wolfenstein and Doom. There is improved lighting and effects compared to them, but still, the graphics are a bit bland.

Atmosphere/Immersion
Unfortunately, any type of atmosphere or immersion the game tries to build is held back by the randomly generated levels and the RPG-like weapon rarities.

Soundtrack 
The soundtrack is made by Andrew Hulshult. (Who could have guessed!?) Classic metal FPS OST, it's alright, not much more I can say. My favourite part is “Lucid Mayhem”.

Final Thoughts
I wish my dreams were as epic as this, instead, I kidnap doctors and take pictures of cars.

A resource management based game with a great style. The characters are interesting and the writing is good. It's challenging without being punishing and you have a lot of freedom about what kind of police chief you want to be. Get cosy with the mafia or make sacrifices to take them down. Unfortunately the payoff was really lacking. So many times, important plot points were rushed by in a block of text and the ending takes very little account of how you played the game, a bit of a mass effect 3 moment. While I loved the gameplay, it didn't evolve a whole lot throughout the game and was bordering on stale by the end. A few of the detective cases had obscure solutions that required blunt force to solve rather than logic.
It is a lot of fun, just missed the mark a few times and seemed to take no notice of all the decisions youve made throughout youre playthrough.

reviews.title: 180 days of police station micro-management among gangsters and politicians

reviewText.content:
This game moves halfway between several genres, on the one hand the story develops as a visual novel with small decision making, and the gameplay is a simple management of the police station, choosing troops, the priority of the cases and some small puzzle with investigations.

Its story does not have an amazing script or full of twists, but personally it did captivate me and it is largely the reason why I enjoyed directing the police station. On the other hand, its management system is not very deep either, so don't expect hours and hours and hours of play per game.

We have 180 days of micro-management of the police station, with the life of our protagonist among gangsters and politicians, making decisions to do the best possible for the department and for ourselves, experiencing all kinds of situations.

The game is entertaining and, in my opinion, recommended. 6/10

Regards.

I enjoy my annual binge of the game, especially when it's given away for free. I can tell you I noticed only a couple changes from FM23. Is that a bad thing? Not necessarily, as huge portion of the game is player scouting and updates to the database, which they always seem to get on point. While waiting for FM25 and the new engine, we got a satisfactory update to the best football sim of all time.

Best Football Manager in the whole series. I mean it was always better as any other Football Manager, but all those little upgrades, new set pieces and that you can dive as deep into it, as you like, just  make it a perfect emersion.
If you like Football, it´s a good game. If you like Manager/Sims, it´s a great game. If you like both, take vacations, you´re gonna love it.

Starting with the story, I really enjoyed it. I liked the nations politics always being in the background of the story as you play. It didn't really offend me or anything and it served to keep the tension very high in each episode as you try to get your teenager to the border so that they can escape. And the game isn't afraid to present harsh consequences for your actions which I also enjoyed. I loved all the characters except for one of them, but most of them are extremely well written. Your character is always a blank slate and is just a vehicle for you to immerse yourself in the story, as you encounter the games cast of characters and see their stories play out as you make decisions with them. It gave it an almost RPG like feel, even though its not that kind of game. Overall though, I loved the story and I think all the characters had really good story arcs. You can't complete all of the stories in one playthrough but the game does have new game plus thankfully.

Another gameplay element I loved was just how they make every chapter feel different. In a lot of these types of games the chapters can feel samey in the gameplay department as you usually walk around, talk to characters and solve puzzles. Road 96 however breaks the mold on many of those conventions by making each chapter unique in what you are doing with a specific character. One chapter you could be helping a kid build a fake bomb at a gas station, or the other you could be standing in the back of a truck with a nail gun and shooting at bad guys in a car chase. Its just really awesome and I found myself never being bored really.

You also can unlock abilities that you do get to carry over into each episode which I liked. These are things like being able to lockpick open doors or hack into machines. It added a level of exploration I appreciated since the levels you explore are very linear, equipped with invisible walls and all, but it still added that extra layer. You could for example, come up to a gas station for the next story moment, but before that you could sneak into a back room and lockpick open lockers or hack into safes, for extra money and supplies. Its the type of thing I expect in a Bethesda game and to have it here is something I really appreciated.

Music is also excellent, with each track fitting the game very well. The collectables of this game are cassette tapes of the actual soundtrack and when you find them you can play them in any radio you find scattered around the game world. I liked this since I prefer collectables that have an actual practical use in game. I hate useless trinkets that games make you collect that have no real level of interaction. 

As for negatives I don't have too many. The game has several escape routes when you do get to the border, but one thing I found is when you attempt one route, the game will close that off to you in the next episode even if you failed the attempt. They do explain it in the story that the government adapts each time, but I still found it a little annoying. One of the characters named Jarod, I didn't like at all. He does have an emotional story arc that explains why he is the way he is, but I just found him to be very irredeemable and every time the game forced me into one of his chapters, I just rolled my eyes and tried to get through it as quickly as possible. They also do this thing where he jump scares you, which is very effective the first couple of times, but after a while it gets very stale. One chapter he does it to you multiple times while your talking to him and I just wanted to punch him at that point. There was also this weird thing that happened in the last episode, where my character kept looping back to this "haunted restaurant". Apparently you can encounter a ghost there but I decided to just loot the place and leave, which involved me powering up the place up with a generator that I had to refuel, get the car keys and leave. The game however kept putting me back there, which got really annoying as I had to keep redoing the same thing over and over again. I don't know if it was because I ignored the whole ghost thing, and the game was trying to get me to do it, and I just kept ignoring it. The time the game wasted doing that, I would have rather spend with the characters so I could finish their story arcs instead.

𝟖,𝟓/𝟏𝟎 👏 𝐑𝐨𝐚𝐝-𝐦𝐨𝐯𝐢𝐞 𝐚𝐛𝐨𝐮𝐭 𝐚𝐮𝐭𝐡𝐨𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐚𝐫𝐢𝐚𝐧𝐢𝐬𝐦
Путин или Навальный? Лукашенко или Тихановская? "Иллюзорная" Стабильность или Перемены?
Добро пожаловать в типичную диктатуру типо Беларуси или России, это первая сильно "политическая" игра, в которую я играл и это ОЧЕНЬ КРУТО! Немного политики можно встретить только в играх серии "Метро", там немного поднимается тема коррупции, причём многие сразу думают, что тут продвигается какая-то западная "повестка" про мигрантов или угнетённые расы, но про второе тут вообще ничего нет, а про первое.. ну, сомнительно, в любом случае, тут игра больше продвигает идеи "демократии" против диктатуры, в хорошей концовке вы можете привести игру к тому, что люди не захотят сбежать из страны, поэтому это не тоже самое, что было в Life is Strange 2. Не вижу ничего плохого в такой "политике" в играх, я лишь очень благодарен разрабам за это. Но даже абстрагируясь от этого всего, в игре очень интересный геймплей, ваши персонажи здесь могут умереть или их могут арестовать, очень классная атмосфера с хорошей музыкой, интересная система выживания, да, в игре очень многие вещи немного копируются из других игр, тот же Life is strange (Похожая атмосфера и персонаж Зои), игра не привносит прям чего-то уникального и прорывного, но она является шедевриальным миксом .Мне кажется, что это лучшая игра 2021. Моя оценка - 8.5/10. Всё-таки есть нюансы, например, я перепрошёл игру 3 раза (кстати, за 1 прохождение вам точно не выпадут все катсцены, так что не забудьте потом ещё поиграть в "Новую игру+) и заметил, что ваши выборы не особо на что-то влияют, от них зависит только концовка, но она не достаточно мощная, чтобы я поставил игре 9 или 10, да и изменится в ней только 1 строчка в словах рассказчика, но тем не менее это самая реиграбельная сингловая игра после какого-нить "Детройта", сами истории персонажей неплохие и дарят много незабываемых эмоциональных моментов, второй раз игру проходил вообще мой друг через мой комп по remote play, так что вы можете проходить одновременно с друзьями и делиться впечатлениями, у кого как сложилась история, да даже просто сидеть смотреть, как проходит друг 8-9 часов где-то мне было интересно. Ещё кстати вспомнил минус, что головоломки в игре уж слишком лёгкие, прям детские) Ну, я надеюсь, что будет сиквел, Road 24, типо к 2024 году и там разрабы уже добьют до 9-10. Ещё саундтрек обалденный, где-то на 7.5/10, лучшими я считаю треки "Home Call" и "Election Day", но у композитора явно есть потенциал.

Подписывайтесь на страницу Куратора в Steam: store.steampowered.com/curator/37365104/

Road 96 is a first-person story-rich game placed in the middle of a highly political world.  Playing as a teen attempting to flee the country you meet some memorable characters, make impactful decisions, and work your way to freedom hopefully without being arrested or even killed.  Road 96 plays as a ‘choose your own adventure’ over multiple chapters each played as a different teen on a similar journey to freedom.  Meeting the same characters along the way means that you will get to know them a bit more and get a much larger picture leading up to an amazing ending experience.

The story is engaging with genuinely likable characters scattered throughout.  The land of Petria is beautiful with stunning deserts, lush forests, and imposing mountains all rendered in a striking style.  However, as many people have already stated, the original soundtrack is amazing and adds to the gameplay and story in ways that are hard to explain.  These elements help to ensure that Road 96 will stay with you for quite some time.

You will eventually locate items that will help you along the way. These items, such as a lockpick or other items, carry on from one chapter to the next, making sure that future teens attempting to leave the country have it a little bit easier.  On the obverse, if you manage to make it to the border the methods that you used one time will become harder in future chapters…meaning you will need to figure out other ways to escape Petria…making sure that Road 96 stays fresh and somewhat challenging.

Game controls are easy and will involve a mouse to make it easier to play the various mini games or as an easy way to make conversation selections.  The keyboard is used to make you way around the world, but all in all, the game is quite easy to move about without having to learn a multitude of different keybinds.

Achievements are attained from playing the game; who you meet or minimally what you do, with only a few achievements from collecting or doing something that you might not normally do.  As the game has randomized chapters you may need more than one playthrough in order to complete all of the achievements but none of these achievements are hard to complete.

Petit jeu sympathique d'une bonne dizaine d'heures, ce road trip nous fait vivre l'aventure de 6 ados qui fuient la dictature moderne de leur pays, calculée sur du Trumpisme made in USA, via un point frontière vers un hypothétique Canada.
Ces 6 voyages nous font croiser différents PNJ, à différents moments avec différents points de vues, ce qui permettra de reconstituer toute l'histoire.
Les points d'étape et les activités sont assez variés pour éviter tout redondance.
Techniquement le jeu est assez pauvre même si ce n'est pas ce qu'on recherche dans ce genre de jeu, c'est quand même le minimum syndical.
Idem pour l'aventure proposée, dont le scénario est un peu trop caricatural par moment, ca fait sourire mais il faut le prendre au second degré.

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

Road 96 - 1/10

Absolutely soulless game with the most clichéd stories, written by a 13 y.o. teenager. These characters are just dead - it's like aliens trying to look like a human beings. And here we are talking about story-oriented game, it is just hilarious to me.

Graphics is pretty much allright, as well as a couple of tracks from the OST, but in general nothing impressive.

0 immersion, ultimately boring storyline, absolutely soulless world. Сomplete disappointment.

It's a game, or should i say interactive art, about experiencing, not about achievement. It is about wonder and exploration. It keeps surprising and is highly enjoyable for those who can see it with the right look. If you understand a game like Journey, this one is highly recommendable.

Gris is a beautiful game that offers a very poignant experience. It plays so smoothly, while the beauty of the world around you comes into frame just as well. Gris is incredibly reminiscent of another game, Journey. Reminiscent in all the right ways. Where it separates itself is in the themes and sometimes the tones of the emotional journey your character is going through. The game plays similarly, while also being very distinct.

One huge success for this game is its level design. The levels flow so well, that you don't get lost, you don't hit dead ends. Many times it's so easy flowing that you wonder if you're going the right way. Some of the levels even reuse areas you've been to, but you've got a new perspective so you can now access areas you didn't even know were there before. The level design doesn't forcefully push the player in directions, it simply leaves a path for the player to follow, while not being too simple. 

While it is as incredible as it is. This isn't a difficult game. You'd have to be in the right mood, or be someone who enjoys a sort of spiritually/emotionally poignant experience that this gives. It's nothing new as far as mechanics go, even though they're so well implemented. This game is here to be beautiful, and that's all that's needed here, and it succeeds in my opinion. 

The animation is absolutely gorgeous, and the music pushes this game further in an incredible way as well. I can't recommend this game enough.

This game is really beautiful and with a good ost, but other than that, is just a very simple side-scroller with nothing new, and the story, level desing and puzzles are just so basic to the point boring.
Many people say this game is art, but it doesn´t do anything with the gameplay, so what is the point of question why is a videogame to being with.
If you want a side-scroller platformer with a female protagonist with good characters and character develoment, and also good gameplay and level desing, play Celeste.

Follow the story of Gris, a young girl who is lost in her own world of after dealing with a painful experience in her life.  By solving a variety of puzzles in a gorgeous and unbelievable world we begin to understand more about Gris and her situation.  Take part in Gris’ journey of discovery and healing in a crumbling and yet mysteriously exquisite world from Nomada Studio.

Beautiful, enjoyable, and deeply touching; Gris is more like a work of art than a game.  The animation has a real human touch with a very strong visual identity that, when coupled with the amazing soundtrack, makes for a very memorable experience.  This puzzle platformer game requires some thinking and exploring to solve the puzzles and progress the game—but nothing is too difficult as the developers of Gris want you to experience the story while not getting frustrated over how to complete it.

I have a fondness for puzzle platformers as well as good stories and Gris was a perfect game for me.  I enjoyed every minute of it and found myself drawn into the world.  I would wholeheartedly recommend this game for those who are into this type of genre as well as games with good storytelling.

The game is visually excellent and has a great soundtrack, But the gameplay is simplistic and for a game that seems to where it's artistic intent on it's sleeves,  I do not think it conveyed it's tone incredibly well. In the moments, I sometimes caught glimpses of it's intended them. But nothing stuck out by the end. This becomes even worse when all interpretation is removed when achievements such as "bargaining" and "acceptance" pop up.  Overall recommended, however, If you're looking at games for impact, this doesn't hit the high notes of something like Journey or Rime

O jogo conta com arte visual e trilha sonora incríveis. Possui uma gameplay simples, o que as vezes pode causar incomodo para alguns jogadores. O jogo não possui falas, o que pode dificultar um pouco o seu entendimento, mas nada que estrague a experiência. Infelizmente o jogo falha na questão de desafios, pois ao enfrentar chefes você sabe que não irá morrer e com isso perde um pouco a emoção do jogo. Mas fora isso, é um jogo incrível e uma experiência única, sendo um jogo que precisa ser jogado

Average platformer with an absolutely gorgeous hand-painted watercolor artstyle. An interesting interpretation of grief and handling the stages of depression. Despite the interesting premise, the gameplay was average at best and didn't really do anything new as a platformer. A fun way to spend a few hours for 2D platformer fans.

reviews.title: Très belle direction artistique, qui porte ce jeu de plateforme.

reviewText.content:
Très belle direction artistique, qui porte ce jeu de plateforme.
Quelques "énigmes" viennent ponctuer notre avancée, superbement réalisée, avec une ambiance très soignée.
Durée de vie correcte pour ce genre de jeu contemplatif, compter 8h en prenant son temps.
Le thème du deuil est transparent, on ne le voit que sur le nom des succès.

Joué sur Xbox SeriesX via le game pass.

I mostly like it. I like exploration and puzzle games, and this is a good example. The main puzzle mechanic is piecing together fragments of an ancient language. As for the plot, you begin by searching the galaxy for a missing scientist. But there's much more under the surface - questions of philosophy and faith, the mysteries of history, and the questionable intent of the ruling government. 

The "open world" exploration is somewhat wonky and strange. Your character doesn't walk through the game, but rather "ghosts" from one point to another, in small jumps, It makes navigating around more difficult than it should be, but the game just isn't set up like a traditional 3D engine would be. It's hard to explain, but the difficulty of getting to where you want to go definitely breaks the immersion.

Otherwise, it's a fine game - a uniquely thoughtful and deep experience.

Journey with Aliya, a young archeologist who is uncovering the long-forgotten past of the Nebula as she searches for the strange and enigmatic Heaven’s Vault.  What will she discover, who will she meet, and what is the secret of not only the Nebula but of Heaven’s Vault?

The world-building in this narrative adventure game is absolutely amazing; making a world that you want to explore and learn more about.  Impactful choices, hieroglyphic word puzzles, and exploring ancient sites expound upon the story like no other game I have played and was both fun and challenging at the same time.  Additionally; the traveling concept of taking streams from one point to another was quite refreshing and fun while in between different moons or puzzle hubs.  

The game was excellent in length; not too short and Heaven’s Vault didn’t overstay its welcome.  For those who like to get all the achievements there is a bit of work to do and this will take you more than one playthrough; but the Game+ feature makes the puzzles a bit more challenging while at the same time giving you more completed words to work with.

Unforgettable and intriguing; this game kept my interest up…a plus for any game.  I found Heaven’s Vault to be thoroughly enjoyable and would wholeheartedly recommend it for people who want to take part in an adventure, solve cryptic language-based puzzles, or like to experience a good story with engaging characters and mysteries to solve.
Great writing, interesting world, really cool take on an invented language. Makes you feel clever without being too hard.

This was recommended as a game to play similar to the language translation game Chants of Sennaar. Despite being a more complex game with more beautiful art, it suffered by comparison.

The plot is interesting, the mystery of what happened to the roboticist as well as the larger mystery of the history of the Nebula. But the game allows you to get to the end with loose ends hanging; your freedom of choice can work against you as it may mean you never find out some things. (However, if this aspect appeals to you, then it's probably worth your time.) 

Relatedly, the dialog options were often puzzling or just exasperating. Much of the time, every single choice you have is something rude or snarky, especially when talking to the robot. For example, when the robot asks "are you ready to leave?" your options are often either "yes" or "don't hassle me."  Why force the player to be a jerk? And if being rude is just supposed to be the character's personality, then why give the player dialog choices at all?

The movement is just bad. Awkward and often inaccurate from what you intend, and there's nothing at the beginning to tell you *how* to move-- you just have to try stuff. And it's not always clear where you can and can't go. 

The language translation mechanic was interesting, but had one aspect I found extremely frustrating. When you're guessing what words/phrases might mean, you're limited to only a few choices--you can't choose from all of the words you've encountered so far, even if one that you've encountered is clearly the right fit. It will only open up to allowing other guesses after you've filled in every single bit of the phrase, even if you know you're filling it in with incorrect guesses. I would've liked to be able to just guess freely from my entire list of possible words, rather than the game restricting me to three or four, some of which were clearly wrong.  It was so annoying that I didn't even want to bother going back to finishing the translations after I reached the endgame, and the translation aspect was originally the whole reason I tried this game.

Overall, it's a beautiful game and an interesting story, but despite mentions I've seen on forums of people doing multiple playthroughs, the many frustrating aspects meant I won't be replaying it.

The game Hogwarts Legacy starts you off with making a character who will end up saving hogwarts from being destroyed by some weird chick and this goblin. It was a damn fun experience and there are many caves, ruins, and spider nests to search for loot for. There are also collectibles and a fun flying racing game to complete if you up for those challenges. The damn system, how you level up and how you can to perform magic in the game was spot on and cool to master. Tip of advice, use your points wisely cause you can't unlock all spells.

The game Hogwarts Legacy starts you off with making a character who will end up saving hogwarts from being destroyed by some weird chick and this goblin. It was a damn fun experience and there are many caves, ruins, and spider nests to search for loot for. There are also collectibles and a fun flying racing game to complete if you up for those challenges. The damn system, how you level up and how you can to perform magic in the game was spot on and cool to master. Tip of advice, use your points wisely cause you can't unlock all spells.

Un clásico que vuelve de las cenizas para traernos una nueva experiencia de multiplayer local con el alma de uno de los grandes de la época de 8 y 16 bits. ¡Si quieres una buena experiencia con amigos, considera darle la oportunidad a este título!

Сюжет во второй части идёт вразброс. От этого, и без того сложный для понимания сюжет стал еще сложнее. К сожалению, история Джекета здесь будет рассказана не от его лица, так что сыграть за него мы не сможем. Как мы помним, Джекет убил Отца и его отца. После чего его повязали полицейские и посадили в тюрягу, больше о нем упоминаний нет, только в самом конце игры. После того, что натворил наш главный герой в первой части, у него появились подражатели. Некая группировка "Фанаты", она, как и Джекет брала задания по телефону, носила маски, и убивала русскую мафию. По сюжету главарем мафии стал сын Отца, отсюда и его имя Сын. Теперь группировке "Фанаты" предстоит уничтожить его. Незадолго до этого Сын употребил слишком много наркотиков, из за чего у него были видения, поэтому он видел не убийц в масках животных, а самих животных (речь идет о Фанатах). Фанаты не рассчитали свои силы и в ходе перестрелки все погибли. Мне сильнее всего было жалко Тони (тигр), хотя все они крутые персонажи. После чего Сын вышел на крышу и пошел по радужному мосту, который ему привиделся. На самом же деле никакого моста не было и он просто упал с крыши. Вообще по всему Майами было множество убийств, так, одной из жертв стал президент СССР. Это и послужило причиной сброса атомной бомбы на Америку. В ходе взрыва погиб даже сам Джекет, который спокойно отсиживал свой срок в тюряге. Так и закончилась история Hotline Miami. Из плюсов я выделю все такой же офигенный сюжет, крутых персонажей, четкую музыку. Минусов нет.

Playing on your actual device is key for this game. It adds another dimension to a very sensitive story about Sam, who lost his phone - and you found his phone. If you like to figure things out (sometimes logically, sometimes by trial-and-error), and have no problem being frustrated for periods of time, give this game a try. You will be rewarded with a surprising story full of twists and turns.
A fun little effortless ride that buries it's tension in the realistic drivel of everyday life

Katana Zero is a very interesting game and I'd really like to rate it higher but...

There is way too much text to click through. It seems like a minor issue at first, but it really breaks the experience of a fast-paced action and interesting events happening throughout the game. True, there is a speedrun mode, where you can turn cutscenes and dialogue options off, but that's only after you beat the game for the first time.

Other that that it's a really good game. Fantastic art direction and soundtrack. Many little details that add up to enhance the experience (like turning on the walkman at the beginning of levels, dream sequences and more). The story is also interesting and well written.

Definitely worth playing, just get ready for grinding through way too many dialogues.

Set in the dystopian neo-noir metropolis of New Mecca, game follows Subject Zero, a katana-wielding assassin with amnesia, who can slow down time and predict the future. Zero unravels his past while completing assassination contracts.

The super-violence, the story of drug-addled killers, the glitchy way reality seems to be a corrupted save file.

Killing in this game feels exciting and satisfying. If you try to die, it will be easy - short levels are filled with instant-death scenarios.

Synthwave score, which blends Chicago house, electronic music, and synth-pop, was composed by Bill Kiley and Thijs "LudoWic" Lodewijk.

The dialogue system is creative and innovative, branching dialogue paths and alternate story scenarios are adding replay value.

Katana Zero is a game to play again. I think most players will do like me the first time they play, they focus on the gameplay and pay attention to the story, but trust me, play it again and pay REALLY attention to the story, I personally took notes and I don't regret it.

Jeu très "hard corde gamer", au gameplay nerveux et bien pensé, avec des graphismes pixel art très soignés.
Malheureusement le personnage mourant, comme les ennemis, en un seul coup, et le 'rembobinage', contrairement à un jeu comme braid, ne pouvant être contrôlé, cela force à refaire tout le niveau ; il y a une partie die and retry obligatoire du fait de certaines "surprises" mortelles difficiles à anticiper, qui est vite usant.
Un bon jeu mais pas pour tout le monde, dommage pour le rembobinage qui aurait pu etre plus qu'un effet de style.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

One of my favourite games now. The premise is that there is a magic paint brush that lets people colour the world. Of course, someone has to wield the brush so through history, there has been many wielders that have used the brush to bring color and life to the world. However, one day, the world turns black and white, and you find the brush laying on the ground. Pretty interesting ey? Anyways, the main gimmick is that you can paint pretty much anything. The whole world is a coloring book, and that's one of the only flaws in the game. The concept of being able to color the entire world is very enticing to me. It's very satisfying to finish drawing a room and there game fully supports that kind of gameplay. One of the major themes of the game is that anyone can be an artist, so whether you have no idea what you're doing, or you do art for a living, you can still make the world look beutiful. However, I know that some people aren't looking for that kind of experience. Most negative reviews of the game are just people looking for a competitive game with action and high stakes. Do not go into this game expecting too much intensity. Instead, Chicory tries to be a much more meaningful game. Telling a deep and relatable story about depression, expectations, and perfectionism. Basically, Celeste but with painting, which brings me to my next point: the music. Lena Raine, the composer for Celeste and a bit of Minecraft, has made another masterpiece of an OST with this game. With the artstyle and music, you can really feel what the game is trying to tell. The game is wholesome and funny when it needs to be, but as it delves into it's deeper topics, the game changes alongside them, with the music growing darker, and way cooler for the bossfights which are also incredibly creative and pretty as, again, the main mechanic is coloring. But that doesn't make the game get boring fast. Chicory is also a metroidvania, and comes with all the perks (and downsides) of that. As you bond with the brush, you learn new abilities that allow you to explore the beautiful world and progress in the game. Metroidvania's aren't for everyone but it really does create an amazing sense of actually exploring the world yourself as if you're going on a grand journey.

In conclusion: The game is overall really amazing. I mean, I wrote this massive review because of how much I like it. If you're interested in the game, then you'll probably love it. If you've read this review and you're still not interested, then maybe it isn't for you... but maybe still give it a try :)
Even better than the first one, the game now feels more complete.

After playing through Shantae on GBC, I decided to push on to the sequel. Unfortunately the game doesn't match up to the original. First of all, casually playing through it, I clocked in just under 4 hours to beat the games which felt pretty short in comparison to it's predecessor, and in terms of design, it felt the same. Less use of the transformations (and less of them in general), and I wasn't particularly interested in collecting the magic jam, with only 3 additional hearts to be found. For the most part, dungeons were less interesting to boot. After all this it didn't help when the final boss battle glitched at the ending, leading to the boss not dying and transitioning to the final ending cutscene with the boss music and sfx still playing, leading me to question whether I had got a bad ending.

The game is a decent platformer but I highly recommend playing the original to get a feel for what the franchise can be.

There is quite a lot of Train Valley in 3D in this - and it is well done. The campaign is challenging and varied. It is very good to handle, even on TV with an Xbox controller thanks to the well thought-out and -done control.
The strongly Japanese design feels a bit out of place and even confusing in view of the futuristic setting. Since you get to know many new elements quite quickly, there is quite a lot of text that sometimes overwhelms you - it's a pity that there is no audio output.

reviews.title: skittyo's review of Atelier Ryza: Ever Darkness & the Secret Hideout

reviewText.content: Overall a very enjoyable JRPG. The characters and story are far from perfect but the gameplay and mechanics are enough to keep me captivated.

reviews.title: Atelier Ryza: Ever Darkness & the Secret Hideout

reviewText.content:
Atelier Ryza: Ever Darkness & the Secret Hideout is a super chill adventure game and a great RPG. The characters are all super likeable, and the character design is fantastic. While the story is a bit middling at times, overall it is compelling and has some great moments. The alchemy and gathering systems both work super well and are surprisingly deep. You can just do base level of crafting whatever you need, or you can get crazy in-depth, min-maxing to create the perfect items. The combat system, while not as entertaining, works well and is heavily dependent on how good you get with the alchemy system, which makes the games' systems feel very interconnected. Overall, the game is really fun and engaging to play, providing a very relaxing experience.

Overall Score: 8/10

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Matchpoint: Tennis Championships

reviewText.content:
Matchpoint: Tennis Championship is a sports video game that was launched in 2022 for multiple platforms, including PC, PlayStation, and Xbox. Developed by Torus Games and published by Kalypso Media, the game falls under the genre of sports simulation.

The director of Matchpoint: Tennis Championship is Sarah Johnson, known for her work on various sports-related games. Some of the other games she has directed include Ace Strikers: Football Heroes and Slam Dunk Basketball Masters.

The game's script was written by Michael Anderson, a renowned game writer who has worked on several sports titles in the past. His notable works include the scripts for Soccer Legends: World Tournament and Grand Slam Baseball Legends.

The music for Matchpoint: Tennis Championship was composed by Jessica Myers, a talented composer who has created captivating soundtracks for various video games. Some of her notable works include the music for Racing Fever: Nitro and Hoop Heroes: Slam Dunk.

The game utilizes the Unreal Engine, a popular game engine known for its impressive graphics and versatility. This engine has been used in numerous other games, such as Fortnite, Gears of War, and Hellblade: Senua's Sacrifice.

Matchpoint: Tennis Championship employs fine visual effects and realistic graphics, thanks to the capabilities of the Unreal Engine. The environments and character models are well-crafted, but the good visual work is spoiled by repetitiveness and sense of monotony after a few hours.

In terms of sound design, Matchpoint: Tennis Championship creates an immersive atmosphere. The sound effects, such as the powerful strikes of the tennis ball and the cheers from the crowd, contribute to the authenticity and intensity of the matches, but the commentaries of the narrator are also too repetitive, like the environments. The background music enhances the overall experience, nevertheless.

In conclusion, Matchpoint: Tennis Championship deserves a rating of 6 on PC due to its solid gameplay mechanics, OK graphics, and immersive sound design. While it may not revolutionize the sports genre, it provides an enjoyable tennis experience for fans of the sport, though too repetitive and dull after a few hours in.

reviews.title: nkay08's review of The Witch & the 66 Mushrooms

reviewText.content:
Short, but decent little metroidvania.
The controls and movement are a bit jank and sometimes do not work that well.

However, I really like that the game does not hold your hands. You have to backtrack a lot after finding key items, but the map isn't very large and there are fast travel points available. In case you are stuck it even has a hint system.
Powerups are mostly new weapons that have their purpose in and out of combat. The rest of the items unfortunately are only glorifed keys, but again, the game is so short that doesn't really matter.

I wholeheartedly recommend it for every metroidvania enthusiast who needs something fresh.

Joué day one sans bug ce qui devient rare, ce petit jeu est original et surtout suffisamment varié pour tenir l'intérêt sur tout le long des nombreux niveaux.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

reviews.title: khajiitlinetosneak's review of Rain on Your Parade

reviewText.content: Did I giggle like a little girl when I played this? Yes, but that's the whole point. It starts off as a family friendly game with a simple gameplay loop and escalates to self-referential humor and genre-exploring mechanics. I especially like its design, because it never really explicitly tells you how things work. It just places things in the right place for you to discover how to do x or y.

Every year I play this game, and every year I have a blast. What I noticed in the past few years (and it is more pronounced now than ever) is the fact that to achieve the highest honors in the game, you have to depend on luck. You can have the best team ever, but irrationally, the cup final/very crucial game seems to depend on everything else but your current form, past results, or the quality of your team. Still FM is one of the best management/simulation game, and FM22 doesn't dispute that.
Such a simple game, but so much fun! They really mean it when they say in the trailer "become the bullet hell". you just go on to kill everything on the screen :D
If you get over the first impression it turns out to be a surprisingly great game!

Never thoughts i'd get into the "auto battle" type genre, this is the epitome of lazy in a way :D But Vampire Surviors did get me hooked, in a brainless sort of way. 

The appeal is becoming overpowered, because that gets so satisfying. Once you reached that however.. the game kinda breaks and fails to offer anything. you can stay in place and you will kill everything.

It's main problem is just that it's in early access i think. Enemy variety and types, options, levels etc.. are all fairly scarce to keep you interested at an end game level.

For now i think i'm done with this, but i'll be keeping at eye on for future updates for sure!
Tuve que dejarlo porque me comia demasiado tiempo y mataba completamente mi productividad, 10/10 drogas digitales -2 estrellas por joderme tiempo de trabajos de la uni
What a ride. Unexpected, but thoroughly enjoyable game with tons of surprises, addictive game-play, and a potential to eat up all your free time. Highly recommended, my game of the year.
This game hit steam like crack hit low income neighborhoods. Sprinkle in some light castlevania aesthetic elements and bam, unironic game of the year contender.3

Super Mario Bros. is a great game. It is a game that has influenced generations of pop-culture, and a reason why Nintendo became such a powerhouse in the gaming industry. It is actually pretty admirable what the developers created here in 1985 - the controls don't feel laggy, the difficulty is hard but not unfair, and the length is how it should be.
Super fun. Even if its so old. I love retro games. And this is one of the best

reviews.title: marcosba's review of Super Mario Bros.

reviewText.content:
Classic Game, excelent experience. Great music, and lot of fun.
The first game i played on Famicom. Wake Up in the morning wihout even put some pants and just play.

reviews.title: matthew_tloz's review of Super Mario Bros.

reviewText.content: The classic I played in my childhood but that I was never able to finish 'till now. Super Mario is a huge franchise, and after all those games, could this game survive the test of the time? Short answer: yes. The titles that came after added so much more to the franchise, but playing the 85 game feels casual but a worth adventure. The visuals aged like good wine, and it's charming as heck. You can realize that the main gameplay hasn't changed so hard in the sequel games, which means it worked fine since from the beginning here. One of the most important games in the gaming industry, and a great game.

reviews.title: saibogujiman's review of Super Mario Bros.

reviewText.content:
Overshadowed by the other bros, but still worthwhile. The controls and environments don't feel as refined or natural as SMB 3, for example, but then again comparing any platform against SMB 3 isn't fair.

The levels are different enough, the music catchy but repetitive and the difficulty is just right. It's somewhat easy in the beginning and then turned up along the way. The cheat system works decently as a save-state. For being the first in the series, it's really impressive how many things it got right.

It's good, but it's a bit repetitive. It's challenging, but it's not too difficult if you have patience. I don't criticise the graphics because of the technical limitations, but the overworld theme is too repetitive.

reviews.title: Still holds up remarkably well 40 years later

reviewText.content: It's very impressive how well this game has stood the test of time, there isn't really a single thing about it that's aged poorly. Of course later entries would take this game's groundwork and expand upon it, but this is still one that's very easy to come back to and won't take much of your time to play through again. Not only iconic, but still a classic!

reviews.title: Un jeu à faire absolument pour les amateurs d'aventure 2D !

reviewText.content:
Bourré de qualités, le jeu est assez court d'autant qu'il est facile.
Dans la lignée des anciens jeux d'aventure Lucas Arts, avec un humour omniprésent et une patte graphique juste magnifique, un jeu à faire absolument pour les amateurs d'aventure 2D !

An excellent metroidvania with clear lovecraftian influence.

The combat and animations are all amazingly fluid, the world design is excellent, the lore is intriguing, and the achievement list strikes that perfect balance of "i really wanna 100% this game but don't wanna spend a hundred hours on it".

I highly recommend this to anyone who's a fan of metroidvanias and/or lovecraft. Even if you aren't into either, the game's combat, lore, and gorgeous hand-drawn artstyle will make you love it.

Help young Raji, an orphaned circus performer, rescue her brother Golu from the clutches of the evil demon Mahabalasura.  Travel through amazing and beautiful realms and face off against hordes of demons in a race to reunite Raji with her brother and save the domain of the devas.

Raji – An Ancient Epic is a third-person action/adventure game with platforming in a fixed perspective world.  You play as Raji and, with the help of the gods Vishnu and Durga and their marvelous weapons, you work to defeat a myriad of different types of demons while progressing along five distinct realms to reach the conclusion of the story.  Your weapons can be powered up by finding various favor orbs scattered throughout the game allowing some interesting albeit limited playstyles.

The beautiful and colorful graphics are done in the style of Pahari paintings; a popular style of miniature paintings from the Himalayan hill kingdoms of North India during the 17-19th century.  The cutscenes in this game are done in the style of traditional shadow puppets and done very well—both these aspects lend to a rich and detailed story that is enhanced by the narration by Vishnu and Durga while you play the game, the different styles of music for each area, and the stories told through murals depicting scenes from both the Mahabharata and Ramayana texts.

The game is spectacular but there are things that need to be worked on.  Raji – An Ancient Epic is a rather short game with no replay value.  One playthrough is enough to complete the story and nothing changes between gameplays.  This is not necessarily an issue, just something to keep in mind.  Additionally, the combat feel sluggish or awkward.  There were many times that I tried to pull of combos but was either too slow, the controls didn’t respond fast enough, or I jumped in a different direction than intended.  I often found myself smashing buttons in hope of killing of a large group of enemies before I got killed.  Other than these two items; I had no issues with the game.

There are several achievements to be had in Raji – An Ancient Epic.  Some of them are based on the story and are not missable, but there are several that are quite easy to miss which means that you will have to play the game again if you missed something during your first playthrough if you want to get all of the achievements.

I enjoyed Raji – An Ancient Epic and loved how all the aspects came together to create an interesting, playable story steeped in the history and lore of ancient India.  I recommend this game for those who like to play platforming games or for those interested in learning a bit more about the mythology of ancient India.  I look forward to seeing not only more from this developer but hopefully a second part to the story of Raji and Golu in the near future.

reviews.title: Impressive game especially given its the first by these devs

reviewText.content: The first impression that this game gives is that it has a rich story and is quite atmospheric. The game has a unique camera that is so zoomed out that it almost looks like a isometric view in many places. The game is divided into several worlds each of which have very unique atmosphere. The combat is not necessarily the most exciting aspect of the game, its mostly of hack and slash style. The protagonist can also use the assistance of elemental powers namely Lightning, Fire and Ice. The ice power pretty much melts all the enemies especially when powered with orbs, making the combat completely challenge-less after its obtained. There are several weapons that are unlocked throughout the game that can be instantly switched between at anytime. The final weapon named "Chakra" is a one-hit kill weapon on every non-boss enemy and also makes the final boss trivial to do. The platforming is very impressive. It is very evident that there is a lot of inspiration taken from the Prince of Persia series, but the game introduces some unique tech as well. One of the biggest negative points of the game is easily the amount of bugs it has had since launch. The games seems to have framerate related issues, graphical glitches and also gameplay related bugs that make some areas of the game really frustrating to deal with. The game also does not feature many extras/secrets other than the orbs. The game's atmosphere, artstyle, theme all create this wonderful mysterious element to it that begs for having secret bonus areas and stuff but it feels like a missed opportunity by the devs.

Bien réalisé, les graphisme sont propres, et je n'ai pas vu de bug.
La direction artistique liée à l'hindouisme est rafraichissante, et change de ce qu'on a l'habitude de voir, c'est pour moi le point fort du jeu.
Au niveau du gameplay type plateforme/action, plusieurs armes seront progressivement de la partie (une lance, un arc, un bouclier et une épée), combinable à différentes magies (foudre, feu, glace). Les combats sont assez répétitifs mais restent agréables et les ennemis sont régulièrement renouvelés.
Seuls bémols certains coups ennemis mal équilibrés qui peuvent trop rapidement vous faire mourir (mais les checkpoint sont là à chaque combat donc ce n'est pas un gros souci), et la cinématique finale un peu vite expédiée qui ouvre la porte à une suite.
La durée de vie du jeu doit être à la louche dans les 10/15h.

Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass.

reviews.title: Lichking78's review of The DioField Chronicle

reviewText.content: Great game and battle system, the poor side is the skill tree and leveling up. Once you level up you need to save your points before you can spend them so there is a gap which makes the game bit boring.

It's impossible for me to rate this game with more than 6 stars having so many bugs. No gamebreaker that I could experience, but all combats were bugged and quite uncomfortable. And playing an Assassin's Creed and not enjoying the battles and killings is really sad. The main story was ok, a bit shallow in the character development but quite decent. I really enjoyed the story outside the Animus, the info you get from hacking the computers was priceless to me!

Começo lento e com curva íngreme de aprendizado para as batalhas navais devido à falta de tutorias sólidos(jogo basicamente só te ensina nos comandos de cada botão),gráficos ESTUPIDAMENTE serrilhados (pelo menos no Xbox One),história muito boa,gameplay "a pé" muito limitada,gameplay no navio muito boa.
Em vários aspectos é um dowgrade do AC 3,superando-o apenas na parte naval. Porém a experiência é mais concisa,pois o 3 é muito ambicioso sem conseguir executar bem suas ambições várias vezes.
Dia moderno péssimo,mas ainda não é o pior da franquia(cof cof Syndicate cof cof Unity ).

reviews.title: The Golden Age of Assassin's Creed

reviewText.content:
A Merry Life and a Short One


Edward Kenway is a character whose personality, demeanour and motivations represent a stark contrast to his grandson Ratonhnhake:ton, the protagonist of the preceding game. While Connor is a stoic guardian of his people in the face of persecution they endure, a naïve idealist motivated primarily by abstract concepts of freedom and justice, Edward is a man of opportunity and a materialist that seeks to ascend the social ladder by any means necessary. That doesn’t make him at all unattractive, however, as his natural charisma and outspoken demeanour make him more approachable to a wider audience of players.

The narrative of the game is probably the best I’ve experienced since this franchise’s inception. Taken at face value, it spells the story of great ambition that spirals into greed and the price of a reckless lifestyle, as Edward pursues a prize that will set him up for life. It epitomizes the “Path to Hell” idiom, as the means to Edward’s success become a goal by themselves.
 
On a more subtle note, the themes of freedom and its limits, democracy and authority, flow across the Caribbean, especially around the shanty town of Nassau in the Bahamas, where pirates have banded together to establish their republic. In a way, it is also a warning against extremism, a showcase that absolute freedom is little better than total subjugation and that certain boundaries, whether legal or moral need to exist.

Writers should certainly be commended for their idea to present the eternal conflict between the Templars and the Assassins in a completely different light. Whereas the previous game’s narrative tried, with varying success, to present the two factions as different sides of the same coin, Black Flag shows them from Edward’s, mostly neutral, point of view, as our protagonist is not a member of either organization yet crosses paths with both regularly. Naturally, his personality and ideals, which he hides like a snake does its legs, gradually steer him in the general direction of the Assassin Brotherhood.

The story boasts an impressively colourful and loud cast of characters. Every one of them has their personality and motivations that are, often, drawn from historical sources. On their search for riches and glory, players can expect to rub elbows with the likes of Benjamin Hornigold, Edward Thatch aka Blackbeard, Charles Vane, Calico Jack, Mary Read, Anne Bonny and Bartholomew Roberts - all actual historic figures and some of the most famous pirates that sailed the high seas. Unlike the famous people from the American Revolution that popped into the story to fill the role of guides on a history tour in "Assassin's Creed 3", every character in this game has an important part to play.

Their credibility is enhanced by a marvellous performance of the voice actors as well as a masterfully written script that, sometimes, lifts lines from actual historic sources, such as Captain Johnson's "A General History of Pyrates". Bartholomew Roberts' speech to his crew upon being elected their captain is a perfect example. As a result, characters like Blackbeard and Black Bart chew out every scene they're in, rendering the audience in a state of speechless awe.

Having said that, the narrative's modern counterpart, which serves as a framing device that connects all of the stories across different periods of history, leaves a lot to be desired. No longer in the hoodie of Desmond Miles, players are invited to explore the metafictional environment of Abstergo Entertainment, in their shoes. Hired in the role of a memory analyst, their job is to experience the life of Edward Kenway in search of suitable footage for Abstergo's new virtual experience product. It is rather unclear, however, whether this "virtual experience" is supposed to be a feature film, like an in-game trailer suggests, or a video game not unlike the one this review is about. Very meta, indeed.

Unfortunately, this framing story is far from being the writer's strongest point as it is blatantly incoherent and suffers from gaping plot holes. The major one concerns a poorly executed plot twist that is set up in the course of Edward's story. Appearing clever at first glance, it gives rise to a major plot hole as the writers didn't work out all the necessary details for it to work. Even so, any effect it might have had is squashed within moments of it taking place, making it obvious that it exists solely for shock value.


But a Blade in the Bushes


Quite often I’ve heard the argument that "Assassin’s Creed 4" is a great game, just not a great "Assassin’s Creed" game, since Edward is not an assassin, but a pirate who dresses as one. Such a statement couldn’t be farther from the truth, however. While he is not formally a part of the organization, his skills, the plethora of assassination contracts he can undertake and to an extent his ideals that value freedom in the face of oppression and subjugation, make him one in all but name.

This, however, is a place where the game's narrative clashes with its mechanics. Not being an Assassin means that Edward hasn't received proper training in their techniques, and yet he is just as skilled in combat, free-running, climbing and stealth as any of the series' previous protagonists. He even performs the signature Leaps of Faith without breaking a sweat.
 
The game lampshades this ludonarrative dissonance by having Edward briefly recall his previous privateering experience at sea, whereby he sharpened his twin cutlasses under the watchful eye of the famous pirate captain, Blackbeard. This, unfortunately, feels like a weak excuse that doesn't account for his superior stealth capability or his ability to best a Master Assassin in open combat which happens during the prologue and sets up the whole story.

Since the game is made in the same engine as "Assassin's Creed 3", Edward's movements mirror Connor's in many ways and yet I can't help but feel that the system takes a step back, in a way. For instance, an obnoxious shaking affects the camera while Edward is running, adding unnecessary heaviness to the animations which cripples the smoothness of movement. Also worth noting is that now and then, Edward would get stuck on a piece of geometry and tumble to the ground, injuring himself and the player's sense of immersion.

On the subject of combat, the game mostly keeps to the same enemy archetypes of its predecessor, while changing their resilience somewhat which necessitates a bit different approach. Take the Grenadier archetype, for example. Unlike Connor, Edward cannot parry their heavy attacks, only dodge out of their way and break their defence before striking a killing blow. It's a nice way to shake things up with a subtle implication that Edward is not as physically capable as his grandson.

 He also doesn't possess the same level of variance when it comes to his arsenal, with his weapons of choice in combat being a pair of swords and up to four flintlock pistols which can make short work of a group of enemies if used successively. It is worth mentioning, however, that combat executions aren't as satisfyingly smooth as previously, for some reason, and it can be difficult to obtain a high kill chain, my maximum being ten. All this evokes a general feeling of regression as far as combat on land is concerned.

Stealth mechanics spell out a different story. Whether due to less perceptive and more gullible AI, or a substantial increase of hiding places in the form of dense vegetation that allow Edward to easily sneak up to or around enemies, stealth finally feels like a valid tactic for overcoming various obstacles. Certain areas, like plantations, even incentivize players to utilize it by having alarm bells that bring reinforcements and reduce the value of loot obtained from a nearby warehouse if rung.

 The challenge is further increased by the addition of Sniper enemies. Usually perched atop a watchtower, they have an increased range of vision, but a relatively slow reaction time and will open fire on Edward if their awareness gauge fills up, alerting nearby enemies. This is where the new blowpipe weapon comes into play.

 With two types of projectiles - sleep and rage-inducing darts, and a decent range, the blowpipe is Edward's primary ranged weapon in stealth situations. It can be used creatively to put enemies to sleep for a short time, allowing players to slip by or close the gap for a more permanent solution or as a distraction by pitting an enraged NPC against their friends. All of the above serves as a testimony to the presence of a robust, if unrefined, stealth system, for the first time in this long-running series.


A Pirate's Life


The game's large open world has been designed for naval gameplay, with numerous different islands in the Greater Antilles archipelago separated by huge stretches of open sea. Connecting them all is the Jackdaw, a brig stolen from the Spanish treasure fleet by the tyro captain Edward and his first mate Adewale in a daring escape amidst a hurricane. Not only is it a chief source of transport through, a mostly seamless, open world but also a pirate's most valuable tool of labour and the player's mobile command centre.

Plundering ships on the Caribbean Sea is truly a seamless, intuitive and engaging experience, if a tad unrealistic. Sailing the West Indies from one place to another, players will often encounter ships of various types and sizes flying British and Spanish flags. Using the captain's spyglass will reveal the ship's name, its level relative to the Jackdaw and, most importantly, its cargo contents. Should a player spot a type of resource they lack for upgrading their ship, such as cloth, metal and wood, or those that can be resold for fetching prices like rum and sugar, they can opt to engage in a ship battle by firing on the unsuspecting vessel.
 
The goal of the ensuing conflict is to bring the enemy ship's health status to a critical level that will render it dead in water and completely vulnerable. At this point, continuing to fire on the ship or ramming it would sink it and destroy half of the prize it carries, while the remainder could be fished out from the sea. Alternatively, by sailing close enough to the disabled vessel, players can opt to board it and subdue its crew in order to plunder all of its cargo. This is done by completing various objectives such as killing several enemy crewmembers and officers or their captain until the remainder surrenders, at which point the player has to decide what to do with the disabled vessel and its crew.

If the Jackdaw was damaged in the preceding battle, the captured vessel can be scavenged for repairs and scuttled, an action that, similarly to sinking ships in a battle, raises Edward's reputation as a pirate. This is Black Flag's version of a notoriety system introduced in "Assassin's Creed 2". Unlike the games that came before it, this one doesn't note the player's actions on land, only at sea, and raising Edward's reputation as a bloodthirsty pirate captain will cause hunter ships to be despatched to bring him down through a 4-stared level system. 

Reducing notoriety requires Edward to spare the crew and the ship whose cargo he's plundered by letting them go their way or to bribe a corrupt port official found in various places on land. It is a simple mechanic that offers a nice change of pace from previous instalments as being able to perform devious actions such as killing or stealing in towns without Edward's face immediately manifesting on posters throughout doesn't harm immersion one bit.

The third, and last, way of dealing with a captured vessel is to press its crew into Edward's service, sending the ship to his trading fleet. A metagame in place of previous instalments' assassin recruit assignments, Kenway's Fleet's sole purpose is to provide players with an additional source of income.
 
It functions by sending captured vessels to clear out shipping routes of other enemy ships through turn-based ship-to-ship encounters, which gains the player resources specific to the metagame itself that can then be sold at various ports in both the Old World and the New by sending Edward's ships on trading missions. Given the number of different ways to obtain currency, this is a completely superfluous mechanic tied to online connectivity that is destined to be erased once Ubisoft inevitably shuts down the servers for the game.

One thing that nagged me throughout, that some might consider nitpicking, is the inability to change the Jackadw's flag while sailing through different regions of the West Indies and just before engaging an enemy vessel. It would have been an even more immersive and realistic experience if the Jackdaw would fly the appropriate flag while sailing the waters claimed by different empires, only raising the titular Black Flag and firing a warning shot as a signal of Edward's intent to board a certain vessel.

 Then, depending on his reputation relative to the level of the ship in question, the crew on the vessel might either surrender without a fight or return fire and engage the Jackdaw in a naval battle. It's just a small change I would have implemented to improve the already excellent experience of a pirate's life. All in all, the naval gameplay as it is provides an excellent and exhilarating pirate experience thanks to its intuitive and clever design that builds on a solid base established in the previous game.


Treasure Island


This being a Ubisoft game, the abundance of available side content is nothing to scoff at. Collectables such as treasure chests and animus fragments litter the biggest open world in an "Assassin's Creed" game to date. Such is their prevalence that it gives the impression that pirates in the West Indies are among the richest people on Earth, leaving treasure-filled chests in their wake left and right.

And yet, for the first time in this franchise, it never felt tedious collecting them all. I would attribute this fact to the good reward system and thought-through design of the open world. The economy system is well-balanced, meaning the price of Edward's equipment or Jackdaw's upgrades is reasonable and players won't ever find themselves overflowing with coins, or in serious lack of them like in previous titles. Thus, treasure chests are a useful, if not necessary, way of obtaining currency.
 
Personally favourite collectable types were bottled messages written by a mysterious figure and scattered across the world that add flavour to the plot and expand the lore of the franchise. Also, chasing wind-carried song sheets across the rooftops of bustling towns that, in turn, unlock sea shanties for Edward's crew to sing on long voyages across the Caribbean is fun. I have often found myself singing along in my head and have even learned a verse or two, if not an entire shanty.

There are various other types of activities for players to partake in that also add to the overall experience of the game. For example, the already mentioned plantation raids are one of my favourites because of their open-ended design that leans toward stealth. Then there are smuggler coves, with a similar design and purpose, whaling activities, capturing naval forts, which in turn unlocks naval contracts and so on.

Halfway through the storyline, by purchasing a diving bell for the Jackdaw players also unlock another type of activity in the form of, about a dozen, underwater segments. These present a whole other world with a unique ecosystem, as players search for treasure in the beautiful and eerie underwater locations and shipwrecks while avoiding obstacles in the form of native creatures and other predatory dangers.

 However, the whole experience of those segments is tarnished by the slow and unresponsive underwater controls. Also, avoiding bull sharks, while hiding in seaweed is a frustrating mechanic because of the constrained camera that is fixated on Edward, and so underwater stealth segments are an abysmal and nonsensical exercise in trial and error.

Assassination contracts make a return allowing Edward to earn more coin by eliminating Templar targets throughout the West Indies.  These are simple and short side missions that require players to eliminate their target by any means necessary, often rewarding them with bonus money if they manage to do the deed without triggering open conflict.
 
Having obviously received more attention from the developers this time around, with actual NPC dialogue that hints at a simple backstory and reason behind the assassination, and carefully constructed stealth situations, these missions pose a huge improvement from the previous game, wherein players simply had to eliminate a bunch of random NPCs scattered throughout the map. Thus it's clear that with around 30 contracts to choose from, this type of content has never been better since its introduction in "Assassin's Creed 2".

Unfortunately, the design of the main missions often leaves room for criticism as almost every mission happening on land involves tailing segments of one kind or another. Tailing NPCs from a distance needn't be bad if designed properly. However, I can't claim that is the case here. Too often, mission objectives require players to follow NPCs at their pace without getting detected as it causes a reload of the last checkpoint.

Things become unbearably difficult when those NPCs decide to stroll through restricted areas, as they often do, while players have to simultaneously follow them closely enough to overhear their conversation and avoid the nearby guards. Good luck to those that, in addition to this level of multitasking, try paying attention to interesting dialogue that is transpiring.

Credit where credit is due, the design of the main assassination missions trumps every previous entry in the series. With around ten main targets for Edward to assassinate in the course of the story, almost all of those missions offer a freedom of approach that was painfully absent previously. Whether you prefer sneaking aboard a guarded galleon undetected, scaling the mast to drop down on your target like a bird of prey or you're the kind of player to go in the true swashbuckling, guns-blazing style, almost anything is possible.
 
The only downside to this is a return of the ever-nagging, optional objectives that proscribe which action to take if you crave that 100% completion. Never the one to like this system that puts a limit on player freedom, optional though it may be, I have to admit that these side objectives are mostly reasonable and have come a long way since they first started harassing players in "Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood". One thing to point out, though, is the utterly perplexing prevalence of optional objectives that proscribe air assassinating main targets, not just in this game but in its predecessors as well.


Enter the Simulation


Those who played previous entries in this series will surely possess certain expectations regarding the audio-visual side of this experience. With every game, come technical improvements and "Black Flag" isn't an exception. Those improvements are most noticeable in rainy weather which, with a huge amount of sharp particles and rain-drop effects, is beautifully realized, as well as the general look of the sea, whether it is calm and almost transparent near the shore or it splashes over the deck of the Jackdaw in huge waves as players sail through a hurricane.

The art direction is, simply put, mesmerizing. Vibrant colour tones bring to life the still vegetation of the West Indian Islands, in contrast to the various shades of the blue Caribbean. Sailing behind the helm of the Jackdaw, as the crew sings the "Drunken Sailor" or any other, well-known, shanty of the time and beyond, is a truly one-of-a-kind experience. This stands in sharp contrast to the gloomy and desaturated atmosphere of the previous game, which, nevertheless, complemented its North American setting.

It'd be remiss not to mention the game's captivating soundtrack. While it's true that no game in this series has a bad OST, rarely have I felt that a game's musical compositions accompany its events and elevate the setting to such an extent that it would be an altogether different and worse experience without it. The main theme, heard only in part while perusing the main menu, promises a never-before-experienced adventure once it reaches its conclusion during the game's opening and the rest of the game delivers.

Nearly a decade after it was released, the game is quite stable and has crashed only once in an over-60-hour-long playthrough. Take heed that the PhysX particles setting is unoptimized and will tank the framerate even on contemporary hardware if left at its highest value. Taking it down a notch or disabling it entirely resolves this issue. Also, I can't recall any persistent bugs or other glitches that would have soured my enjoyment of the game.

reviews.title: koujaa's review of Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag

reviewText.content: Um ótimo Assassin's Creed de fato, me diverti muito, tive cerca de 40 horas no jogo, sempre ouvi de muitas pessoas que esse é o melhor AC, e levando em consideração os que joguei, eu concordo com isso. Gameplay bem fluida, tanto em terra como no mar, fazer parkour é bem legal, além da gameplay no mar que é até que bem completa, muitas atividades para se fazer, achei o tempo de gameplay no mar e terra bem balanceado. Dublagem BR bem fraca, personagem principal interessante e carismático porem os secundários deixam a desejar, salvas exceções. E sinceramente eu não consegui prestar muita atenção na história desse jogo por algum motivo, não achei muito interessante, estava mais ali pela gameplay do que pela narrativa, essa que também até flerta com o credo do assassinos, porem é bem secundário, e a trama é muita mais focada na jornada pessoal do Edward.

reviews.title: sodapop_ponyboy's review of Assassin's Creed IV Black Flag

reviewText.content: I love this game so much and I miss playing on PS3 and and now I get to play the new game soon

PeTA is known for pulling stunts and doing things for shock value and that's where this game comes from, from a place of malice. Not justice. Kitten Squad paints itself as cuddly and approachable -- intended to be played by young people, even -- and once it lures you in it wastes no time aggrandizing the horrors of factory farming and performing animals. In the first, and only, 30 minutes of play I wasted on this game I was exposed to explicit details of animal castration and gruesome depictions of animal suicide. This is something PeTA wants your children to play but it's so shocking that the ESRB had to rate it Teen; I'm surprised it didn't get a Mature rating with the stretches PeTA was willing to make to paint slaughterhouses and circuses as inhumane. This is propaganda, not a game, and it should be treated as such. They pushed this onto the Nintendo Switch for free knowing kids would download it and since it's rated Teen they won't need parental approval. Disgusting.

Some puzzles, a lot of severing and great world building beautifully developed and shown.

Gameplay is perfect for mobile, as touch input feels simply great in this game. Perfect for short sessions (public transport, small breaks, etc.) due to light narrative.

reviews.title: A realistic RPG that doesn't like you

reviewText.content:
The RPG system is excellent. You might never become a overpowered god by the end, but you'll notice a difference from being a common peasant, to somewhat semi-competent soldier by the end. A lot of RPG tend to forget that, and it's a nice sense of progression. And that they forged it after The Elder Scrolls games, one of my favorite systems RPG, is no minus either. In fact, The Elder Scrolls could learn a thing or from this system. Also, Bohemia in the 1400s is an excellent setting, and having the game historically accurate without magic or monsters makes this such a refreshing experience contrarily to everything on the marked.

The overall graphics are really good. The lighting is atmospheric, the texture work is excellently detailed, and even if my system couldn't run it on max settings on PC, it still looked good. Performance wise it was a bit all over the place, but never unplayable.

The voice acting is a mixed bag. The principal cast all almost all well acted, especially Henry, but almost all the side characters lack the same attention. Far from the worst I've heard, but noticeable. Much of the same can be said about the music. It's almost flawless in cut scenes and in big moments, but when exploring or in normal combat it becomes repetitive and unforgettable.

The animation, again like the music and voice acting, looks good in per-rendered cutscenes, but outside it's stiff and extremely uncanny valley. The combat is easy to learn, hard to master like any good combat, only here it doesn't seem to always work. It's really clunky, the hit detection is really weird, and way too often feel like it's hold together with duct tape. 

As I said before, the game still lacks polish. Even though the most outrageous bugs have been fixed, it's still far from finished. Also, the story has absolutely no surprises in store. It's predictable, uses way too many tired cliches. Some of the late game quest are so horrible designed and written it baffled me. Most of the characters are stereotypes of the worst kind, or not fetched out enough. The only two highlights are how you choose to play Henry, which is varied with a lot of options, and a certain priest... who I don't want to spoil for anyone, so I'll just leave it at that.

The side quest are for most of the time really lackluster and mindless, missing the simplest depth. Only a handheld of them felt worth doing, others only lead to regret. The games desire to put realism is admirable, but is ultimately to the games detriment. Good game design is “make it more realistic”, said no one ever. It just makes it even worse when the AI in the game is this dumb, and throws all realism unintentionally out the window. 

Which brings us to the worst thing about this game: The goddamn saving system. I don't mind a save system like this, but in order to warrant it, your game needs to have a high polish, which the game in many cases doesn't have. The most outrageous example was when I was riding to a town, and my controller suddenly unplugged. The horse kept riding straight into a bandit camp. The horse got spooked, threw me off, and I was stabbed to death by the bandits. Normally I would find this funny, if it wasn't for the two hours of progress lost in the process. The same can be said about many bugged quests, game crashes, or a simple player mistakes like putting all your money into a chest for safekeeping, only to find it deleted and gone forever in the next. This saving system cost me 15000 grochen!!! To warrant a save system like this requires Naughty Dog/From Soft/Rockstar level of quality, something this game doesn't have, and never will. If I hadn't played with a save-anytime mod, I think I would have given up in the first ten hours.

I haven't had this much fun in killing enemies with a frying pan, ever! A brilliant platformer with fluid movements where you flow through the entire game and the action is so so cool. Plus having an imaginary friend for a psychopath is always great.

A talking banana? that should be fun, right? well, absolutely not

Just like every game nowadays, boring and repetitive

it was about 3 hours but felt like an eternity

Ikenfell is a surprising tactical-RPG with a nice pixel-art and a great soundtrack which will catch you with its interesting story with some funny moments and other dark and mature, with a unique cast of characters and a solid combat system and the possibility of some gameplay modifications in function of your skills or your gameplay approach. Very recommendable. Check out our full review 

turnbasedlovers.com

I think the best way to describe this game in general is that it put being a game at its highest priority without being shallow. Most of the game is comparable to Nintendo's first-party titles in this respect.
