- un canon des ames automatique et son nouveau petit frère "gnagnagna", ainsi que des bonus aléatoires de notre "leader" ajoutés dans les combats
- un scénario avec son lot de surprises

On garde donc le principe de base du premier épisode toujours aussi addictif :
- 12 personnages qui s'ajoutent au fur et à mesure
- 3 canons, avec pour chaque canon un tireur + un support
- plein de synergies possibles entre les persos, et d'attaques spéciales qui se débloquent en grimpant de niveau
- des interludes pour améliorer son char, faire la cuisine, parler ou faire la lessive pour augmenter les synergies, pécher/planter/élever et aller dans des ruines pour récupérer des items, dormir pour l'xp, etc.
- les systèmes de faiblesse and co dans les combats

Le jeu reste long, compter 35h pour un premier run, divisé en 12 chapitres, avec toujours la même structure (interlude de début/combats/interlude du milieu/combat/interlude de fin/boss).

Pour ceux qui ont aimé le 1er, le second est à faire les yeux fermés, sachant que si on apprend pas mal de choses sur l'univers de Fuga, il reste des informations à apprendre et une fin ouverte sur un troisième et surement dernier épisode.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

RPG shooters like this are my jam, and The Outer Worlds is no different. It has everything you'd expect from the genre, as well as a refreshingly contained world and accompanying playtime. Still, it falls short of similar greats. TOW quickly becomes too easy, and with such brief combat, there is little need to worry about ammo, consumables, or the entire Tactical Time Dilation system. The game invites linear play patterns that don't particularly encourage exploration. Story-developing text is plentiful but rather repetitive. Inventory management is a major hassle, at least with a controller; there are a handful of incredibly annoying quirks about the inventory menus that led me to dread another venture into reassignment of weapons and armor. And the game comes to an end rather abruptly, sealing the deal on my feeling that the whole experience was altogether somewhat perfunctory. It's worth a play, but I'm not surprised it failed to find the same fervent audience as Fallout, Borderlands, or Mass Effect.

An interesting, steelpunk mesh of Mass Effect and Fallout with Dishonored vibes. I enjoyed playing it quite a lot. However, balancing is rather off. I played on the second to last difficulty, and during almost all the playthrough, I felt quite overpowered.

The game is great, I would call it Obsidian take on Mass Effect. So many outcomes and choices, that the games forces you to replay it out of curiosity. The maps are denser and really satisfying, there is noting misplaced and yes you can kill everyone and finish the game. There are different builds and I must admin that having a lot of bits can get you a very interesting character tree.
The game reminds me of KOTOR in some ways. I really like how smooth everything is.

Outer Worlds is a game i really wanted to like.. more. It's good for sure, but it made me realise i have a big issue with games lacking core protagonist. All the freedom of choice advertised, that you can be whatever you wish is great, if you know what to do with it. Unfortunately in my 15-18hr playthrough (i didn't finish it) that lead me to just being a nobody, not really knowing what i was doing, why i was there, what were those items i was constantly picking up... i just felt like an empty fell is a colourful sandbox world. 

I've had the same feeling for the similar Elder Scrolls and Fallout games, it feels empty to me, i must not be getting something :/ The quest system and choice was one of the highest praised points, but it still feels like an illusion of choice to me since i by default with a gaming mind i will always end up picking up the quest an NPC gives out, the potential reward of loot & XP is always greater than the so called role play. Sure you could kill them, but that's more trouble than not. There's a big concept of fear of missing out when it comes to RPG quests, and i feel Outer Worlds has that.

I was really interested in the world itself, the not-so futuristic caricature of a corporate humanity was clever and new. It managed to deliver something pretty fresh compared to the standard tropes. Kudos for originality!

reviews.title: dutchy280's review of The Outer Worlds

reviewText.content: The game, story and look and feel are great. It is frustrating that their are inaccesible worlds, that no DLC has actually filled. There appears to be a sense of the developer abandoning the game in favour of profit, via a sequel. The games main downside is once completed, there is no reason to return to it. I would love in No Mans Sky and this game merged. Each game has missing parts that the other fills.

This game has a really great story. Your choices have a real impact. I just liked talking to NPC because they are very well written and funny. The open world is cool, but there is too much loot everywhere without real interest. The fights are not perfect, the AI, the discretion and melee fights can really be improved so I personally played the whole game with guns.
To conclude, yes the gameplay can be improved, but the story is so good that that's what we remember in the end.

++ Très belle histoire (forcément le point fort de ce style de jeu).
+ Excellente traduction française parfaitement intégrée.
- A noter sur certains PC comme le mien un framerate bas inexpliqué, les DEV travaillent dessus, sans succès pour l'instant. Mais cela n'empêche pas d'apprécier le jeu.

NB : Episode qui fait suite à ToTheMoon, les deux mini épisodes et ABirdStory, mais peut être joué seul (jusque qq références non indispensables)
While not very strong on the "game" aspect, this is the best experience of the 2012. If you are a human - you must play this. =)

Another Telltale game delivering an amazing story full of tough choices and memorable characters. Lee and Clementine are really likeable from the first chapter, and the roster around them isn't far behind. The writers wrote an extremely believable story, the way characters behave is absolutely genuine and you feel for them. Great game, and although it is not as good as The Wolf Among Us, it is a gem. I can't wait to play Season 2.

Hasn't aged well graphically but the story will hold up forever. Clementine is great main character that develops throughout the series. The story for kinda fall off in later games but deserves a play for first couple of games.

Techniquement faible, la mise en scène & l'histoire compensent largement se point négatif. Entre point & click basique & scènes de QTE, le mélange prend bien ! Pas de Vf mais l'anglais utilisé n'est pas d'un haut niveau, ça ne m'a posé aucun souci pour rentrer dans l'histoire, très prenante :)

easily the best game of all time, with just the perfectly crafted story with gameplay that's most definitely minimalistic but beautifully so. Everything from the music, the cinematography, the writing, the acting - *everything*, is just so beyond words amazing that it's honestly a straight up miracle. Must play for literally everyone, but especially those who enjoy a good story or for those who, you know, have a heart :)

- WARNING: I explain in detail about a certain characteristic of the story that is pretty famous already. It's not tecnically a spoiler, but you can foreshadow easily what will happen if you read this. Read at your own risk!

The Walking Dead is a point and click adventure where you have to solve puzzles and make decisions, that Telltale claims that will affect future events of the story.

And as a story (the main point of this game), the narrative is excellent.
The characters feel real. They have some out-of-character moments, but you'll feel pitty of the good guys and want to kill the assholes as soon as the option pops out.
It is really long, as well. For this kind of games, that is (arround 10 hours beating the main story).
The situations that will present in front of you are the point-and-click type. Click things, observe stuff, pick objects, use it to solve things. You know, since the rest of the crowd you hang with apparently are cluless. But it's not that bad. That's classic point-and-click stuff afterall. Good references.

This game has all the ingredients to be a masterpiece. Well, it can't be in other way: we are talking about an indie that came out the same year as Journey and still got many attention.
I would give it a 10/10. 25/3 for the ending.

But it isn't. And you know why?

This game LIES. It's the biggest liar I saw in a while. More than AAAs. More than [insert not-trusty person here that you don't like]. And I can't pass that.

I can pass that this game has a little of "game" and more than interactive movie. I can pass that they used a franchise about shooting zombies and there isn't any zombie shooting. In fact, I appreciate that.


But I can't pass a game that tells me "all your decisions will affect the story" and does EVERYTHING IT CAN to ignore your decisions. No matter how decesive a decision looks: by the next episode (or sooner), you'll see that had no relevance to the plot. And if it did, it will be nullfilled very soon.
And this dulls the game. It dulls the game, because the story you'll read is basically the same no matter what you do. They dull the characters the game puts so much effort to build up, because they will do certain scripted things, no matter if you befriended them or treat them horrible. Sometimes they will act different... but that's because this decision is not crucial to advance the plot. To advance it to the ending the creators had in mind. A good one, but the only one.

That's why I had to quit it so much points. It's not that the story or the ending is bad. They are good. But they didn't let me decide if I liked more the other "options". Despite they told me I would. Too much wasted potential to deserve the perfect score.
great fun little game.  its just you moving a hole and letting things fall in. its just a lot of fun

I loved this game and I found the dialogue and story to be very entertaining. My only wish is that the game could have been a bit longer and maybe more challenging. I'll definitely be playing this one again and I appreciate that this game had me wanting to screenshot many scenes and points of dialogue to share with my buds. I don't know what it is about games where you level areas by controlling an improbable hole in the ground but I want more. 
BK is the perfect sassy little hero.

In Donut County you control a hole in the ground. There game consists out of a series of levels with some story stuff in between. Each level is its own puzzle, but only according to the loosest definition of the term; the puzzles are very easy. My main issue with the game is that there is no challenge. The game prioritizes 'art' over entertainment. The story also just gets in the way of what little gameplay there is.
The game can best be described as short and sweet. It won't take long to beat but dear god is it lovely the characters the art design, the story all just lovely.

Donut County is a short game, where you use a hole in the ground to swallow up everything in the level. The concept is simple and the gameplay is easy but it is all brought together with a cute art style, a silly story, and the unyielding urge to make the hole grow. Donut County may have one of the most chill vibes you will ever encounter in a game and this is elevated by a phenomenal soundtrack. 

All in all, Donut Count is a short and unique game that is well worth a playthrough. The gameplay is simple and not very challenging but it also has an addictive quality that will have you play through in a single sitting

reviews.title: Jeu léger qui amuse une heure ou deux.

reviewText.content:
Jeu léger qui amuse une heure ou deux.
La direction artistique est assez basique, l'idée est originale mais très vite limitée.
L'histoire qui sert de fil rouge est un prétexte qui permet d'enchainer les niveaux.
Donc un petit jeu sans prétention et sans besoin d'investissement, qui permet une coupure rafraichissante entre des gros jeux AAA.

(Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass)

Madness awaits under the thick ice of Antartica…are your prepared to face untold horrors and explore the absolute limits of nature?  Explore the depths of a pre-human civilization, solve ancient puzzles, flee from horrors beyond human understanding, and manage to hold onto your sanity.  Unspeakable and sinister wonders await in Conarium.

The visual world of Conarium is amazing.  It is a spectacular and beautiful look at a Lovecraftian universe brought to life for players to enjoy—from monolithic statues to detailed mosaics—there is obviously a lot of time and effort put into the world.  When added with the soundtrack, parts which still haunt me long after I finished the game, what you have is a spectacular walking simulator game where you are encouraged to explore the horrific vistas and things that man was not meant to see.

The puzzles are not too difficult and are interesting.  However, the number of puzzles is sadly small, and I would have enjoyed more to figure out.  Additionally, I ran into a bug for two of the achievements and with the age of this game I doubt that it will be fixed.  With that being said, I did enjoy my time playing Conarium and managed to keep my sanity…for the most part.

If you are a Lovecraft fan, I recommend Conarium wholeheartedly.  However, if you do not enjoy walking simulators or if you do not know who H.P. Lovecraft is or think that Lovecraft might be an adult mod for Minecraft…give this game a pass.

Главный герой сменился, снова, теперь мы играем за Дегтярева. Сюжет игры происходит после событий Тени Чернобыля. Дегтярева отправили на Зону, чтобы узнать причины крушения вертолетов, которые пролетали над Зоной. Позже выяснится, что случилось все это из за выброса, аномалии сменили свои места, это было не учтено, поэтому и произошло крушение. В игре есть всего 3 локации. Затон, Окрестности "Юпитера" и Припять. Ввиду того, что выживших нет, Дегтяреву надо было выбираться, вот только сделать это не так просто. Выбраться можно из точек эвакуации, а единственная активная находится в Припяти. Все было бы хорошо, вот только тоннель, ведущий туда замурован и заполнен газом. Дегтярев собирает себе отряд и с ним перебирается в Припять. Со временем, он, со своими сослуживцами, которых он встретил в Припяти, улавливают сигнал, находится он под землей и движется на нашу базу. Оказывается, это Стрелок. Он выбрался и пришел сюда. Стрелок готов поделится информацией, которая способна помочь уничтожить Зону. Поначалу начальство не собиралось отправлять эвакуационный вертолет за Дегтяревым и остальными, но когда узнало о Стрелке, то сразу же направило вертолет. Дегтярев и остальные выбрались из Зоны, а знания Стрелка помогают в изучении Зоны. Вообще в игре очень много разных концовок. Каждая концовка складывается из варианта прохождения различных квестов. Чем больше квестов выполнишь, тем лучше будет концовка. К примеру, я выполнил все квесты и получил наилучшую концовку. Первые два плюса - это сюжет и концовки. Третий плюс - это возможность модернизации оружия. По сравнению с Чистым Небом, она стала лучше. Пожалуй единственным минусом будут баги. Их тут не прям много, но они все же есть. Сейчас я расскажу о самых ярких багах, которые у меня были в процессе прохождения. Первый - это баг, при котором все вольные сталкеры становились противниками, даже сюжетные персонажи, хотя я всегда сталкерам помогал, не стрелял по ним, просто они взяли и стали противниками. С этим багом было бы невозможно пройти игру. Но как все началось с бага, так им и закончилось, после того как я перезашел в игру, со временем, все прошло. Второй баг, это баг, при котором НПС невосприимчивы к мутантам. К примеру, на станции Янов, вокруг двора бегало две стаи собак, ни Свободовцы, ни Долговцы не стреляли по мутантам, а просто стояли рядом. Или же уже в Припяти, собаки напали на Вано и еще одного напарника, не помню как его зовут (военный),  а они стоят и не атакуют врага, в то время как те во всю бьют и меня и их.

reviews.title: nikonoim's review of S.T.A.L.K.E.R.: Call of Pripyat

reviewText.content:
STALKER: Call of Pripyat is the third and final instalment in the STALKER trilogy. It is definitively the best one. It has the best gameplay, the best graphics and doesn’t reuse the map like Clear Sky. Technically it is a sequel that takes place after Shadow of Chernobyl, but there isn’t much tying both games together, so Call of Pripyat can stand on its own. Overall, if you want to play just one STALKER game, play this one. 

Story 
The setting is pretty much the same as before, the only exception being that it takes place in a different part of the zone.
You play as an army officer sent to the zone to investigate disturbances that have been taking down helicopters that try to make it to the centre. Story has never been a strong point in the series, including this one. It’s enough to provide an objective while playing, and it is engaging, but not much more. 
Side quests are much better here. There is plenty of variety, it isn’t just go here, shoot someone, take something.

Mechanics and gameplay
Gameplay is at its best here. The only part that’s missing is the faction warfare, but I was never interested in it, so I didn’t mind.
The biggest improvement is to the artefact hunting. The mechanics from Clear Sky have been kept and in addition the locations of the anomalies have been enhanced. Now rather than them being just in a random place, it is, for instance, a fire anomaly in an eternally burning village.
All other aspect is either similar or better. However, the total playtime you will get out of CoP is less than the previous. 

Graphics and artstyle
Graphics are also at their peak. It’s still outdated, especially compared to today, but it isn’t ugly.

Atmosphere/Immersion 
Immersion is also just as good, at times even better. 

Music
As I have said before, the soundtrack is practically shared or at the very least similar among the trilogy. It’s mostly dark ambience. My favourite part is “Live to Forget”.

Final thoughts
“We thank you, oh Monolith, may your light shine down on the souls of the brave soldiers who gave their lives in service of your will.” It is now my daily prayer.

this game is a worthy successor to two point hospital reminiscent of the park building game theme park world from the ps1/ps2 I have a lot of fun with the game, it's really fun to set up your own university

Creativity, story, graphical detail and art design are tremdously awesome. The gameplay is no more than moving plus one button, but as everything unfolds within 3 hours, it doesn't get dull. 

A-must-Play.
The less said about this game the better. Visually stunning adventure that will remain with you for some time. Play with lights off, sound on, and just enjoy what unfolds. Beautiful.

reviews.title: justanothertwitchuser12's review of What Remains of Edith Finch

reviewText.content: Short visually beautiful game. Feels like a playable visual novel with a decent story

reviews.title: alalearl's review of What Remains of Edith Finch

reviewText.content:
Great story, beautiful visual and sound,
controlling is just find
like how the way to interact things but sometime it's very difficult to move around when you play with mouse (keyboard can help but very slow to move things)
too sad that it is very short game but it's still great.

Un gameplay très basique pour une histoire très touchante.
Le personnage retrace l'histoire de sa famille en se baladant dans l'ancienne maison familiale ; donc pas de PNJ et axé walking simulator, avec une durée assez courte sans replay value.
Tout l'intérêt du jeu est donc dans l'histoire, joliment racontée.
Pas le jeu du siècle mais un moment touchant, idéal pour faire une pause de qq heures entre de gros jeux AAA.

(Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass)

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of What Remains of Edith Finch

reviewText.content:
What Remains of Edith Finch was launched  in 2017 for PC, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One platforms. 

It is a first-person adventure game with narrative elements. Giant Sparrow was the studio developer; they also developed The Unfinished Swan. The director of the game is Ian Dallas, who previously directed The Unfinished Swan. The script was written by Ian Dallas and a team of writers. The game has an original soundtrack composed by Jeff Russo. 

It was developed using the Unreal Engine. The graphics used are highly detailed and visually stunning, and the sound design is impressive, immersing you in a mysterious and dark atmosphere. 

In conclusion, What Remains of Edith Finch is a captivating video game with a unique approach to storytelling and immersive gameplay. Its plot, the evolution of the characters and its bold narrative captivated me as few games have managed to do, and they left a mark that I will never forget. 

And for that, as well as the incredible art direction and sound editing, What Remains of Edith Finch deserves masterpiece status.

reviews.title: draw_to_life's review of Baldo: The Guardian Owls

reviewText.content:
Amazing game with an amazing atmosphere. I recommend you don't play the game on touchscreen!

I completed the game with 42 hours clocked in with assisted mode off from the beginning to the end. Burnt out couple of times during the playtrought and had to take weeks off due to getting stuck.

Parts i got stuck on for hours.

-Figuring out getting the Owl bomb

-Bobo temple entrance puzzle

-Sacred Owl Temple music drum room

Played on iphone 13 pro max.

The game has its moments,

Tough its a good game for short bursts of enjoyment, especially with a few friends and a few beers.
The game certainly isn't for everyone though, and as such, it can't be recommended for some one that isn't into this sort of games, but hey, that kind of goes for everyone...

The game has its way of pulling you in, and keeping you playing, trying to beat your friends and becoming better at the game, although its a shame that the cheating is running rampet, the game is a lot of fun to play regardless of the leaderboards, and the added twitch functionality could be used on the couch when playing the game.

Games banning system is pretty bad. You cant say anything pretty much offensive whatsoever, and the hypocritical thing about them is they've said the game isnt a children's game, and yet they come out with thirst trap skins quite frequently and you cannot mention anything sexually explicit. Which makes ironically no sense at all, not a childrens, makes thirst traps skins for people to buy skins more and yet nothing sexual explicit can be said. I agree with most of the banning system but as of lately they've changed too much and have become far far too sensitive and hypocritical with a lot of things. And in MOBA gaming communities bad mouthing is what makes it more enjoyable for most people. You take that away and your player base will fall and plummet i promise you that. Even in league they have a better way of doing things where if you continue to do so in game you're muted and no one can communicate with you at all, you cant talk and they cant talk to you or hear what you say. If anything implement that.

reviews.title: Good game but they can improve it

reviewText.content:
It just has one detail that I'm not really liking: developers are increasingly adding more emotes, that is, powers that are purchased to obviously have an advantage over users who don't use them. Some are good because they add dynamism to the games, but others cause you to be eliminated immediately and it is frustrating because it unbalances the gaming experience. When playing with friends you can remove the emotes but the rewards are zero, the idea is that there is an option to pair you with those who do not use it in any game mode that is chosen.

Many skins are beautiful, they give an extra layer of customization and originality to our characters, plus, with the new update in which they added "competitive mode with ranks" it makes us stay a few more minutes playing. Only after a while the same music begins to get tiring, the system chooses the same maps (with variety) and the sad Pay-to-win which is a clear example of how to damage a beautiful video game.

I play SRPGs, but this is my first Brigandine game. So far, I've finished the Norzaleo route on easy in 13hrs. May come back to play the other routes when I have more time/ interest. [4 Nov 20] I'm looking around on the net, but it seems this doesn't have that big of a fandom. HOT TAKE: this would be more popular if it implemented the social aspect that made Fire Emblem and Persona go boom, but that's just my personal opinion.

reviews.title: Maxim_Nazarenko's review of Hidden Through Time

reviewText.content:
It's interesting "little" cozy game, where you need to find different objects.

A very beautiful cartoon adventure accompanied by pleasant music - so if you need to chill, relax or just pass some time, this game is for you.

It also can improve you mindfulness skills, because you will need to concentrate a bit, in order to find more stuff on the map.

There are DLCs, so you can play the game more and more, in different eras.

Was really excited for this after playing YS VIII, but I'd have to say that, overall, VIII is still better than this one. [Started playing on Aug. 11 and finished on Sept. 11 with 33hrs of playtime on Easy]

reviews.title: nkay08's review of Ys IX: Monstrum Nox

reviewText.content:
The game is the sequel to Ys VIII and it shows. The gameplay is basically identical apart from the addition of new movement abilities.
I don't rank Ys Games by their story or characters, but by their gameplay and I still think VIII is the better game. Exploration of the Island was way more fun than the barren samey looking town of Balduq.
I have some real issues with the combat system that is especially apparent if playing the game on "Hard" or above. The bosses seem to be designed around the mechanics of "Flash move" and the more powerful "Flash guard", which both render you invulnerable for a short time. "Flash move" additionally slows the time down, whereas "Flash guard" fills your EXTRA meter and makes every attack from you critical. These are triggered by pressing the dodge or skill button respectively just when an attack is about to hit you. These moves can mostly be triggered for each of the enemies attacks and you can even use them while you are attacking yourself. On multi hit attacks you can even trigger them repeatedly and thus extend the duration significantly. These tools are so powerful that they are the best choice in every situation. They are they best offense and defense simultaneously, provided you can time them correctly.
The game revolves around flash guard and the spamming your skills. You don't have to learn and react to the attack patterns of the bosses, you just have to use flash guard.

It has the vibe of a many top down perspective shooters but in FPS view. I really licked the speed of the  game and although the levels  were kind of confided space,  the ability to open holes in the walls made sure each walkthrough/attempt is quite different, Would highly recommend to any FPS player to try it out.

Beat'em all avec un très joli pixel art, gestion des collisions OK, jusque là c'est assez classique.
Le jeu a la bonne idée d'ajouter un côté RPG avec un petit level up des persos et de l'argent pour acheter différents bonus (objets, améliorations, etc.)
Joué en solo le jeu devient tout de même vite difficile (perso je bloquais sur la boss 'tisseuse styliste'), je ne sais pas ce qu'il donne en coop, possible à deux ; le problème étant que si on a un perso niveau 20, si une personne veut nous rejoindre en cours de route l'autre perso est niveau 1, pas glop.
Pour un jeu de qualité, sans pixel art mais plus accessible, préférer Street of rage, qui n'a malheureusement pas le second degré bien déjanté de River City Girls !
Dommage pour les personnes non maitres jedi du beat'em all qu'il n'y ait pas une difficulté 'facile', à réserver aux joueurs voulant du challenge.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

Well, it sure is the end of the Cold Steel sub-series.  Honestly, you already know if you're going to play this game or not.  If you've played the previous Legend of Heroes games -- or at least the previous three Cold Steel games -- of course you're going to play this to see how it ends.  If you haven't played those, please go back and do so before you even look at this game.

CS4 has some of the highest high points of the entire series.  It finishes several major plot threads that have been building up since Trails in the Sky the 3rd and it puts a cap on multiple character arcs, and the ending made me tear up a bit.

It *also* has some of the lowest lows in the entire series.  The script is incredibly bloated; big scenes are filled with dozens of named characters who are there for no reason other than to include as many characters as possible at the end of the arc, and everybody always has to say something but most of them contribute nothing.  There are several scenes that drone on for >30 minutes that would have taken 5 if the writers just trimmed the fat.  The game's entire second arc is basically just filler that didn't need to happen.  CS4 is 40 hours of plot in a 120 hour game.

It also dials up the worst tropes from the previous games to the max.  We've got multiple characters whose entire personality is "sexual assault is funny when a woman does it", multiple hot springs scenes where the girls all talk about each others' chest sizes, plenty of characters being saved at the last minute by overpowered NPCs suddenly arriving at the scene, and romantic scenes between the main character, his little sister, and his barely-pubescent student.

If it sounds like I'm being harsh on the game... well, I kinda am.  There is some good content in here, and it's worth playing if you've played through the series up to this point, but there's also a lot of bad content you have to push through, and I hope the next Legend of Heroes series isn't like this.

In a whole lot of aspects, Danganronpa 2 is a clone of the first installment. However, that is largely a good thing. The gameplay, story, characters were all amazing in Trigger Happy Havoc, and that continues here. There are some issues with this game (such as a slow start - again, some elements of trials not making a whole lot of sense, or the overuse of *two certain words*), but I am happily willing to overlook those. Danganronpa 2 is just so much fun.

The game is pretty average nothing really to write home about however that's its biggest problem every floor is the same go to big room, follow linear path, fight boss with horrible mechanic rinse and repeat.

It's not a bad game but i gave up half way through as it just couldn't hold my attention and i did not want to fight another boss.

Luigi's Mansion 3 is a thoroughly enjoyable exploration game. The mechanics overall are pretty well-refined and there's a ton of content contained within.

A lot of what is great about this game comes down to the core mechanic: suck stuff up. It's incredibly satisfying to just clear out a room by sucking up everything in it, grabbing lots of coins along the way. The sounds that accompany this process are great, but the HD Rumble really sets it appart.

The game has a ton of personality and charm, from the animations of Luigi and friends to the designs of the levels and ghosts. There's plenty of creativity throughout the 17 floors of the hotel, with each boss feeling fairly unique and most floors having a cool theme.

After a while though, the gameplay does get quite repetitive. Going from floor to floor and fighting ghosts gets stale after a while, especially considering the length of this game. I still got a lot of enjoyment out of it, but I wish there was a bit more variety. The variety that it does provide lies in the additional mechanics, but these mechanics feel a lot more clunky than the vacuum pack. There were also some level-specific mechanics that weren't really explained/led up to. It was just as though the game expected you to know what to do at all times without giving any visual indications. I imagine some of them would be quite difficult for children to figure out.

The music is really well done, as well as all of the sounds. Visually, the game looks good, aside from the occassional graphical or physics glitch that can occur.

This game looks beautiful, the style is awesome and the animation technique (I'm guessing is at least similar to old hand drawn animation) works so well. They nailed the norse mythology theme. 
The gameplay is brilliant with each are and boss having very different individual mechanics. The game has both quite relaxing puzzle sections and intense battles. I died to each boss at least once and had to walk away from the game because of frustration a couple of times, but its so worth the effort the pay off when you beat it is so worth the effort. And theres some good achievements and other game modes for good replay value.
This game is a lot of fun! With a very standard premise, but with many twist. Also 100 different endings!

Fait à sa sortie et refait en 2014, le moteur 3D tient encore étonnamment bien la route, notamment pour l'incrustation des objets "interactifs" dans les décors.
L'histoire reste intéressante, les mécanismes de gameplay sont classiques, et mis à part les déplacements parfois un peu longs, le jeu a gardé tout son charme, le game design et l'ambiance en générale restant très agréables.
Les énigmes sont la plupart du temps faciles, à part quelque unes qui demanderont un peu plus de réflexion et de temps (rien d'insurmontable).

reviews.title: gatorbox's review of What the Dub?!

reviewText.content: I'm a late comer to this game but I guess I wound up arriving just in time since there was recently a major update pushed out for this game that in my opinion gives it an even higher score. What The Dub is a party game where players watch a video clip (public domain movies, PSA's, work training videos, etc) where a line of dialog has been edited out. The object is to come up with the funniest line of dialog or "dub" to fill in the blank. Players and the audience then vote on their favorite and points are scored accordingly. The game has a tendency to inspire raunchy humor so be sure you're in good company if you choose to bring this one out. The base game comes with several dozen clips however just recently What The Dub was given Steam Workshop access and now you can download clip packs for all sorts of things. This greatly extends the replay value of the game because you're less likely to get repeats that everyone has seen before if you download additional clip packs. Whether you're playing What The Dub locally with a group of friends or streaming it online you're sure to get a lot of laughs and enjoyment out of this game.

16. Project Warlock
(I didn’t finish this game)
Project Warlock is a classic FPS similar to Wolfenstein 3D. This means that there is no need to look up or down, as everything will be on one axis. All verticality is purely visual. Although it has some amazing pixel art and satisfying weapons, the lack of differentiation between level design, and its length hold it back. I would recommend it if you simply want to mindlessly shoot at monsters.
Story
You have to kill multiple evils so that you can fight and kill the great evil. This is not a game to play for the story.
Gameplay
Just like in older games like Wolfenstein 3D, only the x-axis matters. It allows you to look up and down, but it serves no practical function. This also extends to the level design – you are never above or below enemies, and you never move up or down. Another similarity between Project Warlock and its predecessors is its overreliance on key hunts, which in this game is almost every level. All of this leads to the levels blending in together and becoming forgettable. The weapons are at least an upgrade. There is a wide variety of them and each one can be upgraded to one of two better versions. Don’t expect much interaction between them, and also the only reason you have for using weaker guns is if run out of ammo. There is also magic that you can use to deal extra damage and a level up system in which you can invest points to increase your stats. Enemies have plenty of variety in them, but again no y-axis. Bosses are mostly just bullet sponges.
Graphics and artstyle
Project Warlock has amazing pixel art. Everything from the walls to the guns and foes is beautifully illustrated. There is also great particle effect and lighting.
Atmosphere
Whatever atmosphere that it tries to build is crushed by its simplicity.
Soundtrack
This game has a 5 HOUR soundtrack. It’s alright.
Final Thoughts
Could be better.

Project Warlock wants to show you classic FPS experience - it was inspired by many old titles like Heretic, Wolfenstein, Doom and other.

You playing as a sorcerer, who is on a mission to destroy demonic hordes in four different periods of Earth's history, before going in fiery Hell.

There is a great mix of enemies, your protagonist is armed with array of weapons. You will start with Axe and Dagger, later you will find Pistol, Shotgun, Dynamite, Crossbow, SMG, Warlock Staff, Minigun and other.

As you play, you will get upgrade points, which you can use with your weapons.
You can turn your .50 Magnum into flare gun, which sets fire to the enemies, Warlock Staff can be enhanced with ice.

You Warlock also has great magic potential - Storm Rage, Freezing Blast, Holy Guard etc.

Big minus for me - music. It's just feel off.
It's doesn't give you that adrenaline and dopamine rush, which you can find in games like Prodeus, Doom and other fast-paced shooter games.

This game is a good throwback to old FPS games - many weapons, abilities, a little bit of puzzles with a variety of enviroment and monster's choice.

If you liked the first, you'll like the second. Same vibe and core engagement while addressing the issues with the original, without directly retreading any ground. This one had more of a gut-punch for me too, because it revealed its story in a more interesting order.

reviews.title: bugondesk's review of Another Lost Phone: Laura's Story

reviewText.content: The phone UI and the photos had a consistent art style, which helps the players to feel immersive. The puzzles are logical and stay in a comfortable level of difficulty.

I played this when i was around 5-6 years old... (when it came out actually) the game left an insane impression on me and i always remembered it because of it's amazing way to tell a story in such a cinematic way (something pretty much non existent for games of that era). I bought the 15 year anniversary several years ago, and after that i got the 20 year anniversary in steam (would recommend this later version as it has some pretty good features and the game works great). 

Keep in mind that my rating 9/10 is not comparing it to current standards, but the standards of the time it came out, and at that moment there was pretty much nothing like this game.

I cannot deny how impactful for games in general this game was, and still is, but as someone who just decided to play it at random, this game is clunky and painful and honestly, aggravating. There's a lot of things to dislike, and the enemy spawn locations/ratio feel very random and odd, such that you can and will constantly die changing screens. The game is beautiful for its time, and still holds up somewhat, but this wasn't a fun nor an engaging experience as a game. Don't recommend it.

Un jeu d'aventure excellent, pour public averti, contrairement à ce que les graphismes mignons peuvent laisser penser :)
L'interface et les animations kawaii sont plus agréables que ce que les screenshots laissent présager.
Seuls défauts, sa durée de vie et sa facilité, mais vu le prix, les clins d'oeils/références et les dialogues bien marrants, ce jeu vaut vraiment le coup :)

In a similar vein as Dave the Diver, which got immensely popular, a relaxing indie exploration game with a side game where you take your catch and turn them into profit.

The side game is not as fleshed out as Dave the Diver. You can catch fish at any time of day but you need regular sleep, when you return home you can create dishes with the fish you caught and recipes you have. There are lots of mini-games for cutting, boiling, frying etc. but then you just put them in a vending machine and they sell over time. 

The exploration is fun, you can take your boat and explore the area, do some fishing and complete some quests before beating the boss of the area and unlocking a new one. The game is great to chill out and spend some time in.

The Omno feels like if Pokemon had a baby with Journey, that overgrown their parents.

To be honest, it's the best game of 2021. I haven't seen this properly tested game in eons. It's a puzzle adventure game where no quiz was left without a handy little touch of a hint here and there. Who wouldn't love floating green Pikachu? Even light is helping you on your travels. Those are small details that are making the whole game-level design and puzzle design exquisite.

The simplistic voxel-like graphic is astonishing. I was losing my breath while visiting different worlds. A smooth grainy lighting system with a very well-crafted atmosphere and fog make this game so sweet you'll want to lick it. Add to that a contrasting light, a fairy light that doesn't lead you astray. 

I like how the developer plays with the light of the sun rays, which are very accurately placed in multiple places, so you can't miss them. And they look just beautiful.

The minimalist tones of the music give the game a dreamy atmosphere, although if you stay in one area observing the world around you for too long, it becomes slightly repetitive.

The game mechanics are very fresh. Skills make sense and add an interesting depth to the whole game as you grow more skillful. And the map is something you haven't seen yet. I am one of those weird completionist players, so the percentage counter made my life way easier. Other games usually let you sit in the dark.

The only problem I had with the game is that it was developed with a game controller, and the keyboard controls aren't quite right, especially for the "long jumps" this was a bummer.

An interesting game , with a fun art style and world. The game is a roguelike with randomized levels, various power-ups, and final bosses on each stage. The combat can be enjoyable at times, with a variety of weapons and power-ups to choose from; anything in the environment can be weaponized, and there are some interesting pick-ups (cars, giant pencils, etc.) and power-ups. The combat on the whole is third person, and can be janky at times. I found myself taking damage for random things that were outside of my control, and found the tells on enemies and bosses to be present, but uninformative at times. I would say the combat can be fun, but was a negative overall. 

The world itself is uniquely animated and presents an interesting corporate dystopia of start-ups in a megacity, with canned progressivity and bland corporate dystopia - very appealing to this gamer, and a definite plus for the game. The characters in the game are interesting, and feel at times like a little family, with some great dialogue prompts and humour throughout. 

The level design was passable at times, but I felt it was somewhat weak. The randomized levels never feel that random - the same rooms will be present constantly, and are easy to master. Even the progression between levels feels rather similar. New zones will have new weapons with different skin, but for the most part perform in the same way. New enemies may offer slightly different challenges, but again, not enough to feel unique, or really grab my attention.

Going Under was certainly a net positive experience. It offers good third-person roguelike action, which is somewhat original in the genre. The art style was a definite plus for me, as were the progression systems, the powerups, and the characters and humour of the game. Some downsides are the combat and the actual level progression, which often felt vapid and less than unique. All told, worth a play for fans of roguelikes, and those looking for a lighter experience.
Best farming game there is. All the romacable characters are great. Does a good job regularrly adding new content to do. The normal farming is great as well though. Maru beat girl

I absolutely see the appeal of this game to a lot of people, but it's just not for me. The clock each day feels like work, and I can't get over that, no matter how hard I try. The number of activities is certainly a plus, but when you are limited by a game mechanic to stop you from doing anything for an extended period of time, I can't find joy in it. Stardew Valley is a great game for what it is, but not for me.

Stardew Valley is in the overgeneralizing genre of “relaxing games”. For a lot of people, this is the go to when they think of a relaxing gaming experience, and for good reason. It executes that part flawlessly. There is no rush, no overarching narrative pushing you towards a certain direction, you just take care of the farm and interact with the outside world as you see fit. Personally, I enjoyed my time with the game, although I was never taken hold by it as others have. If you just want a relaxing experience, there is hardly a better game for you.
 
Story
Your grandfather has recently passed away and left you his farm in Stardew Valley. As the sensible person you are, you decide to resign from your job and go live there together with its roughly 20+ permanent residents. 
There is no overarching plot. The citizens of Stardew Valley go about their lives, you interfere, whenever you decide. Romance is an option, even marriage, however that's not the case for every NPC.
There is also kind of a villain with the Joja Corporation, which is apparently so desperate for new customers that it decided to build an entire supermarket in this tiny community. They disappear if you progress the game enough while also ignoring them.

Mechanics and gameplay
Stardew Valley has a variety of things to do, the most obvious being taking care of the farm. Planting, watering and watching them grow is what that consists of. However, as the farm grows the player requires better tools, sprinklers and more to keep up. This can be achieved with money earned from selling crops and going into the mine for materials. 
What I described above is what most players will experience at some point while playing Stardew Valley. There is a lot I've left out - fishing, foraging, farm animals and so on. It will be a while before you take part in everything this game has to offer.

Graphics and artstyle
The artstyle of Stardew Valley is simplistic 2D pixel art. Describing it as simplistic is however deceiving, there is a lot of care and attention put into everything to make it fit with the rest of the game.

Atmosphere/Immersion  
Stardew Valley reminds me of reading a book in which I know no character will die, no major drama will happen, but I just can't stop reading, because all of those small moments, those insignificant interactions are so well written.

Soundtrack
The ost is similar to the rest of the game - calming, cozy. I have no idea how this genre is named, but it's the type of music I would put in a “Relaxing music to listen to while studying/sleeping” playlist. My favourite part is “Winter (The Wind Can Be Still)”.

Final Thoughts
I looked all throughout the map and didn't find a single eight lane highway. My initial belief that this is set in the USA is shaking.
Best farming game there is. All the romacable characters are great. Does a good job regularrly adding new content to do. The normal farming is great as well though. Maru beat girl

reviews.title: Stardew Valley: one of my favorite games of all time!

reviewText.content:
Stardew Valley is an enjoyable and lovely RPG game that I have enjoyed very much for many, many years now; ever since 2016. 
Although there are many farming games on Steam, I have never found a farming/agricultural game that has had nearly as much diversity as Stardew Valley, and Stardew Valley is definitely the most fun one, in my opinion!

A great game, with beautiful drawn style and a solid semi-plot, although I can't help but feel it's way too short and way too linear in what it attempts to do. While the plot makes sense in retrospective, and the explore mode helps make sense of it even more, it does feel very surface-level in the exploration of themes presented, in part due to, again, how short it is.

Overall, a good game, but the format in which it is presented plays against it imo.
Really nice and cute. Terraform the continents so nature can come back.

I have found this reverse citybuilder to be a very simple, relaxing, meditative experience. As someone who likes to mix my activities, I've really enjoyed playing this while watching a show or movie. My only criticism is that there should either be more content or a lower price. As is, I do recommend it but wait for a sale.

reviews.title: Un Magnifico Indie Que Merece Mas Atencion EverHood

reviewText.content:
##Gameplay: ufff tiene tantos detalles que me dividire en partes para poder cubrir varios de los aspectos que hacen bueno a este gameplay.

1 La forma de recorrer el mundo: es un juego semilinial, en un punto llegamos a una sala donde hay varias puertas que conducen a varias zonas y podremos decidir por cual ir primero, claro algunas estaran bloqueadas o necesitaremos pasar por una zona antes para desbloquear una cosa en cierta zona, esto hace que nos sintamos con mas libertad e interés ya que el inicio de la historia es algo ambiguo y pesado pero cuando somos soltados aqui se nos da rienda a nuestro sentido de aventura e interes por el mundo e iremos a las zonas que mas nos interesen haciendo que cada uno lo juegue de una manera un poco distinta haciendo que te involucres mas con cada suceso 

2 Los Combates: varios juegos indies rpg que se interesan por contar una buena historia se olvidan de hacer el gameplay divertido, a veces dejando combates por turnos que son simplemente aburridos porque no aportan nada a la historia y no son divertidos de jugar, y este juego no es asi, los combates son un muy buenos incluso si no entiendes nada de la historia solo por estos combates vale la pena jugarlo, viendo netamente el gameplay son como un juego de ritmo deberemos seguir el ritmo de la música o guiarte por tus reflejos para esquivar sucesiones de ataques desde ondas de luz pequeñas que puedes saltar hasta barreras, es simple pero cada combate es diferente porque no hay combates contra enemigos genéricos todos los combates son contra personajes del juego por lo que todos tienen una música distinta y ataques distintos, algunos hacen cosas especiales y todos tienen su estilo distinto y al final tiene sentido porque esa música y estilo en que los ataques vienen hacia ti son parte de la personalidad y esencia del personaje contra el que estas luchando lo que hace que cada personaje se sienta único, y no es solo esquivar, en zonas usaremos una espada para reflejar ciertos ataques de un color, algunos enemigos distorsionaran la pantalla, y se da un giro interesante a los combates haciendo que sean parte esencial del gameplay y nos cuenten mucho, un aspecto negativo es que al principio nos saturan mucho con estos y llega a cansar porque no entiendes que pasa pero una vez pasado ese inicio ya este problema no esta y aun asa los combates del principio son interesantes.

3 La Simpleza, Accesibilidad, Variedad: El juego trae muchos modos de dificultad para que encuentres el que se adapte a ti, esta el modo de dificultad llamado story que hace que seas muy difícil de matar si solo te interesa seguir por la historia, y aun así en el modo normal todo es sencillo, no super fácil a veces querrás cambiar de dificultad pero los controles y todos son muy simples y sencillos de dominar, moverte de izquierda y derecha y saltar, solo necesitas reflejos para los combates y curiosidad para explorar, y no solo eso si no que incluye variedad, podrás ir a unas carreras, esquivar trampas mortales en un lugar, ciertos puzles o acertijos de ir intercambiando cosas, aunque al inicio son puros combates seguidos después nos da variedad e cosas por hacer sin volverse algo complejo es simple entendible y accesible lo que hace que cualquiera pueda jugarlo y disfrutarlo 

##Diseño e Historia: La manera en la que el juego esta diseñado es magnifica, el único punto débil es el comienzo como ya dije, pero después es una maravilla como implementan un mundo tan único raro e interesante y a la vez nos cuentan una historia con un buen mensaje de fondo, aunque no se profundice tanto en la historia atravez de las mecánicas como lo hizo undertale, este juego nos logra contar una gran historia de una forma memorable, con interacciones puntuales bien puestas, le da una personalidad única a todos sus personajes y un diseño muy diferente a cada uno no hay ninguno que se parezca todos son únicos, y no es que sean complejos, tienen personalidades simples, unos son sarcásticos, otros discretos, unos muy graciosos, cada uno esta bien caracterizado y hace que empatices bien con ellos, sus batallas nos cuentan como son puedes asociar una canción con ellos, te hacen interactuar de forma orgánica, no se quedaran en su zona y no se moverán de ahí, puedes encontrarte a algunos en distintas zonas lo que hace que se sienta mas vivo el mundo y sientas que sus personajes realmente son integrantes de everhood que se mueven por el mundo para visitar a sus amigos a jugar un juego de rol, ir al cine o a las carreras. El mapa es muy único con sus zonas diferenciadas a las que accedes a través de puertas las cuales también tienen personalidad y te hablan, el punto de guardado siempre te saluda o te dice algo, cada zona con su iluminación colores estilo y cosas hace que se sienta muy unico recorrer everhood. En cuanto a la historia tiene giros interesantes, te hace empatizar con los personajes de formas sutiles que ya mencione, y hace que puedas llegar a sentirte culpable o aliviado, aunque su mensaje queda un poco al aire por el new game plus pero aun así no es algo que estorbe mas bien añade al gameplay y logra contar todo de una manera muy buena, el new game plus solo esta para que veas unas cuantas cosas mas pero  no es algo que cambie la narrativa es solo añadir mas horas de gameplay para los que quieran exprimir aun mas este mundo porque sintieron que se dejaron unos detalles atrás y cierra las cosas de una buena forma haciendo que al final no sea contradictorio con su mensaje pero al principio lo puede parecer 


##Apartado Grafico: un 10, de los mejores gráficos que he visto, y no hablo de realismo ni nada, si no que todo esta muy bien hecho, efectos alucinantes en los combates, unos gráficos tan sutiles que da la impresión a veces de recorrer un entorno 3D y porque no entornos y cosas 3D mezcladas con sprites 2D los cuales no desentonan, es un apartado grafico maravilloso con un diseño de personajes muy memorables cada uno con sus colores y estilo y con unos efectos tan alucinantes que hacen que los combates sean memorables, no deja nada que desear no hay nada que se sienta feo o que desentone y es una gran propuesta ya que no se limita a un pixel art con iluminación simple si no que mete efectos y mezcla distintos estilos haciendo que quede maravilloso

##Soundtrack: espectacular y variado, lo mismo que con los combates y los graficos, le da personalidad a sus personajes y al mundo, tendremos canciones calmadas, chiptune, canciones de metal, mezclas de ambient con otras cosas, una canción diferente para cada combate zona y aunque algunas canciones suenen raras por fuera cuando la vez en el juego se sincronizan perfectamente con los ataques o se acoplan de forma perfecta a la zona nada mas que decir

Everhood was a unique experience for many, myself included. It's an unusual rhythm game with excellent music, gameplay, and story. During some fights, many visuals will begin to change, such as bright background changes and the screen rotating around; this creates the trippy feeling that the game is known for. The music makes the gameplay even more enjoyable, with the enemy's notes lining up with the timing of the song playing. The story isn't very memorable, but it's solid and intriguing. At some points in the story, I was caught off guard and surprised at how the events unfolded. As you explore the world of Everhood, you will meet a large cast of quirky characters who contribute to making this experience an odd but wonderful one. Overall, Everhood is a game that is incredibly different from any other recent game, and its gameplay and weirdness are the reasons why it's so original and worth playing.

Developed by the legendary Yuji Naka, Balan Wonderworld is packed to the gills with hidden features, like a special diffculty if you're playing too well, and bonus trophies for defeating bosses with an unexpected costume.

But who cares?!

If Yuji Naka is legendary, then I'm fucking Bigfoot, because some of these oversights are basic and inexcusable. Let's get the obvious out of the way: the issue of jumping is but one problem, and they clearly assumed enough people would play multiplayer to have one poor soul be a dedicated jump-slave. The real issue is the level design and practicality of the disgustingly situational costumes.

Why have a dragon costume that can't even shoot fireballs very far, followed by a robot costume that shoots lasers a huge distance like 1 chapter later? These are some of the easiest design issues to reason out during the brainstorming phase of your game, but they must have been braindead during that time. All of this was deliberate: Yuji Naka wasn't drunk when he did this, no sir.

He proudly walked in with a checklist and it said "3,700 costumes, but one button does everything, and get all that Sonic nostalgia out of your head, because we're only moving at the speed of a real hedgehog now." Clearly, we just can't understand his master plan.

Balan Wonderworld is a game that has received an unfair, if not cruelly excessive, amount of hyperbole for simply not conforming to what people wanted Balan to be: a sequel or spiritual successor to NiGHTs.

When you allow Balan Wonderworld to be Balan Wonderworld and stand on its own merits without comparing it against NiGHTs (because it's not), you have an extremely beautiful, surreal, heart warming, relaxing and simplistic 3d platformer that children and adults of all ages can enjoy. The simple, one button controls (technically two if you can the button used to cycle through the costumes you're carrying), allow for anyone to pick up and play the game with ease. Because of this unique control scheme, Balan Wonderworld is quite possibly the only 3d platformer that I can play enjoyably on my phone with just touch controls and Steam Link.

Negative reviews love to whine about the costume system, but what they don't tell you is that the majority of the costumes offer passive abilities in order to not interfere with the player's movement, such as auto-firing projectiles, enhancing mobility with ground pounds, hovering, wall climbing, multi-jumps, flight; or even stopping time! The few costumes that do replace the player's ability to jump with something else is easily addressed by the fact that the player can cycle through the three most recent costumes they acquired, with the oldest being sent safely to the player's dressing room storage (accessible from any checkpoint) upon acquiring a fourth.

Another common complaint the game gets is the fact that later costumes make earlier ones obsolete. While this is true, it is by far nowhere near a game breaking experience. In fact, there's nothing wrong with this because that's how progression works in some games. Of course the late game stuff is going to be better than the early game stuff! It is completely asinine to expect otherwise. That's like calling Super Mario Bros. 3 a bad game because the Tanooki Suit makes the Super Leaf obsolete, or the Hammer Bros. Suit making Fire Flowers obsolete. Or Curaga in Final Fantasy making Cure and Cura obsolete. Or Ultima making practically all offensive magic in Final Fantasy obsolete. The list goes on.

With the elephant in the room addressed, the other thing that makes Balan Wonderworld a wonderful experience is the sheer amount of content you get. The game is LOADED with secrets and extras, and the game rewards exploration in a way more satisfying than the majority of games I've ever played. There's areas I thought would be out of bounds and instead I was rewarded with anything from gems, a Tim egg, a hidden costume, or even a Balan Statue. It never ceased to amaze me how many areas I thought were "cheese" or "out of bounds" only to find out that the stage designers left something waiting for me there as a pat on the back and a "I see what you did there." Collect all the Balan Statues hidden in a Chapter and you're treated to the English lyrics of the song and dance routine that plays after beating that Chapter's boss.

Another neat thing about Balan Wonderworld is the difficulty adjusts itself automatically based on your playstyle. If you like fighting enemies and are exceptionally good at not taking damage, the game will start giving you more and harder enemies. If you tend to avoid combat or take damage too often, the game will reduce the amount of enemies that spawn and replace them with weaker, easier enemies. The same applies to even bosses, who have a unique Hard Mode variant. My only complaint about this system is it's overly cautious about not making the game too hard, and will instantly dial back the difficulty from Hard to Normal upon making a single mistake, while scaling the difficulty back to Hard requires a considerable grind (requiring the player to defeat about 10+ whole waves of enemies without taking any damage or falling off the stage). Overall, at the game feels about as difficult as your average Kirby game, which is to say that difficulty is practically nonexistent outside of Hard Mode, and that's okay because if you came to Balan's Wonderworld for difficulty, you came to the wrong place. This game is about having fun exploring and experimenting.

Speaking of exploration, the game does a spectacular job hiding collectible both in and out of plain sight. In fact, some are so amazingly well hidden that the game thankfully provides a costume with x-ray vision in one of the late game chapters. It also rewards experimentation by awarding bonus statues for finding certain unique ways to damage bosses.

The only real complaint I have about Balan Wonderworld, is that when playing multiplayer, some costumes are exclusive to Player 1.

Overall, if you want to have a fun, relaxing, feel good time, visit Balan's Wonderworld. As someone who 100%'d the game and got every Achievement, trust me when I say you won't regret it.

Lamplight city is a very atmospheric, steampunk, detective game with plenty of dialog, a lot of different aerias to visit and people to talk, and the most important a lot of diverse characters! It's riddles are a bit easy, but the plot is interesting and it has a nice sense of humor that made me giggle quite often. The retro graphics, as always, were a huge plus.

A really good game but with some bad points such as strange situations when grabbing some objects that are really difficult to grab and may get you frustrated. 
Despite of that, it is not that much difficult if you want to play the main adventure and not trying to make a 100% which would take a lot of practice and retries. 

Playing with 2 or 4 persons is really enjoyable and the main point of the game, probably less funny if you try alone as you would not get the same object to move and so on not the same situations as if you are at least 2 persons.

Thank god for assisted mode. I don't really recommend playing this on a keyboard, as precise movements are a pre-requisite for playing this game. And it's still very hard. Team17 obviously wanted to ride the wave of the success of the Overcooked series, and this is honestly a nice try. However, ironically, the people who liked Overcooked and are looking for something similar, are going to enjoy this game less than "fresh" players. Moving Out is fine, but not as good. The addition of the assist mode is a welcome one, as I couldn't possibly enjoy this game without it. It is not long or short, and has plenty of potential.

All in all, a decent game, although puzzles could have been a bit easier. Fortunately, there is a hint system from several stages that helps in solving puzzles without much frustration. Of course, the one who wants to go through the game without help can turn off hints, but to pass the game without help is not at all easy. It takes a lot of search for hidden buttons and levers, as well as where to start, where to go.
   On the other hand, mysticism and atmosphere of Leonardo's time was greatly transmitted.
Some are not happy with the end of the game, but I really like it because it leaves room for the imagination, at least until the sequel, that has been announced, appears.

reviews.title: the_last_b's review of One Piece: Pirate Warriors 3

reviewText.content: Está bien, entretenido, ni más ni menos, es realmente divertido solo si ya conoces el material de origen.

reviews.title: plusleg1rl's review of One Piece: Pirate Warriors 3

reviewText.content: Best game of this series. If you read the manga or watch the anime until certain point, this game is for you.

Game is fantastic. Its super creative and you cant find a fighting game like it, its fast, exhilarating, and fun. Super easy to pick up and play with friends but has a crazy high skill ceiling that will challenge you a ton. The community for the game is great as well, everyone is super welcoming and devoted. You can learn a ton from their resources, and top players are active in the community discord so you can even play them pretty often. 

Highly recommend, please buy this game.

I discovered this game through recommendations of those who've played Hollow Knight-- at first I was unsure, but I quickly ended up spending over 30 hours in the game in total. (I'm at my third run in fact)
The level designs are unique, with beautiful graphics in a pixel-art style game, and the music just captures the atmospheres so well. It truly paints out a surprisingly large alien world, and with some very interesting secrets to discover.

A nice addition as well, is how the low-heath beeping goes in time with the music, and isn't just overwhelming like most other games often would be.

Another fun point is how quite a bit of lore is found through exploration, rather than everything being handed to you. It appeals greatly to my love for discovering things, and makes it that much more intriguing to me.

Highly recommend especially for those who've played Hollow Knight and are looking for something that'll give a similar feeling of exploration.

Gamma Minus as an indie development studio has dared to bring a breath of fresh air into the dusty noir board game genre and you can see and feel it! With Rough Justice we jump into the year 1984 and as an ex-con we have to help our good friend who is in trouble with his detective agency. With well thought out mini-games, agent micromanagement, leveling and a touch of DnD we uncover step by step all sorts of underworld machinations. The story dialogs are lovingly dubbed and the entire gameplay is accompanied by 80's music. 

Rough Justice is also something for the eye and for bookworms. The lovingly designed art style of the 80's lets young and older ;) indulge in nostalgia while the very well elaborated biographies of the individual detectives fit harmoniously into the scenario. 

An absolute MUST for every nostalgic and those who have a love for detective stories!

The resource management, crime and puzzle game I didn't know I needed!

The 80's vibes are unbeatable!
Crime and puzzlement!

Every Agent you can hire is amazing. Whether flashy or somber and muted, they fit right in with 80's crime and other classics. Half the fun is role-playing your own way and leveling up your favorite agents to your liking. The traits at every 3rd level are really fun!

I really hope the indie devs (Gamma Minus) make more games like this, they rock!

11/10 would hire Alex Ripley again.

Was happily surprised by this game having not played time management game of this style in quite a while. Firstly, love that 80s style and the music is great! The interface is very intuitive, the game offers a lot of diversity in the tasks you ended doing with the various agents. One thing I didnt know until a at least an hour in was the ability to stop the time, so much easier then as I thought the game was too frantic otherwise at time. So far enjoying it very much and its a thumbs up from me!

This is an innovative and fun game! The concept is something I have not seen before in this manner, and I love the 80's vibe with the music and characters. The minigames are fun to do and require quite a bit of practise and skill at higher levels. The game is relatively unforgiving, which is not a blocker for me. It's definitely not impossible, but it does require you to make the right decisions. Add a dash of luck in and honestly, no playthrough is the same. Great game overall, would highly recommend it, certainly for its price!

This game has a very nostalgic and slick 80s feel to it. I love the synthwave soundtrack and look to the game. You have the management system in place as you control the tasks that are completed by your hired agents, you have the puzzle elements that you solve as you choose a different case worker to work for and then you have the board game element with the dice rolling. RNG runs this game and you can add to the dice being rolled with gear that helps you to stand a better chance of succeeding. I played the demo of this and enjoyed it then, I have since played the full release and the storyline is interesting and the gameplay is incredibly user friendly with the tutorials to hand. I recommend this if you enjoy 80s nostalgia, time management, dice rolling and the hopes that this will also be developed into a board game.

I must admit that I wasn't really feeling this game when I first started playing it: The start is fairly simplistic, and the characters feel shallow, and tumblr-coded, which isn't necessarily bad, but is a style I'm not really fond of. I still think the first 4 to 6 hours aren't particularly great, and don't serve as a great intro. However, as soon as you get past the first few twists, the game gets extremely rewarding.

This game ends up having a simple but fun RPG setup that is really serviceable for what the game is, a great puzzle system that sometimes feels annoying but is overall extremely rewarding in drip feeding you information that helps you connect the dots really well, and characters which were honestly fairly deep while still maintaining a somewhat childlike atmosphere, balancing drama, trauma, and sugary wholesomeness really well.

A really good game, this one, especially for people who really like old-school RPG maker games. Easy recommendation.

Interesting short sci fi story. The game all takes place on one subway car. You are a detective robot trying to figure out robot dissapearances. The game basically involves exhausting dialogue options until the other robots leave, so in terms of mechanics its not great. However if you like high concept sci fi stories then this will do the job. I was genuinely interested in the dialogue and wanted to find out more about the world it takes place in. I think they did a good job at creating varied and interesting characters and a cohesive world with a consitent and engaging style.

reviews.title: sombresleep's review of Old Man's Journey

reviewText.content:
Old Man's Journey is a small charming puzzle adventure game. Its puzzles are simple, but still fun to solve. The biggest selling point of this game is, of course, its emotional story about an old man reliving his life through a series of flashbacks.

The whole game can be easily completed in less than 3 hours. Its art style is cute, puzzles are satisfying, and it doesn't overstay its welcome.

reviews.title: aeywoo's review of Old Man's Journey

reviewText.content:
Old Man's Journey is one of the more emotional Puzzle games I've played, it includes a good story about a father who left to pursue his love of sailing and ended up living within a house on a cliff overlooking the ocean, he receives a letter that his wife is gravely ill and his presence was requested, you go through valleys, hills, cliffs, meadows and even underwater to get the Old Man home to his wife that he hasn't seen in decades.

The puzzles were very intuitive for the most part, you manipulate the scenery around you and click on the various parts of the land to move the Old Man along on his journey, some of the puzzles require you to go up and down, solve road blocks of sheep herds and even breaking down old cobblestone walls with big stone wheels by using gravity and momentum to break through and let the Old Man continue his journey.

The story was emotional, it showed the story of the Old Man's time in the nations Navy and how he met his Wife, how they had a young daughter and ultimately the story of how the father abandoned his family to pursue his dreams of sailing, and when those dreams were completed and he returned they were nowhere to be seen, leading him to set up a new life by building a house overlooking a cliff which can be seen in the games various posters and cover art.

The end of the story actually had me in tears from how sudden the resolution was, from the Old Man being alongside his Wife as she passed to reconciling with his Daughter, this game was full of surprises and was overly enjoyable and a great use of my time.

An utterly repetitive third person shooter. Only the stop motion cutscenes are well made and they offer you a lot of fan service with the majority of '80s Joes making an appearence.

Also, play it only on co-op, the AI teammate is brainless.

reviews.title: norbie85's review of MLB The Show 24

reviewText.content: Graphics are great and having the ability to work your way up from being drafted to playing in the majors is awesome.

reviews.title: vlndk's review of MLB The Show 24

reviewText.content: MLB The Show 24 has once again solidified its spot as my go-to baseball sim. The gameplay is fluid, the graphics are stunning, and the variety of modes keeps me coming back for more. While the new features aren't groundbreaking, they add enough depth to keep the experience fresh. The Storylines mode, highlighting the Negro Leagues, is a particularly touching and informative addition. This year's iteration is a home run for both casual fans and hardcore players.
Great retro space shooter, loads of fun for the price. Each of the 5 modes puts an original spin on retro shooter mechanics. Loads of ships to unlock and 2 player co-op for less than 5 buck, awesome.

I really want to give this a higher rating, but there just isn't a way I can do that in the current state. To be honest, I had fun playing this, I really did. There is a good game somewhere in here, but it's not here yet. For something that started as an IOS game, it's pretty good, but it just does not stack up against other similar PC survival games, and without further development, it will remain unimpressive. However, it looks like that development isn't coming.

If Found... is a visual novel presented in the form of an art journal, and its fragmented narrative structure is very much a reflection of its central character's ongoing struggle towards self actualization.

The game opens with our mysterious protagonist's alter ego, Cassiopeia, drifting through space as a black hole threatens to envelop the Earth, as this haunting, gorgeous, otherworldly electronic score perfectly sets the backdrop for the scene.

We're soon dropped back into the real world, when a new mystery begins to unfold as our protagonist's real world counterpart, Kasio, returns home from her second year of college. We immediately get the sense that something is off through the way information is presented in the journal; sometimes words might be scribbled out, or written over. The player is provided an eraser to uncover some of these additional details, it's a really nice way to help us delve into Kasio's thought process; we can see the way she constantly second guesses herself from moment to moment.

With each new scene, we're getting a fuller, more comprehensive persepective of her situation; of all of these people and thoughts that weigh so heavily on her psyche. The journal Kasio has entrusted to us holds her innermost secrets and desires, and the journey we take with her is one that feels both intensely intimate, and emotionally sincere.

Though the gameplay in If Found... never really evolves, and admittedly might have grown stale in a longer game, its tremendous visual/aural presentation is enough to keep things consistently engaging throughout the course of its relatively brief 2.5 hour runtime.

Even in 2021, media featuring queer characters are still few and far between, and even more rarely do they feel quite as authentic and fully realized as they do here. While it might not break new ground in terms of its gameplay, it's still a powerful, and often brutally honest representation of the trans experience, and a must play for anyone aching for a great story. An unforgettable and incredibly moving visual novel. 

8.5/10

As for me this is a pinnacle of the whole Game Dev genre. And more suprisingly is that it was made by a very small team. It's better than Game Dev Tycoon. It is more complex, more variable and more intersting. It is better than other games. Yes, there are games which are more complex and more detailed, but as for me Mad Games Tycoon holds the balance between being too complex and thus being boring and being complex and thus being intersting.

𝟕,𝟐/𝟏𝟎 🍹 𝐀𝐀𝐀 𝐒𝐔𝐑𝐕𝐈𝐕𝐀𝐋
Here is the second top survival game of the 22nd year after "Raft" and, concurrently, the main exclusive of the year for Microsft :), still got to the full release, the game was in early access or "game preview", as it is called in the Xbox Store, since 2020 .
And, I say right away, my expectations were much higher, after the full walktrough, I lowered the rating of the game, and, it didn`t even make it into my top-15 of year. If you, like me, were waiting for a full version for the sake of story missions and the final point, then, unfortunately, the authors realised this aspect of the game as tritely as possible, yes, there is an interesting scientific lore, there are a couple of interesting and other "ctrl + v " laboratories of micro-world, there are a couple of 10-second cutscenes-dreams, but in fact there is no plot here, look what the game is about in general:
we are 4 children, somehow reduced to the size of an ant, we begin to eat insects, knit armor from them, along the way finding a laboratory that surprisingly matches our size, inside we meet "Burgle" - a robot who agrees to help us return to our "big" world, it begins to give us all sorts of tasks, like go there, find me some kind of chip there or turn on something.
