In the notes we read about the experience of a doctor who was left without a family, in key places - we met bosses like spiders - "Black Widow" for ex., And in the end, well, it's ridiculous to call it a spoiler, we just increase to a normal size.. and that's it, Yes, we will meet a couple of characters , there will be a final purely gameplay battle, and this is the whole plot.. We just collecting the necessary things, exploring key places, "blah blah blah" in notes / dialogues, and at the end we kind of "grow up", although they won't even show you the cutscene of it, it will be just a 2D clipping from a future newspaper, why and who made these laboratories - this is all described as banal as possible, mad scientist +a thirst for money of no-name company..
I am disappointed, compare with the same "Raft", where each story location had a different setting, provided new gameplay mechanics, even there the missions could be called really "story-driven", not just running around the laboratory in the forest, then lab under water.. then in a cave, and even the story bosses are not "surrounded" by any game design, it's always just a big open location where you have to peck the boss, bypassing him from all sides, because usually the enemies here are hardly fixated on only one person.
Undoubtedly, Grounded by Microsoft Studios has a huge budget, incredible Unreal Engine graphics (Although the optimization for the release is generally dead), good animations, it feels like this is not just another indie-survival, but a really high-quality product, but creativity, "soul", like in Raft, there is much less.

Maybe then the authors worked more on the open world and its research? Well, things really are much better here, the scale of the open world is amazing, it will take tens of hours for full explore, if you also try to find all the secrets that are also well done, again more to the budget - physics.. some sorts of lumps floating under water, or, a drop of dew or spilled soda rolling down the mountain - give the world even more quality and believability.
And, of course, in general - the game gives a unique opportunity to feel very small in our world, climb on ordinary human objects that are so huge from the perspective of an insects, roam through ant caves or get caught in the net of an ordinary, but such a big and scary spider,
And, by the way, about this, about the dangers and the combat system, which is the second main flaw of the project, which, for me, prevented Grounded from gaining more popularity, despite the huge love of players for this genre, the point is that you are constantly..at every step..just CONSTANTLY TEARED..sorry, but I just don’t know how else to say, walk a couple of meters - an ant will attack you, walk another - a wolf spider will beat you, run away from them - in the next location be ready for bites of mosquitoes, bees, all kinds of caterpillars, ladybugs, small, but mad ticks..
Many players, for example, don`t like survival games, like me, by the way, simply because you have to farm incredibly a lot, but in Grounded, add on to this point that you are attacked at almost every turn, if you will attack in response - either you you will suffer, because after 1 enemy, his flock will run into you, or you will suffer - because your weapons and armor, by the way, are also completely worthless even for the weakest opponents, only by the end of the game, after about 50 hours, having a weapon of level 3, only then will you be able to feel on a par with the current inhabitants in terms of strength, before that you will act a lot according to the "Faster feet - not afraid of hits", because of which your HP will constantly be at zero, very simple lifehack - die, respawn, and run to your backpack, this is not a "Raft", where if you died on the island, your body will have to be dragged to the base.
Such a system of incredibly aggressive mobs that spawn in every square centimeter of the map makes the game incredibly hardcore and not very comfortable for a relaxed grind if that's what you're after. Yes, but there are many different weapons, as well as many interesting recipes, visually interesting - armor for ex., some kind of hat made from the eyes of a spider or tick fur, in general, there are no problems with crafting in the game, learning new things is interesting, a normal upgrading system, but not for the abilities, it seems to me that it doesn`t work at all. What is another huge plus for creative people - (although, of course, I have no idea how many millions of years it takes to farm), but judging by the screenshots of other players, the game setting allows you to build incredible cool castles from leaves / mushrooms and other improvised means.

🏆 In general, once again, I summarize, Grounded - is beautiful and perfect in small things, with a well-designed setting, but constantly annoying in its main gameplay, and, careless attitude to the story, and, by the way, to the final location, which also opened just in the full version.. the last part of the map, next to the shed, turned out to be a boring "not stand out" stretching the game for another 10-20 hours, despite the fact that the game is already mastered with all the quests, for 60 hours.
p.s. Now we are waiting for "Forest 2" in February?)

Вот и вторая топ выживалка 22-ого года после Рафта и, по совместительству, главный эксклюзив года Microsft :), добралась таки до полного релиза, игра находилась в раннем доступе или "предварительной версии", как называется это в Xbox Store, с 2020 года.
И, скажу сразу, мои ожидания были гораздо выше, после полного прохождения я понизил оценку игре, и, она даже не попала в мой топ-15 этого года. Если вы, как и я, ждали фулл версию ради сюжетных миссий и финальной точки истории, то, к сожалению, к этому аспекту игры, авторы подошли максимально банально, да, тут есть интересный научный лор, есть пару интересных и остальные "ctrl+v" лабортатории "микро-мира", есть пару 10 секундных катсцен-снов, но по сути сюжета тут нету, смотрите, о чём игра вообще:
мы - 4-о детей, каким-то образом уменьшившиеся до размера муравья, мы начинаем жрать букашек, вязать из них броню, попутно находя лабораторию, удивительно соответствующую нашим размерам, там мы встречаем "Бургла" - робота, который соглашается помочь нам вернуться в наш "большой" мир и начинает давать нам всякие задачи, типо сходи туда, найди мне там какой-то чип или включи то-то. В записках мы читаем о переживаниях доктора, оставшегося без семьи, в ключевых местах нас поджидают боссы типо паучихи - "Чёрной вдовы", А в конце, ну это смешно назвать спойлером, мы просто увеличиваемся.. и всё, Да, мы встретим пару персонажей, будет финальная чисто геймплейная битва, и это весь сюжет.. Просто собираем нужные вещи, изучаем ключевые места, бла бла бла в записках/диалогах, и в конце мы типо "вырастаем", хотя вам даже катсценой процесс не покажут, просто будет 2D вырезка из будущей газеты, почему и кто сделал эти лаборатории - это все максимально банально описывается, крче безумный учёный+жажда денег какой-то ноунейм кампании..
Я разочарован, сравните с тем же Raft-ом, там каждая сюжетная локация имела разный сеттинг, предоставляла новые геймплейные механики, даже там миссии можно было назвать действительно "сюжетными", а не просто беготнёй по лаборотаории в лесу, потом лабе под водой, потом в пещере, и даже сюжетные боссы не "окружены" никаким геймдизайном, это всегда просто большая открытая локация, где вы должны долбить босса, обойдя его со всех сторон, потому что обычно враги тут жёстко зацикливаются только на одном человеке.
Несомненно, Граундед от Microsoft Studios обладает огромным бюджетом, невероятной графикой Unreal Engine (Хотя и оптимизация к релизу вообще умерла), хорошими анимациями, чувствуется, что это не очередная инди-выживалка, а действительно качественный продукт, но креатива, "души", как в Рафте, тут гораздо меньше.

Может быть тогда авторы больше проработали открытый мир и его исследование? Ну тут дела и правда обстоят гораздо лучше, масштабы открытого мира поражают, на полное исследование уйдут десятки часов, если ещё и пытаться найти все секреты, которые тоже сделаны неплохо, опять же больше к бюджету - присутствует физика, всякие плавающие под водой ошмётки, или, скатывающаяся по горе капелька росы или пролитой газировки - придают миру ещё больше качества и правдоподобности.
И, конечно, в целом - игра дарит Уникальную возможность почувствовать себя очень маленьким в нашем мире, позалезать на обычные человеческие предметы, которые такие огромные с перспективы насекомого, пошастать по муравьиным пещерам или попасться в сеть обычного, но такого большого и страшного паука,
И, вот, кстати об этом, об опасностях и боевой системе, что является вторым главным недостатком проекта, который по мне, и не позволил Grounded завоевать большую популярность, несмотря на огромную любовь игроков к данному жанру, дело в том, что вас постоянно..на каждом шагу.. просто ПОСТОЯННО ДЕРУТ..извините, но я просто не знаю как по другому сказать, пройди пару метров - на тебя нападёт муравей, пройди ещё - нападёт паук-волк, убежишь от них - в следующей локации будь готов у укусам комаров, пчёл, всяких гусениц, божьих коровок, мелких, но бесячих клещей..
Многие, например, не любят выживалки, как и я, кстати, просто из-за того, что надо невероятно много фармить и фармить, и фармить всяких ресов, но в Граундед приплюсуйте ещё к этому, что вас атакуют практически на каждом шагу, если вы будете атаковать в ответ - либо заколебётесь, так как после 1 противника, на вас набежит его стая, либо заколебётесь - так как ваше оружие и, броня, кстати тоже, совершенно никчёмные даже для самых слабых противников, только к концу игры, спустя часов 50, имея оружие 3-его уровня, только тогда вы сможете почувствовать себя по силе наравне с нынешними обитателями, до этого вы будете очень много действовать по схеме "Быстре ноги - п*здюлей не боятся", из-за чего ваше хп постоянно будет на нуле, и ещё очень простая схема - умирай, возрождайся, и беги до своего рюкзака, это вам не Рафт, где если вы умерли на острове, вас придётся тащить на плот.
Такая система невероятно агрессивных мобов, которые спаунятся в каждом квадратном сантиметре карты - делает игру невероятно харкдорной и не очень комфортабельной для спокойного гринда, если вы пришли за этим. Да, зато есть много различного оружия, как и много интересных рецептов, интересно оформленной визуально - брони, например, какая-нибудь шапка из глаз паука или шёрстки клеща, вообще с крафтом в игре проблем нет, изучать новое интересно, нормальная система прокачки, не считая прокачку игрока, она, мне кажется вообще не работает. Что ещё огромный плюс для креативщиков - (хотя, я, конечно, не представляю, сколько надо миллионов лет фармить,) но судя по скриншотам других игроков - сеттинг игры позволяет строить невероятные крутые замки из листьев/грибов и прочих подручных средств.

🏆 В общем, ещё раз, резюмирую, Grounded - красивая и прекрасная в мелочах, с качественно проработанным сеттингом, но постоянно бесячая в своём основном геймплее, и, халтурно подошедшая к вопросу сюжета, и, кстати, к финальной локации, которая тоже открылась только в полной версии, последняя часть карты, рядом с сараем, получилась унылым "не выделяющимся" растягиванием игры ещё часов на 10-20, при том, что игра итак осиливается со всеми квестами, часов за 60.
p.s. Теперь ждём Forest 2 в феврале?)

The game  came out with many divisive topics, but I wanted to give it a good chance. Overall though, as of now this sits as one of my least favorite mainline games.  Combining the worst elements of the last two generations, and adding a couple more I disagree with.

To discuss, the graphics, they aren't up to the standard provided by the Switch's first party library, I am unsure if there were bugs but everything looks incredibly fuzzy on console whenever I attempted to play docked, as if the resolution had not been changed, this is without discussing the lackluster wild area.

In terms of gameplay. there were many changes that I wasn't happy with. Although probably in the minority. Random battles were never exciting since every battle was intentionally entered or a nuisance. This meant I ran from almost every battle not encompassing a new pokemon to catch. Because of this change, I also felt like routes were less exciting, which may coinside with the shorter amount in the game overall. Since I never found it necessary to train all my pokemon equally thanks to the always-on exp share, I actually found myself caring less about my pokemon, and sticking to a couple of power houses for anything but type advantages. Even playing this way, I never found myself in dire shape. 

Although the story felt just as stop and start as pokemon sun and moon, there were some interesting ideas presented with the gym leaders, and the last area. Although in the end the game diminished these by making these points extremely easy. 

What I can say is the the music is great as always, and even if you do skip this game. I do suggest giving it a listen.

Honestly, I can't give the game a strong recommendation as it doesn't excel in anything the series is known for. You would do better to go back and try an older game and get a probable better experience. On the other hand, you would not get the zeitgeist and buzz of playing the game with others.

I've been playing Pokemon since Pokemon Emerald, and the last installment I enjoyed was Pokemon X & Y. Although I didn't like Pokemon Sun & Moon, I thought I would give my beloved Pokemon series another chance.
Despite all of it's problems, and there are quite a few, I had fun with it.

Pokemon games, at least the mainline series, have always been one of my favorite games to play. I always wait for the latest update, so I can enjoy the games with every single piece of content possible. I finally decided to play Pokemon Shield. I always get addicted to the game-play loop. I can't say whether I enjoy or I don't the quality of life improvements (such as sharing experience points from the start), as it adds and takes away from the game equally. Pokemon Shield heavily focuses on the wild area, not the story (the pacing is so off), the world somehow seems a bit small, and it doesn't have a full PokeDex. Despite all this, the entry seems fresh, and feels like an evolution. The Pokemon series is never going to go back to the HeartGold/FireRed, and if this is what we are getting going forward, I can live with it.

reviews.title: seekozahero's review of Infinity Strash: Dragon Quest - The Adventure of Dai

reviewText.content: The story of the game itself is a masterpiece. Even if the game is lacking the story itself fills that gap. Yet I would've loved for the game to have more cinematics and fights rather than implementing from the anime. I hope the game will feature the rest of the story from the anime.

reviews.title: A wonderful and very hardcore cyber-ninja simulator.

reviewText.content:
Ghostrunner is a fast-paced first-person action game set in a post-apocalyptic world. It was developed by One More Level and 3D Realms and published by 505 Games. Some of the previous games these studios have worked on include God's Trigger, WRATH: Aeon of Ruin, and Ion Fury. The game was directed by Radosław Ratusznik, who previously worked on Get Even, while the script was written by Michał Kuk, who also wrote for Juggler Games' My Memory of Us. The music was composed by Daniel Deluxe, who also contributed his talents to games like Furi and Hotline Miami.

Graphically, Ghostrunner looks gorgeous, thanks to the Unreal Engine 4. The neon-filled cyberpunk city is stunningly detailed, and the frenetic action is accentuated by the game's smooth animations. The developers also managed to nail the feeling of movement, making wall-running and grappling a joy to pull off.
The one hit death was just too annoying for me. Quit very early on because I knew the frustration would only get worse. Not for me.

Extremely fun fps platformer. The gameplay is close to perfection, so much so that it made me completely ignore the game's story. The controls feel very snappy and fast. 
Visually very cool, cyberpunk style. 
The music is awesome, with synthwave and retrowave genres, which suits the game like a glove
In short, a hell of a lot of fun and perfect for finishing quickly since it's short.

Ghostrunner - 2/10 

Honestly, I did not have high expectations for this game, but it turned out to be much worse. This game is so shallow and boring that it eventually becomes nauseating.

The most annoying thing is the main plot and the lore of the world. To put it briefly: it's a cliché stacked upon a cliché upon another cliché. Seriously, the main characters, the plot, and the story of the world are the epitome of the word "cliché". You can predict what is going to happen after the first 30 minutes of the game—it is so shallow and typical that it eventually makes you sick. In summary, you have no vibe or interest in what is going on. The immersion is at a negative level—that's how bland Ghostrunner really is.

The gameplay promised something exciting, like a cool first-person slasher, but it completely fails to deliver. The progression in this game is so "interesting" that you basically forget to manage it. Moreover, the skill progression is overly drawn out—I have no idea why they made unlocking all features happen on the level before the last one. Fighting with enemies is just boring—95% of it involves repeating the same pattern as before. The boss fights are even worse—I cannot remember the last time I saw such stupid and ultimately boring boss fights. Generally speaking, you have to do exactly what the game wants you to do. The design of the second boss fight is so poor that at first, I didn’t even have the slightest idea what I was doing wrong. The problem is—you must block attacks at the exact moment the game wants you to, even though you see the attack animation. If you attempt to block slightly earlier, the whole combo is reset. I have no idea who approved this...

The only positive thing about Ghostrunner is the graphics. It is certainly not masterpiece, but at least it looks cool and gleaming. However, if you look more closely, you will start to see some problems, but overall, especially when you are in action, it looks quite good and nice.

So generally speaking, Ghostrunner has just a shining wrapper, behind which lies an incredibly mediocre and boring product. And the main problem is that everything in this game is so average that, in the end, you gain nothing—you just regret wasting your time.

Ghostrunner is a fast-paced first-person action game set in a post-apocalyptic world. It was developed by One More Level and 3D Realms and published by 505 Games. Some of the previous games these studios have worked on include God's Trigger, WRATH: Aeon of Ruin, and Ion Fury. The game was directed by Radosław Ratusznik, who previously worked on Get Even, while the script was written by Michał Kuk, who also wrote for Juggler Games' My Memory of Us. The music was composed by Daniel Deluxe, who also contributed his talents to games like Furi and Hotline Miami.

Graphically, Ghostrunner looks gorgeous, thanks to the Unreal Engine 4. The neon-filled cyberpunk city is stunningly detailed, and the frenetic action is accentuated by the game's smooth animations. The developers also managed to nail the feeling of movement, making wall-running and grappling a joy to pull off.

Overall, Ghostrunner offers a thrilling experience that really makes you feel like a cybernetic ninja. The combination of fluid movement, satisfying violence, and the striking visuals make it a must-play for action fans.

reviews.title: thaflu84's review of Tails of Iron

reviewText.content:
It is obvious that a lot of care went into this game. It has a fine plot, challenging combat, a superb art style, and pleasant music.

The most striking aspects of this game are the art style and the Souls-like combat. The Rats vs. Frogs war theme, combined with the 2D hand-drawn art result in gorgeous and distinctive visuals. Also, the executions and light green frog blood are a nice touch.

The combat is tough and mostly fair. The main issue I have with it applies to the bosses/bigger enemies. You usually have to be close to damage them, meanwhile, they have unblockable (but dodgeable) attacks that cover half, and sometimes, the whole screen. Later enemies also dodge a lot of your attacks. Ranged attacks are limited and weak, so it’s best to save for the finish. Thankfully, I had patience and I was never stuck on one fight. Finally, the weight system was poorly implemented and the abundance of gear you obtain is pointless, but those are mostly nitpicks.

The game is short, but the free ‘Bloody Whiskers’ expansion adds a few more enemies to fight and contains a startling secret. This is simply a well-made game across the board on a developer’s first try. Impressive.

reviews.title: A short but satisfying little ARPG!

reviewText.content:
The story is pretty simple with you being a prince whose father is killed by some evil Frogs and now you need to rebuild the kingdom and get your revenge. The story was nothing to write home about, but it was enough to keep me going and I felt it had some good moments throughout. While the characters aren’t voiced the game is narrated by actor Doug Cockle, who of course voices Geralt in the Witcher games, and as someone who is a big fan of that series it was a real treat to get his VO here! The man could read the phone book to me and I would be captivated the whole way through!

Combat has that souls-like feel of dodging, blocking and parrying but thankfully there are difficulty settings which is great for me since I’m not that into challenging games. The easy difficulty felt good for me in that it was more forgiving but not brain dead easy and I did die a few times to bosses. The combat does feel very good though, with the hits feeling weighty and satisfying to perform and your character will even perform executions on bigger enemies which are fun to see. Alongside that you get a pretty nice variety of weapons and armors to find which always makes completing quests or defeating bosses satisfying since you get that great reward at the end of it.

Hades just dethroned Diablo. It's the 2020 hack&slash dungeon crawler game.

I was never disappointed with Supergiant Games game. Their focus on the main story and loveable characters is so extraordinary compared to the other games.

It feels that they've combined story, gameplay, art style, and music from their previous game to make something much bigger. Rogue-like makes the game fresher the more you play it.

El juego que me hizo sobrevivir la pandemia, lo ame, ame cada segundo de el, es adictivo, divertido en todos sentidos la clase de juego que le puedo recomendar a cualquier persona da igual si nivel de habilidad jugando videojuegos, una obra maestra que me ayudaba a desconectar del mundo exterior cuando ardia
One of the best hack&slash that I played, truly a masterpiece.

From the first time you play Hades, you get hooked. The satisfaction of collecting boons, clearing rooms, and becoming stronger and stronger makes you always want to do "one more run". After a few runs, you find your way of playing, and it becomes even more enjoyable - up to a certain point, when, not coincidentally, the main story ends. Speaking of the story, I find it the weakest part of the game. Other than that, Hades is truly great.
it's nothing short of being awesome.
A real one masterpiece, newest classic from great studio Supergiant Games.

Seeing the hype this game gets, I gave it a chance

One of the fastest uninstall ever...

The best rouge like game I've played. The core game play loop of getting booms from gods is fun and all the weapons are fun to use. The main story as well as side stories of characters keeps you wanting to play to learn more.
It's just so damn satisfying, man. Idk what more I can say about it.

The weakest point of the game is it's repetitiveness. For finishing the game you can't just get good and clear the run. You have to clear the select number of runs to get bite-sized dialogs after each clear. To completely finish the game the same principle applies, but x10. And overall nothing will change with each run. You'll have the same set of the boons to be randomly awarded and this will get boring pretty quick, especially if you want to complete the story to it's full end. 
Otherwise, the game is pretty rad. One of the good representatives of the roguelike genre.

It is not often a game comes out and totally takes your breath away, especially a roguelite. The genre has become packed with average games, as the mechanics of a never ending game appeals to developers as it gives more value for money for the player. Hades by Supergiant Games is anything but average. Every aspect of the game is astounding and it shows how outstanding games can be made in early-access. Find out why in my Hades Nintendo Switch review.

Developing Hell

Hades was announced almost two years ago at the Game Awards. Since then, it has been worked on, developed for and optimised until its Switch release on September 17th. In a documentary made by No Clip, you can see that this pivot to early-access was not easy for the developers at Supergiant Games. However, the extra time to make Hades has made it one of the best indie games on the Nintendo Switch and my personal game of the year for 2020.

Escaping Hell

The story of Hades is based on Greek mythology and the little known God of Rebirth, Zagreus. Zag is the Prince of the Underworld and going through an angsty teenage phase. After an argument with his father, Hades, God of the Underworld, Zag decides enough is enough. He wants to join his wider family up on Mount Olympus. The young Prince grabs his father’s sword and leaps out of his bedroom window and tries to make his way through the four levels of Hell to escape to the surface.

Obviously, escaping Hell is no easy feat. So, Zag will need some help along the way. His relatives up on Mount Olympus hear of his quest and decide to help him by granting him powerful Boons, which give his attacks special powers. Nevertheless, even the grace of the Gods is not enough to break free from his father’s realm and Zag is defeated. Luckily, he is the God of Rebirth and cannot really die. Once he is defeated, he is respawned at the House of Hades, which is the central hub for the game.

House of Hades

The House of Hades is despised by Zag but is a great place to get to know the residents of Hell. Here Zag can talk to Greek Legends like Dusa (Medusa), Achilles and even Death himself, Thanatos. It’s here where you can upgrade Zag and the Underworld to make your future runs more successful. However, we will talk about that a little later.

An Ancient Greek Soap Opera 

When describing the story of Hades to players that have never played it before, I describe it as a soap opera. Sure, the main theme and aim of the game is escaping Hell. However, the main story is about family, and just happens to be about history’s most dysfunctioning family.

Everyone knows something about Greek Mythology. It may be from a history class back in primary school or from an episode of Hercules on the Disney Channel, but everyone knows at least some of the characters in Hades. 

There are the main gods: Zeus, Poseidon and Hades, who all happen to be brothers. From there it is very interesting to see which gods and demons Supergiant added to the game. There is Aphrodite, the Goddess of Love, Ares, the God of War, Athena, the Goddess of Wisdom, Dionysus, the God of Fertility and Wine and Hermes, the God of Luck and Travel. These are just some of the Gods in the game. All of whom are related in both close and distant ways. 

Because of all of these interlocking relationships, the soap opera feel of the story is intensified. Gods who are siblings have ancient rivalries with each other and compete for Zag’s attention like small children. They plot and argue together within the game, making me question if it really is a good idea for Zag to join them on Mount Olympus.

Gods and Monsters

Nevertheless, I always look forward to seeing the Gods in the game. Firstly, this is because their designs look fantastic. Artist Jen Zee has gone out of her way to create unique, interesting looking characters that are as diverse as they are powerful. It is so refreshing to see characters that are not all white. It gives the Gods depth and a believableness. This is because Greek Gods and Goddesses were not necessarily all from Greece, as pointed out in this Kotaku article.

Furthermore, their writing is excellent and after about 20 hours of playing the game, I still have not come across any dialogue that repeats itself. It is amazing! What is even more impressive is that the dialogue throughout the game is reactionary to whatever happened in your last run. Therefore, characters will comment on how you could possibly beat the enemy that defeated you (or make fun of you for losing to them). I’ve seen this sort of story-telling before in other indie games, but it’s nothing compared to the extent and level Hades has.

Combat

Roguelikes/lites live and die on their combat. Obviously, if you’re playing dozens or hundreds of hours of chopping down foes, it has to feel good. Hades has one of the quickest, best feeling combat mechanics I have ever played. In my opinion, it is even better than Dead Cells and knocks it off its podium of best roguelite on the Nintendo Switch.

Zag has three attacks and a dash move, and that’s it. The three attacks are broken down to: Attack (Y), Special Attack (X) and Cast (B), with the Dash being on the A button. Though the combat seems quite simple at first, it is the addition of Zag’s weapons that make it so addictive.

Weapons

After a few runs in the game you will have unlocked all six weapons in Hades’s arsenal. There is: a sword, a spear, a shield, a bow, a pair of boxing gloves and a gun- yes a gun. While there is nowhere near as many weapons as Dead Cells, I still believe Hades feels better in both combat and the uniqueness of each individual run. Again, when looking at the weapon types, there doesn’t seem to be anything variety there. However, having put the game through its early-access paces, Supergiant have fine tuned Hades’s combat to perfection. On its own, without any Boons from the gods, the combat is precise and brutal. When you add Boons to it it becomes, well- God-like.

Boons

Boons are upgrades from the Gods that will either temporarily upgrade Zag’s stats, or add additional effects to your weapons. Each different attack can be upgraded by each of the gods, and each Boon has a rarity associated to it. For example, you may have a run where you are using one of Zeus’s Boons on your regular attack, which will send out a lightning bolt every time you hit an enemy. Then you might have a Boon from Dionysus on your special attack, which will inflict Hangover (poison) on your enemies and do damage over time. On your cast you might have a Boon from Ares that turns your cast into a gust of whirling blades.

Finally, on your dash you may have a Boon from Poseidon, which will cause a wave to knock-back enemies every time you dash. These are just a small amount of the Boons in the game, there are dozens that will make every single run feel totally different from the last.

Unique Runs

In addition to the Boons, the way Hades makes every run feel unique is by giving the player a choice to make after clearing every room. Doors will appear with icons on them that show the player what item they will be rewarded with if they beat the next room. This gives the player the control to shape how they want their run to go.

Sure, the actual Boons received may be randomised. However, giving the player all of the decision making to decide for themselves is something I’ve not yet seen in a roguelite. Mostly, players have to wander blindly through a dungeon and are rewarded with random upgrades, which often may not even help the player. This is not the case in Hades and I love it! Every upgrade or item is useful and helps make both Zag and the player better at the game, pushing them further towards the surface. 

Progression

Alongside combat any roguelike/lite worth its salt needs to have a rewarding progression system. The game is hard- all roguelites are. However, if progression is done well a player should want to load up the next game straight away after a death instead of feeling bitter about the death. Again, because of its time in early-access, I believe Supergiant have knocked it out of the park with the progression system in Hades.

There are about seven different items that are persistent throughout the game. That means that even if you die in a run, you will return to the House of Hades with these items. They are: Darkness, Gems, Keys, Nectar, Titan Blood, Diamonds and Ambroise and all act as a type of currency that can be used to upgrade Zag and the House permanently. I’d argue the most important of the currencies are Darkness and Gems. Darkness is used at the Mirror of the Night and will upgrade Zag’s moveset and stats permanently. Gems are used at the Construction Table and add extra challenges and rooms to Hell that will help you get further in a run.

Always Achieving Something

The progression is done so well that after each death you return to the House feeling like you achieved something in the previous run, and more importantly, that the next run will be better. The game is so well balanced that you are given just enough of a reward and incentive to keep persevering. This is something other roguelites fail to do. It was the biggest problem for me in Dead Cells and Neon Abyss. This is because I felt like I was never getting further in a run and always dying to the same bosses because there were no persistent upgrades making me better.

This is simply not the case in Hades. After getting to grips with the bosses you can beat them consistently because you as a player have improved and so has Zag. It means you will progress and keep progressing until every run is a success. Eventually getting you further and further until you ‘beat’ the game. It is something most roguelites never do, in fact, I think Hades is the only roguelite I’ve ever ‘beaten’. That is not because it is easy, but because Supergiant want you to win and wants you to experience the amazing story that is interwoven within Hades.

Art

Jen Zee’s art style has set Supergiant Games apart in the indie scene. When you see a Supergiant game, you know it is a SuperGiant game because of Jen’s wonderful art. Hades is no exception to this. I’ve already spoken about the Gods, but the other characters, even the bosses in the game also look wonderful.

Hell itself has never looked so good! With each level having its own unique look, theme and colour palette. I love the contrast Tartarus and Asphodel’s dark walkways have compared to its green lights and neon orange lava. Elysium on the other hand, feels almost heavenly, with its luscious looking gardens and vivid turquoise theme. It is one of the few dungeon-crawlers I have ever played that I’ve taken the time to actually explore the dungeon and really appreciate the high level of art on show there.

Music and Sound Design

Alongside Jen Zee’s art, Darren Korb’s score and sound design is another aspect that sets Supergiant apart from other developers. The score in Hades is both whimsical and heavy at the same times. It reminds me of being on holiday in Greece while at the same time having deep, heavy metal riffs that fit the brutality of the combat (and the game) perfectly. I am actually listening to the soundtrack as I write this review.

In addition, the voice acting in Hades is superb, with Korb himself acting Zag and Skelly. Supergiant staple Logan Cunningham is back to voice the God of the Underworld and many other characters like Poseidon and Achilles. There must be thousands of lines of text in this game and in my 20 hours of playing, every single one has been absolutely nailed. It’s also interesting to note that other members of the Supergiant team voiced characters in the game too.


Finally, the sound design of the weapons and attacks in Hades adds so much to the pleasure of the game. It is really one of those games you cannot play with the sound off because it helps so much in combat. Little audible cues signal when your combos are finished and adds a subconscious reaction telling you to dash away. Throughout, Hades is a wonderful sounding game- all Supergiant games are. But in Hades’s case, Darren Korb has outdone himself!

Game of the Year

Hades is a triumph of a game and shows what early-access indie games should be in 2020. Supergiant Games is one of the best indie game developers there is and they have shown their class and skill with Hades. Everything in the game is perfect from its art and music, to combat and narrative. There is not one bad thing I can think of about this game, it is simply perfect.

If you are skeptical of the roguelite genre, Hades is the one game that will get you addicted to them. Its progression systems are rewarding, making you want to have ‘one more run’ rather than throwing your controller through the screen after a death.

The story, though simple at its core, is enthralling and makes me want to keep playing over and over to find out the conclusion to Zag’s story. I think this has a lot to do with the excellent writing of Greg Kasavin and the amazing character designs of Jen Zee. I’ve become so interested in Hades that I’ve been Googling and reading up on Greek mythology, to get a better understanding of how all of these Gods, Spirits and Monsters intertwined.

In my eyes there is no question that Hades is my Game of the Year. Honestly, if we didn’t live in a world where graphics rule awards, I would say it should be Game of the Year, that is how good it is. If anything in this review has piqued your interest about the game, please, please try it out. It is truly an outstanding, once in a generation game that should be played by everyone from heaven to hell.

reviews.title: A réserver aux amoureux du rogue like pur et dur.

reviewText.content:
La direction artistique, l'animation, les effets graphiques, les bonus, l'interaction avec les 'PNJ/dieux', tout ca est superbe !
Mais quel gâchis d'en avoir fait un rogue like qui nous fait mourir sans cesse... avec une narration à la Transistor ca aurait été parfait, là les morts incessantes avec reprise tout au début du monde en cours ont complétement érodé l'intérêt pour ce jeu.
Ca donne l'impression de jouer dans un jeu de 'farming' permanent, avec une succession de pièces aléatoirement générées mais toujours un peu les mêmes. Perso ca m'a enlevé tout envie de continuer à jouer.
A réserver aux amoureux du rogue like pur et dur.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass
(merci le pass, dire que je voulais l'acheter vu la hipe autour du jeu, j'aurais été dégouté)

Easily the best roguelike I've ever played that totally overshadows the rest. The music, gameplay, *cough* character design, and the atmosphere are all wonderful and its incredible how Supergiant games always puts out games on a different level of quality.
Dikkat oyun bağımlılık yapabilir

The combat feels kinda broken/unsatisfying. You just keep dodging and shooting while using your skills in-between, which boils it down to button smashing. It has beautiful graphics but I don't think I could play a whole story mode with this combat. I barely got through the early access demo without getting completely bored of it.

Suite directe du premier épisode, on retrouve les premiers personnages mais aussi de nouveaux clients :)
Le gameplay reste le même : une partie novel story, une partie création de boissons (qui a été améliorée pour cette suite).
Les embranchements et donc les fins sont nombreux, plus que dans le premier.
En tout cas si vous avez aimé le premier, cette suite "1.5" est toute indiquée :)

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

Coffee Talk: Episode 2 - Hibiscus & Butterfly is a great sequel that holds up the quality of the first game. The new characters are welcome additions and provide a lot of interesting and compelling story beats. The soundtrack is, like the first game, phenomenal. The coffee system works well. The astronaut subplot still feels a little out of place, but is overall handled much better in this game than in the first. The game overall is incredibly relaxing and enjoyable, and has some stellar characters.

Overall Score: 9/10

Been a fan since I played More Friends of Mineral Town on the GBA two decades ago, so I badly wanted to like this game. I know about the entire Natsume/Xseed/Marvelous issue, but I played Light of Hope before so I wanted to judge the game on its own merit and not by the Harvest Moon name. Unfortunately, although I enjoyed it a lot (42hrs in from 16-22 Jul 21and married to Sami!) and even pulled all-nighters for it, the game was ultimately a frustrating experience. I stopped right after I achieved my goal, which was marriage, and could no longer push through with getting all the festivals, shiny animals, and having a kid.

Moonlighter is a roguelite shopkeeper sim. You inherit a small run down shop near mysterious, regenerating dungeons. The town has seen better days, and you delve into the dungeons to find the keys to unlock the fabled 5th dungeon, and bring prosperity to your shop, and to the town.

Right off the bat, this is a great looking game. I enjoyed the pixel art and style of the game immensely. The shopkeeper and roguelite mixture is interesting, and adds a bit of uniqueness to a crowded genre. The pace of the game takes you into the dungeons, where you fight hard and collect loot to sell in your shop. You then use the proceeds to upgrade your shop, and build weapons, armor and potions to get you deeper into the dungeons. On the third floor of each, you will fight a boss, and retrieve the dungeons key. 

On the downside, I found the roguelike elements to be a tad weak. There are no in-dungeon powerups, making each run feel same-y, as you can only use up to two weapons per dungeon. This was not a game ender for me, but did detract from my enjoyment in a rather large way.

Bu oyunla çok rastgele bir zamanda tanıştım, ama dikkatimi vererek oynadığımda aşırı derecede tatmin edici bulduğumu da belirtmek istiyorum. Bu oyunun bir de Lust From Beyond isminde ikinci bir oyunu var, ama henüz tamamlanmış bir oyun değil.

Oyunun konseptini özetlemek gerekirse; hikaye olarak biraz boş olsa da ağır derecede sembolizm içeren, pek çok kişiye göre yönetmeni Stanley Kubrick'in ölümüne sebebiyet veren ve beyaz perdeye "eksik (!)" bir şekilde çıkmış olan Eyes Wide Shut filminin biraz daha değiştirilmiş ve de genişletilmiş versiyonu diyebiliriz.

Kayıp eşinden gelen esrarengiz bir mesajla çok acayip bir ortama giren bir adamı oynadığımız oyunun spoiler içermeyen özeti için tek diyebileceğim şu: Eyes Wide Shut'ı al, masonluğa değinen içeriği Lovecraftian seviyede bir tarikatla değiştir, alternatif boyut ve birkaç Lovecraftian yaratık ekle, biraz da bulmacayla süsle. İşte, karşında Lust For Darkness!

Oyunun kendine özgü bir lore'u var ve yapımcılar bunun sürekliliğini sağlamak için uğraşıyorlar. Bu sebeple; yazılara, isimlere ve kavramlara dikkat etmenizi tavsiye ediyorum.

Artıları:
+ Oyun 18+ ama seks oyunu değil
+ Lovecraftian tarikat konsepti güzelce işlenmiş
+ Hikaye sürükleyici bir şekilde oyuncuyu içine çekiyor
+ Hoş müzikler var
+ Hoş bulmacalar var

Eksileri:
- Müziğin ayarı bazı yerlerde kısık gelebiliyor
- Bazı noktalarda çözüm yolunu bulmak zaman alabiliyor
- Bu oyunu Twitch'te ve YouTube'da (YT için emin değilim) yayınlayamazsınız (çıplaklık, seks, fetiş gereçleri falan var)
- Bitiyor (keşke bu oyun yüzyıllarca ve kendi çizgisini bozmadan devam etse)

Karanlık konseptlere ilginiz varsa, bu eşi benzeri olmayan oyunu denemenizi kesinlikle tavsiye ediyorum. Ben bu oyunu galiba 4 kere bitirdim.

Y'vh Lauv'abrarc! Y'vh LUSSTGHAA!!

Neat little mini hack n' slash that will take ~5 hours to beat. I couldn't beat the final boss even after a few days of trying. Not thrilled about the difficulty spike at the end. Reminds me of fights like Yellow Devil from MegaMan or the last boss in Devil May Cry. Just unfair. Not a bad game tho.

I have a lot of thoughts about Tunic. It somehow feels very video gamey-y in a traditional sort of way. You play in areas which are intentionally non-linear, confusing, and maze-like. You have to find certain items or perform a certain action to advance to the next stage. The combat is challenging and all about dodging and managing stamina. I see how all of this might sound very interesting for gamers, as something like this has not been released for ages, as these are tropes of old video games. It is absolutely not my cup of tea. I am the type of person who wants to explore every corner of the map, so I get overwhelmed with games like these, especially when death is a possibility all the time.

Sometimes a meta-game comes out that really nails the nostalgia, feeling, and gameplay style of older video games. Tunic has scratched that itch for me. This is a game that pays heavy homage to the games of yore, with a modern coat of paint, soundtrack, and mechanics. Without spoiling anything, the mechanics of the game are discovered as you play, which gave me some moments of discovery that were enjoyable to experience. The visuals in this game are stunning; I have snapped a few for desktop backgrounds, and the world-building and visual homage's to Zelda games are splendid and delightful. Mechanics are often unlocked over time, and the game contains a unique language, ready for the player to figure it out, and offering almost no hand holding to discover the goods. The soundtrack here is also excellent; I listen to it frequently, and it is atmospheric, ethereal, and excellent. 

Gameplay-wise, Tunic plays like a top down "Zelda-like" with interesting mechanics, loads of potions, and items to utilize, and a few excellent combat and defensive maneuvers that contain depth through learning some control hacks to elevate the abilities. The combat is tough as nails; bosses and enemies are tough, and players will need to learn patterns and die numerous times in game to learn how to defeat enemies - and sometimes this only occurs by the skin of one's teeth. I fought one boss in this game dozens of times, giving me some Dark Souls vibes for combat and boss encounters. 

I did find some of the areas of this game, including the final boss, to be onerously difficult, and this is one of the only downsides for me in this gaming experience. To me, this was an excellent homage to smaller adventure RPG titles, and it is one of the best examples in class, in my opinion. Easy recommendation if any of the above sounds of interest.

Comme beaucoup je me suis fait avoir par les graphismes mignons qui cachent une difficulté atroce.
Contrairement à un Death's Door qui est dur mais juste, on a ici un perso lent avec peu de portée comparé aux ennemis, une difficulté élevée pénible dès qu'il y a plus d'un ennemi (qui respawent à chaque guérison au 'feu de camp'), des ennemis qui à chaque coup réduisent le max de la barre de vie et autre malus viennent tempérer toute progression, ...
Résultat dans les options => activation de l'invisibilité, ce qui fait perdre tout l'intérêt du jeu si on veut en connaitre la fin, et des secrets tellement secrets qu'il faut un guide pour certains d'entre eux.

J'ai nettement préféré Death's Door, dur mais juste et plus dynamique au niveau des combats.

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

reviews.title: Best indie game of 2022, one of the best of all time

reviewText.content:
Tunic is a great game, you can feel that it is made with heart, the developers (or developer? don't know) put so much attention to the details, the art, game design, graphics (very good lighting btw), everything.

It has one the best exploration designs, you literally have to use your brain (shocking) to discover mechanics, places, items, etc.

If it wasn't for Elden Ring, it was the best game of 2022.

This game has lots of problems -- from small bugs that make characters go through walls or get stuck in weirdly funny positions, to the shallow content (almost all quests are fetch quests thinly disguised -- some of them up and down mountains).

That said, the game is so light and fluffy, you cannot help but forgive most flaws. All characters are nice to each other all the time; and you can customize your character quite a bit, dress it up in many colorful ways, or turn yourself into a walking Sundae. How can you be mad at this game?

At the end, there is a bit of a feeling of "why?", and a sense that this should have been more polished (the management aspect, for example, is nearly irrelevant) -- but I had a relaxing time while it lasted.

Score: 61/100.
Groundhog Day meets RPG with talking animals... and it's an exquisitely deep story! :)

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Milk inside a bag of milk inside a bag of milk

reviewText.content:
A very short but interesting visual novel. Milk inside a bag of milk inside a bag of milk works as a great insight into the struggles of someone dealing with mental trauma. A slight horror theme pervades the game, with a little bit of humor as well.

Even though it was incredibly short (20 minutes to get all endings), it had me hooked immediately, and that interest did not wane at all.

The visuals and sound effects add to the atmosphere to make the game nearly perfect for what it is going for.

Overall Score: 9/10

I was pretty pleased with The Long Reach, as a very quick game it's satisfying: it has a very haunting feel and is quite creepy.
But unfortunately not much more than that, the point & click mechanics are very basic and the story while interesting doesn't make a whole lot of sense..

Started on 10 Jul 21 and finished the main story on 14 Jul 21 with 15hrs. I've been a fan of Disgaea since the first entry and I've played every entry in the series (save for the 3rd) so I was really looking forward to this one! Unfortunately, this was a disappointment that did not live up to its predecessors.

Un petit jeu aux graphismes dignes de Paint :)
La prise en main est intuitive et très agréable, le jeu possède un humour "what the fuck" qui me rappelle un peu warioland dans l'état d'esprit : on est ici sur du bac à sable avec des petites épreuves et énigmes variées, un fil conducteur avec une histoire rigolote pour donner un peu de cohérence.
La durée de vie est honnête, et ca se joue bien en petites sessions.
La musique est sympa aussi, rythmée dans le ton du jeu.
De bonnes heures de sourires, si on a pas de attentes démesurées :)

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass
Fun dumb little indie game. Only a few hours long with banger music. The characters are all very cute and the humor in the game is perfect. Great game to get if you have xbox game pass.

reviews.title: timmykimmel's review of Thomas Was Alone

reviewText.content:
Cute, but boring. Ideas and story are nice, gameplay-wise it sucks. You sometimes get through the levels faster than the narrator has told the particular part of the story, so you wait at the exit to avoid interrupting him. This is not the only aspect that shows that the game simply lacks proper challenges.
Technical deficits are equally disturbing: The game runs exclusively in 18:9, so on most screens the letterbox frames are part of the game. No frameless window mode, no mouse support, etc. etc. Most of this is not dramatic, but in total the unclean implementation is disturbing.
I love this game. My favorite game of all time? no far from it, but a damn good one. The story was compelling and the puzzles were hard but not too hard.

Dans le même univers que MechaNika, mais ce n'est pas une suite, c'est une aventure en parallèle, donc on peut commencer par celui-ci :)
Plus posé que MechaNika au niveau de l'histoire, la narration a été un peu linéarisée pour gagner en profondeur.
Les références geeks par dizaine font toujours plaisir à voir, toujours autant de personnages "débiles" :)
Niveau artistique on reste sur cette touche indé, très agréable, avec un peu plus de perso et lieux que MechaNika.

reviews.title: Petit jeu de plateforme réflexion, dont l'ambiance et la DA font penser au jeu "Gris", mais avec son identité propre.

reviewText.content:
Les phases d'énigmes et de plateforme s'enchainent, dans une DA très jolie.
Le jeu est divisé en trois zones distinctes, qui s'enchainent avec une narration fluide.

La durée de vie étant courte (3-4 heures), à prendre vers 10 euros max.
Les amateurs du genre peuvent y aller les yeux fermés.

Joué sur SeriesX, aucun bug rencontré.

Deemo is a fun rhythm game with a good selection of songs to choose from. The gameplay is simple, yet addictive. It's easy to learn but hard to master playing the songs, and requires you to really learn them to play them well on the harder difficulties.

The song selection is great, featuring music from a lot of artists that don't get a lot of attention, as well as some bigger names. Every song fits well, and there are a wide variety of genres to choose from. I do wish they were organized a bit better though, as sorting through them to find a particular song is a bit difficult without the wiki open in front of you.

The presentation is very pleasant and relaxing, while at the same time hiding a lot of deeper meaning. I wish the cutscenes were a bit more in-depth and that we had more time to spend with the characters though.

Overall Score: 7/10

Ziggurat is basically my favorite PvE game so I was really excited to hear that its sequel was released. The biggest upgrade is the removal of vagueness when it comes to perks' effects and damage numbers. Also, they added character models and a vastly improved soundtrack (I'd always mute music in the first game and put on Spotify). The progression system feels rewarding and I like how you can choose your initial loadout instead of having randomly chosen for you after sitting through a loading screen. I'd always just immediately surrender when I initially got a weapon I didn't like in the first one. Overall, I'm really excited to see what this game will become on release. Anyone who plays games like Overwatch and Apex Legends will enjoy this.

EARLY ACCESS REVIEW
I really enjoyed this game. One of my favorite aspects of REDO! is having to map the game world out in your head. The game accommodates this by making the world just small enough that the process of doing that isn't straining whatsoever. By the end of the game you are intimately familiar with the locations and the routes to them which feels very rewarding. The kick down ladder short cuts are a simple but nice touch too because they push you to explore the world to make it more interconnected and easy to navigate. The ladders and the save points feel really good to discover because they are just limited enough to make it feel like you've earned finding them. The art style is fantastic. It can be subdued in a lot of areas but that helps it build up to some of the really impressive rooms you get to explore. The sound design created a very tense and mysterious atmosphere. The combat was really fun to learn. I liked how each item I found that I didn't understand at first had an enemy that it was perfect for. Some were more useful then others, the riot shield felt useless because of the bubble shield and energy beam, but I used every one I obtained for something. I loved the enemy and boss design. The story is the only thing I was hit or miss on. It's serviceable and I liked reading any diary entry I found but it ultimately lead up to an ending that felt like an anti climax. The journey was better than the destination in this case. It's still in early access so maybe the hardcore mode ending will be better.
I recommend it if you like a challenging but fair game.

Most of the puzzles are obtuse af, but this isn't bad overall. I'd say to check it out if you're into puzzle games.

Only real complaint is that about half of the puzzles don't give you any sort of clues or hints as to what to do, and they kinda feel like the devs didn't bother to have non-devs playtest them.

Or maybe I'm just dumb, who knows?

Either way, it's worth a shot - especially since it's only $3.

It's a very interesting game with a great mechanic. Some of the levels are on the right difficulty, but for others it is really unclear how to solve them. If you do eventually give up and look up the answer my response was mostly "how was I suppose to know that" rather than "man I'm an idiot". Though there are also great moments when you discover the unique ways in which you can solve a puzzle.

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Baba is You

reviewText.content: Here is the deal about Baba is You. It is a fantastic idea, no doubt about that. The initial rules are simple, and once you grasp what is asked of you, it becomes fun, but stays challenging. The problem here lies within the complexity and manipulation of the language and its connection to the game. It becomes a guesswork in what you can and can't do, because the rules are not very clear with the increasing complexity. And to me, that was very frustrating. However, I still recommend playing Baba is You, to find if that is your cup of tea. You might just want to play all 200+ levels the game has to offer.

reviews.title: A game that never need a 2

reviewText.content:
Overwatch 2 is a squeal to a game that never needed a squeal.

I personally enjoy the game when I'm not getting railed by the Winston one trick smerf on the other team or when my Lifeweaver teammate is not throwing because of silly haha Twitter and YouTube views. This game can genuinely be fun and enjoyable in the right scenarios. May I also add that just like the weird free mobile app you installed last night that kept pushing ads and shoving microtransactions in your face, Everything in OW2 is optional. From Battle Passes, to skins, to taunts. So from everyone in this review page complaining about the Free-to-Play model that OW2 has taken is completely useless and is not worth complaining about in the first place.

Something I will say is valid to complain about is the PVE that they did promise back in 2019 I believe (That from my understanding started development back in 2016) that is also the only reason for a "2" to be placed at the end of "Overwatch". While the PVE was canceled it's still here and is $15... Remember when I said buying anything in this game is optional I mean this BIG time with the PVE. From what I have seen from PVE on YouTube, the missions are like 15 to 20 minutes long maybe and are not worth the $15 at all. The story the PVE is telling is also just bleh in my opinion. If you like story and want to spend $15 on 3 15-20 minute story missions that are here to tell us lore on a story hundreds of people have been waiting 7 years for that also starts talking about what there "was" but we have not never seen or heard of the story of the "what was Overwatch" then go ahead and slip your 15 into Blizzard's wallet!

Gameplay wise the game is fun, OW2's competitive nature makes it a little angering after a while but it's still fun nonetheless. But back to the "competitive nature" thing I said, Overwatch 2 is a competitive MMO shooter that was made by a company that (from what I know) has never made a competitive shooter in their lives. Nothing can change my opinion of this game being forced to become a competitive game, the facts are all there, Overwatch League is on death support and Half if not most of the competitive streamers have been playing Quick Play and custom games It's mot much but It's enough for me if I get the see the OWL fall to the ground.

Over all this game is good but 1000% needs more improvements to make the game fun and engaging for both casual and competitive sides. If the next hero Blizzard releases follows what happened for the last two heroes of "Oh this hero is shit" or "Damn this hero is overpowered as fuck" for them to be nerfed and be useless or them to be buffed and still be useless.

Update: The seasons are also kinda mid.

Update 2: After BlizzCon 2023 - WE ARE SO FUCKING BACK WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO!!!!!!!!!
5vs5, trash competitive, balancing, grouping, heroe customization, heroes spam voice lines nonstop etc

Graphics= Lights and some details improved
Playability = I think is more balanced now
Queue = some struggling in the beginning but now is better!

The decision to replace the cherished Overwatch (1) servers with Overwatch 2 has left a bitter aftertaste, introducing an overpriced cash shop and an unoriginal, linear battle pass system. Both of these changes appear to prioritize monetization over player satisfaction due to FOMO and inseparable cash shop bundles.

Among the significant letdowns is the abandonment of the promised PvE Hero Missions and power progression. These were initially promoted as the game's unique selling points and the very reasons justifying the sequel. The emphasis has now shifted towards PvP modes. While we did receive Story Missions, they now come at a cost and are going to be infrequent seasonal releases. This absence of Hero Missions and progression creates a void in the gameplay experience, stripping away the anticipated core PvE mode.

While Overwatch 2 retains the vibrant and captivating hero-based shooter that drove its predecessor to success, it stumbles notably in several aspects. Ongoing balance issues, disarray within the competitive scene, role queues, and character skins that often feel like mere cash grabs – straying frequently from the character's theme – all contribute to this setback. Furthermore, game balance itself faces a potential compromise, as new heroes remain inaccessible behind a paywall. As a result, those who choose not to pay may very well find themselves at a disadvantage in certain scenarios.

The game's visual and artistic components continue to amaze with intricate character designs and lively environments. However, these strengths can only go so far in compensating for the content deficiencies.

The potential of the rich and captivating world of Overwatch has been overshadowed by these questionable monetization tactics and lackluster decision-making. The game's unique heroes and villains deserve a better home where their stories and gameplay potential can flourish without being hindered by corporate strategies that prioritize profits over player satisfaction.

reviews.title: Overwatch 2: A Heroic Attempt at Progress Hindered by Monetization

reviewText.content:
Overwatch 2 brings a plethora of new content to the table, including the introduction of new heroes, which expands the already diverse roster. Each new hero is thoughtfully designed with unique abilities and playstyles, adding even more depth to the gameplay. The new maps are visually stunning and showcase a variety of environments, from futuristic cityscapes to ancient ruins. The improved graphics and updated art style make Overwatch 2 a truly immersive experience.

A significant addition to Overwatch 2 is the inclusion of a story mode, allowing players to delve deeper into the game's lore and experience the narrative from their favorite heroes' perspectives. The story mode features engaging missions and cinematic cutscenes, which help to flesh out the game's universe and provide more context to the ongoing battles.

However, the shift towards a more free-to-play model has introduced an overemphasis on monetization, with numerous in-game purchases for cosmetics and other content. While some players may not mind these options, others may feel that the game is pushing too hard to make a profit, detracting from the overall experience.

Furthermore, the decision to shut down the Overwatch servers for Overwatch 2 has been met with mixed reactions from the community. While it is understandable that Blizzard wants to focus on their new release, this move has left dedicated Overwatch players feeling abandoned and frustrated.

Good game not gonna lie
people are hating cuz why a 2 ?
but in fact
thats still a good game
Got 6 accounts banned for no reason. Useless bot in the customer service.

reviews.title: turtledsloth's review of Mia and the Dragon Princess

reviewText.content: game sucks. horrible story, terrible acting, bad decision options

Prodeus is a great representation of classic first person shooter game.
Game has it all - graphical design, music, different weapons, different enemies, level design and other stuff.

Graphic blends into a perfect imagination of classic FPS with a modern look on it. Pixel art is very smooth and complements the game.

Andrew Hulshult is composer here, he literally consumed every important part of different music that infuenced him and created exact sound that we need to hear through the meatgrinder FPS game. You can also know him by his work in Dusk, Quake Champions, Doom Eternal and other projects.
For me - music is a core for such game genre.

You can find different weapons for your taste - pistols, minigun, rocket launcher, plasma rifle, shotgun etc.

Level design is quite good in Prodeus, it never feels repetative, it pushes you to play game forward.

So if you're looking for some really smooth FPS experience and incredible music - this game is for you.
A great FPS, quick, deadly and nostalgic. No BS, just a bullet hell and many deaths :)

Fait en solo je le ferai à l'occas en coop local, ce qui sera je pense plus intéressant.
Pas mal de  scoring et trucs à collectionner pour les amateurs du genre (perso je passe mon tour).

If you like "parkour" 3D platformers there is absolutely no reason not to play this game. It utilizes some simple mechanics - with the grappling hook being the primary one  - to offer some fun swinging and jumping in a cyber/outrun aesthetic.
If you have played "A Story About My Uncle", this one feels like its hardcore version (both in the setting and the gameplay). With that being said, I have one mildly important reason to be a bit disappointed by it. One of my biggest pet peeves in video games is when the difficulty scales exponentially towards the end, just to prolong the ending a little bit more. Whether this was done intentionally or not, the level design changed drastically from open spaces that offer different routes to achieve better times (in accordance with its "speedrunning" tag), to confined box-like spaces with insta-death "lava" surroundings, warping its identity from an open speedrunning platformer to a precision, muscle memory based, "learn by losing" platformer. While I generally don't mind the latter, it felt like a poor way to handle level design and scaling difficulty, forcing me to finish it with a feeling of doing a chore.
The story is very basic and doesn't even finish properly. I cannot complain too much since this is not what you're looking for in this genre. Controls are very responsive and a joy to adapt to. Music and graphics very atmospheric, I noticed no drawbacks on these aspects.

reviews.title: akr90sgamer's review of Shalnor Legends: Sacred Lands

reviewText.content:
I picked this and another game, Vosaria: Lair of the Forgotten, on sale for the Xbox One in 2020. From trailers and pictures they looked like similar games from another major game company. I bring up the date. I played through the mentioned game first. It was short, a good challenge, and did not take me exorbitantly long to complete. I moved on to this one. According to submitted prior playthroughs, this should take around 15 hours. My first playthrough is tracked as almost 35. This may be skewed by how I ended up playing only a half hour then taking a few weeks away and end up redoing the same part several times. Real time speaking it did take me a couple years at that pace to play through the story on normal.
At first it felt real good. Armed with a bow and sword you go on your quest. Right away you will find that certain things will require a change of day to trigger. The mechanic of this is beds scattered all over. These are quite frequent and generous. Not only do they serve a function of day/night change, but also saving and restoring health. Believe me, testing out how far you can go without saving was a factor in the higher time it took me.
There's 9 different sections of the game, making up 4 environments and major parts. After completing the first part, you will likely be pretty filled to capacity with all the items carrying. Time to start upgrades. This is one of the problems I have. There's only a few options to choose at first and you can only really pick one. It'll take all your gold for that one. Then you have to go back around grinding for gold again.
At this point you will probably just want to progress the story to the next section. This is where I found the difficulty start to increase. Enemies start coming at you more often, they're faster, and take a lot more damage to defeat. Here is where you also find the standard pattern for the game. Fight through the first section, collecting 4 pieces before going to the next part to retrieve the part stating you passed to unlock the last trial. During this part of collecting the four pieces in the first section, you have to go talk to the merchant who is selling one of the parts for pretty much your maximum capacity of gold. I would be remiss to point out that no section is significantly huge and can be reached in a minute roughly once unlocked. Other than going back for upgrades, they are easily completed in one stretch and not needed again.
I thought the enemy difficulty steeply increased after the second part, and found myself having trouble with progressing to the next little without stopping save point to save point. Couple that with a boss battle that required a lot of patience, while being battling with below intended power, made it very easy for me to drop the game for weeks at a time. After I got past the one boss I went and upgraded some of my stats and found it was a little easier to complete the game. My only problem at that point was finding a good solid enough time to make it through.
Overall I found it a nice clone of a similar well known series. Given the way I played the first time I would not do that again. The difficulty increases makes it frustrating to want to continue on with low powered abilities. I do consider this about a three and a half star game (on a five point scale). The retro graphic style look good, music not very memorable, combat could be better with some defensive abilities other than just absorbing hits, and without having a big wallet early, it can be a grind to be able to get all the upgrades necessary to have a great amount of enjoyment. I do recommend it for the price I paid which was 99 cents when it was on sale, and in a way it supports the indie development.

I played this many years ago, almost entirely because it was free and I had nothing else. It's simply a zombie survival game, it doesn’t do anything exceptional, it doesn’t have great graphics or a story, but it's free so what more could you ask for. It's possible to even play with friends, if one decides to make a server. Don’t forget the mods as well.
 
Story
As I said, no story. There is some lore as far as I have heard, but it's so obscure in the many hours I played I never thought to look for it.
 
Mechanics and gameplay
Have you ever played a survival game, like the ones where there is hunger, and you have to watch out for some kind of danger, and maybe there is also building? Well then, you’ve practically played Unturned. In, I would say, boil down almost any survival game to its core and you get Unturned.
That’s not to say I didn’t have any fun. There is no end goal, but for the 20 to 30 hours I spent simply building up my base and getting better gear, I was entertained. After a while, the realization that I was building up towards nothing came to me and I stopped playing.
 
Graphics and artstyle
I once saw someone refer to this game as “Minecraft with zombies”, which, ignoring the irony, give you an idea as to the graphical quality that should be expected.
 
Atmosphere/Immersion  
I still like Unturned after all it was part of my childhood. That’s why I can’t really say anything about its atmosphere – I can’t tell what’s real and what’s just nostalgia.
 
Soundtrack
I barely remember the ost. I can recall just one song “Unturned theme song” so I guess that’s also my favourite.
 
Final Thoughts
Even after all these years, those zombies can still scare me.

As a fan of "Valkyrie Profile" I thought this game would be my jam. It's main combat gameplay is heavily borrowed from that game and it does well for the most part.
However, the game is far too long (30h and a large part is still to come) and the gameplay gets very repetitive. Combat breaks down to a blocking phase and an attacking phase. To succeed in the harder battles, you have to master the timed perfect block mechanic. The attack phase is more freeform with one button associated to one of the 4 party members. There are a lot of party members you can recruit with different moves and abilities. It is fun to try out the different characters and how they can create combos with each other.
Unfortunately, this got very repetitive for me. Many of the enemies have a large health pool and thus take very long. They also respawn each time you revisit an area and you cannot flee from combat once it has started.
The areas are diverse but you have to revisit them a few times which also got on my nerver.
played the hell of this game until my cheap intel hd graphics laptop's plastic shell turned into slag (which usually happens during the 40 min mark)

Graveyard Keeper is a Grind game which you can relax while playing so it does not need a lot of hand eye coordination.

There are a lot of good about this game, the pace you upgrade and unlock things, the art, the music.

Now you are playing and having fun, slowly unlocking and upgrading yourself, your church and your land. When this sense of advancing becomes max you think "while I wait to continue with the story I can upgrade my business'" the game just gives itself and ends abruptly. And the ending is as far away form an satisfying ending as could be.

If you want a grinding game while you relax this is a good game, but the game is far away from its final state.

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Needy Streamer Overload

reviewText.content:
On its face, Need Streamer Overload (Needy Girl Overdose in Japan) seems like a very simple management/visual novel hybrid about managing an anime girl's life as a streamer. Getting further into the game, one finds complexity both mechanically and thematically that make the game rise above others.

The simple mechanics of the game quickly open up, requiring the player to balance many competing stats in order to keep OMGkawaiiAngel happy and healthy. Also important is the deadline of 30 days to gain 1 million subscribers. These factors elevate the game above a simple visual novel into a management game that is very satisfying to play.

Where the game really shines is portraying the emotions and mental state of the streamer. The game tackles a lot of complex issues like depression, drug abuse, and loneliness. These themes get related to internet culture in a way that not a lot of games have tackled. The multitude of endings really allow the player to fully explore the streamer's mental state and provide tones of replayability.

The game's music and graphics complement each other really well, offering up a retro-modern vibe that is really enjoyable. The music will also mold to the streamer's emotional state, which is a nice touch.

Overall Score: 9/10

reviews.title: LostTenshi_04's review of Needy Streamer Overload

reviewText.content:
The recent growth of technology, especially the internet, has raised an incredible amount of debates and fears about its effects on people and consequences on society in the short and long term. Although there are quite a few works in the art world that deal with the problems or results of the information society, in the medium of video games, it is not a concept that has been explored in many titles. Of course, there are works like "I Have No Mouth and I Must Scream," based on the novel of the same name by Harlan Ellison, which, like other titles, delves into the idea of AIs taking over the world and human extinction. Most video games always take the post-apocalyptic side of the technology revolution, acquiring fatalistic and existentialist tones in most cases.

However, I had never seen a game that dealt with the consequences and current problems of society, instead of a dystopian future. This is the case of the video game "Needy Girl Overdose," which defines itself as an interactive visual novel, presenting a critique of the internet and the figure of the streamer, wanting to present mature and dark themes despite its cute aesthetics, based on Japanese anime.

This video game puts us in the skin of P-chan, our avatar and direct representation within the game as it has no gender or face, to serve as a direct bridge to Ame, the true protagonist of the story. And this is quite important because the whole game is based on Ame's relationship with the player and depends deeply on us getting fond of Ame, as technically, according to the narrative of the title, we are her partner.

The purpose of the game itself is to get Ame to fulfill her dream of being a streamer, giving you the direct orders of what to do to spend her time in pursuit of getting a million subscribers. You can do different activities, such as hanging out together, researching in forums, watching movies, or, of course, streaming.

The target audience for this game is apparently the gamer and otaku community, seeming at first glance (if you do not read the description of the game) a romantic title to have a good time. However, "Needy Girl Overdose" characterizes Ame as an adult with psychological problems and a childish mentality. She had a hard childhood because of school bullying, a bad relationship with her parents, and an incredible internet addiction that led her to become a "Neet," that is, a person who has left school and does not work and usually dedicates herself exclusively to her hobbies.

It is almost funny how ironic it is that the target audience of this title is the object of criticism and mockery in it, as the game takes the opportunity on numerous occasions to show the selfishness, arrogance, and the need for attention of the protagonist, as well as the avoidance of reality to which Ame herself voluntarily submits.

This character in itself is a critical commentary, mainly towards certain "social tribes" of generation Z and later, showing the consequences of the information society on the personality and education of a young girl. Not only through its script, which we will talk about in more detail later, but also through its game mechanics.

As we said before, you, as a player, decide what Ame does. Each of the actions you do has a time cost, and you have a limit of 30 days to reach your goals. The activities you do will not only serve you to have new ideas for streamings but also have a direct impact on the statistics of Ame.

"Needy Girl Overdose" is played in a similar way to "Reigns." In "Reigns," you make decisions that increase or decrease some of your resources: military power, religious power, money, and population.
