If any of these resources reaches its maximum or minimum, you lose the game. Ame works in the same way as your kingdom in "Reigns," but its statistics are stress, affection, and mental state. Each of the activities you can do with her positively or negatively affects more than one of her stats in most cases. If you stream, it raises stress and lowers affection; if you spend time with her, it lowers stress but raises affection; if you take drugs with her, it lowers stress and raises her mental state, etc. The large number of actions you have at your disposal, the 30-day time limit, and the fact that each action affects different stats make "Needy Girl Overdose" a stressful experience due to the difficulty you have to manage her emotions, making this an unpleasant experience is actually a wise move as it exemplifies the fluctuating mental state of a person with psychological disorders and insecurities with a dependent relationship towards your person, portraying a toxic relationship of self-imposed emotional submission in which you are complicit.

During the course of the days, Ame will talk to you on the phone (despite living in the same house), being the main way in which the narrative develops, talking to you at all hours and scolding you if you do not answer. Messages, most of which you can only reply to using stickers, not only continue with the idea that Ame has a deep dependency on P-chan but also make a satirical comment on the almost parasocial relationships that are established between young people, communicating primarily through images. A situation in which I myself find portrayed. The narrative of this title develops mainly with text messages in the in-game equivalent to WhatsApp, in addition to what Ame speaks in streaming and the tweets she puts in the equivalent of Twitter. Each of the three forms gives rise to different comments and subtexts about the person/internet interaction.

During the Streamings, Ame takes the nickname "Kangel," disguising and making herself up as a Japanese idol, putting on a figurative mask and adopting a completely different personality, much more friendly and self-confident, to please her audience, which she rarely breaks. Continuing the topic of fakeness in social networks, but what is really interesting about the streamings is the chat that you have to moderate by deleting negative messages. The script of the chat during Kangel's live streams is incredibly well written. Each of the messages looks like a comment from a random person on the internet. They are poorly written, use abbreviations and foul language, which gives a layer of immersion and reality that the game needs to keep playing with its credibility. Likewise, Ame's dialogues are brilliantly thought out, just like the chat. She writes in abbreviations, with misspellings, using insults and expressions clearly used by the 2000s generation onwards, which in the same way, contributes to the credibility and immersion of the character as a real person. This is really important to feel the right emotions in this game.

While on Twitter, you, as P-chan, can read both her public account as Kangel and her private account as Ame, showing both sides of the same coin.

When we combine the stressful gameplay with the storyline, then we begin to see the true colors of this game and its critical commentary. A young adult, completely in need of attention on social networks, with an extreme dependence on her partner, a perfect and untouchable facade as Kangel and another completely needy as Ame, who goes to the extreme of self-harm, drug abuse, and nymphomania in order to stay on the Hamster wheel of constant dopamine stimuli, all of them directly or indirectly due to the internet addiction she had since childhood.

Although it is true that the approach to the idea of this game is incredibly striking, especially considering the times we live in, and its approach in its gameplay is correct when it comes to generating adequate sensations regarding the subtext of the narrative, the truth is that "Needy Girl Overdose" fails to get its message across.

Let me explain. Even if I defend what I said above, "Needy Girl Overdose" has about 30 different endings depending on Ame's stats and our actions during the 30 days of gameplay. Although the description of the game itself encourages us to find a good ending, being all bad endings in reality, the game fails catastrophically when it comes to achieving a catharsis or, in general, a powerful emotion with any of these. Mainly due to the fact that the endings do not unfold in the narrative bit by bit due to the very nature of this title; rather, they are the spontaneous consequence of your statistics or your actions. In other words, when day 30 arrives, you have your ending, but on the way, there doesn't have to be any kind of conversation that has led to that point. For example, even if you have an ending where Ame breaks up with you because she has little affection for you, during the other 29 days of the game, she has not expressed that lack of affection in almost any way. It is true that the lack of love for you is a direct cause of your actions, but on a storyline level, there is almost no hint of the ending you're going to get because "Needy Girl Overdose" doesn't develop the conclusion of the route during the days you play. You simply see the end results, breaking the immersion in the world and character. Also, this gets the endings to not have the impact it should. For example, although all the endings are supposed to be bad, some of them seem good or neutral due to their lack of development. Similarly, some endings that in script are positive, the game itself poses them as bad endings or Game Overs, again, thanks to its lack of development.

It is surprising how the game gets it right for 29 days and then fails in its climax due to a design error from the early approach of the development. Also, the fact that there are 30 endings is a problem in itself because although this achieves a very organic and different first experience for each player, its script suffers for the same reason, in addition to the fact that the endings themselves eventually step on each other with similar concepts diluting the meaning of them. If you take this game as an experience in which you are only going to live a couple of endings, doing only a couple of routes, then you will not see these seams as clearly as I see them. However, the game itself encourages you to get all the endings, as the game load menu itself shows you a list with clues of all possible endings and confirming the existence of a secret ending when you get them all, which, without spoilers, is tremendously unsatisfying to experience for its obtuse dialogue and its lack of depth in the message.

Even so, the end of a piece of art is nothing more than the final touch to it. Although they seem to me to be badly carried out, they have the ideas in place just like the rest of the game. And even if this one fails to develop many of the issues it wants to deal with (which are not few), "Needy Girl Overdose" is a breath of fresh air with respect to the criticism of the digital world, dealing with issues that I never saw portrayed before within the video game industry. So all in all, this title gets my respects. Plus, a tiny little hole in my heart, thanks to its way of exemplifying the flaws that unfortunately my generation has developed because of digitalization, including myself.

You wake up, shut off the alarm, and check your phone.  You straighten your tie, brush your teeth, push down your hair and realize you are already late for work.  Day in, day out…the tedious grind of the life as a cog in the machine.  But one day something happens as you make your way to work, something that, ultimately, challenges your life as you know it and opens the door to something different.

Mosaic is a narrative-driven modern ‘adventure’ game where you play as a cog in the corporate world.  You wake up, brush your teeth and head to your job where you perform meaningless tasks day after day.  Mosaic has a beautiful art style with a drab color palette and blocky faceless characters that works well with the story it is trying to tell.  Through the gameplay you will run across things that brighten your spirit and those are represented by intense colors which seem jarring and out of place at first but are designed on purpose.  In addition, there are interesting and fun perspective puzzles which leave you just as confused as the protagonist and figuring out how to complete them is part of the fun.

However, while beautiful and interesting in many places, Mosaic has its problems.  The game is rather dull throughout most of the runtime and, when coupled with the slowness of the character, leads to frustration.  And while this may be the main point of Mosaic, the dullness of modernity and daily life, it doesn’t translate well into a game.  There are other issues with Mosaic, minor really when compared to the tedious gameplay, such as uninteresting achievements, slow progress, predictable ending, and high price tag.  It’s not to say that the game is bad, but Mosaic has some issues and may be too “artsy” for many people.

As for achievements…well, Mosaic has them.  All of the achievements are attained from the in-game diversion called Blipblop, a game that distills all mobile games into their pure form: repeatedly tapping the screen.  While it was fun for a while it quickly lost its glamor as time progressed.  Some of the achievements for this are easy others are extravagantly time consuming to attain.  While I normally would go after all the achievements there are several in Mosaic that are, quite frankly not worth my time and nobody should have to spend hours and hours clicking a button repeatedly just to get a perfect game.

Strong concept, mediocre execution; the game’s appeal is mostly in the visual design rather than the actual gameplay.  Mosaic is a very short game that some may enjoy and certainly others will not.  It does bring a message, even if a bit thin, but I would recommend waiting for Mosaic to be on sale before diving into this bleak world as the asking price is a bit steep for this type of game.

You are sent to a space station in orbit around a strange planet where a small three-person crew has mysteriously gone missing while studying a sentient alien civilization.  It up to you, a recon specialist, to figure out what happened to the crew of this malfunctioning station.  Walk the mysterious dark hallways, enter the rooms of the crew and snoop around, perform tasks to fix the station, and keep your wits about you as you work on solving the mystery of The Station.

The Station is a short, first-person exploration game where you complete various projects and solve puzzles in order to access different parts of the station, thus helping to complete the story.  The story is quite rich indeed with little pieces hidden everywhere just waiting to be found if you investigate a bit.  When added with the sound logs you can puzzle together more information on the mystery.

Overall this was an enjoyable game with beautiful graphics and an engaging story.  My only issue with The Station was that it was very short; but the story, the puzzles, and the graphics made up for its short run time.  The Station was a fun game where the clever puzzles and perfect space-mystery atmosphere was a joy to play and I look forward to more games like this from the developers!

Jeu orienté plateforme 3D exploration sans combat, la prise en main est intuitive et ne fait plus lâcher la manette.
Nos petits amis avec leurs pouvoirs permettent d''explorer de plus en plus de zones d'un niveau au fur et à mesure qu'on les accumule.
Simple dans le principe, la réalisation soignée donne un vrai plaisir à résoudre les énigmes proposées et chercher les secrets dans tous les coins. Addictif !

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

This is easily one of the more enjoyable games i've had played recently. Only discovering it from Steam's Demo Fest as one of my more anticipated indie games for the year. It did hold up to my expectations. Mostly taking elements of other games like Pikmin & Mario Odyssey, making it with its own unique twist to it. The controls for it being tight & responsive.

The whole premise of it is that you're an alien that crashed into a house, and you're trying to repair yourself a ship to go back home. The general atmosphere that this game gives off is similar to 'Honey, I shrunk the kids' where you are exploring this massive human-sized room to you as the insect-sized player. there are plenty to chew in content with there being 3 side missions to the actual objective, along with collecting pollen.

Each room in the house is littered to the brim with Tinykins. They act much like pikmin with the five types of tinykins that are in each of them come with their own unique abilities; ranging from igniting things up to flames, levitating, however they will not carry over level to level.

The Pollen in-game is the equivalent to Gems in the spyro trilogy in which they are spread around the entire room. Once you pickup a certain amount that is listed, you go and get a new bubble to levitate longer than you normally would. After that it's all extra from there to just to say "I've done and seen everything" with a cheevo to add on top of that.

In terms with my least favorite things about Tinykin is all honestly, it felt like it just was too short. As soon as you start to get your last new ability with one of the tinykins' it just feels like once you get past the other two levels left (including the one you are introduced to it) it feels almost left emptied out. With a game like this where it puts it's collectathon inspiration proudly on it's chest. I would personally love to master this title but it just feels like it's an a chore to do that when all you have left is searching around a level for the last dozen pollen that could possibly be anywhere, maybe something like an attachment to the binoculars where you can spot out where the last remaining pollen would at least make things more easier on mastering this game.

I can easily recommend this game whole-heartily, especially if you love the 3D Platformers/Collect-a-thons. Definitely something that you could finish over a weekend. Hope that there is plenty of stuff to be added more in the future.

What a twisted little gem, oozing with putrid freshness :D
I can't think of something i randomly picked up such as this and be so delighted as fitting my interests so spot on. 
If you're a fan of anything horror, in particular of David Cronenberg's early work, play this. 

This is so... satisfying.

Boa noite, excelentíssimos! Hoje vou postar a minha resenha do Carrion!

Desde que vi o anúncio dele em um dos shows surtados que a Devolver Digital faz na E3 fiquei muito interessado, mas acabei apenas pegando para jogar agora que assinei o Xbox Game Pass.

Pra começar, Carrion é um jogo de “terror reverso”. Mas o que seria isso? É um jogo que dá medo?! Peraí, veja só a premissa do jogo: uma massa monstruosa, composta de incontáveis tentáculos e bocas com dentes afiados,  escapa da cápsula de um laboratório onde estava sendo estudada e sai por aí destruindo tudo e todos que aparecem em seu caminho até a liberdade. Aterrorizante? Nem tanto, por que quem controla o monstro é você!

A mecânica principal do jogo aparece quando você percebe que dependendo do seu tamanho você recebe um kit de poderes diferentes, mas ao mesmo tempo altera o tamanho da sua vida. Para crescer você precisará devorar humanos, e para diminuir você poderá depositar um pedaço de sua massa em locais específicos do mapa. Controlar o seu tamanho é necessário para ultrapassar obstáculos, ou também para escolher como passar por inimigos altamente armados. Algumas sessões de combate poderão parecer desbalanceadas, mas desde que você se lembre de salvar constantemente isso não chegará a ser frustrante.

Existe apenas um tipo de objetivo opcional, que é o de encontrar todas as Unidades de Contenção, grandes cápsulas que, ao serem quebradas, melhoram algum de seus poderes. Estas unidades estão bem escondidas, normalmente sendo necessário que você tenha que atravessar uma grande parte do mapa para um lugar que era previamente inacessível. Por causa disso acabei não encontrando quase nenhuma quando joguei, portanto os upgrades não são necessários para avançar na história principal, que é bem superficial. 

Por ser um indie o jogo é bem baratinho, mas também curto, provavelmente levando uma média de 5 horas para alcançar os 100%, o que não é uma coisa ruim. Pela sua simplicidade senti que o jogo tem o tamanho perfeito para não ficar enjoativo, tendo até uma DLC grátis chamada Greatest Time Of Year (Melhor Época do Ano) para quem quiser jogar um pouco mais. A DLC dura por volta de 1 hora.

No final das contas Carrion é um jogo muito divertido pra quem gosta de coisas bizarras, e quer algo simples e barato pra passar algumas horas.

Le gros point positif est pour moi le gameplay et la sensation manette en main, c'est très jouissif de contrôler ce monstre :)
Avec 3 formes possibles et des capacités différentes à chacune, le gameplay est plus varié que ce qu'on peut penser, avec des approches tantôt bourrines tantôt plus subtiles (sans spoiler). Les ennemis humains varient également le long du jeu, et la difficulté en général plutôt simple fait qu'on avance rapidement dans le jeu. Quelques "énigmes" à bases d'interrupteurs viennent également ponctuer le jeu.
La durée de vie est honnête pour le prix ~5h pour le jeu, 1 ou 2 pour le DLC 'noël' gratuit.
C'est beau pixel art, plein de détails et avec une ambiance graphique mais surtout sonore très bien travaillée.
Pas le jeu du siècle mais une bonne surprise donc :)

Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass

Guilty or innocent?  Divinely guided or demonically possessed?  These are some of the questions you will ask as you find yourself trapped in a terrifying journey as a priest on a quest to prove his innocence.  Sin, guilt, and shame are explored as you traverse heaven, hell, and the indistinguishable realm in between that is the Gray Dawn.

Gray Dawn is classified as a Religious Horror; a little used theme for games and the first one of this subgenre that I have played.  I was impressed, horrified, fascinated, and sickened—all in a good way.  Gray Dawn is a feast for the eyes in a first-person surreal world with photo-realistic realms overflowing with religious iconography, blood, and grotesquery.  The game doesn’t hold your hand; instead you must figure out what to do next and solve simple puzzles.  While Gray Dawn is heavy on the atmosphere and story it is sadly light on the gameplay itself and I would have liked to have more puzzles to solve.

The story unfolds in a somewhat disjointed manner and the tale can seem a bit muddled at times.  You will be left with questions at the end of Gray Dawn, but I feel that this was the goal of the developers as a way to match the atmosphere of the game.  The sound of Gray Dawn works well with the game—singing choirs, deep somber chords, and angelic sounds; but the voice acting was not the best (with a few exceptions) and the voice acting sometimes detracted from the overall experience.

Achievements are easy to get as most of them are based on the story.  However, a few can be easily missed on the first playthrough and you will want to replay the game one more time to get the rest of the achievements and the alternate ending. 

Playing Gray Dawn is like walking though someone’s nightmare.  I found the game horrific and entertaining, and Gray Dawn easily kept my interest for the three hours that I spent experiencing a nightmare landscape and horrific story.  I recommend this game for those who may be interested in a good horror game that will stick with you for quite some time afterwards.

Those that may be triggered by religious symbols, both the sacred and profane, along with those who do not want to listen to religious ideology, or those that may be upset by violent images that include children should probably avoid Gray Dawn.  However, if you are interested in a unique and memorable experience go ahead and give it a try.

Regular game. Not worth its price.
There was a good concept at work here, but it failed to deliver.
The story was very cryptic but resolved itself in a terrible cliché, therefore the abstract comings and goings between chapters were meaningless. 
The game has 0 replayability. Max 5 hours worth of gameplay.
It's basically a walking simulator, but with terrible (and easy) puzzles.
The art is interesting but graphics are outdated. Animation is so horrible it breaks the emotional impact and your involvement in the game.
Soundtrack is regular, when present. Sometimes it's like the game misses sound cues for certain events and nothing is played when a sound is expected.

reviews.title: Plus une expérience psyché qu'un jeu

reviewText.content:
Expérience cosmique musico-psychédélique, la réalisation impeccable et psyché finie rapidement par se noyer dans sa surenchère d'effets et son manque de narration.
Pendant une poignée d'heure on enchaine les scènes "spectateur", des phases de "walking simulateur" et des puzzles sur base de logique "point'n click".
La fin est malheureusement presque un soulagement tellement ca fini par partir dans tous les sens et ne ressembler à rien.

Joué sur SeriesX via le gamepass.

The game gives you a lot of what you've been missing from jet ski sims - but also simply nothing surprisingly positive. The game doesn't keep the ambition alive for long, even though it includes numerous tracks and vehicles.
this game is sweet and easy to play, no matter when you start playing you never feel like your behind. it's cozy cute,

It's not skill based: You follow the arrows and press A, then listen to a joke. Sometimes there is no way to know what you need to do, but the arrows point you in the right direction. It's not always clear the exact spot you need to stand to progress. It's very automatic, mindless fun.

There are occasional 3D platforming skills needed. It's basically a parody of cop movies. The locations keep changing, the dialogue is funny and it's not hard, so it's amusing. The missions can feel pretty long, however. There were also a few bugs, like during the first chase where I couldn't steer until I reset the mission manually.

Fait à sa sortie et refait en 2014, le moteur 3D tient encore étonnamment bien la route, notamment pour l'incrustation des objets "interactifs" dans les décors. L'histoire reste intéressante, les mécanismes de gameplay sont classiques, et mis à part les déplacements parfois un peu longs, le jeu a gardé tout son charme, le game design et l'ambiance en générale restant très agréables. Les énigmes sont la plupart du temps faciles, à part quelque unes qui demanderont un peu plus de réflexion et de temps (rien d'insurmontable).

reviews.title: J'aurais aimé aimer Fe mais non

reviewText.content:
J'aurais aimé aimer Fe mais non, y'a pas moyen d'aller au bout de ce jeu.

Dans les plus il y a la direction artistique, l'univers créé, le dialogue pour le son, ... sur la forme tout ca donne envie de se lancer dans le jeu et de découvrir son histoire.

Malheureusement entre une caméra trop proche qui est parfois casse pied, une maniabilité parfois peu précise, une obscurité parfois génante et surtout un level design complétement raté ca rebute. Le level design est beaucoup en verticalité ; sauf qu'il faut sans cesse faire plein de détour parfois peu intuitif, et que le moindre saut raté fait revenir en bas avec toute la montée à refaire. Perso l'escalade du grand cerf m'a gavé et fait jeter l'éponge.
Il manque clairement des explications sur les objectifs et les actions attendues, pour ne pas tourner en rond de façon désagréable.

Dommage car ce jeu avait du potentiel !

(Joué sur SeriesX via le Game Pass)

The game itself is great, but has many problems in its development that annoys me.

Many bugs and problems to connect to other players and the lack of major improvements are kind of a disappointment.

There are many games inspired in Among Us (like Suspects) that are getting a better support
I have played both the mobile and switch version and can say that that it is pretty fun for what it is. The Switch/console version is super mediocre, though.

Petit jeu de plateforme très mimi, qui se laisse jouer avec plaisir.
Parfois un peu approximatif dans les contrôles, un peu court, on prend quand même plaisir jusqu'au bout à suivre cette aventure :)

Joué sur SeriesX via les jeux gold du game pass.

A story-driven game about a group of misfits being gifted a mecha called Cowboy and then trying to climb the ranks of a fighting tournament with it. The dialogue can be lengthy sometimes, but the story was great, the characters had depth, and the turn-based mecha fights were fun and satisfying. You play as the protagonist, Dominic Shade, who manages Team Cowboy. Throughout the game, more of Shade's backstory will reveal itself, showing the player how he ended up reuniting with his close friends, Knife and Duque. Players can customize Cowboy with different kinds of parts that each have their own drawbacks and advantages, and the pilot, Knife Leopard, can equip various moves and stances, allowing the player to develop their own mecha-fighting playstyle throughout the game. Almost the entire game has high-quality voice acting. It also has a unique and stylish art style. Overall, Wolfstride was an experience that was like no other game for me, and I believe that it's a highly underrated indie gem.

This game starts with a murder, and you're the detective that arrives to solve the case. Sounds simple. But as you start to question the inhabitants of the small town Pineview, you soon realise that the game has much more to offer than a 'whodunnit' crime investigation.

You'll learn much about life in the idyllic small town, every character you meet adds a bit of their own perspective and story. If you enjoy to learn about the motivations and backgrounds of different people, you'll enjoy this game!

It's about the big questions in life, relationships, and how to deal with sad events that happened in the past. But the investigation also progresses, the further you are into the game. I'd say if you invest one or two hours, you'll get hooked, and the game takes you on a wild ride: Down into the valleys of sadness and up into the clouds of wholesomeness and inner peace.
Fun for a while but after a couple hours you have experienced everything the game has to offer. Still kinda fun to build unique team comps with champs available.

reviews.title: twobears79's review of The Stillness of the Wind

reviewText.content:
An old woman on a homestead in the middle of nowhere spends her days collecting eggs, tending her garden, and turning goat milk into cheese.  From time to time a traveler arrives at the homestead bringing news from the outside world as well as trade goods that the old woman might need.  Reminiscing over her life, the old lady lives in loneliness as the days become shorter as Fall quickly turns into Winter.

The Stillness of the Wind is a third person limited farming simulator where you will harvest items in and around your small farm.  A traveler will appear almost daily to bring you news of the outside world, deliver any mail that you may have received, and trade for seeds, chickens, or items that you don’t really need.  The main theme of the game is routine, and you will eventually develop a limited routine that will apply throughout your time in the game.  Controls are extremely easy (mostly falling on the point and click spectrum) and the game can be completed in a couple of hours.

The game is quite beautiful with a charming design and soothing soundtrack but do not expect exciting gameplay.  The stillness of the Wind is an awkward mix of cozy game and artsy storytelling where your repetitive tasks are affected by a decaying world with nothing that can be done to stop the inevitable.  On top of the repetitiveness of the game; the story is chock full of pretentious writing which, with the secondary story being confusing, only adds to the frustrating nature of a game that could have been good but sadly missed its mark.

The game prides itself on abstractness; from the world around the main character to the letters received daily from her friends and family.  However, too much abstractness can cause a lack of interest as well.  While I did look forward to receiving mail from strange and distant lands; the stories meant nothing to me and those letters, which were meant to expound upon the world, simply were a distraction from tedious chores around the farm.

It is important to note that there are no achievements for this game.

I found The Stillness of the Wind to be more of a chore to complete than something I was excited to play.  While the art is beautiful the gameplay is tedious and slow.  I honestly feel that The Stillness of the Wind would have been better as an animated short film, but as a game it is just a frustrating experience.  As such, I would not recommend The Stillness of the Wind unless you are really interested in experimental games that offer monotonous experiences or, perhaps, want to try your hand at raising digital chickens.

reviews.title: gatorbox's review of Angels with Scaly Wings

reviewText.content: I remember this game from so long ago that it was named "Dragon Dating Simulator". It eventually got a name change and tidied itself up to be more of a visual novel than a dating sim but I was still interested in it nonetheless. This game tells the story of how humans contacted a world of dragons by way of opening a portal to a parallel dimension. Now the humans and dragons work together and exchange knowledge and technology, but there is something amiss with the relationship. It's not all its made out to be. While going about your business in the dragon world there are a number of partners you can court (the player character's gender is never defined) and depending upon how you handle your interactions you'll be rewarded with CG's of the dragons in various poses and situations, none of it being explicitly pornographic however. While this is going on there's the main plot line to keep up with and it threatens to end your dragon romances and this ends with a culmination of all the main characters meeting in the same place to hash things out. I won't spoil the ending I got but I'll just say I think it was the worst possible ending in the game. Angels With Scaly Wings has been out for seven years but its companion comic "Angels With Broken Hearts" is still running and the developer is working on having plush toys made of the more popular characters as I write this review. Angels With Scaly Wings is still very much alive in 2023. It's a unique visual novel with a compelling story and I definitely think it's worth diving into if you have the time.

reviews.title: griha24's review of The Many Pieces of Mr. Coo

reviewText.content:
𝟕,𝟑/𝟏𝟎☕
Nothing unusual, just another extremely surreal point-and-click quest),
not everything is directly drawn by hand, a combination with real photographs is used, but there are enough funny moments, and the drawing clearly refers to classic cartoons,
At first I thought that the name meant the versatility of Mr. "Coo", but no, everything turned out to be much simpler) although .. who knows,
The game, of course, is not as surprising as "Chuchel",
Just a couple of cute sketches with black humor, on which the author has been working for 6 years, it is ideal to complete it for breakfast in 1.5-2 hours and get a boost of energy for the day, it’s impossible to refund this.
The difficulty is medium, increasing, but there are hints for each compartment of the level, but not always clear.

Bugs! - To Devs: Personally, I encountered 2 soft locks that caused me to reload a section, for example, when I clicked on a point very far from the character, and mr. ku just stuck in place, not understanding how to get through. Also, in principle, not everywhere on earth you can click to move, which confuses and makes you engage in "pixel hunting" sometimes. In the interface menu, it is generally not clear what this or that button is responsible for.

😊Subscribe on my Steam`s Curator`s page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550/

Сюжет в этой игре не имеет большого значения, но все же, для полноты картины расскажу. Мы играем за напарника, или же за друга какого-то наблюдателя, который решил отойти ненадолго, оставив нас за главного. Перед выходом он попросил ничего не трогать. Вот и весь сюжет. В игре есть, если не ошибаюсь, 25 концовок. Некоторые из них довольно просты, а над некоторыми придется идти в гугл, чтобы понять, что от тебя требуют. В игре полным полно отсылок к каким либо фильмам, мультфильмам и ко многому другому. Тут даже есть отсылка на Футураму. Неожиданным повортом событий был выход из игры. Я имею ввиду, после получения одной из концовок игра сама закрылась.Из плюсов я хотел бы отметить: звуковое сопровождение, сложные головоломки и отсылки. Ну а минусов тут нет, вот такая это хорошая игра.

I like arcade racers. And Hot Wheels Unleashed is one of the good ones. The direction the creators went for is very suitable for the hot wheels universe fans, but also for people looking for an arcade racer with cool environments. However, as the game is now, it feels a bit unpolished, and looking to be made on the budget, so to speak. That will certainly be improved with future updates. When it comes to racing itself, it is fun, but if you play on your own, it has a limit. Kudos to the creators for including several difficulty settings for every level of player. Nice game for a few games and for online play, but if you can, wait a bit for the full collection with all the DLC's, cars and environments the game will have to offer.

reviews.title: thecrowspain's review of Hot Wheels Unleashed

reviewText.content:
"Hot Wheels Unleashed," released in 2021, is available on multiple platforms, including PC. The game was developed by Milestone S.r.l, known for their work on racing games like the MotoGP series.

The game was published by Milestone S.r.l as well.

The director of "Hot Wheels Unleashed" is Michele Caletti. While there isn't a lot of information available about his previous game direction, he played a significant role in this title.

The game utilizes the Unreal Engine 4, a popular engine in the gaming industry. Unreal Engine has been used in numerous other games, including "Fortnite," "Gears 5," and "Street Fighter V," among many others.

Regarding gameplay, we find that Hot Wheels Unleashed is easy to handle but certainly challenging to master, requiring significant effort in some races on normal difficulty. This makes it more than just a children's product and turns it into a quite competent racing game.

It's a shame that the track setting becomes repetitive, and the purchasing system is based on loot boxes because, otherwise, it's a notable game that is definitely worth a try.
Me encanto mucho la calidad el diseño me asuste  en algunas partes pero estaba bien echo
It is grindy at times, but also somehow very relaxing. Exploring is fun, you can farm and gather resources or trade when you need something - no pressure! :D

reviews.title: An extremely chill adventure with some cuteness sprinkled in

reviewText.content: This weekend I wanted to play a game where I could chill out.  Something that wasn't stressful but was an escape from reality.  This game scratched that itch.  It starts you out in a small region but soon you unlock other biomes.  The world starts slowly opening up, more and more.  The best part about this was that the world felt large enough to feel different but not large enough to where traversing was a labor.  The side quests and main quests were never boring but weren't challenging either.  They were simple yet satisfying.  The story was predictable but in a way it was nice to have something presented that was predictable.  Story/Gameplay aside the graphics were great.  I played in 4k and the game looked beautiful.

One of the nicest casual games that's not casual at all, Wilmot's Warehouse puts the player in a pleasant illusion of sortability. You, Wilmot, are expected to put things in their place. The more you do this, the more things you need to find a place for and there's only just so much warehouse for it all to go. This exercise in organizing gradually becomes an exercise in futility. Between long sessions of customer service, you are allowed to do stock take, essentially a "free play" time to clean your room or suffer in the levels that follow. There's no real way to anticipate what's coming unless you can afford an expensive upgrade, and the helper robot you're given, Borky, does about as good of a job as his name and :/ facial expression suggests. He also refuses to move an inch if you're trying to watch what he's doing. Things spiral out of control if you're not trying at all level over level which makes WW feel like Tetris in slow motion or, unironically, like a job. The only sad thing about this game is that it feels like a missed opportunity to teach the human player anything at all. As a person that struggles with organizing objects in a limited space in the real world, it makes me sad that I played this game for hours and only feel like there's no way to win either game. On the flip side, whatever methods you come up with become uniquely your own and people are keen to share their finished game screenshots which perhaps is an invitation to learn from other players—people—about how to become better the next time there's a mess of objects in front of you.

Ok, so after all of it is done I want to change the review quite a bit.
I now regret preordering the series and supporting the project and am sure to NOT buy the next installation which is sure to come. As with most things the rule "the first part is always the best" works 100% for this one.

The first game hooked me up with incredible variation of settings, story and twists. This part doesn't have that. For the most part it's actually boring, it falls back on the "OMG emotions", but kinda fails to inspire any. Contrary to the first game, it has less interesting choices (or rather doesn't even pretend that your choices even matter). Most of the "conflicts" in the game are dumb, characters barely likable (except for the main protagonist of course), it seems like the writing for this one was done not out of inspiration, but mainly out of "we_need_to_hit_them_deadlines". And well, in a story-based game with barely no gameplay - bad writing is a no-go.

Overall, if we consider the first game 10/10, this one is 7. And I would prefer I've never played it just because it ruined the good name of Walking Dead (the game) for me.

A solid, very good game that's' an emotional roller coaster as any TWD game should be. It's hard to get into after the emotional ending of TWD season 1, but the emotional payoff after a while is totally worth it. The pacing is excellent, though the novelty of the experience is a little lost having played through season 1.  My ending felt unsatisfying, but I'm not surprised how it turned out based on my own personality and the world of this game. Guess that's how  you can tell it's successful.

I liked the Season Two better than Season One. Don't get me wrong, Season One was great as well, but the emotional weight has really came down on me with this one. More so than ever, you feel that your choices actually matter and shape the story, which is not always the case with these types of games. To not spoil anything, I won't mention much else. Just my recommendation: make sure to play in longer multiple sessions for the best emotional impact. It really is a roller-coaster.

reviews.title: dariovaccaro's review of The Walking Dead: Season Two

reviewText.content:
A significant downfall compared to Season One. The game is technically horrendous, the acting (except for Madsen's) is below average, and the story is really repetitive at this point. Also, as usual with TellTale games, 95% of choices don't matter in the slightest. 
Episode 5, the final one, is the best one, with some really dark moments and better writing overall.

Histoire sympathique mais moins prenante que la saison 1, et surtout desservie par un portage PC honteux.

+ Retrouver Clémentine
+ Techniquement ça tient mieux la route que la saison1 (même si petits bugs, genre personnage statique avec son fusil dans les mains qui bouge tout seul)

- Personnages moins attachants, problématiques moins prenantes
- On retrouve un ancien personnage de la Saison1 mais aucun flashback pour nous resituer son histoire
- Traduction française réalisée par des fans sous forme de patch, alors que Telltales a les moyens financiers d'en faire une native
- impossible de jouer avec la manette (si périphérique USB branché, alors écran noir au démarrage)
- impossible de jouer avec un casque audio (si périphérique USB branché, alors écran noir au démarrage)
- impossible de jouer dans la définition native de mon écran (1920*1080) (sinon écran noir au démarrage ; en baissant la définition du bureau windows en 800*600 puis celle du jeu en 1900*600 ça passe)
- impossible de mapper les touches en Azerty. Très gênant, car normalement en Qwerty on utilise les touches typiques des FPS "WASD" pour se déplacer, et les touches "E" et "Q" juste à côté pour les QTE. Or en Azerty il faut utiliser les flèches directionnelles pour bouger, sauf que dans les situations d'urgence on a besoin d'utiliser soit 1. la souris 2. les flèches directionnelles 3. les QTE, donc trois endroits en même temps au lieu d'avoir 2. et 3. sous la main gauche, vraiment pas pratique quand il faut être réactif !

It's a interesting battle royal, yeeeees it's another battle royal, but, let them an opportunity, it's not a shooter, it's like more a LOL, with Fortnite Graphics and a Wizards...Yup Wizards, Sorcerers, magic!..
So how is the game dynamics? well, it's a challenge, because you need to discover how to use the spells, how can you combiner and how can you block from your enemies with magic, like in dragon Ball...

So you need to learn how combine an element with other to cause more damage or neutralize an enemy element with your elements, and another thing what you do is combine your power with your squad, for example, you throw a Fire Blast, and your team invoke a twister, so now you have a Scary Fire Twister..

CloudPunk is a game that on name alone would have you hope that the sky is the limit. I went into it hoping a futuristic steam punk world that meets a compelling narrative as you dive deeper and not only develop your character but choose the destiny in which your protagonist sets her destination towards. Instead CloudPunk let's you know real quick that the limit is the sky in which you fly around in, and are confined to it's stereotype characters, one track storyline where there are little decisions you can make, as you realize once passed the clouds, this game somewhat resembles a visual novel with a set pace and only one destination. Without going into any spoilers, you play a character who has taken a new job as a courier for what seems to be a less than reputable delivery service who seems to go through employees constantly, which the former couriers all meeting a forced early retirement as insinuated by your dispatcher. One would think your character would take that as a hint to maybe think twice about continuing on with this job, but she decides to continue along, even with it's low paying scale. Looking at prices when you buy items from street vendors, drug dealers, and food stands, those characters all seem to make more money on selling a few of their items than what you make on a starting delivery. I know I am debating the imaginary economy of a game, but it does have me question that our protagonist would be way better off opening up a soup stand than delivering who knows what. But since she insists to continue delivering for some reason, the one helpful tip the dispatcher gives her is to not ask any of the customers whats in the packages. First thing your character does? She asks whats in each package. She pries into the personal lives and activities of each NPC she comes across, who all give her some sort of attitude, or hint that they dont want a conversation with her, and yet she insists. I would be fine if this was a dialogue option in which I choose if my character wants to be curious or if I want her to just do her job. But there is no option, it's just sitting back and seeing your character cringefully get into other people's business, where you would hope one would realize that asking too many questions (or any question at all for that matter), might be risking your life. Unfortunately your character decides to poke into the lives of each stereotypical character she comes across, coming off somewhat intrusive in some cases. The one npc that seemed that wanted to talk to her (known as a loud broadcaster i believe in achievements unlocked), she instantly brushes off for being a "bro" and we get the stereotype of a bro attitude from the npc, that was not initially established when he approached her, so it kinda comes off that she was rude at first to him and thus he is just reacting negatively towards her, rather than the "bro" being the rude one from the start, from my perspective. So after seeing that I really have no dialogue options, and that this game consists mostly of delivering from point A to point B (or Point C if you choose to do something different, this is where you can only make choices in the game it seems), i decided to see if i can take decisions into my own hands....by crasing the Hova Delivery vehicle. Can we get it to explode? Can we get the engine to stop running? Will we fall from the sky? After spending around 30 minutes crashing into other vehicles and buildings/structures, other than my vehicle emitting plenty of smoke and a few sparks, as well as moving slowly, it still was capable to reach destinations albiet it a slower pace. So then I wanted to see what would happen if I run out of fuel, surely then the engine stops and I've made a critical decision that could potentially end the game, correct? No. I recieved a few warnings from the AI installed in the cab, as well as from the dispatcher, but when my tank reached zero, my vehicle still floated, still moved (at a very slow speed), and in game it mentions that it runs on some other power source that makes sure you are able to make it to the closest gas station. Maybe in later stages of the game the training wheels or plot armor disappears and a game over could come to fruition from such potentially fatal decisions, but it definitely doesnt happen throughout my gameplay of the game. Realizing that I felt I had little decision into what happens to my character, and that there isnt any real risks of damage to my vehicle, I felt that the clouds dispersed and that I was punked from the experience i had hoped to play. With that being said, I do love the graphics and the setting, which when we think of Steam Punk or future iterations of our world with flying cars and all, this game captures that setting just right with the pixelated graphics that gives off this adorable touch to the world your looking at. Which is funny because this setting is defined as grimmy and dark and yet you find the beauty, the allure of it all, at least aesthetically. Unfortunately the story and the character didn't appeal to me, nor that I felt that I could take helm in this adventure and live vicariously through my protagonist, and rather I was just in the backseat of a broken down sky taxi set on a course that wasnt mine to make. You might have a better experience in the game, and if I gave it more time (Steam mentions I played this game for more than 2 hours) maybe the story would develop more to my liking, but I wish I had more control with the choices and whom my avatar would be in this world from the start. Cloudpunk is available on PC and has mostly positive reviews on Steam.
I've been trying to get into dungeon crawlers after having failed to get into Savior of Sapphire Wings/Stranger of Sword City Revisited. I love horror so I jumped at the chance to play this.

An old machinist plots his escape from Communism and starts out on a perilous journey on the road towards freedom—will he survive the many dangers and be free of oppression and tyranny?

Black the Fall is a beautifully crafted side-scroller puzzle platformer game where the puzzles are fresh and intriguing and oftentimes leave you scratching your head while trying to figure it out.  The macabre scenes, while often shocking, lend to the oppressive atmosphere and enrich our connection to the protagonist.  Overall, the puzzles along with the setting are quite memorable and makes for a good game that remains with you for quite some time.

The controls are somewhat easy, with my only difficulty being with the laser pointer required for a good percentage of the game.  I just didn’t have the speed and accuracy enough until the middle of the game once I got used to it.  However, those players that are already familiar with the controller should have no issue navigating the world and puzzles.  Another bonus to Black the Fall is when you fail at a puzzle, and by fail I mean die, you are brought back very close to where you were before failing and you are allowed to try again as many times as it takes to complete the puzzle—this style of autosave I liked and was very thankful for.

Getting all the achievements is made easier by the chapter select feature though many, if not all, of the achievements are well hidden and can be difficult to find without a guide.  If you are a completionist I recommend finding a good guide online for this game.

Overall, I found this game challenging with an impressively gloomy and depressing backdrop and engaging narrative.  The game is quite memorable with a great story to be told and the ending was quite satisfying.  I can easily recommend Black the Fall for those who enjoy puzzle platformer games.

The first Battle Royale game that I actually like.
I have tried Fortnite, PUBG and Last Man Standing. Barely played them because I found them frustrating, boring and not fun except if you try hard (which is not really having fun anymore).

Before I uninstall Apex Legends, I am going to leave some notes about this game. Personally, I cant say this game sucks, because I am suck playing the Battle Royale shooter game, so in case of curiousity. I play the game for sake of tasting the bits of Battle royale hype and current trend for gaming mode. 

Generally, the game is well polished and has astonishing look with its realism. I am not familiar with the campaign cause its said the "story" or "lore" based on Titanfall which I am not interested to play. 

People say a game sucks because they dont know how to play it. And this game takes a lot of aspects I dont really like. I can shoot people and have fun with it. But playing a game where you have to run for 10 minutes and get gun where a final moment to win the game based how last you kill someone or get killed bores me sometimes, but why I still play it? Because Apex has particular skill with each characters where this game combined Hero shooter mixed with battle royale. 

Unfortunately, playing the game several times makes this game becomes so stale and nothing new to improve player experience where win based on luck and doing nothing on empty arena where players just run and loot some boxes (So, its not fast paced shooter which I dont like). 

The characters design seems okay-ish but I predict it will not make developer getting successful skins selling with just bland recolor and "not enough" waifu (so if you want to some cute girls or sexy women) this has no sign for you. I hate generic pretty boy and girl character design in most of Battle royale mobile though, but i dont know it seems the characters are just being there, but still each players have its own skill where player can master to help winning the game. 

So, based my judgement for 5 hours playing and trying this game, I can say this game has potential, but considering BR is just a fad like fidget spinner, I can say this game is good fidget spinner where at first you are impressed with its looks, but get tired everyone make their own fidget spinner. 

6.6/10

Apex Legends is an enjoyable game. My friends and I have been hooked on this game for the previous two and a half months. The movement in this game is the greatest strength, it is fun to explore the options the movement system creates for the player. The different legends all have unique personalities that are fun to discover. I play on PS4 and the servers are hit or miss. Sometimes the game runs fantastic, other times it is a horrible mess. As mentioned earlier I play with my three friends. The main game mode in this game is for squads of three, which limits how we are able to play together. I would enjoy a permanent duos game mode for when all four of us would like to play so that we are not forced to cooperate with random unpredictable teammates so often. My final issue is with some of the legends. There are a clear few legends who are much better than others. The abilities of legends such as Pathfinder, Gibraltar, and Wraith are way too good when compared to someone like Octane or Mirage. I would hope that as the game progresses, so does the balance of the characters. Overall, Apex Legends is a very fun game that I see myself and my friends sinking hundreds of more hours into in the future.
Los servidores son super malos, el juego crashea, caes y lo primero que encuentras es una mozambique o una P2020

The best BR that has come out. People forget Apex revolutionized the staple mechanics that are in all BR's today (respawns, pings, sliding, etc.) Great feel with all the guns and the best movement mechanics in any game. Also an established and successful pro scene and easily the most fun esport to watch.
El unico shooter en el que pude realmente ser bueno y el shooter al que más tiempo he dedicado
très bon jeu assez compétitif et il y a beaucoup d'armé et de personnage différent  mais il ne sont pas très difficile a maitriser pour auttant

Apex was a fun game when I was playing it with friends. Even then, I still get bored of playing it very quickly. This game is like a stale chip; you think it looks good when looking at it, but when you start to eat it, everything goes downhill and fast.

To start off, I am a solo player; I like to play games alone for the most part. And when I learned that this game is only playable with at least one other player on the team, that really upset me. There was a period of time where I played this game a lot, but when I want to casually play the video game by myself, I still needed to have a teammate with me. I don't care about my battle royale ranks or where skilled-based matchmaking places me, but that doesn't mean the one other player on my team does as well, so if I am trying to chill out and casually play the game without a care in the world if I die or win, that will suck way more for the teammate that wants to get in higher ranks.

The maps were fine; I didn't like that they swapped out every few hours; the guns were nice to shoot; and the characters could have been better. Really, my main complaint about the game was the lack of replayability, the lack of solo play, and the lack of interesting updates.
Possibly the best game I’ve ever played in my life no other game, so like it Better than Fortnite and better than call of duty best of the best

reviews.title: TOS of EA is the department should be sacked

reviewText.content: Bad experience by myself, One and half years game time, account gets hacked by someone, This COMPANY ONLY CARES ABOUT MONEY. All they do just banned my account. Shit experience, better close soon.

Lately, Apex has been having a cheating problem. The devs are unable to make an effective server-side anticheat, and are unable to prevent Windows tooling from injecting into their game, so they've resorted to blaming the tiny percentage of Linux users who were playing just fine for 2-3 years. Scapegoating Linux is going to accelerate the cheating problem, too: Cheaters will see this as an admission that there is no working defense against them, and the pursuit of ineffective strategies and scapegoats will give them room to proliferate. Compare Overwatch (say what you want about it, it functions nearly cheater-free with active Linux players) with Call of Duty (cheat city, in spite of kernel-level protections in windows and no Linux access) and you'll see how these strategies play out.

The game, which once used to be so much fun to play, has now turned into a sad shit-show of game devs trying to suck out every last penny from their long faithful player base.
With no further innovations in tech security or gameplay, this once beloved game is now just a reminiscence of appalling and hideous monetisation methods as it holds on to the final stages of its downfall. 
It is always surprising to witness how the general greed of a Dev Studio can turn even the games with boundless potential to just a crumbling deck of misery and torment.

KUDOS EA. THERE YOU GO AGAIN.

This game is incredible. From the visual style, to the music, to the story, every single aspect of this game is a masterpiece. 

Please don't be turned away by the pixel style graphics, because it tells a beautiful story about a group of friends and how they cope with trauma. I was in tears by the end of the game, and I was left with so much to think about. 

Not to mention, the battle system is good fun, it's not an incredibly complex, but the emotion system works really well, and allows for good synergies and a unique playstyle for everyone. Also the battle music is absolutely amazing. It is a traditional turn based system, which I know isn't for everyone, but the rest of the game really makes up for that if the combat isn't your thing.

A majority of the game is a very cute and fun world, but occasionally the game will give you a reminder that it is a horror game, and I love how well the scares work.

All in all, it's probably my favourite game of all time.

Look, /v/. I've been here all summer and I know that you guys can be some of the most jaded, cynical people in the world when it comes to video games. I don't blame you for that, but, I gotta say moments like this really make me think you got a bright future ahead of you. 

OMORI had all the hallmarks of a future PIXELS ARE ART champion. The oh-so-quirky trailer from its Kickstarter campaign mixed crayon drawings, kooky music, and RPGMaker in a way that didn’t so much say “this is inspired by Yume Nikki and Earthbound” as shouted for the world to hear! Its director, OMOCAT, had never worked on a game before. And after raking in over $200,000, the project basically went radio silent for six years, leaving bakers waiting for something to happen. Even when it reemerged in late 2020, it did so into a world drawing in indie games that all claimed to deal with “heavy topics” like depression and anxiety.

By all rights, /v/ should have torn this game to shreds. But OMORI did not succumb. It takes a lot of balls to admit you like anything on /v/, so seeing the reception OMORI’s enjoyed – hell– it even got some nominations for Least Worst this year. It’s been heartening to say the least.

So, here’s to OMORI. The game that proves that sometimes, in spite of everything, it’s going to be okay.
A beautiful game.  It made me cry, after the Final Duet played.

reviews.title: Life is Strange 2: Racism is Bad

reviewText.content:
Most importantly, the story and characters are great. I was interested in what happens next; I liked the relationship between two brothers and cared about their fate and journey. 

Since the brothers are on the run, the environment is changing all the time. For some people, it's not a good thing, but I like it because every episode looks fresh. 

Soundtracks are spot-on. The gameplay is very similar to first Life is Strange, but instead of time rewinding, you can ask your brother to use his telekinetic powers. And, since Sean is an artist, instead of taking photos, you can sketch, and I loved it.

Compared to life is strange 1, graphics are highly improved. The environment is so beautiful I did tons of screenshots of landscapes. Character model design is not at the same level as environment design, but it's not bad either. I like hair animations of Daniel when he uses his telekinetic powers, but it's still and plastic on other characters.

The game has several endings; You have a lot of hard choices to make, and they matter in the end, although sometimes whatever you choose, the result is the same. 

Like in most of the games there are a bunch of bugs too but nothing serious. For example, characters walking on furniture, invisible walls, characters standing in T-pose, punctured hand by walkie-talkie, and others.

The only thing that annoyed me was that there is too much politics in it. And there are so many racists on Sean's path that it becomes a little bit unrealistic and forced. For this reason, I am giving it eight stars instead of nine.

Some very good action sequences, wasted by unnecessary laidback exploration and forced political agenda.

Two brothers are hunted because the little one is an X-Man. Every episode is like a villain of the week and 2-3 hours long.

Be aware for wannabe mature writing, which is just a facade for bad writing and character development. Even the choices have in most cases stupid impact.

As far as the LIS Universe is concerned, you have small meaningless encounters with the city of 1 and the most annoying character of 1 (and Before the storm)...

Captain Spirit plays major role in one episode and it's a far better game, even as a tech demo of 2.

The best episode is 3, because it's the only episode that reminds of "Life Is Strange".

I have now really low hopes for the third game...

TL;DR

This game feels like it was made in the 1990’s… and I love that.

General Thoughts

As a JRPG fan who grew up in the 90’s, Square Enix’s SNES and PS1 era JRPGs were a huge part of my childhood. Final Fantasy VI and Final Fantasy IX are two of my favorite games of all time. Suffice to say, I’m a sucker for games that cater towards this nostalgia.With that being said, my experience with “I am Setsuna” so far is everything I could have wanted or expected from a game like this. “I am Setsuna” is by no means the best game of 2016, but if you go in expecting to experience what it’s like to play your favorite 90’s JRPG for the first time again, you’re in for a treat.

The good

Music

My words would not do the music any justice, just listen. The music in this game, consisting mostly of solo piano pieces, is haunting, full of emotion, and absolutely carries the game. The soundtrack has an amplification effect on all aspects of the game. The characters, settings, story events, even the gameplay all feel more “full” due to tracks that perfectly set the tone throughout the game.

Gameplay

While the gameplay isn’t exactly deep or challenging so far, it is still very satisfying. The battle system is very similar to that of Chrono Trigger, while the equipment/skill system is similar to Final Fantasy VII. Skills aren’t acquired through levels, they are acquired by combining loot obtained from monsters. The way the drop/loot system works is genius and something that I wish more JRPGs would try to emulate. There are no random drops from enemies, instead, enemies drop items when you satisfy certain conditions with the way you defeat them. If you satisfy multiple conditions, you will get all of the items for the conditions that you satisfied. For example, if you defeat an enemy with a powered up lightning based attack, then you will get two drops from the enemy: one for defeating them with a powered up attack and one for defeating them with a lightning based attack. Random drops are extremely frustrating; This system feels like a breath of fresh air for the JRPG genre.

Scale

The game oozes “small budget production” in almost every aspect of the game, but this is a good thing. The budget (or lack thereof) forced various design decisions throughout the game. The developers didn’t have the budget for an overwhelmingly amount of side quests to distract you from the surprisingly personal story of sadness and suffering that this game tells. The developers didn’t have the budget to populate the world with hundreds of NPCs in tens of towns, so they created a small world with personality. I appreciate the fact that I won’t have to invest large amount of time to experience all that this game has to offer.

The not so good

There’s not much that I don’t like about the game. I’m very satisfied with every aspect of “I am Setsuna” at its core. However, the game is not perfect and there are a few things that I think could have improved the game. I consider the below points nitpicks about an otherwise great game.

Setting

All of the environments I’ve reached in the game so far can be described as “snowy, wooded, wasteland”, and I don’t see this changing much for the rest of the game. While I do like the general graphics and art style and how the setting matches the tone of the story, I can only handle so much snow. I think the town and dungeon design is fine; I enjoy exploring all of the environments in the game (mainly because that means I get more time to listen to the soundtrack). However, instead of thinking “Nice, a new dungeon/town! Can’t wait to explore it!”, I find myself thinking “oh… another icy/snowy town/dungeon…”.

Menus/UI theme

This complaint arises from my complaint about the setting. The main menu which is used to manage items, skills, equipment, party, etc. has a sort of “gray, arctic” theme. This is fine, looks great, and the UX of the menu is pretty good. However, because most of the game takes place in a snowy environment, the menu tends to blend into the surroundings. It can be hard to navigate the menu in certain areas of the game due to the colors blending in to the background.

No Attack Range Indicators

In battle, many attacks and skills are targeted at an enemy, but affect an area around the enemy. Unfortunately, the game doesn’t show you the range of the attack you are using. This means you will often be asking yourself, “I’m targeting enemy A, is enemy B close enough to be hit by this?” and you will often be wrong. If the game were actually difficult, this would be a huge problem, but as it is, this is just a minor annoyance.

reviews.title: Maxim_Nazarenko's review of Forgive Me Father

reviewText.content:
I will leave kinda mixed review, because my main experience with this game was with 1.0 version, that I've played at 2022.05.02 (2 may 2022).

There were a lot of bugs and glitches, and invisible enemies were one of the most frustrating things, because they can kill you silently and you wouldn't even notice that.
You can softlock yourself in some places, if you're not so careful with your jumps.

Level design.
At first, the game is really so interesting, it consumes you into itself.
Closer to the end of the game - it starts to look like an unfinished labyrinth.
At some points the game is inside the space and you cannot even see your path/road. There is void under your legs and you need to guess where you need to go, otherwise you will fall and die. But you can use your gun, so you will shoot under your legs, so you can see something at least.

Platforming.
I don't know who decided that this will be a great idea. There will be places, where you cannot see anything. And you will need to jump from one platform to other.
Yes, you have a flashlight, but it cannot be always active.
Protagonist's jumping feels kinda "off". In other games you can feel where are you jumping, but in Forgive me Father you just cannot normally calculate where you will land.

You can be easily shooted down, if you will stay under open fire.
Game models are 2D, and if you will stand to your enemies in 90 degree - it's very hard to see them.
By the same reason - you cannot see some projectiles and particles, so in really deep combat you cannot evade them.

Leveling up and abilities.
I thinks it's always best to start with Experience Upgrade.
But there so many non-obvious with Weapon Upgrades and you cannot rollback your decisions.
Some upgrades are changing type of ammo, so you need to be careful and plan everything at first steps.

Music is really great in Forgive me Father.
Comic style adds some style and unique feeling.

One Night Stand is a nice indie game walking you through a morning after. Many different endings, many different paths you can take with your character, many choices. It is great to see how things end up if you play it how you hypothetically would in real life, and then trying out different combinations of different choices. I will definitely check out other games by this developer.

reviews.title: bugondesk's review of One Night Stand

reviewText.content: I played this game three times in a row and was really impressed by the high-quality animation, localization, and story writing. It's hard to believe the designer put so many turning points in such a short game.

I should start of by saying that I am huge fan of the comic as well as anthropomorphism. Both of these are adding some positive points to my list. So big part of me enjoying the game is to be in Blacksad's world.
As for the gameplay part, it is painful. Controls are unresponsive and clumsy and most of the time it is pain to just move the character around. Camera is not helping either, I guess it was supposed to help the "comic feel", but it killed the gaming part. Another annoying things are times for everything, most of the time absolutely unnecessary. A lot of times I had to choose response in dialog without managing to even read all the possibilities. And lastly, a lot of choices are just illusion of choice because either they have no impact on the story or all other choices but one lead to your death...

Summary:
As a game is Blacksad not really good and if you are not fans of the theme and style (anthropomorphic noir detective story) or original comic, stay away. But for those who do, it is definitely worth playing for the story.

reviews.title: luisnazario9's review of Blacksad: Under the Skin

reviewText.content: I agree on what sh4dow_86 said. Allthough my rating would be "good" instead of "fair".
Automate automate automate. Automate automate!? Automate!!! (Hodor ?)
Great concept, flawless executio,n these guys really love and play their own game.
Amazing automation game! There are so many mods that are basically a new DLC

Rags-to-riches survival games are a dime a dozen these days, but Factorio’s wild ambition and open-ended format takes the potential for complexity up several notches. It starts you off as a spaceship crash survivor with only a pickaxe with which to explore its randomly generated 2D planets, but stick with it long enough and you can build all the way up to fighting aliens with tanks and creating manufacturing megastructures in seconds with a personal robot swarm. While it gets a little slow in certain places and its ultra-complex logistics chains can be overwhelming, the rewarding depth that can be extracted from its whirring conveyor belts and steam-belching power plants are worth the trouble.

The most important thing to understand about Factorio is that it's one of those games you probably won't figure out how to play optimally through trial and error alone. My first couple of experimental factories ended up being such a mess that I decided it was better to simply abandon them and start over rather than trying to salvage the tangle of assembly lines and mining drills I had created before I understood some key tricks and common pitfalls. You’re best off doing your homework and reading wikis and watching tutorial videos, or bringing along a friend who knows what they're doing in multiplayer, because Factorio won’t guide you away from frustrating disaster.

Cool game with a great art style and sound design! The multiple endings felt very samey though just with slight differences between them. Its why I don't think the Groundhog Day-like approach to stories in games really works with this and Stories Path of Destinies not living to their full potential.

Буду краток, игра великолепна. Сюжет полон загадок, персонажи великолепны. Тут даже присутствует периодически меняющийся геймплей. Это меня, конечно, тоже удивило. Тут даже визуальная составляющая иногда терпит изменения.

reviews.title: VidyaGaemAwards's review of Ghosts 'n Goblins Resurrection

reviewText.content:
It's not a party without Arty, and Professor F is back to make sure you know it. While plenty of casuals may not know this series, gaming itself has been shaped by this series as far back as 1985. Even now, we still see games influenced by it: some are pretty good, some not so much. And yet, Arthur is still king.

Over 30 years of tearing apart Ghouls, Ghosts, Goblins, and everything in between show that he's no slouch, and Resurrection is further proof of that. The magic system has been reworked for the better, and there's plenty of passive skills to make the journey easier. Ironically, you don't need any of that to even beat the game.

No amount of level-ups or power-ups can replace your skill and the power of your two thumbs. That's gaming at its core. It's what distinguishes it from books, music, TV, and movies. Even if you watch someone else succeed in a game, it won't ever match the high you get when you do it yourself. It's an inherently masochistic medium that makes you work for your enjoyment. It's not the princess that keeps you going, not world peace, not even a high score. It's the thrill of conquering. It's what separates the casuals from the hardcore. No matter how many times you lose, you keep going until (YOU) win. And in this game, you will lose. A lot.

The best looking game in the series. Artwork and details are amazing. Definitely better than 3-rd and 4-th parts. Puzzles are logical and you don't have to combine everything with everything like in some other games. Most puzzles are pretty simple, but entire series was more story oriented as well. The only bad thing about this game, that it became more serious and lacks more humor the first games had.

reviews.title: Un bon petit jeu dans son genre

reviewText.content:
Petit point'n click à l'humour anglais, le jeu nous fait alterner entre l'assureur George et la journaliste Nico, dans une enquête de vol de tableau.
L'humour du jeu parfois assez caustique permet de tenir sur la durée ; les énigmes sont classiques, quelques unes tordues, mais il y a un système d'indices dans le jeu pour se débloquer.
L'histoire déroule tranquillement avec un final "what the fuck".
Un bon petit jeu dans son genre.

Joué sur SeriesX via les jeux Gold.

Right now, it's one of the best rated games on Steam, and I can see why. If you have a great game-play loop and you develop enough levels for it with various levels of difficulty at a reasonable price point, people will try it, and some people will get hooked. I didn't, but I still could appreciate the fantastic ideas and game design.

Survival games nowadays consists of plots involving a zombie apocolypse or an extraterrestrial threat, or mutants and monsters from the fallout of a nuclear war. Developers go pretty imaginative when it comes to the threats a player confronts in their games, when in reality the most thrilling challenges come from those that are real. That's where The Long Dark excels, as it takes you into a fictional world that feels very real in both the challenges you will face combined with the vicarious connection you instantly find yourself having with your character.

When the game first came out, the Story Mode known as Wintermute wasn't available at that time, since then Hinterland has released 3 of the 5 chapters and plan on releasing the 4th by the end of 2020 (delays have taken place due to Covid, mentioned in the Dev Diary). This review is based on Survival Mode. In this mode, the mission is to survive as long as possible. There is no hand holding, no objectives or quests, just your character and a setting that will test your skills to live. What we find out is that your character survived a plane crash and is now lost somewhere in Northern Canada known as Great Bear Island. A once small thriving community spread throughout the island, we now find it to be mysteriously abandoned for the most part, every once in a while finding an unfortunate soul who succumbed to the elements that now engulf the region. Modern amenities like electricity, heat, and running water have all seem to stop functioning as well, with the rare short occurances of the Aurora Borealis inexplicably "spark" (no pun intended) life albiet it slightly to a few aplliances and utilities for a short while, almost as a haunting reminder of what the world was just before your accident, teasing you for a small moment as it disappears alongside the Northern Lights. And with the absence of humankind, the wilderness thrives once more, as the wildlife expand their boundaries to what are now the ruins of their human neighbors. What would seem a simple search for food supplies in an abandoned town for instance can immediately become dangerous as you run into a pack of wolves, or a bear, who are also looking for their next meal. Or when canned foods and rations run out, do you decide to turn into a predator yourself, as you hunt for deer or rabbits, or hope to catch fish. All this taking place during one of the worst blizzards faced in the region, where hypothermia becomes a common risk on an almost daily basis. Not to mention at times, your own body might decide to go against you by becoming ill, or injured, or tired. Even in the comforts of finding shelter, you have the risk of getting "Cabin Fever" if you stay indoors for too long, where the only remedy is to confront the elements once more. This game does a superb job taking into account a variety of dangers both obvious and unexpected, and placing you smack dab in the middle of it all, with no remorse nor guidance. This is Survival afterall, what more do you need to know other than do whatever it takes to do just that....survive.

In my numerous playthroughs of the game, my character has died in various of ways to the point I've made a long list of each one, since they are all mostly unique and rarely the same way. Where I learn from my mistakes, I'm bound to make more, or in some cases the game leaves no other choice but to fall into "The Long Dark." And yet never do I feel like I want to "rage quit," or give up on this game. It leaves me wanting to start a new session and hope I last longer. And the key word there is hope, because there's always a sense of hope, even if it might be false, you hope that the next region is filled with supplies, hope that the blizzard dies down, hope that the wolves have dispersed from outside your shelter, hope that the next day is a good day. There is no end game, no getting off the island, no rescue team coming for you, you will eventually one way or the other succumb to "The Long Dark." And yet finding the resemblence of hope in the form of a place, an item, a skill learned, in just plain luck, that hope drives you to keep going.
