Now whether its taking you faster or slower towards the inevitable, thats doesnt matter, it's the experience throughout the journey, as lonesome and dire as it might seem at times, that you are willing to overcome.

I might have digressed a bit into what this review should also describe, it's just I really admire and enjoy this game so much. So with that in mind, let us talk about the mechanics and techinical aspect of the game. The graphics of the game might take you away from the reality it tries to incorporate. It seems at times it resembles a TellTale game the way the world is drawn. Not that it takes away from it too much, you definitely forget about it instantly, but don't go expecting advanced motion capture and realistic 3D rendering. For instance, whenever you come across human remains, its in one of two positions,  and theres no details or resemblence of this once being a living person, it just seems like a husk. Or maybe looking around houses and seeing the portraits and paintings on the wall, they are all blurry and not interesting. Not that they should be of course, but I think there would be more of a sense of eerie-ness seeing these smiling faces in a potrait staring at you as you scavenge through their property. At times you might come across a book bag that you search through for supplies and items, yet you can't pick it up and use it, as your character needs to balance item capacity carry. There is an item that you can craft that is a satchel of sorts, but if the game is already showing me that there are carrying bags in the game that I can interact with, one would imagine your character would pick it up and use it themselves. There are also mechanics that are a bit annoying, for instance your character can not jump. I might come across a small platform or dock or rock or some sort of slightly elevated foundation/obstacle in front of the character and would in no ways hold you back or detour you in real life, and yet in the game you need to go around. There are glass freezers you will find in gas stations that sometimes contain soda cans and water, yet the doors to them slightly open enough to maybe squeeze a hand in, becoming at times a mission to select the items inside with your mouse (or controller). In reality you would imagine being able to fully swing open the door, or break the glass as to take the much needed content inside them. There are a few other items I could nitpick on, but none of them affect me enough to not love this game.

The Long Dark continues to add content and updates, as well as Hinterland Studios being very open and communicative with the community, so the game still has plenty of potential patches and additions to be brought into the game. That's great to know in a game where the replayability value is immense. I love this game, and I imagine it might show in my review here. And although taste is subjective, I know this is a game that I could recommend to the most competitive of gamers, all the way to someone who hardly plays videogames. The Long Dark is available for PC/Playstation/XBox/and soon Switch.

I was itching for a survivor genre game and decided to give a chance to The Long Dark. 

At first, I was skeptical because the visuals are very simplistic. But the gameplay is so immersive, I got addicted to it, and I started to like landscapes too and found the interiors comforting and relaxing. I didn't mind that animations are stiff and unrealistic, that textures are muddy, and despite what you are wearing, your hands stay in the same cloths. 

If you are playing on a hard mode, the game hits you hard, and you have to prioritize things to survive.  Every task needs a specific time, so you have to manage your time correctly because if you waste your time, you waste your food and water. 

Unfortunately, I started this game on easy mode, because I had no idea how to play it, and progressed through the story. I ended up with so many recourses the game became too easy to be fun, and I could not change the difficulty in the mid-game. The story is not the strongest part of this game, so I didn't want to start it over, and I gave up on it. Instead, I started survival mode. I got addicted to it, but since there is no story in survival mode at some point, it becomes repetitive and you have a feeling that you don't achieve anything. So I stopped playing and hope to start over the story mode after some time.

The only thing that I didn't like was a lot of walking, which becomes boring even in games with advanced graphics.

Overall, despite the graphics and weak story, the game is good, because of immersive gameplay

Suite directe de "Chains of Satinav", cette seconde et dernière partie de l'histoire surpasse pour moi la première en tous points. Pas ou peu de second degré ou humour noir, mais une très belle histoire d'aventure fantasy :)

Played on iPhone. Both simple and complex control modes are prepared by the game, however, the simple is too simple, you only need to swipe left or right to collect energies or doing shifts, and the complex mode is too hard to control.

reviews.title: corvo01011's review of Darkest Dungeon II

reviewText.content: A great game that brings back some of the amazing mechanics we loved on the first one, but with several changes that may not please everybody.

Oyunun hikayesi size büyük bir keyif ve sürükleyicilik sunuyor bu yüzden çok eğlenerek oynuyor, kendinizi oyunun içinde buluyorsunuz. Daha önce Wales Interactive oyunları ya da herhangi bir interaktif oyun oynadıysanız Blood Shore'u da oynamanızı mutlaka öneririm çünkü battle royale konusu interaktif oyunlar arasında çok işlenmiş hatta bildiğim kadarıyla hiç işlenmiş değil bu farklı deneyimi yaşamanızı isterim. Oyuna puanım 10 üzerinden 8.

Başlarda ya da oyunun devamında tek başımıza takılabilme imkanımız olsa ( 6 saat birçok seçenek deneyerek oynadım ama belki de vardır :P ) çok güzel olurdu ancak ben rastlamadım. Bunu eksi yön olarak söylüyorum onun harici çok güzel, en ufak gibi görünen detaylar geleceği ve ekibin size davranış biçimini etkiliyor bu detaylara önem verilmiş, oynamanızı öneririm.

reviews.title: Not BloodSnore, but Not BloodScore Either

reviewText.content: Battle Royale is one of my guilty pleasures, so I was looking forward to playing this. It is a much smaller and tighter experience than expected, yet the producers create an illusion of the game being bigger than it really is. Some choices are critical, while others don't matter much, and as always, it's all about how you want to play.

But on the other hand, the game gets boring even despite its short duration of 2-4 hours, in fact, it is a typical horror-quest, we have several locations (pizzeria, house, school, etc.), each with several rooms, and we have to run back and forth, finding various "openers" (we have a hand-drawn inventory with key items, items for achievements and read-items), if we run for a very long time, we stumble and make a lot of noise, so along the way we sit under tables (or ventilation-fast travels), enduring Golden Freddy passing by, with the rest of the animatronics only scripted moments and self-repeating tasks for crafting baits, although there are already sound baits for distraction Yellowbear scattered across all the maps.
The plot about a parallel reality after descending into a bathtub of balls is interesting only conceptually, the prologue, for example, is very atmospheric, but all the dialogues/characters are very simple, the ending is a template for a horror, although i can't say that it's bad, there are 4 of them, which are classic for such a game, and they open quite simply.

😊 𝗦𝘂𝗯 𝘁𝗼 𝗺𝘆 𝗦𝘁𝗲𝗮𝗺`𝘀 𝗖𝘂𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗼𝗿`𝘀 𝗽𝗮𝗴𝗲: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550
//
С одной стороны это достаточно свежо для франшизы стильными 2д-скримерам от 1 лица с QTE-механикой (но не очень стильным общим визуалом), и хорошей работе со звуком игры,
Но с другой стороны - игра надоедает даже несмотря на свою короткую продолжительность в 2-4 часа, по сути это типичный хоррор-квест, несколько локаций (пиццерия, дом, школа и т.д.), в каждом по несколько комнат, и мы должны бегать туда сюда, находя различные "открывашки" (у нас есть рисованный от руки инвентарь с ключевыми предметами, предметами для достижений и просто "почитабельными"), если бежать очень долго, то спотыкаемся и издаём много шума, так что попутно садимся под столы (или вентиляции-фаст трэвелы), терпя проходящего мимо Золотого Фредди, с остальными аниматрониками только заскриптованные моменты и самоповторяющиеся задания на крафт приманок, хотя тут итак по всем картам раскиданы звукое приманки на отвлечение "Жолтиго".
Сюжет про паралельную реальность послу спуска в ванну из шариков интересен только концептуально, пролог, например, очень атмосферный, но все диалоги/персонажи очень простенькое, концовка шаблонная для хоррора, хотя нельзя сказать что плохая, классически для такой игры их 4 штуки, достаточно просто открываются.
❗👨‍🔧Вообше следовало поставить бы дизлайк, потому что игра жутко тормозит и виснет, да, вот эти вот пиксели, не у меня одного такая проблема, теряется напряжение во многих хоррор-моментах, почти что неиграбельно, постоянно ждёшь, пока отвиснет (Иногда помогает сворачивание/разворачивание окна игры), но я понимаю, что рано или поздно пофиксят и будущие игроки уже поиграют нормально.

Machinika Museum is a puzzle game whose gameplay is very similar to "The Room" series -- each puzzle is an alien object you have to fix or activate. Such objects are beautifully rendered, and can be rotated at will; and rotate you will, because tons of switches, buttons and alien puzzles are all around their surfaces. The puzzles are not too hard, but do require good observation skills. There are some creative ideas there -- there are a few recurrent tools which are well designed and fun to use, including an all-purpose screwdriver which I wish existed in real life.

Extra points to the rich sound design -- every action you perform is rewarded with nice clinks, clanks, buzzes, and some wonderfully mechanical "ka-ta-chunk" sounds, reinforcing the physicality of the experience. The music isn't memorable, but supports the mystery mood nicely too.

There is a bit of a suitable story behind your actions, which ends with a "to be continued" (but it does not feel too incomplete). Now, while generally the graphics are extremely nice, the very last screen is graphically underwhelming -- the story demanded a much more beautiful and detailed scene there.

Finally, the game is short -- currently there are 9 objects, and the whole thing is over in about 2.5 hours. That said, there is nearly no filler here, which makes for a nice experience all around.
My blood is pumping! I feel like a real man! This game is somehow better than the 2016 reboot.

Disappointing considering the game that came before. It's as if they did not get what make DOOM 2016 great and invested in all the wrong stuff. It still has moments of brillance, when everything works together it feels like the best single player shooter on the market, but too many times the game forces you to play in an hyper-specific way and will punish you quickly if have a different idea. They expanded the story in all the worst ways, investing in the lore and going overboard with the self-aware humour. All that said, this is a technical powerhouse, looking great and running perfectly even on console. The basic gameplay is still very fun though, it gets the job done.

Once can call Doom Eternal one of the best shooters of the generation, I wouldn’t be afraid to call it the best. Even with the DLCs, the scale of the game is massive, combat demands a lot of you, if you play on the highest difficulties, but the accomplishment feels amazing. Once you master all the aspects of this heaven vs hell story driven game and finish the last part of the DLC as your heart is pounding and the brain is alerted, you know, you witnessed something special.

DOOM Eternal - 10/10

At the moment, DOOM Eternal is the best action FPS-shooter ever made. It has everything: flawless gameplay, quality graphics, astonishing level design, a decent and well-written storyline with perfectly expanded lore, and, of course, a divine soundtrack, which elevates the enjoyment of the game to the highest possible level.

Compared to DOOM (2016), the gameplay has been refreshed and upgraded to the next level. Annoying flaws were fixed or adapted organically to the new gameplay features. Platforming, which allows one to behold the scale of the game, is a cool way to explore beautiful locations. Unlike the previous game, finding secrets is much more convenient, making it really hard to miss anything. The main gameplay not only remained the same but was also carefully and thoroughly improved with a variety of new features and tools for slaying hellish fiends in the most extravagant and creative ways, each time filling you with pleasure.

One more thing that still amazes me is how vast and majestic the world feels—it really feels as if you are wandering between worlds: those lost and on the verge of oblivion. The magnitude of events is truly breathtaking.

To my surprise, the lore of the universe is truly deeply thought out, drawing you deeper into the action. The only issue is obtaining 95% of the information from codex pages, which can become tedious at some point. However, the breadth of the narrative is definitely worth it.

The sound design and soundtrack are at the highest possible level. Not only is the fight music amazing, raising your adrenaline to the top, but the ambient tracks are made with such passion, making you feel 100% immersed in the world you are in. Although I am not a music expert, I feel like the sound of the fighting tracks was refreshed with the addition of more electronic sounds compared to the DOOM (2016) OST, and I truly enjoy that.

The only flaw I cannot overlook is some critical bugs I've encountered. The situation is much better compared to DOOM (2016), where I was literally magically flying over the entire level or was banned by devs from passing through doors :). But in any case, some bugs are still in the game, for example, music and sound disappearance, checkpoint/level stuck. Maybe at some point it annoys, especially when you have to replay some hard encounter or slayer gate, though to be honest, in around 30 hours of gameplay, there were only 4 or 5 instances, so considering how enormous this game is, this can be overlooked.

DOOM Eternal is indeed a masterpiece, and I'd definitely like to try the Extra-Life mode, or even Ultra-Nightmare someday.
This is a super mario on steroids. Jump around the hoops and kill some monsters.

Quelle claque ! N'ayant pas joué à un doom depuis celui de 1993 sur mon 486DX2.66 je n'ai pas de comparaison avec les précédents épisodes.
Le gameplay est nerveux, intelligemment pensé, varié, et une fois maitrisé les sensations sont top.
Les fonctionnalités/armes sont amenées progressivement, de même que l'agrandissement du bestiaire, tout est géré de façon très progressive et équilibrée.
La campagne solo est longue, le level design et les graphismes géniaux et impressionnants de détails.
Le jeu a vraiment été poli jusqu'au bout par les DEV, et le résultat bien au dessus de mes attentes, difficile de lui trouver un seul défaut !

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

This fits the hardware, but it didn't fully execute what it was trying to do. It's the same battles over and over with no differences. The Gem Apples currency is  cute and all but all it's used for is new skills. Playing later on, it becomes a grind to get those.

Every player will see the same ending. However, which specific fragments of the greater truth they will have collected by the time the game ends will differ vastly from player to player. Even if the thousands of little decisions in conversations or time-management the player has to make don't seem to matter when the plot resolves; they matter tremendously along the way. The illusion works, and the overall experience is unique.

And that might be one of the many points Pentiment tries to make: How complex and fragmented the truth is; and how fleeting and malleable it is to the extent that it's always in danger to not really matter at all in the end. And then life just goes on. People try to forget and that's terrifying for those who care for the truth. Even phyiscal evidence in books or any other form cannot stop this collective process of erosion.

The characters and dialogues in Pentiment are realistic and alive in a down-to-earth kind of way. Some will find it boring; I found it refreshing and endearingly subtle. Love or hate for this game will hinge on that. Objectively, every theme that is touched is explored with great care and research behind it, which is immensely satisfying. Pentiment really sells the illusion of talking to real people in the 16th century and the gameplay is defined by trying to get information out of people by interpreting their social norms and guessing what they like to hear.

A Game very different from anything i've played before, with a story so gripping and anartstyle so utterly beautiful i finished it over the course of a weekend. 
If you don't mind reading a lot of well written dialogue and truly thinking thinking for yourself to solve murder mysteries without any handholding, this is a must-play. The ending is especially good.
The only critique i have would be to have more closure on certain story-aspects at the very end

Très bon jeu d'aventure 'historique', sur une enquête menée au moyen âge.
En trois actes séparés dans le temps, le jeu prend le temps de bien développer l'intrigue, les personnages et leurs relations.
La direction artistique est agréable et homogène tout le long du jeu.
Le jeu parle beaucoup par contre, pour un second run c'est un peu lourd parfois.
Ici pas d'objet à ramasser comme un point'n clic, mais des dialogues et des choix à embranchement.
On sent le souci du détail historique dans les décors et les discussions, un vrai travail de fond et de forme a été effectué.
A noter que les sauvegardes sont automatiques, mais on peut revenir jusqu'à 8 sauvegardes en arrière pour tester différents choix.

Joué sur PC via le game pass.

The roleplaying mechanics are dialed back a bit from other Obsidian games but its still pretty effective here. You can pick things like where Andreas (the main characer) studied and what he studied. I picked Law and Occult studies, and it made for an interesting combination. Both skills came up quite often in conversation and were very handy when I was investigating leads. When talking to characters sometimes when you make dialogue choices the game will pop up a "This will be remembered" message like in a Telltale game, and this basically comes up later when trying to perusade someone, as it will list a bunch of options you picked before and whether or not that person agreed with you which leads to either a successful or unsuccessful persuasion. Simple but it gets the job done. 

The comparisons to Disco Elysium are fair in some cases but a bit off base in others. It definitely has that similar detective vibe of you trying to solve a murder, but otherwise its quite different. DE has a lot more systems at play and the skill checks are based on dice rolls, where as this is just a simple you either have the skill or you don't system, which I ultimately prefer. I do wish there was a leveling system similar to DE's but otherwise theres not much to complain about.

The story overall I thought was very good and well told. The first two acts had me hooked as to who the killer was and I kept feeling like I was making the wrong decisions, but in a good way. There's plenty of choice and consequence here and I love to see that in RPGs. Act 3 did drop off a bit for me in terms of my interest in the story, as your not really solving a murder but rather learning the history of the town, which I didn't find as interesting. However it does pick up towards the end and I found the twist to be very unexpected. And I thought the story wraps up nicely by the end of the game.

Otherwise I don't have many complaints. The OST is very good but it only plays during certain key story moments and I would have liked it to be used more. Even just a simple town theme that would play when your running around the town would have been appreciated.
A half-assed attempt to make some extra cash on success of the previous franchise installment, poorly done even by musou standards.

Strikers seamlessly continues the captivating narrative of Persona 5, diving six months into the lives of the Phantom Thieves. Set against a backdrop of societal issues like bullying, obsession, redemption, and forgiveness, this mature and immersive game explores relevant themes. It introduces charismatic new characters like Sophia and Zenkichi Hasegawa while delivering dynamic gameplay that blends action RPG elements with the Musou style. Players will find the familiar Persona franchise features intact, from elemental strengths and weaknesses to stealth mechanics. Switching characters mid-battle and using the environment as a weapon keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. This visually stunning game paints a vivid picture of Japan's cities, complete with well-produced animated scenes that enhance the story. The soundtrack, with its mix of rock, pop, jazz, and electronic influences, complements the game's unique identity. "PERSONA 5 STRIKERS" is a worthy tribute to the Persona universe, making it a must-play for fans and action-adventure enthusiasts alike.
This is one of the best games I have ever played. The atmosphere is amazing and very creepy. The Little Nightmares story is one of the best stories I have ever seen in any game.
Very bad, awful controls, cliche enemies, dont bother with this one

reviews.title: leffdano's review of Little Nightmares II

reviewText.content: Très bonne suite de Little Nightmares. Question narration, c'est toujours dans la même optique. L'ambiance du jeu est très flippante malsaine et c'est ce qui fait sa particularité. J'ai toutefois l'impression que le saut est différent que dans le premier. On doit souvent recommencer des passages où il est possible de réussir du premier coup juste par problèmes de contrôles des touches, ce qui nous sort un peu du jeu.

Little Nightmares II surpasses its predecessor in everything that the first game was already good at, such as atmosphere and art design. Thanks to the AI companion, it also adds more gameplay depth and environmental storytelling opportunities. I particularly appreciated the introduction of opportunities to fight back and have a few swings at combat rather than just running away.

The core game-play of this game is top notch. Inspired by old RPG's (shout out to Pokemon trainer encounters), this sport-made-videogame is a great blend character leveling, compelling story, and fast-paced game-play. The only reason to not give a 10/10 is a dragging ending, but maybe that was inspired by some other games in the RPG genre as well. Give Dodgeball Academia a chance, you won't regret it.

I currently have 38.5 hours into this game I recommend this game to anybody who wants to give racing/drifting a try also the price is not very expensive. The game is amazing at first but after a while it gets boring. You can play friends or with strangers within the online co-op to enjoy the racing/drifting together. There is a good amount of cars to earn in the catalog that it offers also notably the customization is solid to make the car to your own liking styling or performace. Lastly there is more content you can buy for such as maps or cars to explore more in. The game itself does still get updates after a while so its a nice to comeback after while just to check whats fresh

Мы играем за сборщика компьютеров. В наши руки перешел офис, где нам и предстоит работать. Первоначально офис был один, но со временем разработчик добавил еще два рабочих места. Первое из них выполнено в стиле Razer. Повсюду зеленое свечение и их логотипы. Ну а второй в стиле ASUS, аналогично, как и с первым вариантом повсюду характерное свечение и их логотип. Со временем в игре будет меняться геймплей. Это, конечно же, первый плюс этой игры. Если в начале мы просто чистим компы от вирусов и от пыли, то под конец мы уже будем искать поломку в компьютере, полностью его разбирать и собирать, тестировать и разгонять. Все мелкие детали были соблюдены. Например, даже если вы собрали компьютер из самых лучших деталей и попытаетесь его разогнать по максимуму, то некоторые детали просто сломаются. Второй плюс этой игры - это настоящие бренды. Тут можно встретить Razer, ASUS, Intel, MSI, AMD, NVidia и многие другие всем нам знакомые бренды. Как говорится в описании игры цены на комплектующие указанны максимально приближенно к реальным. Ну и наконец третий плюс этой игры - это возможность создать ПК своей мечты. Вот серьезно, сомневаюсь, что я смогу в ближайшие 10-15 лет собрать себе комп с RTX 2080Ti и Intel Core I9, но тут можно это все собрать и кастомизировать как пожелаете. А теперь первый и последний минус этой игры - это плохой сюжет, а точнее тут он сделан для галочки. Можно было бы сделать более проработанную историю с логическим концом, но к сожалению тут этого нет.

reviews.title: PC Building Simulator - Fair n short review

reviewText.content: It's a low class game which is not worth its price at all. Very similar with "Internet cafe simulator"

reviews.title: arm_m4's review of PC Building Simulator

reviewText.content: Typical indie simulator. Very similar with Internet Cafe Simulator

reviews.title: Yadi12345's review of Super Monkey Ball: Banana Mania

reviewText.content:
Super Monkey Ball: Banana Mania isn't very impressive. The game is fundamentally the same as previous entries in the series, which is fine since the core physics and movement is pretty tight. Besides that, Banana Mania doesn't have a whole lot going for it.

The campaign mode varies significantly in quality between levels. On one level, you might beat it first try in 20 seconds, but on the next you might get stuck there for dozens of minutes, only for it to go back to extremely easy on the next level. The difficulty doesn't really have a natural progression to it. The first few worlds seem to be geared around the assumption that you'll go for collectables, but if you don't care about those you'll breeze right through the levels.

One of the core issues is level design, which is desperately lacking in some parts. The game is constantly throwing new mechanics at you, but doesn't seem interested in helping you actually get better at the game. Sometimes everything clicks and sometimes nothing does.

One thing that the game has going for it is the style. Music and visuals combine to make an enjoyable experience. The characters are pretty cute and make lots of noises as you play the game. I also like the little comic-book style cartoons before and after each world.

Overall Score: 5/10

An absolute masterpiece of a game. Well deserving of the "Game of the Year" mantle.
Also, the expansions add a HUGE amount of content, not like your run-of-the-mill DLC which gives you cosmetic skins and stuff (though there ARE 16 such DLC, they are completely FREE)
If you like RPG, and haven't played this game, you're missing out!

reviews.title: markayawann's review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content:
The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt stands as a story-rich masterpiece that leaves a lasting impression. Its characters, motivations, and captivating narrative have etched themselves in my memory, even after considerable time has passed since I played. The game's immersive world and engrossing quests create an unforgettable experience.

However, the combat mechanics, though once groundbreaking, show their age and can be a source of frustration. Engaging enemies in tight spaces can be a clunky and cumbersome affair, detracting from the overall enjoyment. Despite this flaw, The Witcher 3's strengths in storytelling and world-building shine brightly, making it a game that lingers in the mind long after the adventure concludes.

LONG REVIEW (Covers main game + both expansions)
This game is overrated! is probably what your thoughts will be as a person who straight jumped into the 3rd Witcher game, it’s a massive game, and your opinion about it would count after at least 30 hours which is almost the time to play a new game, those who feel overwhelmed by it and found it tedious will probably not wait for ~30 hours to decide. Which is unfortunate, as its only after about 30 hours that this game progresses from something that is tedious/slow/overwhelming to come show itself to be one of the most polished deep video games that's been made to date. And when I say deep I don’t meant it to be very abstract in its writing, or bombarding the player with themes and theories that they couldn’t have up with, in fact there is nothing very deep or unexpected in it. What it has however is a sense of scale that is unsurpassed in any video game I've ever played.

The Witcher 3 continues the story of Geralt of Rivia, a known monster slayer aka Witcher who …you guessed it ..kills monster! After the events of the Witcher 1 & 2 Geralt has restored his memory and now he is searching for his former partner Yennefer of Vengerberg, Geralt with Yennefer have to look for Ciri who is constantly on run and is being chased by the "Wild Hunt"
The story starts slow as Geralt wants to find Ciri his adopted daughter, the game just like its prequels consists of prologue, acts, epilogue, the prologue starts with a tutorial area called White Orchard which teaches the player about the game and introduces them to its basics, it is this part that is slow and tedious because the game didn’t kick in yet, the game continues with act 1 main goal which is to find Ciri, the story may seem very simple as you have to look for a character but inside the journey Geralt will meet very complex characters and the main quests start going branching paths to side quests who are among the greatest side quests ever written in gaming. The game continues with ACT 2 and takes into the epic battle genre this time, in this act the game has lord of the rings vibes, an epic battle, which then continues on its epic scale into ACT 3, until the epilogue which can vary depending on the player decisions in the game. No matter what ending the player gets it always has something great and emotional behind it.

The story doesn’t end there, after the main game CD project RED introduces an expansion (Hearts of Stone) which is a short story expansion that blew my mind at how smartly written and engaging it is, the expansions introduces one of the most cunning and mysterious villains in history of gaming, and another equally amazing character. Unlike the main game in terms of side quests the quantity is very low, as the main focus here was to tell the short story in the main quest. The expansion also added some of the best boss fights in the whole series, boss fights that were a huge step up from the main game, requiring more mechanics to beat and having more advanced pattern.
The story progresses afterwards to reach the second expansion (Blood and Wine) which marks the end of Geralt journey, in my opinion an expansion one of its kind, very huge area that is also very beautiful, contains some of my favorite characters in the series, the expansion starts as a murder mystery then progresses into something fairytale-like that is full of neat references to famous books and finishes with one of the most memorable boss fights I have ever had in gaming.

It has to be noticed I have not mentioned the other aspects of the game, which I will cover in short. The Gameplay itself is very good, and while the combat and controls may feel clunky at first it won't take much time to get used to them, which afterwards Geralt feels like a dancing swordsman which is what he really is (according to the books and the lore). The combat itself is fairly basic and limited (again because of the lore) and contains light/heavy attack and dodge(side-step)/Roll buttons as well as having signs (mini-magic) it has similarities to Batman combat system, however I find the combat to start getting more advanced and having more depth once the players starts going with alchemy (bombs-oils-decoctions-potions) which basically adds new abilities to the gameplay, on higher difficulties the player needs to take advantage of monsters, read about their weakness and use the Witcher tools to overcome the challenge, the gameplay progresses by increasing levels and unlocking more skills to make various builds and especially around the second expansions it adds another layer to it by adding something called mutations. There are a lot of monsters and each has interesting ideas and design behind them. The dialogue choices are impactful and then there is one of my favorite mini games ever made called Gwent, a tactical card game that is really enjoyable, I sunk many hours into it while forgetting about the quests that im doing. 

The Music is Slavic inspired and feels folklorish, its simple music most of the time, not an orchestra type of music, its simple and has as Geralt says "Nice Tune" it contains many memorable soundtracks.
The voice acting is greatly done as well, there is a difference in accents between regions which strongly showcase the different cultures the game tries to portray. 

The art direction is simply breathtaking, the game is very screenshot worthy, to understand this point simply go to any thread on the internet and check for Witcher 3 shots, preferably on PC high settings and the amount of details and beautiful art design is mindblowing. It looks amazing. The character cast is among my favorite, they have great distinct personalities, they have good development and backstory counting the previous games as well, some of the most complex and well written characters in gaming are presented in Witcher series, memorable cast with beautiful design and nice personality. You may notice most characters are not really good and not really bad, its shades of gray as in Witcher world there is no absolute evil or good. 

In-Conclusion the game is open world story driven rpg, the main draw behind the game is its worldbuilding and writing which has main & side quests and characters. The game has the other good aspects as well, but if you are into open world story driven rpg games I cannot recommend this one enough, it is a must play game and is truly among the greatest games of all time, its recommended that you at least be familiar with the prequels Witcher 1 and Witcher 2 at least, to further understand the story better and enhance your experience and immersion. 

Thank you for Reading!

I ended up uninstalling the game, it is so frustrating and doesn't hold the comparison against the Elder Scrolls franchise or the Assassin Creed one.

Have to say, the lore is wonderful, and its open world is huge. Geralt is certainly badass, and there's loads of content (Bestiary, NPCs, Gwent, sidequests etc.)

Issue I have is it's LONG. not long as "Ah i'm so glad i am going to have 300 hours of unlimited fun", but long as "I need to go from point A to point B for a quest, by the time i finish the quest I will have spent 30 minutes, whilst the boss fight itself will take 2 minutes at best".

Also, had some bugs that I saw are shared with other players, where the game is bugged with the gamma and appears extremely dark, to the point you cannot see in dark environment (despite having a torch lit). This can be ultimately solved by manually editing some config files of the games but it's annoying.

Finally - and that's what made me cringe most - geralt and/or his horse must have some rare handicap where they are blocked any time there's a small obstacle in front of them that even a dwarf could walk onto. So you might be running wit your horse and suddenly it stops. Because of the angle of the camera you wouldn't even see the obstacle.

good game overall, especially if you're a fan of the Witcher saga, but sorry I will go back to Skyrim or Assassin Creed

Best action-crime story of the decade. Maybe of ever.
Most people misunderstand that this is a RPG game, with all the tropes, whereas it is a number of crime stories, enhanced by the classical language of cRPG games: the fight, the adventure and the exploration.
It is truly superb.

This game is critically acclaimed and for good reason. Its big, beautifull and deep in every aspect, yet is doesnt touches the sweet spots for me personally. Something keeps me from being pulled completly under and i was glad when i completed the game (even replayed it because i told myself that this is the best RPG game out there and i wanted to play both DLC). As said it's my personal opinion and i do aknowledge the greatness of this game (in the same way as i like breath of the wild but dont love it).

Truly one of the best game of all time. Each part of the game on its own is definitely not perfect, but together they blend really well and with the strong story based around the themes of family and growing up player can enjoy every minute and just needs to get at the bottom of it all. Witcher 3 is packed with content and different stories, which mash together almost instantly. One of the best parts of the game is setting and the moral choices, which paints the world not in black and white but rather shades of moral grey.

The game looks still amazing after many years since release and the music of it all is memorable as hell. You only need to hear a few notes, to start your emotions once again.

reviews.title: krizak201's review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content: Absolutely great completion of the game series The Sorcerer. Together with the data discs, it opens up a huge world where almost everything goes, and you will meet many characters from the books.

reviews.title: ondra1611's review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content: Truly exceptional game with memorable characters and quests, mostly the side quests. Developers has built this big world full of details. Main story with Ciri is really strong and takes your heart together with music and stunning visuals. All together the game is maybe a little too big, but most of the parts are really well made.

reviews.title: xenaven_'s review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content: Long and immersive gameplay & story. It's an experience that everyone should enjoy.

reviews.title: keyduq's review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content: One of the best games I have played in my life, the only one that I regularly come back to play the whole thing again.

reviews.title: disillus10n's review of The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt

reviewText.content: An absolute monster of a game – personally, this was one of the most satisfying experiences I had, the environment is beautiful (especially Toussaint, of the Blood and Wine expansion). I played it on two platforms just because it's so great, the story and sidequests are crafted with passion and attention to detail. If I could only play one last game, I'd start another run of The Witcher 3.

If there is one game I would recommend, it would be this one. Since the beginning of the story in White Orchard to the lush fields of Toussaint found in the DLC, this game has changed me. I would highly recommend this game to those who enjoy playing a game for the story and taking the time to immerse yourself in this world created by CD Project Red.

Just a warning, this game is very very long. If you plan on completing all the quests for the DLC and base game, you should expect to play over 100 hours. This isn't a personal problem for me, if anything you know that you will be getting your money's worth. (especially when the complete edition of the game goes on sale for $15) Although, the main story is a monster to complete and I know that can be a turn off for some people.

Side quests feel well written, almost as good as the main quests, if not better. They just add another layer to this dozen layer wedding cake of a game, baked with care and love. The only part I wasn't a fan of was Gwent. Gwent is a minigame found throughout the entire game that provides more play time, extra quests, and even alternate decisions in quests. Thankfully, Gwent is never mandatory to play, although I felt forced to play it as a 'completionist' to 100% the game.

Overall, if you are debating on playing this game or not... play it. It is worth all the time and energy spent. Like I said earlier, this is a big recommendation to those who enjoy experiencing long and rich stories.

reviews.title: A game worth playing more than once

reviewText.content: Witcher 3 is one the best games I have ever played. As I typically like story driven games, and skill issues.
Have thing is 60 seconds its fun love it good art work keep it up

An interesting and relaxing sliding puzzle game with a background narrative told through level names, the year indicated and the actions required to complete some levels. For those interested in trying to put it together. 
It took me around 5 hours to complete and find everything in the game on Steam.

The goal of the game is to collect all the pearls in a level using the indicated number of moves, though you can go over that number and continue to progress. There is also a jewel hidden in each level, which can be a puzzle of their own due to the steps needed to access some spots.
The main game has 84 levels that are split across 7 shelves by year, each shelf has 3 pictures and each picture has a set of 4 levels. New mechanics are introduced on almost every shelf with the difficulty increasing through mechanic interactions and the number of moves required to complete levels.
There is a hint system in the game that I didn't interact with, from what I remember it apparently gives a hint for the first token used then shows you the intended puzzle solution for the movement number indicated. 

Some levels can be completed in less moves than indicated because of specific mechanic interactions. These small skips mainly matter for the leaderboards that ranks that amount of moves used on each shelf of puzzles. The global leaderboards do have some cheaters listed with impossible scores but it can still be satisfying to see your rank with a group of others that found a skip or simply finished a shelf of puzzles perfectly. There is also an option to compare scores against friends on Steam.

reviews.title: Bien sur le papier, fastidieux/ennuyeux sans directive claire dans la pratique

reviewText.content:
Malheureusement une grosse déception.
Le jeu boucle sur un temps d'une dizaine de minute, dans un lieu clos, mais notre personnage uniquement garde en mémoire ce qu'il a pu apprendre des boucles précédentes.
Les possibilités sont nombreuses, mais de temps pour tester est à la fois court (frustration de ne pas pouvoir tester énormément de choses avant la fin de la boucle) et trop long (refaire un test dans une nouvelle boucle demande de refaire toujours les premières étapes ce qui vite ennuyant).
Au finalement jeu fait avec un guide, je n'était pas du tout dans l'état d'esprit qu'attendais les développeurs, jamais je n'aurais trouvé le cheminement de toutes ces actions.
Le twist de milieu de jeu m'a paru de plus peu crédible.
Donc bien sur le papier, fastidieux/ennuyeux sans directive claire dans la pratique.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

La estética cansa rápidamente y los movimientos de los personajes son bastante toscos. Aunque la idea podría ser interesante y me gustaría ver más propuestas con esta premisa, el juego no va tanto de averiguar qué está sucediendo como de descubrir qué quiere el juego que tú hagas y hasta donde te permite llegar.

The biggest problem with Twelve Minutes is the premise of time loops. Avoiding spoilers, the game-play is not satisfying, because you often find yourself stuck doing the same things, especially with a timer for each "run". Not to mention that in order to progress, sometimes you literally have to do the same thing as the last time. It makes sense from a story-telling perspective, but you being the character and repeating these steps is just tedious. I had to find a walk-through after a couple of hours because I was interested in the story, but I just did not want to play it anymore. The atmosphere and the story structure itself are good, and I do not regret playing this, it just doesn't work. I would only play a sequel to something like this with some quality of life improvements.

Great idea, but the story is so boring, still nothing compared to the disappointing ending! I am really sour, the game had so much potential.

Just FYI:
There is an annoying "bug" and in order to avoid poetless hours, I would say play in high\very high brightness.

I finished Bastion in 4 hours, but I did only the necesarry missions.
This points stood up for me

+ Artwork; Bastion has a very lovely style and the Artwork is awesome
+ Music; The soundtracks are really remarkable.
+ Atmosphere; This is a big plus, the atmospehere of this game is actually really deep, thanks to the narrator.
+ Story; I like how the story is told without telling too much. And there are 1 or 2 decision you have to make, that will change the story.
+ New Game Plus; After you finished the game you can start over with all your abilities and items you already have.
+ Difficulty; You can change the difficulty in game in many ways, and you get also more experience and *money* this way.

· Leveldesign; It does not change very much.
· Perspective; sometimes it can be problematic to see what is above or below you.
· Gameplay; It is not bad, but it is very repetitive, but it may change with harder difficulty

Overall it is a really good game.
An absolute blast of a game that inspired countless play sessions and built a basis of games as art for me. I believe this game excels in all aspects.

Bastion is well-known for the unique gameplay experience it offers, creating a wonderful sense of discovery amongst the floating island asthetic. The story is rich and left me genuinely conflicted in my emotions-not regarding my enjoyment of the game, but how I should feel towards the different characters. Who are the heroes and villains of the story? I'm not sure, and I love it!

A must play game. Story, sound, gameplay. It's got it all. I would suggest you play this with your significant other, as it will bring many emotions and might be very enjoyable for both of you. One of the most enjoyable soundtracks also, be sure to grab that with the game =)

reviews.title: The Calamity Begins... Or Does It?

reviewText.content:
In Bastion, the ground comes up under The Kid's feet as he walks; the ground that remains, that is. You must visit these broken-up islands, eliminate the enemies that attack you, and collect shards of power so that you can provide power to a large structure called "The Bastion," which becomes your player's home base. It also becomes the only safe haven, as well as the player's space for new buildings that can be built, which allow many different bonuses, utilities, and also some options that can provide different challenges.

The game's currency, fragments, can be used to purchase upgrades, make buildings, and improve weapons. Gaining experience also boosts the player's stats and gives them more health. Throughout the game, there are various weapons that you can collect, although you can only have two equipped at a time. You can also equip a special attack, and there are quite a few different types in the game. Enemies drop potions, that, when drunk, can restore some health or give you the special items needed in order for you to use your special attack moves. In order to change your weapons, you must use an arsenal at The Bastion.

You'll often find structures and ruins, and places where life suddenly stopped; when The Calamity hit. You will come across many fun and challenging areas, as well as challenges that reward you with EXP and with other items.

reviews.title: thexder0's review of Blades of Time

reviewText.content:
Blades of Time is primarily a hack-and-slash game (attack, block, slide out of the way, jump for different attacks), but there are many interesting mechanics which add tons of variety to the game:

* Once you get enough "rage" by hitting enemies, you can unleash a variety of spell-like abilities (fire spells, freezing spells, heavy strikes, sliding attacks); all of these are satisfying to unleash and the interface with the controller is well thought out and easy to remember.
* There is a "Time Rewind" skill. This can be used to solve a few light puzzles, but, more importantly, it can be used in combat as well. This makes for some exciting fights, where multiples copies of you are casting, shooting and hacking at an enemy (and some enemies must be attacked from multiple angles at the same time);
* Yes, shooting, because the game also has a few rifles, and their mechanics is surprisingly smooth and satisfying, meshing well with the other game systems, even with a controller.
* And there is a little bit of other stuff which is better left to be discovered (use of light and shadows in a particularly interesting level, a few uses of an "order" spell, some other cool movement options).

The plot is not groundbreaking, but it is interesting enough, and it adds to the gameplay -- in the second half of the game, there are rivaling factions, and you often see your enemies fighting each other, which adds more chaos and action to the scenes. The dialogues aren't Shakespearean, but are well written enough, and the voice acting is also good enough.

Also, the graphics aren't exactly technically groundbreaking, even for a 2012 game -- models are blocky, textures aren't too sharp... But artistically, I found them very appealing; the surroundings evoke mysterious and alien architectures and are very pleasant to look at. The bigger spell effects feel particularly "punchy"; when many of your copies perform a big spell simultaneously, it is even hard to see what is going on... but it still looks super cool. And the animations are well done, the whole game feels very responsive and smooth as a consequence.

Finally, there is this "Outbreak" mode, which is a very light MOBA mode (think "simplified League of Legends") but with the mechanics of the single player game (except Time Rewind). I played a few single-player rounds with it and had fun, but did not really dabble in any MP with it.

All in all, this is an awesome underrated gem. Score: 86/100.

reviews.title: Snaplyn's review of Secret Files: Sam Peters

reviewText.content:
Als abendfüllende, seichte Adventurekost völlig ok, aber selbst für 2013 sollte der Dialog- und Charakterschreiber am höchsten Feminismusbaum aufgehängt werden.

Hier findet man eine frauenfeindliche Reduktion der Hauptcharakterin auf das Tomb Raider artige Cliché-Püppchen gemessen an unzähligen Kommentare beim Untersuchen von Orten und Gegenständen. Das ist mir wirklich negativ aufgestoßen. Und das sagt ein Mann, der nicht viel von Frauenquoten oder Päritäten, sondern viel mehr von Kompetenz und Eignung als Kriterium hält.

This is a hard one to judge.
I purchased this on the release day with the sole purpose of playing coop with a friend, but that failed miserably as the net-code of the game was severely broken and it was unplayable @ multiplayer.
So, I forgot about this game for half a year and just now realised that I haven't played it yet, so I gave it a try.
This is a classic hack-n-slash, let's break it down to points a little bit.
pros:
-Good setting, steampunk, mad scientists, vampires, monsters. All that good stuff.
-Gameplay feels solid. UI is good, mechanics are there and do not fall apart.
-Katarina =)
cons:
-Out of 3 classes of heroes - 2 are locked away in DLC. That's just a dick move really.
-Simplicity of it's core. Zero build diversity, while you have to appoint attributes and skills - it's pretty much useless, you might as well had them auto-allocated. Action is not as good and diverse as in Diablo 3, systems behind the game are not as deep and complex as in Path of Exile.

I will definitely finish the game, because it grabbed me in some way, but I really couldn't recommend to buy this game, as it seems like a easily skippable one.

reviews.title: Decent ARPG that didn’t overstay its welcome

reviewText.content: Decent ARPG that didn’t overstay its welcome. Huge plus for having a WASD control option.

Chaos;Child is a very dark murder mystery visual novel with fun character interactions and shocking, unpredictable twits, but fails to really stand out due to the bloated dialogue and very, very slow plot advancement.

There's nothing that really 'repels' me about the game - but in the end, the question remains for me as to why this game is actually needed. The controls are kind of okay, the fact that you regularly move from 1st place to 8th place and back again during a race is noticeable in a negative way and you can switch off the soundtrack completely without a second thought. It's still nice. If the game were particularly innovative at any point, I might play it fairly regularly. But here I have the feeling that I've seen pretty much every aspect of the game implemented better somewhere else.

This game has been installed on my PC to try, since it's free-to-play, and everyone remembers the fundamentals of the legendary game Bomberman. Super Bomberman R Online is basically a battle royale style game using the game mechanics of Bomberman. It is a great idea in theory, but in practice, it just hardly works. Yes, playing against other players trying to trap them and win the tournament sounds fun, until you actually try it. It is erratic, the game field is very small, so the walls are down within a minute, and then you start chasing other players waiting for someone to make a mistake. The game definitely has the potential, but it needs a lot of refinement to be actually fun.
Best gameplay Mechanics. Loved the web swinging and shooting so much :)

reviews.title: If you expect a cute short story with adorable characters, then this is what you'll get.

reviewText.content: Don't get me wrong, I really enjoyed this part of the experience, as well as the wholesome chunky graphics. But the rest of the game is pretty... meh? It's really, and I mean REALLY, slow. Even your character moves slowly without any sprint button, which is especially noticeable in locations like apartments or an arcade, where you need to get up the stairs or up and down on an elevator. And there is no beautiful scenery that you need to slowly enjoy. You manually slowly move your camera, because things like doors or characters are usually somewhere offscreen or behind another object. And when camera moved by itself (like during or after the cutscenes), it made me motion sick. For you to slowly change the location tile you need to be outside and in the starting point of that location. Which means that in an arcade, for example, you need to get back to the other side of the second floor, click on the elevator, wait to go down, run through the whole room to the door, click on it, wait and only then go through the tiles, probably accidentally skipping the one you need. In the park you can't open your tiles even if you are in the OUTSIDE PART of the hideout, you need specifically be near the playground. Most of the quests are either "go to the other side of the room, say this to that character and then go back to me so we can repeat that process" or "exit 3 rooms, go to that tile, run to the end of it, get into the building, find that thing and backtrack all the way back to me, only for me to give you another quest IN THE SAME PLACE YOU WERE IN BEFORE SPENDING 3 MINUTES TO RUN BACK". And I'm not even talking about side quests, where you need to talk to some character, whose name you don't remember at all, so you need to run around, talking to everyone and just hoping one of them will be some kind of blended together in your head spice or herb name that you need. I originally thought that this game is just a bunch of minigames or arcades, where you challenge characters on rock-paper-scissors and things like that. But it's not. In the end there are only 3 and a half minigames: rhythm-game, race, lemonade stand and a main one about fighting and collecting more fruits then another team. None of them are particularly good. Rhythm-game is really clunky, so I, as a vivid rhythm-games enjoyer, didn't beat even a first opponent and gave up on that one. All races are held on the same exact map that you will get tired of on the third lap. They are boring and really easy, especially as soon as you realize that you can just hold a speed up button and constantly drift from side to side. Lemonade stand is whatever, it gets repetitive really fast, so I actually played it like 1-2 times. And a competitive game is pretty unfair: your teammate's AI is stupid and ruin half of the matches, while the opponent team is always together and just ambush you 4 on 1 when you are running to the blender. Controls in this minigame are clunky, you often miss and even if not you still barely deal any damage. It's always held on the same map with the same fruit placements and the same team sides (except 1 time), so it's not really challenging and still is boring. Dragging through those minigames to get buttons is a chore. I've encountered a lot of softlocking and regular bugs, that forced me to alt + f4 the game and lose my latest progress. Every time when I closed the game and opened it again it was on 0% volume for some reason and my accessories were taken off. I still 100% the game and the story about childhood adventures is something I personally really enjoy in my media, so I guess it says something.

Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night Review
By:
Wanderingoff
If you are looking for a game that can bring you a challenge and a lot of exploring this game will be for you. When playing this game you will find yourself lost more than once and wonder what you need to do in order to get to the next part. Sure that can be annoying and very frustrating. Let me just say this the game will give you an amazing experience in your first completely blind playthrough of it. The gameplay will have you excited to figure out the map and with a few patients and poking your nose around every nook and cranny you will finally figure it out. Personally, for me, I would get completely stuck with no idea of what to do so I would spend time running through it all again and again just to see what I may have missed or if something I did finally unlocked a different part. The good about this was that I would get to kill monsters over and over-collecting shards and then selling them. As I said earlier that can be rather frustrating and even annoying. Yet for some reason the way this game is designed it really did make it so it didn't actually get too frustrating.
The gameplay itself is simply fantastic and yes normal can be a great challenge. There are two other difficulties Hard and Nightmare. At the time of writing this, I am currently working on my hard run. I really want to jump into Nightmare and see what it is like although in order to do so hard must be beaten. Now don't get me wrong I am thoroughly enjoying my playthrough on hard. Something about this game though just makes me want to find out what Nightmare is actually like. I am guessing pretty brutal.
I must say this that the excitement for the game became even more real when I got the first boss on hard. Something was a little different than what it was like on normal. Now to me, this makes it epic. I really enjoy the fact they added something. We get to a boss expecting the same fight and don't think much of it at all no matter what difficulty setting we have it on. Because low and behold we have already beaten it once so we know what to expect. Well to throw a wrench in things on thing got added and changed the entire boss challenge completely. This is why I am even more excited about this game.
The first boss encounter for me on Normal, die okay well I can get that die, and then beat it. First boss encounter for me wtf??? DIE, level up, DIE, LEVEL UP, DIE, I'm never gonna get this boss what do I do. A few hours later oh hey if I do this it will help me not to DIE. Finally, at level 13 I was able to defeat the boss. I will say this for the first few times of attempting it I did get frustrated because I had no idea what I could do. So I ended up logging out of the game. A few hours later I got back into and went to work with a bit of patients and just watching the moves that were happening I was finally able to figure out how and what I needed to do. In all honsesty, I almost didn't think I was going to get through it. You can see the result of the fight here:
https://clips.twitch.tv/DepressedPiliableCobblerCopyThis 
Only if you wish to. I strongly suggest that the best experience that can be had is for you to do your first playthrough on normal. Then do a playthrough on hard and get to see the change for yourself. It was great for me because I had absolutely no idea there was going to be anything shocking to expect. I do not mean to spoil it for you and the reason for the clip is because well yes I am very proud that I managed to beat the boss. With all of that said the game is so much fun you can find many ways to go about playing it. There are a great variety of choices as far as weapons and shards to use. Test them out and find which is the way that fits your play style. 
Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night has many reasons to play through it again. Apparently, there is a New Game Plus option after beating the game. I just barely learned about this a few days into my hard run and after beating it on normal. The thing is it can actually be something you miss entirely if you don't know there actually is a New Game Plus option. I missed it completely and so yes I am doing a clean run on hard with no benefits from the new game plus. In that aspect, it can be very easy to miss if you don't look for it.
My reactions while playing through this game have really been exciting while entering a boss battle or even just trying to get through a hallway. Lol, there is so much damage that could be avoided altogether easily right... I eat every single thing an enemy throws at me really it's not funny yet I just can't help but laugh knowing some of the hits I eat are completely dodgeable.
There is so much about this game that just makes me enjoy playing it. The developers just went out of their way to make the game epic and it is greatly appreciated. It will be a game I will play many more times without a second thought.
Now the characters in this game I don't really know that I like them per se. It isn't really about getting to know them though it is more about okay go do this and that and win the game. The quests should have been picked up all at the same time with one click. Rather than click five million times to collect each quest while hearing the same phrase over and over again. Sure the quests are worth doing but in away after you see what happens when you first receive them it is a little too plain and really boring. That is probably one of my biggest issues with the game in all and I got over it.
As far as the story goes it was short and easily skippable so for me I didn't really pay attention at all to what was going on. I just went and killed things, collected shards, got lost, died and restarted areas multiple times. There is much more to say about this game and well I am waiting to get to start playing on Nightmare to be able to say a lot more about it.
Value Of Game worth $39.99 Yes
Story is Not Applicable
Characters fitting into Game Yes
Balanced Yes
Graphics Fantastic
I hope that you enjoyed my review of Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night.
Wanderingoff

reviews.title: JustLukas's review of Bloodstained: Ritual of the Night

reviewText.content: What a callback to one of the best games of all time, and Bloodstained can proudly stand on its own as well. Pure heaven for metroidvania gamers, full of diverse abilities, hidden treasures, different environments, tons of enemies. Towards the end of the game (and the very beginning), the game is however very challenging, and the saving system really has you your skin in the game. Also, what you need to do to progress is extremely tough to find out on your own a few times in the game. Still, one of the best metroidvanias I have ever played. It really scratched the Castlevania itch.

reviewText.content: There 're many things to do Exploring the castle with many hidden room, grinding to get all item, techniques, monsters, shards, customize appearance and still can play endgame for collect achievement and item things. Controlling still problem about jumping and directions, It's more accuracy when use arrow button but when you use L stick it's would be hard for attack direction and use some skills.

𝟕,𝟏/𝟏𝟎
I saw this game when it just came out, but did not pay attention to it, because I did not understand that it was a direct copy of left 4 dead with a couple of gameplay innovations, yes, the game is very short, and there is no workshop and map editor, yes, special infected and game design are poorly done, but there is a positive trend, though not fully implemented, for me personally, the atmosphere of the land occupied by aliens was something fresh and a little scary, in some places there was even a good ost, but alas, no one worked fully on the atmosphere and these are just such small "notes". Also about the opponents, yes, the crowds of mindless aliens look a little awkward, but in principle it's funny and looks like an interesting skin-addon from the l4d2 workshop) The gameplay mechanics with the construction of walls are also not so bad, you can play with friends, even despite the fact that I spent about 25$ to play with four friends, I don’t mind, 1. attempts to make good atmosphere, 2. modern graphics, 3. normal impact from shooting 4. The last levels took place in hazmat suits (The authors even tried in some kind of story). In general, the game turns out to be some kind of not very intelligible craft, a test one, I won’t be surprised if this is the first game of the studio, but it doesn’t cost very much, and I think you can buy it, because it’s still another opportunity to plunge into l4d- similar cooperative gameplay in modern graphics, this was enough for me to quench at least a fraction of my thirst for Left 4 Dead 3) and compared to the previous attempt to create a new left4dead "Revelation 2012" by third-party developers, it already looks a little better. And for attempts in the field of atmosphere and plot, at least an attempt, I will never raise my hand to dislike the game and hate the authors, thanks haters, we got an absolutely plotless and atmosphereless "Back 4 Blood". Left 4 Dead never had enough story.

Subscribe on my Steam Curator`s page: https://store.steampowered.com/curator/41977550/

What a fantastic little puzzle game. Though short, this is now in my "Top 10 Puzzlers" of all-time, next to "The Sexy Brutale" and heavy-weight "The Talos Principle", to give an idea of how much I enjoyed it.

Solving a puzzle here feels like cheating on a Stealth-Action game; the main mechanics is that you can rewind or forward time at will, so you can time narrow escapes perfectly. Once you solve a level, you can then watch the action unfold in real time, and it looks really cool, with all those impressive moves you carefully built. This might sound repetitive (there is a lot of trial and error for your timings if you want to solve a level in a time-efficient way), but the well thought-out interface makes it very easy to advance or rewind a few frames at a time until you get it just right.

Also, the puzzles had a perfect difficulty level for me -- they had me thinking hard at times, and every so often I needed a new idea, but I never had to look up solutions of anything. The story is only hinted at, but has a few well done dramatic moments.

Finally, I thought the last few puzzles to be brilliant -- they caught me off-guard, but adapting to the new challenges made up for great playing moments, the kind you want to tell other people about.

Score: 88/100.

Timelie is a short puzzle game that puts a lot of eggs in one basket: time travel, stealth and grid movement. These ideas together work very well and being able to turn back time in order to redo an error doesn't end up making the game frustrating. It's a short game, so the gimmick doesn't feel too old too fast but the game being linear it means that once you're done, you have no real excuse to play it again.

#I do not recommend this game. It's not unique.#

It's short and very straightforward, that's a big plus for such game. Some monster ideas (jars) are just amazing. But the controlling system is meh. There's also virtually no space for story. You are just noname warrior. Your enemy is noname enemy. Enemy and boss difficulty is awesome, but jumping session is eeh. If you are into "very hard platorm jumping, easy enemies that keep spawning" it could be enjoyable, but I've found myself in "meh, this is just boring bullshit trying to prolong game" situations way too many times.

I love the recent South Park games (The Fractured By Whole and The Stick of Truth). I've always been a sucker for JRPGs, and their battle system reminds me of Final Fantasy (in a cartoonish way of course). The map is fun to explore, and it's nice to visit places and homes and stuff. There's a bunch of side quests, which makes it easy to go at your own pace and "explore" if you want (although the map isn't that huge). I'm really a fan of those games.

reviews.title: tanonero's review of South Park: The Fractured But Whole

reviewText.content: Perhaps due to playing this sequel before the first instalment, I found The Fractured but Whole to be a distinct, refreshing, and incredibly enjoyable experience. It retains the traditional satirical commentary that is exaggeratedly humorous, complementing a well-crafted turn-based combat system and basic exploration mechanics. I am eagerly looking forward to playing the Stick of Truth, as I simply couldn't get enough of this game.
