reviews.title: Another win for the Steam series

reviewText.content:
Steamworld as a series is a great example of modern platforming in my opinion, it encapsulate a lot of that retro classic nintendo-like era into a neat package. It has vibrant art style, snappy humour, great tight controls and some innovative gameplays. 

Playing through Dig 2 in particular is a pure joy as far as "classic gaming experience" goes in my opinion. I felt transported back to Saturday morning playing games as a kid, it's a great feel good sort of game. It also improved vastly on most of the elements of the original.

One thing that was particularly apparent is how the grind is pleasant to go through. while you have to go back to town frequently to unload your findings and inventory,the back and forth never felt a chore as you always leave with something new creating an incentive to keep on going. And i'm definitely not a fan of grind and repetitive back and forth in gaming usually.

One obvious negative was that i was surprised when i reached the end of the story. i wrapped up the main quest in just about 8hours. Sure there's still a lot of collectible to be found, but i didn;t expect it to be so short.

I didn't really get the appeal of the first game. Sure it was fun but It wasn't incredibly special, however going into this game, It quickly clicked on me how relaxing the exploration is. Sure there is tension but the simple gameplay loop was was elegant. This was the perfect game to follow up long or difficult games and can be finished in about six hours.

reviews.title: Digging is more fun than I thought

reviewText.content: I liked the digging aspect and trying not to get trapped. It has a fun core mechanic to the game. This was my first SteamWorld game. Image & Form worked hard to distill the game experience. Their games seem to transcend their genre.

The main goal of the game is straightforward: we must find our friend. To reach areas connected to his disappearance, we need to dig deeper and deeper. To dig deeper, we need better equipment, and to upgrade that equipment, we have to mine resources.

The game’s standout feature is the titular digging. Thankfully, it’s more than just mindlessly drilling downward. The gameplay is carefully designed and requires planning—our character has limited vision, which decreases with time spent underground. Digging down is easy, but climbing back up is more challenging. So, we have to carefully plan our routes to specific minerals and decide which rock fragments to break with our pickaxe. Some structures will collapse under our weight, some are fragile, and others remain intact. Without proper support, they can fall and create a new shaft.

This system is very intuitive, and navigating the mines feels natural. Of course, it’s not all about digging—various enemies await us underground, each offering unique mechanics depending on the biome. The diversity among enemies is impressive, ranging from snails to spiders to cultists. Combat flows seamlessly with the gameplay, as the tools we use to mine minerals are also used to fight enemies. This ensures that combat doesn’t feel disconnected from the digging experience.

The music perfectly complements the game’s biomes, building atmosphere without breaking immersion. Harmonica sounds and calm melodies give the exploration a Western vibe, creating a unique atmosphere of mystery and adventure. A few of the tracks are enjoyable even outside the context of the game.

[20-26 Dec 22, played the Moral route] I've been waiting for this since the first trailer and because I liked Cyber Sleuth. A lot of people were thrown off because it's a VN but I play a little bit of VN, so that wasn't a deal-breaker for me. Ultimately, I enjoyed the time I spent with the cast, but wish combat was better and stronger. I look forward to the next Digimon game, in whatever genre that may be!

Nippon Marathon is like Mario Kart except it's a footrace and everyone is tripping and ragdolling over track hazards. It's a game that refuses to take itself seriously and basks in how extremely Japanese it is. The commentator speaks English, mostly, in a thick accent as he calls the shots and it adds to the charm of the game. You can race against the CPU but this game is meant to be played with couch multiplayer with everyone laughing and having a good time. If you want to play solo the game's story is all over the place (in a good way) and you'll wrack your brain trying to keep up with the craziness. I've played this game on the Nintendo Switch and PC and even though the game doesn't run very well on the Switch I'd have to recommend that release for its ease of multiplayer.

RWBY: Arrowfell is basically what you think of when you think "cheaply made licensed game". Which is weird, considering that RT clearly put some budget into it with the cutscenes in the style of the show. WayForward, however, appears to have just slapped the game together around these cutscenes.

So, in terms of gameplay, Arrowfell could loosely be considered a Metroidvania, but it's lacking a lot of the soul of the genre. Level design is boring and doesn't really encourage exploration. You basically just go to the level on the map that the marker tells you, and then run through it until you find what you're looking for. It doesn't really feel like you are traversing an interconnected world.

Movement and combat are both extremely clunky. There's not a whole lot to talk about. The only interesting parts are the boss fights, which are pretty easy once you observe their patterns for a bit. Also, the level-up mechanic is designed assuming that you will evenly spread your points across the four playable characters, but there's nothing stopping you from just dumping them all into one character. So, you can get a fully-maxed out character very early in the game, which makes most of the game a breeze.

Regarding the story, it's pretty boring and really just there to tie it more to the show and get fans engaged. That being said, I do find it extremely weird that RT of all companies decided to make a story where the union leader is the bad guy, while the CEO character just gets to go free despite him also doing a bunch of bad stuff. Curious that RT would write such a story. Hmmmmmm.

Usually I don't have any issues with music in games, even if the music is "just there" and nothing special. However, here there were certain songs that just made me burst out laughing at how poorly they fit the game. There's a lot of over-the-top lyrical songs that don't fit at all in a 2D-platformer, and it pulled me out of the game a few times.

To give some things I liked, the cutscenes were the highlight, since they were in the style of the show. The art style overall was a good way to fit the characters into the genre as well. There were also a few character moments that were good as a fan of the show.

Overall Score: 4/10

Sort of limited by the hardware (developed for Vita), Lacrimosa of Dana is a great simple RPG with too many loading screens. Combat is fun, story is fun (although takes a while to get interesting), the characters and their fighting styles keep you busy. The story tends to drag a bit towards the end (with many, many dialogs and unnecessary information), but overall, it keeps you going. Not a lot of games are this long on a handheld.
Now at the end of my Ys journey and a great one to end on. There isn't really much I can say about this game. It feels like a culmination of the last 3-4 YS games and is done well.
My first Ys game! Finally finished (with the true ending) at around 37hrs.

There's more to Cuphead than I originally thought there would be. It's not even the hardest platformer I've ever attempted to play. It is punishing though. Like most people, I've never seen the vast majority of the game because I simply cannot progress. Beating any level at all is near impossible. It's a game I've moved to my "played" list despite feeling like I barely started, trapped in a loop of playing the same three or four levels over and over, never winning. Oh well. Mad points for the aesthetic and what's been put together here. Massive deductions for the difficulty.

I see what you did, but it's not for me. 

This game is clearly a work of love, and it has been made with an incredible level of quality. The look and feel of the game is absolutely fantastic, and the story itself has enough to establish the premise of the game while not getting in the way. 

Unfortunately for me, I could not progress beyond the second Island, and it quickly stopped being fun banging my head against the same boss over and over. I think I understand why they didn't provide for a way to decrease the difficulty-as this is a labour of love and the devs clearly had a vision for the type of experience they wanted to create. Unfortunately, insisting on that particular experience effectively bars gamers like me from actually enjoying the game.
the anime style is amazing, but the game is a little hard for me.

reviews.title: Cuphead: entretenido y único a mas no poder

reviewText.content:
Apartado Gráfico: vamos con lo que primero llamo la atención de este juego y lo que posiblemente es el mejor apartado de este juego, si cuphead fuera un indie con pixel art genérico seguro hubiera acabado como death gambit o otros juegos del estilo que pasan sin pena ni gloria. El apartado visual de este juego es una maravilla en todos los aspectos, diseños, animación, detalles, todo lo hace bien, los gráficos malos no son importantes y no arruinan un gameplay, y los gráficos buenos no te dan un juego entretenido, pero cuando un juego bueno tiene un apartado visual que es una maravilla como lo es este caso deja un gusto muy bueno, no solo porque se vea bien, si no porque este en concreto es único, no vamos a encontrar otro juego que se vea igual, y eso aporta mucho a que se nos quede en la mente y lo recordemos. Las animaciones son suaves y dinámicas, los diseños y los ataques también, cada ataque que te lanza un jefe es perfectamente visible y esquivable, los fondos están muy bien hechos y cada jefe se siente único, se nota el cariño y trabajo puesto en esto, no es solo uno de los mejores gráficos en un juego indie si no uno de los mejores gráficos en general que seguro nunca va a envejecer. Los pequeños detalles como la estática en la pantalla, o el sonido de cinta antigua cuando inicias el juego hacen que realmente te creas la ambientación y hacen la diferencia, las letras el diseño de los menús y la interfaz, todo esta perfectamente encajado y nunca te saca de la atmósfera de una animación antigua. 

Apartado Sonoro: a primeras luces parece igual de espectacular que el visual pero, realmente después de escucharme todo el soundtrack porque no recordaba las canciones, pueees, solo cumple, a nivel de soundtrack creo que algunas canciones llegaron a decepcionarme, como la de la pelea contra King Dice teniendo en cuenta que La canción de King Dice cuando te lo encuentras en las habitaciones cuando te bloquea el paso a una zona es una de las mejores pues deja mucho que desear, siento que algunos bosses pudieron tener mejores canciones o mas identificables y no pido nada que no puedan hacer porque Floral Flury es una canción muy buena iconica y que te mete en el combate, no pido que lo hagan con todos los bosses pero almenos si en los mas importantes, se siente como potencial desperdiciado aveces. Pero, no es malo del todo, creo que aveces es adecuado porque aunque no te mete en el combate del todo, aporta mucho a la escena, sigue teniendo temas iconicos que puedes tararear y no molestas, y que en algunas batallas la música este tan en segundo plano ayuda a concentrarte ya que vas a morir muchas veces y pues puede terminar cansándote la canción si destaca mucho, aunque siento un desperdicio que no hayan hecho algo con la canción de King Dice, la canción de su combate es adecuada considerando lo largo que es, es un soundtrack adecuado para el juego pero que no es excepcional y que no se siente genérico solo porque este es el único juego con esta ambientación, pero bueno es justamente el soundtrack que te esperarías en un juego como este, cumple perfectamente y aunque no sea la quinta maravilla sigue siendo mejor que varios soundtracks genéricos que ni aportan nada al gameplay y aveces llegas a silenciar por lo repetitivo que son. En cuanto a los sfx cumplen demasiado bien, todos los efectos de sonido potencian la ambientación, los sonidos de un jefe cuando lo derrotas, los sonidos de los disparos y ataques, cuando desbloqueas algo, cuando estas en el menú, son sonidos que van muy bien con el apartado visual y potencian la atmósfera un 100% junto a el soundtrack

Por lo que este juego es excepcional en el apartado visual y cumple en el sonoro pero siendo único en los 2. 

Gameplay: el Gameplay es muy simple y se agradece, saltar hacer dash y disparar, con estas mecánicas bases se ira desarrollando el juego, tendremos pequeños niveles como Run n Guns, o los mausoleos, pero el principal atractivo de aquí son los jefes, el juego va de enfrentarse a jefes, son el principal atractivo, ir hacia un jefe sin pasar por un nivel molesto o muy largo, para que esto funcione cada jefe tiene que ser único, retante y entretenido, y así es como son.  Cada jefe tiene una apariencia y combate único, no hay un boss que sea un clon de otro a nivel del combate, todos son únicos, hay unos mejores que otros pero es normal, pero en términos generales no hay ningún boss que sea malo, todos tiene su dificultad bien balanceada, para que no te los pases a la primera ni a la tercera, pero para que tampoco estés muriendo contra el mismo jefe 500 veces, con este perfecto balance y jugabilidad simple cuphead logra que el boss rush como mecánica principal funcione, que nos interese ver cual sera el siguiente boss, que cada boss nos represente un reto y sintamos satisfacción cuando lo derrotamos. Y aunque sea simple hay variedad, tenemos distintos tipos de disparos, y amuletos, cada disparo es diferente y no es que vamos a desbloquear un disparo mejor y el primero queda inutilizable, en algunos bosses volví  a usar el disparo básico aun cuando ya tenia los otros, y es porque todos están balanceados, y nos pueden servir mas o menos dependiendo del boss, por lo que no solo tenemos que perfeccionar nuestra habilidad si no encontrar la forma mas cómoda de poder vencer un boss, la forma mas cómoda para nosotros. Y hablando de comodidad, los controles, no lo son, si juegas en teclado, intente configurarlos y no no encontré forma de hacerlos cómodos, tal vez si hubiera estado otro rato encontraba una forma de hacerlo cómodo, pero vamos que se nota que este juego esta hecho para jugarlo con mando, es lo adecuado y jugar con teclado no termina siendo una tortura solo por costumbre, pero si no estas acostumbrado a jugar juegos retantes y tampoco estas acostumbrado a jugar con teclado, pues no vas a pasar de la primera zona. Con un Gameplay simple pero eficaz Cuphead es una muy buena experiencia, no es el gameplay mas original pero si uno muy efectivo dando mucho juego y posibilidades para cada boss

Diseño: la forma en que esta puesto todo hace que este juego funcione y sea tan entretenido, vamos primero con los combates en si 

Tenemos unas cartas que se van rellenando con nuestros ataques, estas sirven para hacer un ataque especial (que depende del disparo) o un ataque super que hacemos cuando llenamos todos los espacios de las cartas (ataques que desbloqueamos en los mausoleos, que son 3) también tenemos la posibilidad de hacer parrys (desvíos o cancelar un ataque del enemigo) sobre objetos rosas, y tenemos una cantidad de 3 vidas osea que en 3 golpes se acaba el combate, todo esto puesto en la misma mesa hace que los combates contra jefes ganen mucho, en primer lugar tenemos la decisión de si ir lanzando especiales o esperar para llenar el super, y dependiendo del jefe o de nuestro modo de jugar puede irnos mejor unos o otros, luego están los parrys, los cuales al hacerlos sobre un ataque nos recargan una carta completa, por lo que aveces podemos arriesgarnos para hacer un parry ya que estos nos recompensan, que los parrys sean sobre objetos rosas es algo también bueno ya que nunca sera ambiguo cuando podemos hacer un parry y cuando no y hará que Mono ver color rosa neurona activarse, y el que solo tengamos 3 vidas es lo correcto, si tuviéramos una barra de vida seria algo mas ambiguo cuanto podemos resistir, porque aveces en otros juegos vamos con toda la vida al máximo y un jefe nos baja la mitad de un solo golpe pero resulta que después nos pega con un ataque diferente y solo nos baja un cuarto, esta bien para esos juegos, pero para un juego donde solo paliaremos contra jefes, que te hagan x daño dependiendo de como se levante esa mañana el boss, son cosas que a la larga puede resultar frustrante o aburrido, por eso solo tener 3 vidas y que cualquier ataque nos baje solo 1 es lo adecuado, así podremos manejarnos mejor, tener mas tensión cuando estamos a una vida, y dar aun mas juego intentando que no nos golpeen para llegar con 3 vidas a la fase que nos cuesta y así poder recibir mas golpes y no recibir un golpe que nos baje toda la barra de salud. Y hablando de fases, otra cosa buena de estos combates es que no hay barra de vida en los bosses, osea no sabemos si esta apunto de morir o no  evitando que nos confiemos o desesperemos, el progreso de cada boss lo vemos en sus fases, todos los bosses tienen distintas fases donde cambia el combate, empiezan a hacer ataques distintos y cambia un poco el combate, dando así mas variedad a cada boss evitando que sea esquivar los mismos 3 ataques de mierda  durante 40 minutos donde la única dificultad esta en que el jefe es un tanque de HP que no se muere con nada a no ser que tengas equipado un montón de mierdas que nunca te explican como se usan o para que sirven (ya te vi genshin impact), también el que este dividido por fases hace que sintamos progreso en cada combate, porque podemos aprendernos todos los ataques de la primera fase y pasárnoslas a la sexta vez sin que nos golpees, siendo así los bosses como mini niveles donde iremos aprendiéndonos sus patrones e iremos pasando cada fase muriendo y aprendiendo en cada una, y como cereza sobre el pastel tenemos que cuando morimos nos muestran que tan lejos llegamos en el combate, lo cual hace que cuando vemos que estábamos a casi nada de derrotar al jefe digamos, “aaa juego asqueroso”, o que digamos que esta ves estuvimos muy cerca y nos motivemos mas  seguir intentando. 

Eso con los combates que hay de el resto, pues el juego no es un selector de bosses, tampoco es ir recorriendo zonas donde cada zona hay un boss único ambientado solo para este, hay 4 zonas en el juego donde están los bosses, el mapa termina siendo casi un selector de niveles que en vez de ser un menú es una mini isla, lo cual le da sentido a el juego ya que básicamente estamos yendo a matar deudores para darle sus almas al diablo así que es como irrumpir en la casa de alguien para matarlo y llevarle sus pertenencias al dueño del casino en el que apostaste todo, cada pelea contra boss esta puesta como un elemento del escenario que destaca por lo que no se sienten puestas fuera de lugar y el mapa no se siente como un selector de niveles disfrazado, ademas que de buenas a primeras el mapa estará bloqueado por alguna zonas, y para desbloquearlas tendremos que matar a los bosses, en dificultad fácil o normal, la dificultad fácil solo nos abre el paso pero no nos da el contrato del alma del jefe que necesitaremos para avanzar a la siguiente zona, por lo que vencerlos en fácil sirve para explorar toda una zona o ir a un nivel Run N Gun que necesitas para ganar monedas, y hablando de monedas y Run N Guns, los disparos y los distintos amuletos los compramos en una tienda, las monedas para comprarlos las encontramos escondidas por el mapa (lo cual lo sabemos porque en la primera zona hay un npc que te dice que no confía en los bancos y dejo todo su dinero por ahí y una moneda esta puesta en un lugar que de seguro la encuentras por lo que sabrás que hay otras escondidas) o haciendo los niveles Run N Guns que nos dan unas cuantas monedas, si queremos comprar un disparo que creemos que nos va a ayudar contra un boss que nos cuesta, podemos derrotarlo en fácil e ir a el nivel Run N Gun para desbloquear monedas y comprar el disparo, así que el modo fácil en los bosses no están tan de adornos. En cuanto a los mausoleos son 3 y solo sirven para desbloquear los ataques super, por lo que pasan sin pena ni gloria y una ves hecho no se pueden repetir.

Ya habiendo hablado todo lo anterior queda hablar de los puntos en los que noto que el diseño falla, el primero es que unos NPC te dicen algo útil para darte una moneda y los otros solo sueltan palabras al azar, y no es muy entretenido ir hablando con todos porque carisma no tienen y solo están de fondo, se agradece pero bueno,  que un tipo me de el reto de hacer 3 parrys  seguidos para darme una moneda y otra me diga que consiga un atajo para decirle y que me de otra moneda esta bien, pero que ambos estén en la misma zona y que en la zona siguiente no haya un npc que me diga algo de valor pues esta un poco flojo y se pudo solucionar haciendo que simplemente uno de esos 2 npc este en la otra zona, no se porque a una zona le ponen contenido interesante y secretos y la otra la dejan vacía haciendo que efectivamente esa en concreto parezca un selector de niveles disfrazado, es solo un detalle menor que no se nota a la hora de jugar pero que se pudo hacer mejor para dar mas sustancia a la tercera zona y no concentrar parte del contenido en la segunda siendo que en esta segunda zona encontramos 3 de las 5 monedas secretas que hay por el mapa. Y otro problema que si se nota a mi parecer, es el pobre balanceo de los amuletos, todos los disparos están bien balanceados y sirven para algo, no hay ninguno que sea remarcablemente mejor que otro en todas las situaciones, pero los amuletos son otro cuento, 2 son una mierda, 3 son decentes y 1 es realmente útil y casi indispensable, el cual es la bomba de humo, que remplaza el dash convencional por un teletransporte, este amuleto nos salvara de incontables golpes y hará que algunas peleas sean mucho mas sencillas, y en ciertas peleas note que había ataques que de no ser por ese amuleto eran casi imposibles de esquivar, esto podría pasarlo por alto de no ser porque estos amuletos se compran en la tienda, jugando puedes perder un montón de tiempo y dinero probando y comprando amuletos que no te sirven para nada, ademas la bomba de humo es uno de los primeros amuletos que te podías comprar, por lo que la intención no era ir usando amuletos decentes hasta llegar a la bomba de humo y ahora si sentir una progresión, la intención era que al igual que con los disparos puedas elegir el que mas se adecue a ti sin dejar una diferencia abismal en lo útil que podían ser, perdí algo de tiempo probando amuletos que muy útiles no eran, almenos el de los dash automáticos sirve para la pelea contra King Dice, los que te dan vida extra a cambio de que hace menos daños son insufribles, el que te permite hacer parry a los bosses pues sirve si quieres no se pasarte el juego sin disparar, y el que va recargando pasivamente las cartas no es tan útil ya que con el del parry automático seguro hasta lo recargas mas rápido, pueden servir a la larga si ya te aprendes los patrones de los jefes y no se quieres ir spameando especiales o te cuesta hacer los parrys para sacar calificación perfecta, pero teniendo en cuenta lo mucho que la bomba de humo facilita algunos bosses pues te resulta mejor aprender a hacer parrys que aprender a esquivar ataques casi inesquibables si no tienes la bomba de humo, Al final esto es un detalle menor donde solo perdieras unos minutos pero teniendo en cuenta que los disparos están bien balanceados me da la impresión de que esto lo dejaron así porque quisieron y porque la bomba de humo estaba algo rota como para ser el dash convencional.

Adaptation du roman éponyme, l'histoire est découpée en 3 livres et une vingtaine de chapitres.
C'est un mélange de point'n click pour les énigmes, et de dialogues déterminants pour la suite de l'histoire.
La direction artistique rend très bien honneur à cet univers anglais moyenâgeux, et les doublages en anglais sont très bons.
L'histoires est très prenante durant la quinzaine d'heures de jeu, la qualité globale restant constante, avec des dialogues et intrigues toujours très bien écrits.
Quelques petits bugs graphiques parfois mais rien de méchant (un perso qui "clignotait").

A game from creators of Bastion. Oh, what expectations I've had for this one. Obviously had the preorder with the soundtrack going and played it day one. And what a strange experience it was. I like most aspects of the game, and yet I wasn't inclined to play it at all next time, so I finished it only now (2-3 months later?) by forcing myself to do it which is pretty sad, because the main story is actually VERY short. Without much of side "challenges" (which are decently designed but most of the time force you to play with predesigned powers ("functions") installed and it was pretty unfun for me, because I like to design my own tactic in this game) the game takes around 3 hours to finish. With getting "some" challenges done it goes up to 4-5 hours. Nevertheless, I don't think this gamelength is really acceptable, so that's a sure "con" for me. Now some pros and some more cons.

Pros:
-The music. It's very good, wouldn't expect otherwise from Darren Korb. While the game was sitting idle in my library, the soundtrack I have purchased got it's share of plays in the last months. Just like in the Bastion. One thing I would say it feels a bit lacking of electronic elements, which would be suitable in this setting. 
-The art is impeccable, with great love to detail. Just like in Bastion.
-The setting. Very strange, interesting, kind of unique. Just like in the Bastion.
-The "functions"-system. Robust and full of variations, makes for good replayability and interesting levelups.
For some cons:
-The story. Very basic, not trying to hook you in at all. Mostly it goes by like "whatever, I am here somewhere, go on now". There's not much happening at all, the synopsis of the story would take approximatly 1 page after it's all done. I mean, I don't belong to the type of players, who cna't play a game, which is weak on story, but I require at least good gameplay to have interest in it.
-The game-play. Repetitive, gimmicky and boring overall. The "planning thing" is gimmicky, overpowered and breaks the flow. The regular mode makes you feel seriously underpowered and is a bit of a cluster-fuck. After I've found the "right" functions combination, all of the fights where just a grind. In combination with the first flaw - it is why it felt like I don't want to go on (I just couldn't figure it out in the first hour yet).
-The sword. He is so whiny and emo it makes me want to smack him and tell him to grow a pair. While he is the 80% of the means how the story and setting is conveyed to player, in the end I just wished he would shut up -_-

Overall, you might want to check it out at your own risk, but this is no Bastion.
A superb and sublime experience that is an easy recommendation. I believe this game excels in all aspects.
A game that's trying to do a lot but succeed in nothing. I get what they were trying to do and some things have high quality feel to them but does not deliver and it is not fun to play.

reviews.title: Très bon jeu, qui aurait pu être un incontournable !

reviewText.content:
++ Une direction artistique magnifique, moteur graphique très fluide, plein de petits détails, du très bel ouvrage
++ Un gameplay basé sur le déblocage progressif de capacités ("fonctions") que l'on peut combiner de différentes façons. Le tout est fait très intelligemment et de façon très logique, beaucoup de combinaisons intéressantes à mettre ensuite en pratique
+ La difficulté reste constante et assez élevée. Pas question de se reposer sur ses lauriers, le personnage n'est pas "cracké" à la fin, comme dans les RPG ; un new game plus d'ailleurs est nécessaire pour débloquer les dernières fonctionnalités
~ Malheureusement celui-ci n'apporte rien d'autre qu'un level up supplémentaire, rien ne change au niveau de l'histoire
-- Histoire d'ailleurs très en retrait, c'est le gros manque : on enchaine les combats, mais peu d'infos sur le monde dans lequel on est, et quasiment aucun PNJ (juste une voix off qui parle bcp et reste sympathique, mais sur le fond n'apporte pas grand chose)

I will be honest this is an useless game. At the beginning is very cute with an adorable art direction and the gameplay itself is not that bad. It is pretty easy to play but sometimes challenging.

That said, the game doesn't succeed in its community aspect, you are asked to have friends or to join a team but you can't contact them (it feels like other players are just bland characters in the game) and the missions you share with them doesn't bring any interesting new things.

You also quickly made the turns of it even if you still have a big amount of missions left... It doesn't work in the long term and it's not addictive enough to convince mobile players to keep going.

Terraria appears to be quite a simplistic game at first. I would assume the majority of players first played Minecraft to some extent and figured they'd try what appeared to be a sidescrolling version of that game.

While everything seems straight forward for the first hour or so, it wasn't long before i realised just how much depth there is with this game. There's a lot to it, much more than i had anticipated. Worlds within worlds, lots of different environments, enemies, weapon types, spells, armor and items to keep you entertained and occupied. I usually don't like to compare games when reviewing them but i think many will draw a comparison to this and Minecraft, and personally i find this to be much more combat and adventure focused rather than the sandbox/building focus that lies with the latter. For me personally, that's a good thing. There are a dozen or so bosses and they all pose different challenges and can be fought in different ways. The world itself feels very alive and as so much of the game is random different playthroughs on different worlds can provide many hours of entertainment.

There aren't too many major flaws with the game itself. Controls can be a bit awkward (on PS3 at least) and there is the occasional bit of slowdown and lag, but nothing too severe. My only real problem with Terraria is the negative aspect of the huge amount of depth within the game. I find myself having to use the wiki or a guide most of the time i play, as every hour or so you find yourself with a bag full of items that can be pretty confusing as you're never really sure what to do with it all. You have to build houses for NPCs and storage space for the many items that you'll need on your travels. Bosses normally require summoning along with an 'arena' of some kind and specific items/equipment to get through, all of which takes time and can be incredibly awkward. The challenge of each boss is good, but the sheer amount of preparation beforehand detracts from the experience somewhat. I find myself spending a lot of time micro-managing items and manipulating the land itself just so i can do x y and z before finally doing what i originally set out to do. While playing i sometimes just wish everything was a little bit more straight-forward.

Terraria is a game that doesn't tell you anything about how to play it or what you should even do, but that's the biggest issue it has.

The game itself is quite fun, and can be played quite a bit (as evidenced by my 1500 hours, lol).

There's a lot of ways to fight, explore, fight bosses, etc. - and the devs keep adding more (anyone else been here for 3+ "final updates"?)

Some say it's "2D Minecraft", and in terms of the sandbox style and modding community, it kind of is - but that's where the similarities stop. Terraria sets itself apart by having a stable game engine that doesn't die if a ton of mods are added, good optimization, and better ways to interact with the world.

Overall, I'd recommend this to anyone. It's a fun introduction to games, but it does have a bit of a learning curve (might wanna keep the fandom wiki open while ya play).
I just start playing it. So many emotions at the start! Like it!

I consider Terraria one of the best exploration games there can be, with a wide variety of weapons, instruments, mobs, bosses, and thanks to the weapons, they allow you to enter different classes. An unknown lore, easter eggs, an excellent soundtrack, a good atmosphere.

A game I really wish was good but it just isn't. The commentator that you hear throughout the game tries his best but isn't as good as if they just had voice actors for every characters. Every idea in this game is cool on paper but just isn't executed well at all.

I have not had much experience with dating sims before, so this genre is a new one for me: and it was a little strange. However, the writing of the ghost personalities was actually very good, and I enjoyed some of the conversations, and some not - which might be intentional, since this is a dating simulator. Original, funny, sad, and with some hidden messages. Nice little indie game.
Great fun for a couple of nights but in the end there is just not enough content to make it worth the price.

reviews.title: Lichking78's review of Minecraft: Story Mode

reviewText.content:
I don't think its for adults, more for kids. My 5 year old couldn't get into the game either, will keep till he gets bit older. I played around 30 min. 
Dragon Quest Builder is far superior to this 9/10!

Tried Last Stop simply based on the trailer once it came available on GamePass, i thought it looked vaguely quirky and mysterious. And it was in the end, the odd characters and underlying story were definitely the high points. But while i was hoping for some weird x-file/Twin Peaks vibe.. it never got to that level. 

Overall it felt like Last Stop had unrealised potential, the story unfolds in an interesting manner (3 side stories played in chapter successions) but then the story itself just.. falls flat? Honestly, i'm not even sure how i could sum up the story itself after finishing it (maybe there are multiple endings?). The final chapter came about very abruptly, out of the blue and did not explain or resolve anything much.
Throughout the story there's a couple random gameplay features that feel a bit out of place. QTE while running, a random FPS investigation chapter, a body scan?! but.. why? they don't add anything, and most of the time feel clunky. 

There's a lot of dialogue choices here, but it never felt like they had any decisions tied to them. I think they open different dialogue trees, but i first expected branching paths or events (like a TellTale game).

Having lived in London for many years a while back, gotta say the setting definitely gave me a smile and brought some personal nostalgia. Which is a very big plus :D Anything from the pub, to the row houses, or the chippy felt pretty delightful. 

All in all, while i enjoyed it somewhat i can't say it's worth a big detour. But if you're into story driven dialogue type games it's a fairly quick play and is entertaining enough. Just lacks in depth.

An ambitious project for an independent studio, that is for sure. I can see where they were headed, but it just didn't materialize. The game certainly had its glimpses of genius here and there, and I was caught up in the mystery at one point. I like when games comprehensively explain what is/was going on, but Last Stop does a poor job at that. Not to mention horrible optimization PC. I do not exactly regret playing the game, but I can't say it was an enjoyable experience. It was so close, though.

Trois histoires qui se croisent, en alternant les chapitres de chaque personnage, puis une conclusion qui vient répondre à toutes les questions (ou presque).
Les histoires de ces trois voisins de quartier se font en parallèle, même si parfois il y a des connaissances communes ou que les personnages se croisent dans la rue, il s'agit plus de clins d'oeil qu'une adhérence dans les histoires.
Ces trois histories sont très différentes, les personnalités et évènements étant différents, mais ont la même qualité d'écriture et de mise en scène, point fort du jeu.
Les graphismes type Unity sont propres et rendent très bien l'ambiance, aucun souci de ce côté là, c'est fidèle aux captures d'écrans qu'on peut voir.
Le gameplay est par contre plus proche d'un telltale avec des choix de dialogue, généralement sans impact fort : il ne s'agit pas d'un jeu d'aventure avec des objets à récupérer ou des énigmes à résoudre. On déroule donc la narration qui est toute tracée, ce qui est pour moi le point faible du jeu (j'aurai aimé un impact plus fort des dialogues ou plus d'exploration/énigmes).

Joué sur SeriesX via la game pass.
I loved this game. Plan to replay it regularly. Can't wait for more content.

reviews.title: Interesting idea but somehow boring and hard.

reviewText.content: Interesting idea but somehow boring and hard. No matter what different approaches I try I keep dying. Probably need tons of upgrades to finish anything but I just left this game.

reviews.title: Una Mejora en la Historia pero un Retroceso en el Gameplay

reviewText.content:
Jugabilidad: el control del personaje es cómodo, pero a diferencia de momadora donde los ataques son muy simples y tendremos que ingeniárnoslas contra los enemigos empleando de forma inteligente el arco y nuestra arma, aquí en momentos se vuelve un machaca botones contra los enemigos básicos, el momento en donde usamos todos nuestros recursos es con los bosses, donde tendremos que usar de buena forma todos nuestros ataques talismanes de curación y todo lo que tengamos para poder atacar a distancia, siendo un sistema simple pero efectivo para mantener batallas duras, pero eso solo es para los bosses, las zonas están a veces repletas de enemigos y tendremos que solo machacar botones ya que no nos queda de otra. LA jugabilidad y control del personaje es cómodo pero se puede sentir tosco a veces por las animaciones, además que las armas que nos da el juego no son algo variado para desenvolver nuestro propio estilo, solo son un chiste malo y 2 armas que atacan exactamente igual pero con un ataque especial diferente, la primera espada solo la usaremos para vaciar el ataque especial en un jefe o enemigo fuerte y después la volveremos a guardar es un total desperdicio los ataques no son casi nada diferentes.  

Diseño: el mapa esta bien implementado pero a veces es ambiguo a donde ir o volver. hay decisiones extrañas como poner el dash aereo en una zona abierta al final donde casi no se ve y solo nos lo dan para utilizarlo una vez para avanzar al final, una habilidad que pudo dar mucho juego y movilidad para que no se sienta tan tosco, ni siquiera hubiera hecho mas fácil las batallas porque todas están bien hechas y una ventaja de movilidad solo haría que sean mas justas en ratos donde no podemos casi ni esquivar. Una vez pasas las zonas no hay tantos incentivos para hacer backtracking no hay cosas que recuerdes como ooo ahora que tengo esto puedo volver a esa zona, ya que la mayoría de obstáculos son una puerta o una plataforma alta que no nos da interés y parecería que llegaríamos desde otro lado, lo cual terminaba siendo cierto en ocasiones, pero en las ocasiones en las que teníamos que volver, de no ser que te pases todo el juego en un día, se te va a olvidar y terminaras dando vueltas por todo el mapa. 

Dificultad: es ajustada, a veces mas difícil a veces mas fácil, mientras mas avanzas mas fácil se hace y su solución es ponerte salas repletas de enemigos difíciles o un jefe overleveleado, para lo que tendrás que ponerte a farmear para subir de nivel.

Graficos: son incomodos aveces, las animaciones se sienten toscas y el estilo poco trabajado, pero como en momodora, el diseño de los personajes es muy bueno cada uno tiene sus caracteristicas que hace que los diferencies y te parezcan bonitos, pero esto solo para los jefes y personajes principales, los enemigos tienen un diseño mediocre parecen clones todos con la misma cabeza o un diseño plano y aburrido que no se beneficia de los graficos.

Soundtrack: decente no hay ningun tema memorable ni nada solo cumple su funcion bien pero nada que destacar 

Historia: lo mejor, tiene un giro interesante, los personajes son genuinamente queribles y el final es muy bueno, las interacciones entre los personajes construyen bien la relacion entre estos sin necesidad de cuadros inacabables de texto, los fragmentos de texto que nos cuentan la historia no son textos inacabables de lore y lore si no que son concretos por lo que es facil enterarte de todo y si no te paras a leer, diálogos puntuales te insinúan el lore y todo. una mejora muy buena en comparación a momodora que es llegar y matarse a coñazos con monstruos y pegarle en las tetas a una bruja sin contexto alguno, aquí desde el principio tienes interacciones lore y objetivo 

a pesar de todo lo bueno que menciono, esas características buenas tampoco son peak, son normales, es un juego simple y disfrutable puedes conectar con la historia pero las zonas y los enemigos no dan para mucho lo mas interesante esta en los jefes y la historia

It was $20 dollars which is not bad but the game is fine, lack of content and not a "fun" as the game says. I don't understand why you would play this when the Wii version has 25 mini games and collectibles, that game came out over 10 years ago and I had more fun playing the Wii version than this
nice
Finished 10 Apr 2021 with 168 loops. [This is the 3rd time I'm writing this review of the game after the first two disappeared. Getting really tired of this site.]

Si la première moitié du jeu est sympathique (ambiance soignée, concept simple et original, ...), la seconde moitié (monde miroir) est vraiment trop tirée par les cheveux, laissant la logique de côté pour des actions hasardeuses et millimétrées qui finissent par dégouter du jeu.

Donc au final plutôt à éviter, dommage.

I really had my hopes up for this game – 2D point-and-click are kind of my thing, humorous or not, and it being set in the lovecraftian setting seemed great as well. And it was really fine too, up to the last two chapters, where everything kind of went downhill. Some of the puzzles lost their logics, some parts of walkthrough seemed as if they should do something but didn't, and it all ended with a very anticlimactic ending, very weakly connected with everything that happened so far in the game, which kind of marred overall playing experience.

this game is my favourite horror game of all time. the story is simple but really interesting, there isnt much to gameplay but thats honestly preferred as I prefer horror games to be more of an experience - and this is definitely a terrifying and constantly tense experience. i felt the ending was a bit ridiculous but i still love this game
i also played whistleblower and that DLC may honestly be even better than the base game

Pretty good. Bought this forever ago when I was going through my "I love horror and only horror" phase. I had never, ever finished it before because I kept getting stuck on some of the puzzles. I realise now I also was just panicking too much about being caught which is why I just kept struggling to complete certain puzzles for years on end. I was literally not letting my brain work XD Now that I've actually managed to play and complete it, it's time for a proper review.

I really enjoyed Outlast. The storyline is simple enough with just enough of a mysterious twist to it that keeps you thinking and wondering until pretty much the end of the game. Speaking of, that ending? WHAT?! I absolutely did not see it coming at all which also helped with how much I enjoyed the game. Don't get me wrong, I enjoy a game where you can easily work out what is going to happen but it is still more fun playing games where you can't guess the ending. There wasn't a huge amount of character development which I was okay with since they focussed more on the story development. There's an appropriate amount of collectibles and it's nice that they glow as well so you can see where they are (at least in the mode I played it in).  The first person aspect worked very well in this game and I enjoyed the way in which they incorporated the video camera. Especially later on in the game where it then begins to feel like you're playing more of a "found footage" horror game because of the involvement of the camera.

Was I still screaming and jumping at every little jumpscare? Yes! But did I still enjoy the game as a whole? Definitely! Would recommend for anyone looking for a solid horror game with jumpscares, puzzles, and an unpredictable ending.

Мы играем за журналиста или репортера, короче за того, кто бегает с камерой и снимает все что попадется ему на глаза. Он приезжает в давно закрытую психиатрическую лечебницу, но открытую снова в 2009 году. Приехал он по причине того, что там происходило что то необычное. Прямо с входа его встречает куча трупов. Спустя некоторое время он уже хочет сбежать но у него это не получается и на него начинают охотится местные маньяки. В конце концов главный герой получает возможность сбежать, но вместо этого попадает в подвал, где производились эксперименты над людьми. Его начинает преследовать дух - Вальридер, у нас получается сбежать, но не совсем. Открываются двери, а там стоят солдаты. Они начинают стрелять. После того как наше тело упало мы слышим, как Вальридер разбирается с ними. Так и заканчивается Outlast. Я не очень хорошо передал здешний сюжет, но скажу так, он мне понравился, это и есть первый плюс. Второй плюс - это хоррор составляющая. Хоть я и не пугался, но особенное чувство все время меня преследовало, в частности во время чейзов.

The main attraction to this game for me was people talking about the ending, which was supposed to turn the story on its head, and be something totally unexpected. The premise of the game was not appealing to me, but I gave it a try. I stuck around just to see the ending. See, if you are that hyped for something, it rarely delivers. And this was so true with this game. While the game-play part was better than I expected, and catching Bugsnax/interviewing/finishing quests was fun, the hype over the story and the twists was way too big for it to deliver. My only reaction after finishing the game was asking if this was really it, and I could not understand why everyone raved about it. The game as a package is fine, mostly suitable for children, and is okay to spend a weekend on. Nothing more, nothing less.

Awful in every sense of the word. It's a combination of copy and pasted ideas from better games and movies, without a single original idea in sight. Silent Hill, Observer, Layers of Fear, Amnesia, The Shining, Stranger Things, Repulsion (though I doubt the devs have even seen that movie with how embarrassing their "homage" was) nothing is safe from this game's shameless imitations. Nothing in the game escapes the mindnumbingly awful brush that these unimaginative paste eaters smear over every inch of the experience. How Wired Productions picked this up to publish is beyond me.

One of those few racing games that are always fun to play for beginners as for pros, especially with lots of people. The gameplay is great, but is somewhat marred by the very daring playlist (for me rather: off-putting) and the, especially for a visually not too demanding game enormous (!) loading times at all corners. But to be honest, the fun of the game is too great to really let that stop you.

reviews.title: An Interesting Twist to Egyptian Mythology

reviewText.content: Including Lara Croft in a game which heavily relies on Egyptian mythology is an interesting and very appropriate choice. The game is fun but can get a tiny bit repetitive as in it's set up that you do this tomb, then the next, and the next, etc. I know that's the point but also the action is also pretty much the same from tomb to tomb. In some you can die from fire, in some from spikes in the ground, and in others from ice cold air coming out from the ground. Avoid these to complete the objective of each tomb, all while being attacked by a variety of very easy to kill enemies in order to bring back Osiris and you'll have to play it yourself to see why Osiris has to come back. Occasionally, some of the enemies were harder to defeat but it was also a little confusing trying to work out exactly what you had to do to defeat some of them, particularly when closer to the end of the game. As always, I found myself constantly forgetting to change weapons which could have maybe made my playthrough even easier if I had remembered. Also, some of the collectibles seemed almost borderline impossible to collect (though this may have been another skill issue of mine). Definitely would say some of the achievements on Steam are also pretty difficult to get, for me at least. The number and variety of weapons was pretty good, and I enjoyed the fact you could also customise which outfit Lara was wearing as well, though more options would have been great as well.

This was a really moving short story. I loved the premise (two scientists altering a dying man's memories so he can die happy). The story was really well done with entertaining dialogue and likeable characters. It also treated some important topics, such as end of life care and autism, with a lot of sensitivity intelligence. The only drawbacks I had for this game were the controls being a little clunky, some repetitive puzzles at the end of sections (although they dont take long and there arent that many) and at first I really hated the art style which looks very bland and to make it worse most of the game happens in memory sequences where a filter washes out the little colour it had to start with, though I got kinda used to it by the end and it didnt spoil a really moving story.  All in all its just a fantastic moving story, of the quality you don't often see in games.

The story is pretty great and full of interesting and bold themes and impressive twists and plot developments. Also the ending, though I found it to be too uplifting at first, is just the right amount of sweet-bittersweet when you think about it. However the writing is spotty and a bit inconsistent, while the game's "game" nature is still in question in my mind. The small bits of interactivity are clearly shoe-horned in and the game only takes advantage of exploratory storytelling in a couple of instances. The fact that they're making it into an animated film says a lot, though I'll still be looking forward to it since this should've been an animated film to begin with IMO. Overall the lack of interactivity and the clear option of a different medium to better convey its story took away from my experience with it, but it's worth playing nonetheless; a great story presented as a decent experience that falls just short of the story's high standard.

reviews.title: darabadan's review of To the Moon

reviewText.content:
I don't know if there is any other game that uses the medium as well. Perhaps the only one that competes with it are the titles of Sam Barlow, which in part is still a story interwoven. To the moon as a book would not work, as a series would be somewhat bland but as a video game that does not use many playable resources works like a shot. It is a tender and very nice story. It may not be a game that everyone can enjoy because it is still a narrative game and nothing more than that but that along with the great soundtrack that makes it a beastly experience and one of the best stories and narratives that have ever had video games.

Highlights:
Emotive and Deep Narrative: 'To the Moon' stands out for its moving story and emotional themes, exploring love, loss and regret in a unique way.
Creative Puzzle Integration: The connection between narrative and puzzles is exceptional, revealing deeper layers of the protagonist's life as challenges are solved.
Nostalgic Visual Design: The retro visual style creates a nostalgic and melancholic atmosphere, perfectly complementing the emotional tone of the story.
Impactful Soundtrack: The soundtrack, along with the sound effects, contributes significantly to the experience, enhancing the emotions and key moments of the game.
Accessible Gameplay: Intuitive gameplay and clear feedback facilitate immersion, making the game accessible to different types of players.

Worst:
Low Replayability: The game's lack of branching options and linearity could affect its replayability. The inclusion of elements that encourage a second experience could improve this aspect.
Relatively Short Length: While the short length may be beneficial to some, some players may wish for a longer experience. The inclusion of additional content could satisfy those seeking a longer experience.

I enjoyed the first 20 minutes or so despite the clunky controls and bickering between the two main characters. But the unlikeable characters became tiresome, and the story didn't engage me until a couple of nice beats towards the end that weren't enough to save it. I played to the end hoping I'd find what the overwhelmingly positive critic reviews had found, but I ended up hating the game more the more I played it, and it was a relief when it was over. Aside from the soundtrack, it felt like a waste of my time.

reviews.title: Très belle histoire, et du beau pixel art

reviewText.content: Gameplay type aventure 2D très basique, histoire intéractive de qq heures, très bien déroulée, avec deux DLC gratuits, qui promettent une suite intéressante.

Story 9/10
The concept of the game is interesting, it manages to tell a very emotional story based on memory, it knows how to be comical and dramatic when it should be. It also touches on very identifiable issues: that either one can interfere in the life of another person or the meaning of happiness, who would like to fulfill their dreams before dying, even if they were false? Very few games tell a romantic story.
There is also no direct exposition, one is watching the story through the scenes and without redundant dialogues.

Characters 9/10
Each and every one of the characters, not very complex but they are very human, with defined personality and very identifiable and queribles.

Narrative 5/10
The work would gain more by being a movie or an animation. The game uses a lot of in-game animations taking control of the character, plus a lot of dialogue. What's more, gameplay and story are completely separate, unlike Half-Life or Outlast.

GamePlay 4/10
The gameplay is very limited, there are not many mechanics and it is often repetitive, so it is good to last only 4 to 5 hours.

Graphics 7/10
The game shows us a very good detailed Pixel-art, with realistic and beautiful backgrounds. It also gets a great atmosphere for the drama, but it usually goes a little bit, especially in comic scenes, where the sad tone of the game does not clear a bit. The design of characters is decent, besides the animations, although good, there is not much expression on their part for the scenes.

Music 9/10
The soundtrack is beautiful, many songs based on piano, that are perfect in the game and its emotional story. However it is not perfect, in the realm of how it is used, because there are comical moments where these songs sound and a little off.

Final Score 7.1 / 10
If they are people who look for fun and playability, it is not recommended, instead if they are looking for a good, emotional and identifiable story, yes.

While I understand what the devs were going for, the result is a frustrating platformer. The general premise and design is good and captivating, the execution is lacking. It is totally possible to accept a task for a pagie (the collectible moving you forward in the game), and being locked out of it due to not having the ability to complete it. Half of the time you are running around trying to solve a puzzle you can't. Contrary to the reviews, I found the camera just fine. But I understand why the studio decided to go another direction for the sequel.

reviews.title: Bon jeu, à deux doigts d'être un chef d'oeuvre

reviewText.content:
Très joliment animé et avec un pixel art bien travaillé, côté graphisme c'est original et agréable.
Côté gameplay notre personnage va progresser et étoffer ses capacités au fil sur jeu ; les différentes attaques/actions sont très bien pensées et bien exploitées, manette en main les combats qui représentent 80% du jeu sont très agréables.
Pour la difficulté il n'y a pas de réglage, et le jeu est assez exigeant sur certains passages ou la majorité des boss, mais ca reste faisable en prenant le temps de bien maitriser le personnage et analyser les paterns.
Les checkpoints sont très fréquents et mourir nous faire revenir avec tous nos points de vie donc le jeu n'est pas du tout punitif.
Son principal défaut est le scénario et ses dialogues imbitables qui font que l'on reste en surface et que les dialogues sont lus en diagonale. Les métaphores à tout va avec le monde informatique deviennent rapidement absurdes et incompréhensibles, ce qui créé un détachement au lieu de se sentir impliqué. Dommage car l'univers est cohérent et bien pensé.
Son second défaut dans la première partie du jeu est l'absence d'une carte ; quand on vient de récupérer une clef, il est parfois nécessaire de chercher en long et en large du niveau la porte qui correspond ; même si en réalité c'est assez rapide (qq mn car les ennemis ne respawns pas naturellement donc il faut juste traverser les écrans) c'est assez gavant. Sur la seconde partie du jeu les évènements s'enchainent et on est plus en mode 'couloir'.
La fin ouvre une grande porte pour une éventuelle suite, qui dépendra surement du succès critique et/ou commercial de cet épisode ; pour celui-ci en tout cas il arrive au bout de son histoire.

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.

A heavily stylized indie action and platforming game that's a tribute and a parody to the '70s new age spiritualism and '80s synthwave era. Its strong point is definitely the art style and environments, but that is not to say that the gameplay is not good. They have developed enough fighting mechanics and enemies that get gradually introduced into the game, so you don't get tired of it, despite its relatively simple nature. It is unpolished and exploitable at times, but overall enjoyable. The story is interesting, and although it suffers from exposition, this serves the tongue-in-cheek character of the game. It makes some annoying mistakes, like drawing the last two boss fights for way too long compared to the rest of them, but I still recommend it if you watch the trailer and are interested in it. Hoping the next installment comes soon.

reviews.title: Beautiful graphics and very nice indie game, but it's so hardcore on most parts!

reviewText.content: The graphics of this game are nice! I like the title screen as well since it has a cool mysterious effect! My overall gaming experience of this game from the very first mission to the epilogue or last mission is still great overall even though there are some parts or challenges that are so hardcore or challenging like those unexpected enemy reinforcements, it's still a cool game overall! One of my most favorite games from the year 2016 and it's still one of my most favorite all-time indie games...

I really enjoyed this game despite the slightly confusing storyline. It's a very interesting concept to make a game using this mechanic where you have to make noise with your cane to "see" the room you're in or contact somebody via your phone to explain to you what you're looking at. I did get jump scared sometimes, especially when the "entity" or whatever they refer to it as just randomly breathes in your ear. I understood the storyline as far as you being in this house to work out what happened in your life however I was occasionally confused by the different people being mentioned in the different sections of the game. I'm still not super sure who some of the mentioned names are or the relevance to the storyline. I honestly didn't expect the ending, I also didn't expect the game to have been based on a true story. I was a little confused about the obsession with the tree but turns out it's usually just an indicator that you've reached the end of that chapter. The end chapter was probably the section where I was wondering what the heck was going on but overall, still a good storyline despite the odd plot hole. Character development of the main character was okay and I like that there are 2 modes you can play it in depending on how much voice lines you want to hear. Puzzles weren't too difficult either.

reviews.title: Melgacius's review of The Pinball Wizard

reviewText.content: The Pinball Wizard mixes pinball, RPG and roguelite genres to create a very fun game. The mobile nature of the game is quite clear, but it's great to play on any platform. I've played it on Steam.

This is definitely one of the most interesting plots in a game I've ever played! And one of the most atmospheric too. I've read and heard about a lot of adventure games to be called horror and turning out to be just another thriller, but this one actually is! I won't lie, in the bigging I was a liitle dissapointed about how simple the graphics were, even for me, but the plot and the atmosphere helped me to completelly forget about it. To be honest there where some scenes I was happy for the low-fi graphics, cause they would probably be a bit too much otherwise. At some points it felt like I was reading a book that I couldn't close before finish it. (yes, I'm also a bookwarm!)

Es el meh absoluto, ósea esta bien y me gusta bastante pero realmente no destaca en nada más alla del diseño, fuera de eso es básico en todo sentido y siento que se extiende de mas en muchas partes porque si durara menos no me molestaría tanto lo básico que es.

Cris Tales is turn based RPG immediately set apart by its utterly gorgeous art style, and intriguing use of split screen, differentiating between three timelines; past on the left, future on the right, and of course, present in the center. It's the sort of game that makes a striking impression even from a screenshot. Disappointingly, the game built around this immaculate presentation just doesn't hold up under the same microscope.

For starters, there's the performance issues, especially on the Switch, which is where I happened to play it. Load screens are something you'll become intimately acquainted with in Cris Tales, and each of these loading screens last around 20 seconds on average. (It's also worth noting that a loading screen accompanies each and every random encounter)

In addition, there's also just a startling lack of polish to the game all around. The opening hours in particular are incredibly poorly balanced, and between the lack of money and the inability to heal until reaching level 5, even the most common enemies can prove to be a challenge. The balancing does improve considerably once you acquire your healing skills, but even then, you'll still encounter a huge spike in difficulty at random every 4-5 hours or so. (Hope you didn't forget to save often!)

There's also a few other minor inconveniences, like the way town names aren't listed on the world map, or that the tent item, which I think is intended to be fairly common, is WILDLY overpriced up until near the end of the game.

Setting all this aside, Cris Tales just isn't very interesting; the story and combat system both feel largely uninspired and derivative, and even the time manipulation elements are rarely used or even beneficial during combat. It's a real shame. It really is stunning to look at, but even the gorgeous aesthetic isn't enough to prop it up from its myriad of issues as a game.

5/10.

Not great. The physics are amazing, the levels are creative and full of ideas, but the difficulty curve is super punishing, the game is buggy, crashes frequently, and over time, becomes an unpleasant experience. Yes, this type of game is about skill, but for me, it went from "hard" to "impossible" in a matter of few levels. Combine it with constant crashing and bugs, I didn't want to play the game anymore. I was addicted to it one day, but had to put the controller down the next.

reviews.title: Wait this is a puzzle game?

reviewText.content:
The more i played it the more i realised that Trials doesn;t have much to do with a Sports game, or even a racing game. Instead, i'm willing to put it as a Puzzle game. 
Once you get through the concept it's more about how to approach a level in various ways rather than blazing through it as much as possible.

The gameplay is simple while really challenging. The harder levels can be seriously tough, and require a very precise handling of your bike and the physics. which.... caused some problesm with playing on the Switch. TLDR,  the joycons really could benefit from having a proper trigger for the gas & break to control the bike. Unless playing on the go is your main argument, i would honestly recommend playing it on PS4 or xbox.

There's a truckload of pointless collectibles, and yes lootboxes. which maybe make sense if you play online, but as i played exclusively solo it had absolutely no value to me whatsoever... meh.

I've always been a big fan of Metroidvanias, so having that coupled with a co-op action brawler is right up my alley really.
at first i didn't feel there was a lot of differences introduced from the first one, it's very familiar.. which isn't a bad thing per say but it wasn't hugely innovative aside from the added power upgrades and more prominence of the chicken powers (which are a ton of fun XD).

Both the humour and the artwork are fantastic, you'll find yourself nodding and smiling all the way through. And it would actually be a very 'feel good' kinda game.. if it weren't for the sadistic platforming :D

Don't get me wrong, those controls are buttery smooth and it plays fantastic, but some of the platforming gets insanely hard to the point you have to redo the same screen 50 times in a row, and some of those being the main path not simply the optional chests. The other main issue is that those sections are pretty much impossible in co-op (yet alone with 4 players i imagine!), so you end up with your buddy floating in the air trying to stay out of your way while you desperately try to make it through a screen.

I can't remember so much instant fun on a competitive local multiplayer since first playing Bomberman in the 90s (Super Bomberman 2). It only takes a quick game or two to get the hang of what's going on, and Hidden in Plain Sight is a great pick up and play game, with a few mini games to choose from.

In my favourite mini game, you're placed into an arena with identical characters (one for each human player and lots more AI-controlled - a number that is customisable). First, you have to figure out which character you're controlling. Then you have to gain points by pinging a totem without the other human players figuring out who you are, hunting you down and punching you (one-hit kills).

Death Race is also fantastic. Again, each human player has to figure out who they control (characters do look different in this one) without giving away they're a human player to the other human players. Each human player has one gunshot to use on a player they suspect might be human. First to the finish line or last standing wins.

There are other fun mini-games and a couple we don't enjoy so much, but for

In this decent hour-long experience, gameplay takes a backseat while the story and dialogue step into the limelight. While lacking in gameplay depth, this game manages to offer a handful of dialogue options, providing a hint of replay value. The strength lies in the captivating narrative and well-written dialogue, which ultimately carries the game and keeps players engaged throughout their short journey.

Premier jeu en 3D fait par un stagiaire ; à oublier.
Au suivant.

Joué sur SeriesX via les jeux gold du game pass.

This game is total rubbish in terms of the narrative, gameplay, and visuals. The fact that it costs around $15 is appalling because it offers practically no quality!

Gameplay: 0/5
Visuals and sound: 0/5
Story and writing: 1/5

This game is a joy to play with a friend. The art style is gorgeous, allowing for sights serene and sinister alike. The story, while not necessarily one of the best I've come across in this medium, is still quite touching, particularly towards the end. The core concept underlying the game (that of the two players experiencing different versions of the game in parallel) allows for some enjoyable puzzles to crack as well as lending replayability to the game, and is one I would love to see more developers play around with.
such an interesting game! i haven't played through completely yet, but the art style is so pretty and aesthetically pleasing!

The idea, the initial game-play loop, and the career mode progression is truly exceptional. A lot of people will appreciate this just for the nostalgia factor, but even the way it plays feels good, so it isn't just the nostalgia that makes this game so popular. My biggest issue is the difficulty curve after a while. The game starts throwing obstacles on you which you can't do anything about, so it starts to get frustrating. The career mode is a tad bit too long also because of this.

The game is fantastic in so many ways, it has good puzzles and the way new items unlock and characters reappear in new areas makes exploring the spooky castle compelling. The aesthetic is great and I genuinely was scared by enemies. I felt really intruiged by the games premise and story telling and desperately wanted to unpick what was going on. But there is a fatal flaw that frustrated me to the point I had to uninstall it. The only way to save is with the gold coins you find around the castle. Theyre pretty limited and you also need them to unlock items in the game. This meant that I had to save them up to progress but in doing so I would have to go long stretches without saving and mutliple times I died and lost a huge chunk of progress, forcing me to replay the same sections I had just beaten. This ruined the entire experience. I cannot reccomend this game at all since the save system completely. undermined everything I enjoyed so much. At this point I'll probably just watch a playthrough to see the rest of the game rather than waste any more time replaying parts I already did.

A beautiful homage to the memory of Final Fantasy 8 (my personal fave) and helps get us over FF8 not aging well in 20 years

With amazingly beautiful character and creature designs, beautifully painted backdrops and a surprisingly good, if a little long winded, story, this is perfect if you miss the old school FF style of game before they went action adventure/MMO

SemiSoft are also great devs that like to listen to criticism as much as praise and current reworking dialogue for the western audiences for the long winded issue I mentioned above

I DARE you not to fall in love with the characters!

Really didn't click with me, but maybe because i was playing on kbm. The storytelling didn't catch me, i got lost a lot and even the movement felt a bit half-baked. it's definitely playable and enjoyable, but not that i'd prefer to spend much time with it myself.

I just finished observer. I think its a great game because I enjoyed lot. I'm a computer engineering student and I love the games about computers or technology. So, the concept of the game is touched me. If you love the games like that, I really recommended this game to you. When I started to write here, I can't stop myself :)

Just finished , wow , more pls bloober . 
Incredible story and atmosphere , If u are and sci fi / light horror fan this one is a must play 
10/10

great music, violence, action, and stylized graphics.  Imagine the original Postal meets Donkey Kong seasoned with a dash of Olly Moss's aesthetic for good measure.  simple to learn - difficult to master.

reviews.title: Pour se renouveler la dernière mouture des Darksiders adopte cette fois le hack'n slash

reviewText.content:
- côté direction artistique la patte de Maduirera fait mouche et est parfaitement réalisée
- c'est fluide, c'est beau, des effets de lumière et de bim bam boum dans tous les sens mais ca reste lisible
- l'intrigue sert de prétexte à passer d'un environnement à un autre, du feu à la glace en passant par la forêt and co, c'est très varié et on découvre de nouveaux ennemis, des nouvelles capacités pour nos personnages ou mécanismes de gameplay régulièrement.
- la durée de vie est bonne avec 17 niveaux pour une quinzaine d'heures en ligne droite, plus si on prend le temps d'explorer, et encore plus si on veut faire du 100% en revenant sur les anciens niveaux une fois toutes les compétences débloquées.
- le gameplay est assez varié on peut tenter différentes approches en fonction des personnages (qu'on alterne quand on veut à la volée) et leurs capacités.
- la difficulté reste accessible avec différents niveau qu'on peut changer facilement ; pour les boss il faut prendre le temps d'un premier combat pour comprendre le pattern puis si besoin un second pour y arriver, les derniers boss étant un peu plus ardus quand même, mais rien d'insurmontable.
- les sauvegardes auto sont réalisées de façon transparentes, on reprend la partie là où on était sans devoir refaire tout le niveau depuis le début.
- les voix en VO stfr sont excellentes, et on peut grossir les soustitres, option bien utile mais pas si courante

Bref pour moi du tout bon, qq souci quand on cherche les passages secrets et que parfois on tombe dans le vide entre deux éléments du décors, mais sinon pas de grand défaut si on le prend pour ce qu'il est : un bon spin off dans une bonne licence, mais pas le jeu du siècle => 8/10 soit 16/20

Joué sur SeriesX via le game pass.
I wasn't able to play this with others. Some area were tricky without multiplayer but I enjoyed the balance of being offensive and defensive.

The promising setting to explore about Sunken London city in the future apocalypse where you play a girl to save your dying brother after running away from abusive father where the main character what to do scouting supplies in abandoned buildings and then use her boat in small open world exploring the cities through silent dialouge and drawings about her story and the city. 

The gameplay is not exciting and even bores me a little where all I have to do just visit the building and doing puzzle-lite platforming like climbing every outside the building to the top. This is literally climbing simulator that want to surpass Assasins Creed XD. I realized that I am playing this kind of walking simulator type, if you are root for your character at least you want to finish the game as fast as possible and without even bother collecting left item that just small plot revealing. The great aspect from this game are graphic and the beautiful scenery of 3D world that is not half-baked but lack of animation in character (who do the same acts in every chapter), the music makes myself yawning several times with chill-piano for 3 minutes and then gameplays becomes quiet until finishing each 8 chapter.
So my final verdict is 7.

Whether you're new to rhythm games or a hardened veteran of beating down notes, muse dash is a great entry in anyone's library. With it's cute style and wide variety of difficulties between it's many songs, I've grown to love this as one of my personal favorite rhythm games.

У нас тут довольно необычный файтинг со своей физикой и фишками. Убить противника просто только с помощью оружия или же столкнув его с площадки, последнее и является частым способом убийства врагов, ведь оружие еще надо найти, но и это не вся проблема, ведь стрелять с него также неудобно, как и передвигаться в этой игре. Это и есть первый минус - неудобное управление. Вторым минусом я выделю отсутствие сюжетной кампании, все что в игре можно сделать - это подраться с другом, либо же с другими игроками, что довольно быстро надоедает, потому как никаких наград за победу не выдается, и смысла идти драться попросту нет. Будь в этой игре хотя бы сюжетная кампания, со своими наградами за прохождение и кастомизацией своего стика было бы куда интереснее играть. Ну а из плюсов я пока что могу только выделить неплохую задумку, потому как игра выглядит довольно цветасто и сочно, да и боевка тут неплохая, со своими фишками.
I had a blast with this game. A lot of fun and the puzzles are not hard, but descent.
Fantastic surprise after Trine 3. Return to 2.5D greatness. Superb visuals and great puzzles that have many ways to solve. Very addictive. Recommended highly

TL,DR Review

Help save Bulb Boy's family from a dark corruption and survive hostel entities along the way. A point-and-click game on the shorter side, what's here is good but consider playing on a touch interface.

Full Review

Under a quiet night at the Bulbhouse, Bulb Boy and his family enjoy an evening of television. After Grandpa Bulb's falls asleep on the couch and his teeth somehow ends up in the fishbowl, Bulb Boy and his flying Bulb Dog head to bed. While Bulb Boy has a nightmare, a dark force enters and corrupts Grandpa Bulb and transforms the whole Bulbhouse with horrific results. Take control of Bulb Boy to save his family and survive what awaits.

Bulb Boy is a point-and-click experience that takes you from one set piece to another, there's no huge area or map exploration here and there's little chance of getting lost or wandering aimlessly. Pacing is varied with a mix of horror & lighthearted moments that help to keep the game from feeling too similar to something like Fran Bow.

The environmental puzzles have a good amount of challenge without feeling too obtuse but know that some are time-sensitive so try not to idle for too long. There's a nice amount of creativity to the world of Bulb Boy from environmental changes to enemy types so it never ends up feeling stale.

Mouse control works well enough, although you get the impression at times that Bulb Boy was targeted for touch controls on a smaller screen.

This game is on the shorter side with around 90 minutes to 2 hours to get through and even with some optional achievements to acquire, there isn't much reason to revisit. Even so, I did enjoy the game for what it was and I have no criticisms outside of it's runtime. Bulb Boy is worth playing if what's here appeals to you but consider it at a reasonable sale price.

reviews.title: Jeu court mais gameplay original et gamedesign sympathique

reviewText.content:
Jeu court mais beau graphiquement et au gameplay original, et gamedesign sympathique qui se rafraîchit au fil du jeu, même si le gameplay lui ne bouge quasiment pas.

Pas fan de jeux de rythme, j'ai bien aimé le mélange rythme/plateforme, avec un très léger die and retry.

Les points de respawn sont nombreux, par contre de sauvegarde bcp moins (il faut terminer le niveau commencé)

Le boss de fin est un peu abusé par contre et vient gâcher le bilan, avec 3 formes dont la deuxième qui se régénère trop facilement, et la troisième qui n'est pas dans l'esprit du jeu, avec du reflex pur sans aucune logique musicale qui demande un sans faute.
